HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rule on Political Giving Delayed

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The rule-writing group for municipal bond dealers announced yesterday that it was delaying for at least two months the effective date of its rule on campaign contributions from bond underwriters to government officials who can award them municipal-bond business.
The basic proposal will remain unchanged. The rule bans an underwriting firm from doing business for two years with a state, local or other issuer of municipal bonds, if disallowed political contributions have been made. Contributions cannot be made to an official with a role in choosing a bond underwriter by the firm, employees of the firm's municipal bond department or top executives. 
 The group, the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, said it had yet to finish writing its formal proposal and needed a delay, to at least March 1.
The board plans to submit the proposal to the Securities and Exchange Commission by mid-January, according to Christopher Taylor, the group's executive director. The S.E.C. must give final approval to the rule.
Mr. Taylor said the board would pick an effective date at a meeting Monday, when the board would also discuss other possible changes in the proposed rule.
 
More Join in Ban
 In another development, the S.E.C. released a list showing that 23 firms doing municipal bond business have joined the 17 big Wall Street firms that initially endorsed a voluntary ban on political contributions in October.
The list of these additional firms, which was gathered by the Public Securities Association and given to the S.E.C. yesterday, includes mostly medium-sized and small firms.
The report of the new list comes as representatives from the original 17 firms are scheduled to meet today with the chairman of the S.E.C., Arthur Levitt Jr., to present their final rules for carrying out the ban they adopted in October. The meeting is in the New York office of the S.E.C.
One of the most closely examined parts of the voluntary ban will be how it deals with consultants that firms hire to help them get underwriting business. Many executives in the municipal bond business contend that the use of consultants is a way to get around a ban on political contributions.
Some executives and analysts have argued that the use of consultants should be further limited because they are often a way to win business by hiring the friends of bond issuers even if political contributions are never made. But it is not yet clear if either the voluntary ban or the separate rule being written by the municipal bond dealers board will expand the restraints on the use of consultants.
People involved in the writing of the voluntary ban have said that the ban will prohibit contributions made through consultants. And one said that there would be procedures outlined to make sure a firm could not just "close its eyes" and let the consulting firm do what it wanted.
The two-year business ban would also apply if the underwriting firm hired a consultant that had made political contributions. But it is possible that the municipal bond dealers Monday will consider further changes in the rules applying to consultants and on public disclosure of political contributions.
 
New York City
 The demand for New York City bonds yesterday was another sign of a sudden takeoff in the tax-exempt municipal bond market, which has been outperforming the Treasury market in the last several trading days.
Some analysts had thought this could be a difficult week for new bonds from New York City and New York State because several other issues were scheduled and there had been a rush of other New York paper recently. In addition, a recent report by a commission appointed by Mayor David N. Dinkins painted a grim picture of New York City's long-term budget problems, concluding that they were more serious than previously thought.
But some year-end buying, a new focus on how this year's rise in the top income tax rate makes the yield on municipal bonds even more attractive and some relief that the supply of new issues next year will be slowing has suddenly made tax-exempt bonds the thing to buy.
Because of the interest from buyers, the underwriters, lead by Prudential Securities, were able to cut the yields on the issue significantly when they repriced the issue in the afternoon.
For example, the long-term bonds due in 2015, 2016, and 2017 were priced to yield 5.90 percent after being initially priced to yield 5.98 percent. the yields on other maturities were lowered by about five basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
 
Treasury Market
 Treasury prices and yields were little changed yesterday as traders and investors awaited the two key inflation reports for November, which are due tomorrow and Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond due in August 2023 was unchanged as the yield remained at 6.16 percent. The price of the two-year Treasury note was off 1/32 as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 4.17 percent, from 4.15 percent Monday.

HEADLINE: Seeing Poor in Greater Need, Donors Give More

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
Charities in New York City see a spontaneous increase in donations this time of year. For some people, the gifts are as integral to their Christmas or Hanukkah traditions as trimming the tree or lighting the candles of the menorah. Others give in remembrance of a mother, a father or even a teacher whose absence is felt more acutely during the holidays.
Still others donate because they see the gap between the haves and have-nots yawning wider at this time. 
 With the latter in mind, many people have begun to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, making its 82d annual appeal. In dozens of letters accompanying checks, contributors say they are giving because the plight of the poor seems worse than in the past.
"During previous campaigns I have read of the start of the fund, decades ago," wrote Arthur D. Tenenholtz of Brooklyn, who sent $75, marking his eighth year of giving. "Of late, I am beginning to believe that New York more closely resembles those years than the city of my youth. Surely, the Neediest Cases Fund is more necessary now than it was a few years ago."
 
Origins of the Campaign
 The campaign began when the city was experiencing many of the same problems as in the recent recession: widespread unemployment, growing numbers of homeless people and a large population of poor immigrants. One such immigrant, an orphan from Denmark, made an impression on Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The New York Times, on Christmas Day in 1911, when the man asked Mr. Ochs for money for food and shelter.
Mr. Ochs helped the man and decided the following year to begin a campaign publicizing the city's "100 Neediest Cases," reasoning that if readers were more aware of the conditions of the poor they would give money to help. That year, $3,630.88 was distributed by three social-service agencies. This year, seven agencies will depend on the campaign for millions of dollars in help. The Times pays all of the campaign's expenses so that all of the money is given directly to the charities.
Ruth A. Unterberg of Manhattan sent a note saying she was increasing her gift to $200 because of what she sees on the streets. "I'm very concerned with the growing number of men, women and children who need financial assistance with housing, food and clothing," she wrote.
Others, like Mary Pierce of Wilton, Conn., gave despite their own economic pressures. "I felt badly that my own income was so low last year that I was unable to give as I had been each year since my beloved redheads were born Dec. 25, 1987," she wrote, referring to her twin granddaughters. This year, Mrs. Pierce gave $30 for each of the five years that her granddaughters have graced her life, or $150 in all. "In the hopes that it will ease the lives of some other children in New York City," she said.
Other contributors give with the boundless hope that the future will be better. "I am 9 years old and I am lucky to have a lot of things I could possibly want," wrote Jeremy Schwartz of Brooklyn, in a letter with his donation. "I decided to give $20 to the Fund to help kids that can't get anything they possibly want."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Cocoa Prices Fall as Traders Study Ivory Coast Situation

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Cocoa prices declined yesterday despite worries that supply might be reduced by political uncertainty after the death of the Ivory Coast's President.
March cocoa briefly jumped to a new high of $1,318 a metric ton but then sank as investors took profits. The contract closed $12 lower at $1,281 a ton on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. 
 The Ivory Coast is a leading cocoa supplier. But Judith Ganes, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, said it was too early to determine the impact of the death of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny on the market.
"The only thing that could cause a problem is civil unrest, but otherwise cocoa is too important for their economy and they need the money from its exports," Ms. Ganes said.
 Cocoa prices have risen from a low of $984 in August because of poor crops in the Ivory Coast and Brazil.
Mr. Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving head of state, will likely be succeeded by either the Speaker of Parliament, Henri Konan-Bedie, or Prime Minister Alassane Ouattara.
At the same commodity exchange, coffee prices soared and dipped violently. March coffee reached an early high of 76.95 cents a pound, then fell to a low of 75.50 cents before closing 0.80 cent higher at 76.75 cents a pound.
 Meanwhile, oil prices posted small gains in volatile trading at the New York Mercantile Exchange. January crude oil ended 13 cents higher at $14.70 a barrel. It hit a new five-year low of $14.51 during the session and then rose to $15.03.
 The president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Abdullah al-Attiyah of Qatar, dashed any remaining hopes for an emergency meeting or any OPEC output cuts yesterday, saying that the organization would stay with its September agreement.
 January heating oil fell 0.02 cent, to 44.54 cents a gallon, and January unleaded gas rose 0.39 cent, to 40.77 cents a gallon.
 In Chicago, rice prices posted another advance. At the MidAmerica Commodity Exchange, January delivery rough rice was up another 37 cents per hundred pounds at $12.81 -- double the $6.34 level seen in September.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Ignoring Economic Gains, The Dollar Barely Moves

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar ended narrowly mixed yesterday as investors remained on the sidelines, apparently worried that the dollar had not been able to capitalize on evidence of gains in the broader United States economy.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery, the most actively traded futures contract, gained $1.50 in late trading, settling at $379.30 an ounce. The Republic National Bank quoted the spot price of gold at $377.50 an ounce, up $1.50 from Monday. 
 David Durst, a vice president at Bear, Stearns, said the market was assessing the dollar's surprising weakness over the last few sessions in spite of a variety of positive American economic news.
Many dealers who had been positioned for a dollar rally were particularly frustrated with the dollar's inability to make headway after a report on Friday of a robust gain in payrolls in November and a decrease in the nation's unemployment.
"People are really trying to determine what Friday's reversal meant to the big picture," Mr. Durst said, "and whether it broke the back of the dollar's rally."
Dealers also said that activity slowed with the approach of the holidays, and as many traders have begun squaring their books in anticipapation of the year's end.
In foreign-currency dealings, the dollar rose slightly to 1.7018 German marks late yesterday in New York from 1.7005 marks late Monday. But it slid to 107.53 Japanese yen, from 107.96 yen Monday. Dealers said that a large speculative purchase of yen from an overseas buyer helped depress the dollar against the yen.
The British pound closed in New York at $1.4930, down from $1.5040 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes, included: 1.4593 Swiss francs, down from 1.4600; 5.8560 French francs, up from 5.8430; 1,676 Italian lire, down from 1,681, and 1.3231 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3221.

HEADLINE: Brazil Plans Price Index

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Finance Minister Fernando Henrique Cardoso disclosed plans today to stabilize the economy through an anti-inflation price index that could lead to a new currency.
Mr. Cardoso warned of chaos in Brazil, Latin America's biggest country, if Congress blocked the Government's proposals aimed at curbing inflation of 35 percent a month. 
 Mr. Cardoso said at a news conference that his program to stabilize the economy was based on a balanced 1994 budget, a price index pegging the cruzeiro real to the dollar and the creation of a new currency.
The moves were "steps that are going to put Brazil on the road to eliminating the deficit, driving down inflation and giving Brazilians a strong currency," he said.
A single price index would peg Brazil's currency to the United States dollar and would be called the "real value unit." Mr. Cardoso said its imposition would be gradual and would occur only after Congress had approved a balanced budget and constitutional changes.
The index would calculate Government increases for things like interest rates, prices and utility rates. Its use by the private sector would be voluntary.
The index would eventually form the basis for a "strong currency with stable purchasing power," replacing the cruzeiro real, he said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Yankees Find Roster Holes That Might Be Hard to Fill

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
Left field is barren, the closer seat belongs to a novice and the starting rotation will remain unchanged unless some expensive contracts are trimmed. Welcome to another wacky off season with the Yankees.
Dion James has left New York to play baseball in Japan, Lee Smith was not offered salary arbitration yesterday so he has left for a place that will be determined later and the players the Yankees would like to discard are not moving via trades. 
 The latest problem to blindside the Yankees is the void in left field. Will they find a capable left-handed hitting reserve to replace James? Should they consider Rickey Henderson? Should they scrap their $45 million budget to chase Rafael Palmeiro and convert him into an outfielder? Are they still sour on Tim Raines?
While James fled to play for twice the amount New York had offered him and unearthed new questions about the outfield, the Yankees did answer one question by declining to offer Smith arbitration and thus losing their right to negotiate with him until May 1. Basically, the Yankees ended their association with the career saves leader because he will surely sign a contract before then.
 
Hernandez the Yankee Closer?
 Because Smith saved 43 games for the St. Louis Cardinals and three more after being traded to New York, the Yankees were worried that he could receive as much as $4 million in arbitration and disrupt their budget. Since they passed on Smith and have shown scant interest in re-signing Steve Farr, the Yankees seem prepared to enter the season with Xavier Hernandez as their closer. The 28-year-old has never been a full-time closer.
In an off season that has been dominated by their futile attempts to secure another quality starting pitcher, the latest problem appeared after James agreed to a two-year contract for almost $4 million with the Chunichi Dragons of the Japanese League. It was about $2 million more than the Yankees offered. Although James was not the full-time left fielder, he was a superb reserve who hit .332 in 343 at-bats.
Michael did not return telephone messages, but he has previously declined comment on Henderson. The career stolen-bases leader turns 35 on Christmas Day, and teams have so far been hesitant to pursue him. So hesitant that Dennis Gilbert, his agent, called selected sportswriters last week to interview Henderson and try to arouse interest.
 
'A Logical Fit'
 "I think he's always felt that the Yankees were a logical fit," Ken Gurnick, one of Gilbert's associates, said of Henderson. "He's played there before. He's handled the New York media. Without Dion James, it would make it even more likely."
Although speculation about Henderson returning to New York has been rampant, George Steinbrenner told Yankee officials after the season that he was not interested. But that was before James left.
"Going into 1994, I heard they were talking about getting Rickey or Palmeiro," James said. "If that would have happened, Dion James would have been back on the bench and not getting any publicity at all."
Because of the substantial offer from Chunichi and the guarantee of playing every day, the 31-year-old James happily departed.
"You're talking to a man who was unemployed three years ago and whose career was over," James said. "Then Gene Michael gave me an opportunity and I got back on my feet. I made a business decision. I got two years of security. This was the chance of a lifetime."
 
INSIDE PITCH
 The Yanks did not offer arbitration to MIKE WITT and had already not offered it to STEVE FARR and FRANK TANANA, free agent repeaters, in October. Interestingly, they offered arbitration to DION JAMES as a precaution in case his Japanese contract hits a snag.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
China and Global Warming

BYLINE: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY

 BODY:
If global warming materializes as the threat many scientists predict, the world's ability to head it off may well be determined by China. The United States is currently the world's leading emitter of carbon dioxide, the chief man-made contributor to global warming. But rapid economic growth and heavy reliance on dirty fuel may soon propel China toward that unenviable distinction.
China's pell-mell industrialization is powered largely by huge reserves of coal, the dirtiest of fuels in carbon emissions. Three-quarters of China's energy needs, from factories to home heating, are now met by burning coal. The result is all too palpable, as I found on a visit to several provinces late this summer. Noxious fumes sting the eyes of city dwellers, haze obscures the views, and acid rain falls as far as Japan in one direction and southwest China in another. More worrisome for the rest of the world, China's smokestacks spew tons of carbon into the atmosphere, increasing the buildup of heat-trapping gases. 
 China already ranks third in carbon dioxide emissions, behind the U.S. and the former Soviet Union, and when Soviet emissions are split among the newly independent republics, China may well be second. Emissions will almost certainly climb higher as China's economy expands and its population grows bigger and richer. Chinese consumers will inevitably seek a higher standard of living, with more cars, more refrigerators, more home heating, more consumer goods, all requiring more energy to produce and operate.
Chinese energy and environmental officials expect coal consumption to rise from the current level of 1.1 billion tons a year to more than 1.4 billion tons by the year 2000 -- and carbon emissions are expected to rise sharply as a consequence. One American projection even suggests that China could pass the U.S. in carbon emissions by the year 2025, though China's own projections suggest the U.S. will still lead the pack.
The outlook would be even worse had China not done an exemplary job of controlling its energy appetite despite furious economic expansion. The Chinese have made astonishing gains in industrial efficiency over the past decade, thereby holding energy growth to half the rate of economic growth. But most analysts think the easy part has been accomplished and that further gains will be much harder.
Chinese officials, though not fully convinced of the global warming threat, recognize the need to head it off. Qu Geping, the Government's top environmental official, said in an interview that even before global warming is fully proved all countries should take steps to control carbon dioxide emissions.
In a wide-ranging effort to boost its economy and clean its environment, China is already taking steps that will have the beneficial side effect of reducing carbon emissions. Such programs include a big hydroelectric project in the Three Gorges area of the Yangtze River that will produce power without emitting carbon dioxide; a tree-planting program that has increased forest coverage for the first time in years; the building of large generating plants for greater efficiency, and experiments with cleaner approaches to home heating. Zha Keming, Vice Minister of Electric Power, believes that nuclear power, which emits no carbon dioxide, could become the chief energy source 50 years from now.
Global warming, if it occurs, could harm China itself, an added reason for curbing emissions. But China's leaders do not appear to give the threat high priority. They point out, correctly, that industrialized nations emit far more carbon dioxide per capita than China and have done so for a very long time. Those nations, they imply, should bear the brunt of cleaning up the mess. And when Chinese officials are asked what environmental problems are most acute, they invariably cite urban air pollution, population growth, clean water or soil erosion. No one cites the distant prospect of global warming.
There is no doubt that the nations of the world will need to enlist China if they ever unite to head off global warming. That could pose some very hard questions for the West, such as whether to subsidize China's conversion to cleaner fuels and more efficient factories, or whether to allow Western companies to meet emissions goals through investments in China. But without forceful action, whatever progress is made elsewhere in curbing carbon emissions could be undercut by an enormous increase in emissions from China. PHILIP M. BOFFEY

HEADLINE: Help Welfare Clients, Not Their Employers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President Clinton's plan to aid employers who hire welfare recipients is not a new idea (front page, Nov. 28). Unfortunately, such efforts have a long history of failure. 
 Our welfare system is based on the English Poor Laws. England's Speenhamland Law of the 1800's was started as an aid-in-wages, ostensibly benefiting employees, but actually using public means to subsidize employers. The primary result was to depress wages. In some geographic areas only those people covered by welfare had a chance of employment and those who tried to keep off the dole were hardly able to secure work.
Between 1815 and 1830 the Speenhamland scale was reduced by one-third. It was not simply the rise in welfare costs that caused calamity but rather the economic effect of a subsidy to employers in reducing the productivity of labor that was the root of the trouble.
The Clinton Presidential campaign devoted considerable attention to the notion of a "high-wage, high-skill work force." The subsidy of a low-wage, low-skill work force will not achieve that goal. Such a strategy will instead reduce productivity as the Speenhamland law did.
Welfare reform is indeed long overdue. Expansion of special programs like the Jobs Corps, to assist the long-term unemployed, is essential. But we must bear in mind the history of the Speenhamland Law if we are not to repeat the mistakes of the past. To "end welfare as we know it" we should help recipients, not subsidize employers.
 
JOEL B. FREEDMAN
Washington, Nov. 29, 1993
The writer is assistant to the president for economic development programs, International Union of Bricklayers & Allied Craftsmen.

HEADLINE: International Report Card Shows U.S. Schools Work

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
In contrast to studies that have painted grim portraits of American education, a new report finds that compared with other industrialized nations, the United States does a reasonably good job of educating its citizens and preparing them for work.
The report, issued yesterday by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, based in Paris, indicated that American students lag only slightly behind their counterparts around the world in math and science and that a higher than average percentage of American students get college educations. 
 The United States spends more per student on higher education each year than any other nation -- about $13,000 compared with the average of $6,000 to $7,000 for the 24 countries surveyed. Thirty-six percent of Americans between the ages of 25 and 64 have college degrees -- among the highest percentage in the world. In addition, the percentage of women enrolled in colleges or universities is higher in the United States than in other countries.
 
Public-Private Ties
 At a time when all industrialized nations are grappling with how to train a work force for the future, the report calls for stronger ties between employers and educational systems. It notes in particular "the need for sound initial education," for "better integration between academic and vocational studies" and for "an adult training system adapted to the needs of employers, workers and nonworkers."
Although American colleges and universities are improving their efforts to prepare students for the workplace, much of the real training is being done by two-year community colleges, a long tradition that is being strengthened through Federal, state and local grants.
The report offers a statistical portrait of American education that is far more favorable than several studies undertaken in recent years by American educators. Much previous research indicated that American students lagged their counterparts elsewhere in core academic subjects and that scores on standardized college entrance exams have been sliding in recent years.
 
Scores Are Stabilizing
 But in recent years, the free fall in entrance exams has stopped, and scores in math and science have stabilized. The study released today finds, for example, that American students score above average in reading comprehension and about average in science.
The study also showed that, despite criticism of early childhood education in the United States, 90.2 percent of all 5-year-olds attend public or private early childhood programs, a percentage that places the United States among the top 5 of the 24 nations surveyed.
Describing the report as "full of pluses and minuses," Education Secretary Richard W. Riley said yesterday that the study "illustrates why the American habit of being comfortable with just being average comes up short in the new global economic environment." Mr. Riley said the report "confirms why there is an urgent need to press ahead in our continuing efforts to give every American child a world-class education."
The United States' proportion of science graduates in the labor force -- 653 per 100,000 -- is slightly higher than the proportion in other nations. While lagging behind Britain and Japan, it is about the same as Germany.
Although only 15.3 percent of all college degrees awarded in 1991 in the United States were in the sciences -- math, computer science, engineering or natural science -- more people attended college, producing more science graduates for the work force.
In Germany, 32 percent of all degrees are in the sciences, but the percentage of people attending college is less than half that of the United States. In Japan, 25.7 percent of degrees are in the sciences, but the percentage of people attending college is only two-thirds the rate in the United States.
 
Competing Pressures
 On the whole, American colleges and universities continue to outstrip competing systems, not only in the total number of graduates but in dollars spent for education. The United States spends $13,639 on each college and university student. The vast majority of other countries spend between $6,000 to $7,000 per student, the study indicated.
Not surprisingly, the study indicated, the more educated a worker is, the better his or her financial rewards. This is especially true in free-market systems.
Among the educational strengths and weaknesses cited in the report, France and Finland had the highest literacy rates, Belgium had the lowest student-teacher ratio, and Portugal, which recently expanded its public education, ranked lowest in math achievement, behind the United States and Spain.
The report is a systematic comparison of education in the industrialized world by what is essentially an international research center specializing in the economies of its member nations. The first such study by the 33-year-old organization, which includes the European Community and the G-7 nations, was done last year. This year's study is more encompassing, taking into account different structures in educational systems.
While the report calls for increased attention to linking educational systems with employment, United States educators have a history of resisting what they perceive as the vocationalizing of academic studies.
"There's pressure pushing the university to emphasize occupational education, and there's counterpressure to offer all kids a liberal arts education," said Michael W. Kirst, a professor of education at Stanford University and an expert on the politics of education. "The way American colleges and universities have dealt with this is specialized institutions."
Some institutions, particularly comprehensive state university systems, have established schools in engineering, nursing, medicine and other professions. "The question is whether you want to standardize higher education in America," Mr. Kirst said. "Our response in America has been pluralism."
The report and its authors also helped explain some of the shortcomings of American public schools, in which high school students spend about 25 hours a week in actual course work, compared with 38 hours for Finnish students.
 
Difference in Focus
 "In the United States, schools are given a wider mandate than almost all of your competitive countries," said Albert Tuijnman, an economist and one of three authors of the study. "The health, social services and sports functions are considered important, but there is a distinct difference in the focus of an American school."
Mr. Tuijnman also suggested that inefficiencies in spending, on everything from books to buildings, and little involvement by teachers in decisions involving schools contributed to the mixed academic performance by American students.
The United States spent $5,177 per student in primary grades for the 1990-91 academic year, the highest of any nation, and $6,472 per student in secondary grades, the third highest, Mr. Tuijnman said.
In reading, American 14-year-olds outperformed students in 12 other nations. (Not all comparisons covered all 24 member nations because of incompatible data.)
In math, American students scored at the bottom of the scale, just behind Spanish students and ahead of only Portuguese students.
In science, American students scored about the same as their counterparts in Canada, England, France, Scotland and Spain.
The United States' scores were compiled from 16 public school systems, a representative sampling that included suburban and rural systems as well as schools in New York City, Washington, Chicago, Atlanta and Dallas.
While the United States spends considerable sums for public education, the authors of the report said many of the extra dollars went not into the classroom but to workers other than teachers.
Teachers make up 2.6 percent of the American work force. Custodians, bus drivers, cafeteria workers and maintenance workers represent 2.9 percent of the work force, and they are typically paid from school budgets. In other nations, such services are supported by private enterprise, an idea just beginning to find favor in the United States as evidence grows that private companies can provide services like transportation and cleaning for less money than school systems spend.
The center is part of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a group of the world's industrialized nations that was formed in 1960 to study common issues. The organization measures unemployment rates, tracks trade volume and studies how the economic decisions of individual nations affect the world economy.

HEADLINE: CLINTON PROPOSES TOUGH NEW RULES ON BIAS BY BANKS

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration proposed tough new tests today that are intended to insure that banks end discrimination in their lending to members of minority groups and to people with low and moderate incomes.
The changes are the latest effort by the Administration to broaden access to credit, financial services and investments. Officials predicted that people and businesses in these groups would gain access that they might not otherwise get to billions of dollars in credit once the proposals take effect in 1995. 
 The regulations, which set higher standards for banks, for the first time apply objective measurements on three levels. Banks would be tested in several ways to determine if their overall pattern of lending in specific neighborhoods was biased, when compared to their overall lending and those of competitors. They would also be judged on whether they were making investments in a community's growth, like grants for economic redevelopment, and whether they were providing a full array of customer services.
 
Concrete Penalties
 Although Federal examiners would still have a fair amount of leeway in determining whether an institution was complying with the law, banks could for the first time face sanctions like binding orders or fines to change their practices.
That would give regulators additional power. Now, a bank's poor record in this area can affect whether the Government will permit bank acquisitions or mergers, and institutions that fall short have been sued by community groups or regulators. Lately, Federal regulators have blocked bank acquisitions when they regarded a lending pattern unfavorably.
The proposal is the most important modification of equal-lending enforcement since 1977, when Congress passed the Community Reinvestment Act. That law was intended to force banks to make loans to individuals, businesses and groups in neighborhoods that many large financial institutions had shunned.
While the law has been effective in some ways, there were growing complaints from consumer groups that the method for evaluating a bank's lending activity was too lenient. While it has been hard to measure how much discrimination has gone on, numerous studies, including one from bank regulators, reported that minority-group applicants for home mortgages, for instance, were denied loans at a higher rate than whites were offered even when other social factors were considered.
Banks did not like the law and its regulations because compliance required excessive paper work.
Under the newly proposed standards, regulators would evaluate banks based on specific lending and market-share data that would measure actual lending. But they would not set fixed credit quotas. The proposal is subject to further review and debate for two months, but faces no major opposition and requires no Congressional action.
Today, consumer groups and banking organizations, which have not seen eye to eye on lending regulations, praised the central elements of the Administration's plan, although each side found something to criticize in the details.
The Administration, which promised the changes months ago, has been pressing on several fronts to increase lending in poor and ethnic-minority communities. The issue of fair credit has been increasingly prominent in recent years, as several studies have shown that banks have persistently failed to provide equal credit opportunities, despite laws and regulations.
Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency and the Administration's leading advocate of fairer lending practices, said the new approach emphasized "performance over paper work."
All four Federal banking agencies are expected to issue similar rules. But some members of the Federal Reserve Board, which plays a crucial role in enforcing the law, are less enthusiastic than some of the other agencies about the new approach, something that is likely to emerge at the board's meeting on its proposed regulations on Friday.
In particular, the Fed has opposed the collection of racial data on small-business loans, as is done already with mortgage loans. Advocates of more aggressive enforcement of the fair lending law called this an important gap in the proposed new rules.
"The Fed appears to have won many of the key battles in the fights among agencies over these rules," said Deepak Bhargava of Acorn, a national group that lobbies for lending and housing reform. "I would almost characterize their efforts here as obstruction of the President's efforts. I would call them the George Wallace of C.R.A. reform, blocking the door to getting something done."
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a governor of the Federal Reserve, who appeared with other officials at the White House to discuss the proposal, said in a telephone interview that he and his colleagues had some concerns about the proposals, but were not at odds with the other banking agencies.
"This is a very radical proposal; there is no question about it," said Mr. Lindsey, who heads the board's committee on the Community Reinvestment Act. "It will benefit at this stage from public comment. We are going where no man has gone before, and if you do that, I think you want to do it right."
Among bankers, Leo F. Mullin, president of the First Chicago Corporation, said, "The proposal represents a positive and promising step toward improving the effectiveness and efficiency of the Community Reinvestment Act."
Michelle Meier, counsel for government affairs at Consumers Union, said, "The Clinton Administration is on the right track."
 
Banks Like Some Changes
 Banks welcomed the fact that smaller institutions, with assets of less than $250 million, would be eligible for streamlined examinations, and that banks would have the option of developing pre-approved plans for compliance, so that they could then be evaluated against those plans.
For the first time, banks would have to publish data detailing where in their marketing areas they provided services like checking accounts and automated teller machines, and what types of community investments they had made.
In the past, they had to document their efforts to expand operations throughout their local markets, but these might not be good indications of actual lending.
In the end, regulators based assessments on 12 factors, a time-consuming process that often resulted in subjective judgments..
The new rules set three evaluation standards for banks to meet. If a banks was given relatively low ratings on the tests, it would have time to improve before facing sanctions.
The lending test would evaluate direct lending as well as indirect lending through participation in loan pools or credit subsidiaries.
The service test would evaluate the bank's branch network in low- and moderate-income areas, and the availability of credit services like counseling.
An investment test would take into account investments in groups that foster community development, minority ownership of businesses, and affordable housing. It would also look at, for example, whether the bank is buying community bonds for housing or hospital financing.
Under the lending test, a bank would be evaluated in two ways.
First, its loans would be assessed to see how its lending patterns compared with other banks operating in the same local markets.
In a second and separate test, its loans would be analyzed without regard to how other institutions were performing, but on whether its loans were concentrated in one part of its market. Agencies would examine the ratio of the bank's loans made in neighborhoods of low and moderate income in comparison to loans throughout its service area.
The regulations would not require a bank to offer specific types of loans, to make any particular loan or investment, or to make loans or investments that were expected to lose money or otherwise undermine the bank's safety or soundness.

HEADLINE: Court Weighs Abortion Protest Curbs

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
The argument that abortion clinics can invoke the Federal racketeering law to sue violent anti-abortion protest groups got a receptive hearing at the Supreme Court today. As their past decisions indicated, the Justices appeared reluctant to write into the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act any limits that Congress did not put there when it passed the law in 1970.
The question for the Court today was whether the racketeering law, known as RICO, requires proof that the defendants -- in this case, Operation Rescue and a coalition of clinic protest groups called the Pro-Life Action League -- were motivated by a desire for economic gain. 
 Two lower Federal courts, finding that the groups' actions were aimed at driving abortion clinics out of business rather than making money for themselves, held that RICO did not apply and dismissed a suit brought by the National Organization for Women on behalf of two abortion clinics.
But "Congress didn't say a word about economic motive" when it wrote the law, Fay Clayton, a lawyer for NOW, said at the beginning of her argument. It was a simple argument that the Justices, well versed in RICO's intricacies from a series of Supreme Court decisions interpreting the law broadly, appeared to find compelling.
 
Lawyer in Uphill Battle
 The lawyer for the anti-abortion groups, G. Robert Blakey, a law professor at the University of Notre Dame who wrote much of the RICO legislation while serving as a Senate staff counsel, had an uphill battle before a skeptical Court.
The question of whether the law requires economic motive, and whether it can apply to abortion clinic protests, has been alive in the lower courts for years. This case, which began in 1986, assumed particular significance earlier this year after the Supreme Court ruled in an unrelated case that Federal judges did not have authority to protect abortion clinics from violent protests.
The Court based that decision on a section of a 19th-century law, the Ku Klux Klan Act, which numerous Federal courts had invoked for that purpose. The ruling, in Bray v. Alexandria Women's Health Clinic, appeared to leave RICO as the only Federal law available to the clinics.
Since then the landscape has changed considerably. Both houses of Congress have passed similar versions of a bill known as the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act, which makes it a Federal crime to damage an abortion clinic or to use force or intimidation against the clinic's patients. The bill, which has the Clinton Administration's support, is expected to receive final passage next year.
The Ku Klux Klan Act has also been revived as a potential source of protection for the clinics. In a ruling in October, a Federal appellate court permitted a suit under a section of the law that the Supreme Court did not address in the Bray decision.
But even if RICO is not the only law in the Federal arsenal available to abortion clinics, this case, NOW v. Scheidler, No. 92-780, is still important. The racketeering law is a powerful tool under which successful plaintiffs receive triple damages. The clinic protest groups have argued that its application to what they describe as a social protest movement would threaten their constitutional right to free speech.
 
A 'Campaign of Terror'
 Ms. Clayton, arguing for NOW, sought to deflect that concern, describing the protest groups as conducting a "nationwide campaign of terror."
When Justice Antonin Scalia offered an analogy between the clinic protests and a campaign to persuade supermarkets to stop selling grapes, Ms. Clayton said there was a difference between peaceful picketing and the violent incidents at abortion clinics.
"We treasure the defendants' First Amendment rights like we treasure our own," she said, adding that abortion protesters are constitutionally protected "when they picket, when they pray, when they leaflet, when they petition Congress." The racketeering law would apply only when advocacy becomes force and violence, she added.
The law makes it a crime to conduct the "affairs" of an "enterprise" through a "pattern of racketeering activity." In dismissing the NOW lawsuit, the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, ruled that the clinics' allegations, if proved at trial, would show that the protesters had engaged in a pattern of extortion, a crime listed in the law's definition of "racketeering activity." But the appellate court ruled that the word "enterprise" indicated that Congress meant RICO to apply only to economically motivated crimes.
 
Emphasis on Illicit Gain
 Mr. Blakey, representing the anti-abortion groups, offered several arguments based on the text of the law. "This statute can be summed up in two words: illicit gain," he said, adding, "The common, everyday meaning of 'enterprise' is a business venture."
He also said the Hobbs Act, the Federal extortion law cited by the appeals court, did not cover the clinic protests. And he said the law's reference to conducting the "affairs" of an enterprise implicitly meant business affairs.
All Mr. Blakey's arguments met with a skeptical response from the Court, particularly the last.
"Affairs cover all sizes and shapes," Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg told Mr. Blakey. "There are private affairs, family affairs," she said, noting that Congress could have said "business affairs" if that was what it meant.
Finally, Mr. Blakey asked the Justices to read the law as a whole, rather than focus on any particular word. "Interpretation of this statute is a holistic endeavor," he said.
The Clinton Administration argued on behalf of the abortion clinics. Miguel A. Estrada, a lawyer in the Solicitor General's office, said that reading an economic motive requirement into the law "would really cripple the role Congress thought RICO would play."

HEADLINE: Can Unions Run United Airlines?

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
As the unions for United Airlines strive to conclude their six-year effort to buy the company with negotiations this week in New York and wrap up the host of financial questions, one overarching question remains: Can employees really take over a business that is so big and so complex?
 While there are few parallels in the airline industry, workers have taken over companies in a variety of industries. And as those experiences suggest, making employee ownership work is difficult, but possible.
Some of the employee-owned companies, like the Avis car-rental company, have prospered. But in the case of United, skeptical investors and analysts fear, as Samuel C. Buttrick, an airline analyst at Kidder, Peabody, said, that "the interest of minority shareholders would get lost to job preservation issues." 
 The ideal of employee ownership is that workers will care more about their company and managers will involve them more in the company's affairs. Several recent studies have found that employee ownership alone does not affect large companies' performance, but when the workers are drawn into day-to-day management, those companies do markedly better.
 
'Culture Change' Held Needed
 And there is a hurdle for United, which has had its share of battles with labor. "Only a real culture change can bring this about," said Joseph R. Blasi, a professor of management and labor relations at Rutgers University.
Still, it has been done before. Although Avis is private, it is often held up as a standard.
After workers took over the company in 1987, Avis created what were called employee empowerment groups that meet monthly with management to make suggestions about running the company. The success of Avis's Employee Stock Ownership Plan is perhaps best measured by the rise in the company's stock value, as appraised by outsiders, from just over $5 a share at the time of the buyout to $18 a share recently.
Avis employees were not required to sacrifice anything personally to help finance the transaction. In contrast, many E.S.O.P.'s like the one at the Weirton Steel Corporation, were formed in exchange for large concessions from workers -- as would be the case at United.
When Weirton's workers took over the company in 1984, their interests appeared aligned with management. The worker-owners accepted layoffs and wage and benefit cuts of 32 percent. In 1989, the company sold 4.5 million shares to the public, letting Weirton invest $550 million to modernize its plant and buy back shares from some of Weirton's 6,100 employees.
But then the recession hit, Weirton started losing money, and the workers began pointing fingers at management and directors. They were the target in workers' recent protests of a stock offering intended to help pay down debt.
"While you're making money, nobody cares," Rick Garan, a company spokesman, said. "Once things go awry, blame is always easy to dish out."
The airline industry offers a mixed record on employee ownership, which was used in the early 1980's to help win concessions at carriers including Pan Am, Eastern, Western, Republic and Trans World Airlines. Employees were awarded stakes ranging from 12 percent to 32 percent with seats on the board of directors.
 
T.W.A.'s Unions Quarreled
 Indeed, even at T.W.A., which is in its second round of swapping concessions for equity, employee ownership has had different results.
To help restructure itself to get out of bankruptcy, T.W.A. gave its workers 45 percent of the company last year in exchange for $660 million in concessions.
Since then, pilots have spent their own money on billboard and radio advertisements urging consumers to try the airline. Flight attendants, machinists and pilots have frequently visited travel agents to pitch the airline's service, which now includes extra leg room in all classes of seats.
Their extra effort, especially during flights, has apparently paid off. In a recent survey by J. D. Power & Associates, the research firm best known for its car surveys, business travelers rated T.W.A. as the best airline on long flights, and second only to Delta on short flights.
But T.W.A.'s three largest labor groups -- pilots, mechanics and flight attendants -- have not always pulled together.
 
A Pilot Initiative Generally
 Typically the pilots initiate concessions-for-equity swaps because, with many pilots at major carriers earning over $100,000 a year, they are best able to absorb the cuts. They also have the most to lose if they are laid off, because getting bumped to the bottom of the seniority list at another carrier results in a sharp pay cut.
The pilots initiated the stock ownership proposal at T.W.A. in the mid-1980's, in return for concessions that enabled Carl C. Icahn to buy the company. The machinists reluctantly agreed, but the flight attendants struck.
A principal reason that labor groups at Northwest Airlines disagreed on swapping concessions for a big minority stake concerned shared sacrifice. Pilots said that all workers should give up an equal percentage in salary, benefits and work rules; the flight attendants and machinists argued that because pilots' salaries were so much higher, they should pay a higher percentage.
The split led to fractured negotiations that were resolved only hours before Northwest planned to file for bankruptcy last summer.
 
Northwest Machinists Critical
 Since the swap, the machinists' union at Northwest has been a lone and vocal critic of airline management, sending out frequent news releases boasting of a "steady barrage of attacks" on Northwest executives who "still very much like the indentured servant management model."
Martin Shugrue, the trustee for Eastern Airlines who also led concessionary bargaining in the early 1980's while at Pan Am, said, "What the unions need to do is to bury and put behind them their historic animosity toward each other." But, he added, "History tells you that has yet to happen in the airline business."
Will it happen at United if the unions take over, particularly when the employee owners are confronted years from now by the need for more sacrifices?
"That," said Julius Maldutis, an airline analyst at Salomon Brothers, "is the $64 question."
 
Rohatyn an Adviser
 Before that question can be answered, however, the unions must gain control of the company, and history makes many industry analysts skeptical. But consider the current momentum. United has hired Felix G. Rohatyn -- a Wall Street deal maker who served on the President Clinton's airline commission this year -- to help revive talks that broke off in mid-November when the unions offered $5.5 billion for the airline.
As last month's strike by American Airlines' flight attendants showed, President Clinton is taking an interest in such matters. United executives met recently with Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena and Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich to discuss the buyout's prospects.
For the first time, the company put forth its own proposal last week, rather than reacting to union suggestions. And United's chairman, Stephen M. Wolf, also became involved personally for the first time in the talks.

HEADLINE: New Analysis Finds Higher Costs in Health Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
A comprehensive analysis of President Clinton's health plan finds that it would reduce the Federal budget deficit, as Mr. Clinton said, but that the costs to Government and business would be higher than advertised by the White House.
In the most complete independent analysis of Mr. Clinton's plan, Lewin-VHI, a respected nonpartisan consulting concern, said today that insurance premiums for the wide range of health benefits promised by Mr. Clinton would be higher than estimated by the White House. Under the Clinton plan, employers would pay at least 80 percent of such premiums, and consumers would generally pay the remainder. 
 The study accepts Mr. Clinton's assumption that the Federal Government can slow the rate of increase in health care spending by regulating insurance premiums and by increasing competition among doctors and hospitals.
Using this assumption, Lawrence S. Lewin, chairman of Lewin-VHI, said: "The Administration's cost estimates are overly optimistic, but the Clinton plan still reduces the Federal budget deficit, and it holds together logically. It meets the President's requirement of providing universal coverage, and it does so without relying on an increase in broad-based income taxes."
The study is probably as authoritative as any by a private company and could set the tone for public debate until the Congressional Budget Office issues its analysis early next year.
John F. Sheils, chief author of the Lewin study, said that from 1995 to the year 2000 the Clinton proposal would cost the Government $78 billion more than the Administration's estimate of $286 billion. It would reduce the Federal budget deficit by a cumulative total of $25 billion in that period, rather than the $103 billion predicted by the Administration, he said.
 
Vindication Is Seen
 Alice M. Rivlin, Deputy Director of the Office of Management and Budget, welcomed Mr. Lewin's report as a form of vindication. It "essentially verifies our estimates and the soundness of the financing of our proposal," she said. She asserted that Mr. Lewin's cost estimates were "roughly the same" as President Clinton's.
A major premise of Mr. Clinton's plan is that the Government can save money by slowing medical inflation and by forcing employers to pay some costs now paid by Medicare and Medicaid, the programs for the elderly and the poor.
Kenneth E. Thorpe, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, said: "Most people out there don't believe there will be any deficit reduction. The Lewin report shows the President's plan will indeed reduce the deficit by billions of dollars. Our numbers are conservative, and the Lewin study confirms that."
Mr. Sheils said insurance premiums for employers and consumers would, on the average, had to be 17 percent higher than the President estimated to pay for the health benefits proposed under the Clinton plan.
To pay for the benefits, the Lewin study says premiums in 1998 would average $2,732 a year for a single people, $5,172 for one-parent families and $5,975 for two-parent families with children.
Lewin-VHI, a subsidiary of Value Health Inc., is respected by Federal officials and has done work for a wide range of businesses, labor unions, consumer groups and Government agencies. Mr. Lewin is a Democrat, but his company includes people who served as health and budget officials in the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
Under President Clinton's proposal, the Government would pay subsidies to small businesses and low-income people to help them buy insurance coverage. The Lewin study said such subsidies would cost the Government $153 billion in the first six years, about one-third more than the $116 billion estimated by the White House.
Because of the need for higher premiums to pay for all the benefits promised by Mr. Clinton, the Lewin report shows a net increase in employer spending for health insurance through the year 2000, while the President predicts a net reduction in such spending.
If private employers continued spending on health care as they currently do, the study says, they would spend $254 billion on health care in 1998. Under the Clinton plan, it says, they would spend $283 billion. Under the Clinton plan, "employer health spending would remain well above currently projected levels into the next century," but it would grow more slowly, the report says.
Mr. Clinton said his plan would increase Federal tax collections because employers, with lower health insurance costs, would have higher profits and pay higher wages. Both forms of income are taxable.
But the Lewin study said the requirement for employers to provide health insurance would reduce their profits. As a result, it said, Federal tax collections from 1995 to 2000 would be $18 billion lower than expected under current law. The White House, by contrast, said tax collections for those years would be $23 billion higher than projected under current law.

HEADLINE: Energy Dept. Will Spur Search for Oil and Gas

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
In a proposal to spur the domestic energy industry and reduce dependence on foreign oil, the Department of Energy will announce initiatives today to encourage greater use of natural gas, the opening of Federal lands for oil and gas exploration, and expanded drilling in the Gulf of Mexico.
Secretary of Energy Hazel R. O'Leary acknowledged in an interview yesterday that the plan contained no quick fixes for an industry that has lost about 400,000 jobs in the last decade and that is spending less money at home and more overseas on exploration and production. 
 She said her aim was to set off a debate that would make Congress and the public more aware that a growing dependence on imported oil would cost jobs in an industry that now employs 380,000 Americans. About 50 percent of the oil consumed in this country is imported.
Secretary O'Leary said that while the current drop in the price of crude oil, to less than $15 a barrel, meant lower prices for gasoline and home heating oil, it would also make the United States more vulnerable to supply disruptions from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
"Over time the cartel will capture more and more of the U.S. market," she warned, "and will be in a position to impose a dramatic price spike."
Ms. O'Leary said that cheaper imported oil also caused a decline in the output of natural gas, the use of which, she said, must be encouraged to reduce pollution as well as lessening dependence on foreign oil. "It sends the wrong signals," she added.
Ms. O'Leary said that Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbitt would issue a statement soon on the opening of Federal lands to exploration. This has been a touchy issue with environmentalists, who have been able to keep much of the East and West Coasts closed to new drilling.
Ralph Cavanagh, energy program director of the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental lobby, said yesterday that "in responding to the clamor of the domestic oil industry, one loses sight of the broader objectives of society."
He added that the Clinton Administration had "not put forth a strong initiative on fuel economy for automobiles," adding, "We ought to be hearing more about that before we hear about plans to expand drilling and production."
Anna Aurilio, a Public Interest Research Group scientist, said, "I don't see the justification for opening up new areas for exploration to get more oil until we figure out how to use the oil we consume more efficiently."
Much of the plan to be announced today speeds up existing energy efforts and coordinates Federal agencies in simplifying regulation while not compromising the environment. The plan calls for the formation of task forces to study the various proposals. One of those proposals is to increase production in the deep-water outer continental shelf in the Gulf of Mexico. It has vast oil and gas deposits, but has been difficult to develop because of technological challenges in very deep water.
The plan indicated that the Interior Department had set up a group to study incentives for companies to develop these fields. The department is expected to make a recommendation by the end of the month.
Theodore Eck, senior economist at the Amoco Corporation, said that while the plan was full of good ideas, such as the strategy to encourage more natural gas use, there were few real incentives to get basic energy users like utilities to switch to gas.

HEADLINE: 2 HOSPITALS FELT PRESSURE TO UNITE

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Under great economic and political pressures to overhaul health care, two prestigious teaching hospitals here, the Brigham and Women's Hospital and the Massachusetts General Hospital, said today that they had agreed to merge.
The merger was approved by a vote of the boards of both hospitals today. 
 The joining of two of the nation's oldest hospitals, with origins dating to the early 1800's, is arguably the most striking example of the effects of the Clinton Administration's health-care reform program on teaching hospitals.
The two nonprofit hospitals have been fierce competitors for many decades and have many duplicated specialized services. Now they have become the latest to join a wave of mergers of hospitals. About 1,000 hospitals have closed or merged since 1980, but they were mostly for-profit hospitals that are not teaching institutions.
The wave is expected to continue as the Administration presses for more economy in the health care system. Leaders of the two Boston hospitals said they wanted to try to influence the changes as best they could now, without waiting for Congress to pass legislation, and did not want to stand by idly, watching the parade.
 
Largest Boston Employer
 Dr. J. Robert Buchanan, the head of the Massachusetts General, said at a news conference, "There is no real claim today to leadership on the part of an academic health center if it does not assert its leadership in reforming and modernizing the health care delivery system."
With a payroll of 17,500 employees, the leaders said, the merged hospital would be the largest employer in Boston and the third largest employer in Massachusetts, behind the Raytheon Company and the Digital Equipment Corporation. The merger will also create what one hospital official said he believed would be the largest teaching hospital in the country. Both hospitals are major teaching hospitals of Harvard Medical School and have a combined faculty of 2,200 doctors and an additional 2,900 doctors-in-training.
Leaders of the two hospitals said the principal reason for the merger was to serve the needs of the community better, not to cut costs.
But in reading the mission statement, Dr. H. Richard Nesson, the head of the Brigham and Women's Hospital, said, "We recognize that we can maintain excellence and leadership only by reducing costs of services and by attaining ever superior quality of care."
 
20% Budget Cut Planned
 Dr. Nesson and Dr. Buchanan also said they expected to cut the $1.2 billion annual budget of the two hospitals by at least 20 percent over the next few years. They said they had not yet begun to determine where the cuts would come.
The merged hospital is expected to be the hub of a new integrated health care delivery system for Massachusetts and the New England region, the leaders of the two hospitals said. The two hospitals have been leaders in the high-technology brand of specialized medicine known as tertiary care, which deals with the sickest patients and those with the most complicated illnesses.
But such hospitals are now being forced to move into the community and expand primary care. They are doing so by allying with networks of primary care doctors like family practitioners, pediatricians and internists. The leaders of the two hospitals said they expected to form alliances with community-based hospitals and managed-care programs to improve primary health care.
Such alliances might decrease the number of primary care patients treated at either of the two merged hospitals but would increase the number of referrals of patients needing tertiary care in the merged medical center, Dr. Nesson said in an interview.
In recent years, hospital stays have been cut, occupancy rates have dropped and many hospitals have concentrated on expensive and lucrative high-technology medicine. But as Jack Connors Jr. a trustee of the Brigham and Women's Hospital, said of the merger: "The need is great because we have a significant overcapacity in terms of hospital beds and the ratio of specialists to primary care physicians."

HEADLINE: Proposed Coal Industry Pact Would Give Miners More Say

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON, W.Va., Dec. 8

 BODY:
A proposed coal industry contract could change the relationship between management and labor, allowing them to work together to resolve problems early on, officials said today.
Richard Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers, said the union had achieved "better wages and pensions while protecting our health care and our working conditions." He also said the proposed contract "drew the line against double-breasting" -- the practice of closing union mines and setting up nonunion subsidiaries. 
 An estimated 60,000 working and laid-off United Mine Workers who would be covered by the agreement will vote next week. A selective strike, which began on May 10 and expanded to 17,500 miners in seven states, will not end until a new contract is in place.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in a statement that the contract included "provisions that further strengthen workplace democracy and provide for miners to have a real say in the way work is performed."
 
'A Neutral Forum'
 The proposal calls for the establishment of "a neutral forum -- an industrywide, labor-management cooperative committee," Mr. Reich said. The committee will allow miners and managers to resolve problems "before they face the urgency of an expiring contract," he said.
Coal companies, mediators and union leaders refused to give details of the proposed five-year contract. But people who have seen the agreement said its main points indicated that both the U.M.W. and the members of the Bituminous Coal Operators Association, the industry bargaining group, achieved many, though certainly not all, of the goals enumerated at the start of talks a year ago.
The U.M.W. sought future jobs for its members. They could otherwise expect to be unemployed within the next seven years when existing mines are depleted.
Mr. Trumka had demanded 100 percent of the jobs created by the union's employers, even if they were created at nonunion subsidiaries.
 
60% of New Jobs
 People familiar with the talks said today that the proposed agreement gave the union 60 percent of the newly created jobs at all existing, new or newly acquired mines, even covering parent companies and related subsidiaries.
A similar proposal in the contract that expired in May fell apart because its language only covered the companies that actually signed the agreement, not their parents or subsidiaries.
The union has promoted changes in the labor-management relationship similar to those in the proposed contract, and it included them in an agreement signed earlier this year with four independent companies.
That contract allows managements to adopt radical new work rules if they are approved by members of the local union and if they will increase the number of jobs available to union members.
 
Still a Blacksmithing Clause
 That could spell significant change in a union where the contract still contains references to "blacksmithing" and "checkweighman." The latter is a holdover from the era when miners were paid by the amount of coal they loaded. Miners, believing that employers short-weighed their coal, demanded independent verification of weights.
The people close to the talks said the contract includes wage increases of more than $1.30 per hour. Under the old agreement, wages ranged up to $16.61 an hour.
Most retirement and health care issues were resolved by Congressional action last year in a bill supported by both the industry and the union. It requires every company that employed U.M.W. miners after 1950 to take responsibility for retirees' health care benefits. Previously, retirees were covered by industry-financed trust funds into which only a few companies had continued to pay.
At the start of talks, employers said they needed language that would help contain rising health care costs. Under the 1988 contract, employers pay 100 percent of health insurance premiums; employees are responsible for up to $200 a year in co-payments for prescription drugs and doctors' charges.
Under the proposal, miners would receive a $1,000 yearly bonus to cover their deductibles and co-payments.

HEADLINE: DEATH ON THE L.I.R.R.: The Suspect;
In Notes and Past of Accused, Portrait of Boiling Resentment

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES

 BODY:
The Brooklyn man accused of opening fire on a Long Island Rail Road train Tuesday was an unemployed loner who, within the time of three years, had gone from making the dean's list at a Long Island college to surviving on odd jobs in his Brooklyn neighborhood.
Notes that the police said Colin Ferguson carried in his pocket at the time of his rampage offer a portrait of a man filled with seething resentment: toward the whites and Asians he met and believed were racist; to the black attorneys he said refused to help him, to the elderly woman who rented him a room inside her Brooklyn home. 
 In February 1992, he was arrested and charged with harassing a woman on the subway. The case never went to trial, but he later sent letters to New York City's Police Commissioner and others complaining that his arrest was "viscous and racist." In September or October, a lawyer said, he threatened members of a law firm, telling them of a massacre that had happened in California. And in the last several months, he would call state workers compensation officials and the offices of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine to complain about his compensation case stemming from a job injury in 1989.
Yesterday, police officials, neighbors and acquaintances tried to understand what compelled the 35-year-old Mr. Ferguson to carry out the shootings. But the most telling clues may have been in the four pieces of notebook paper that investigators said he carried in his pocket Tuesday night, scribbled with a rambling explanation for the shootings.
He wrote in one of the notes of the "sloppy running of the #2 train," and "so-called civil right leaders such as the Rev. Herbert Daughtry, C. Vernon Mason, and Calvin Butts."
He also cited "racism by Caucasians and Uncle Tom Negroes."
Included in the notes were the names and telephone numbers of the state's Lieutenant Governor, the Attorney General's office, and a Manhattan law firm where lawyers were compelled to lock the door of an inner office after Mr. Ferguson called and threatened them, a lawyer with the firm said.
 
'I Felt Uncomfortable'
 The attorney, Lauren Abramson, remembered when Mr. Ferguson asked for a consultation about a year ago. She said that from the beginning she felt something was wrong. "I brought in a law clerk because I did not want to be alone with him," she said. "I've never done that before. I felt uncomfortable."
Though Mr. Ferguson was neatly dressed, be behaved oddly, giving her a false name before telling his real one, she said. Months later, he called and threatened the firm, she said.
"He feels discriminated against by everything and everyone," she said.
Yesterday, in a Long Island courtroom, Mr. Ferguson said nothing. As he was arraigned, he stood quietly, and did not enter a plea. He is being held without bail.
For the last two years, Mr. Ferguson had rented a room in Brooklyn from an elderly Haitian woman. But he began his life in Kingston, Jamaica, where he was born Jan. 14, 1958.
The son of a pharmacist, Mr. Ferguson was a well-rounded student who played cricket and soccer, said Joseph Earle, principal of Calabar High School in Kingston, which Mr. Ferguson attended.
While Mr. Ferguson was still a teen-ager, his father was killed in a car crash, Mr. Earle said, and his mother died soon after.
 
Difficulties in Class
 Mr. Ferguson made his way to the United States in 1982, and enrolled in Nassau Community College, where he made the dean's list in 1990. But Mr. Ferguson was forced to leave a class after a disciplinary hearing found that he had been overly aggressive toward the teacher, said a county official who insisted on anonymity. Mr. Ferguson later took the class again and received an A. He transferred to Adelphi in the fall of 1990.
There he majored in business administration, school officials said. But in June 1991, he was suspended for disciplinary reasons that officials declined to explain because of confidentiality rules. An official added that Mr. Ferguson was welcome to reapply after his suspension expired, but that he had not chosen to do so.
Mr. Ferguson also did clerical work for a company called Ademco Security Group in Syosset, L.I., but filed a workers compensation claim in April 1989, after he injured his head, neck and back by falling off a stool, said Barbara Patton, chairwoman of the New York State Workers Compensation Board. In September 1992, he was awarded $26,250, but last April, he tried to reopen the case, claiming the money was not enough.
"This agency bent over backwards for Mr. Ferguson," Ms. Patton said, noting that the agency had re-examined the case because of his persistence. "There is nothing that we ever saw in this man to lead us to think he would do something like this."
In Flatbush, the working-class Brooklyn neighborhood where he lived among many other West Indian immigrants, neighbors spoke of Mr. Ferguson as a quiet loner who seldom spoke. When he did, he said little more than a hello.
For a year, Catherine Workman and her six children lived next door to him. She recalled how neat he was, always dressed in a sweatsuit and crisp white T-shirt. She remembered standing in her doorway, seeing him walk down the street. And she remembered his silence.
"He never talked to me," she said. "He never smiled. He never looked at me. I'd look at him and he'd turn the other way."
