HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
As a cost-cutter, General Motors consolidates most of its media buying at one group of agencies.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
THE General Motors Corporation, in one of the largest consolidations ever of the media functions on an account, has named the Interpublic Group of Companies to handle the buying of about $800 million of the $1.3 billion it spends annually on advertising.
G.M., the nation's third-largest advertiser behind Procter & Gamble and Philip Morris, said yesterday that it would assign all national television and radio buying, with billings around $500 million, to a new dedicated unit in New York to be headed by Marc Goldstein, who is now a leading media services executive at the Interpublic agency Lintas U.S.A. 
 And all print buying, with billings estimated at $300 million, will be consolidated at a new dedicated unit in the Detroit suburb of Warren, Mich. That unit is to be headed by Karen Ritchie, a top media services executive at the Interpublic agency McCann-Erickson Detroit in Troy, Mich., the agency for G.M.'s Buick division and a partner in McCann/ SAS in Troy, the agency for G.M.C. trucks.
Mr. Goldstein and Ms. Ritchie, whose titles have not been determined, will report to Richard D. O'Connor, the chairman and chief executive of Lintas Campbell-Ewald in Warren, a sibling of Lintas U.S.A. that is the agency on G.M.'s Chevrolet car and truck account. G.M. has also not decided on names for the new units or staffing levels.
The units, which G.M. hopes will open by March 1, are emblematic of a trend among large marketers to seek additional efficiencies and economies in how their agencies buy advertising time and space. Among others that recently combined media functions are Anheuser-Busch, the Chrysler Corporation and Johnson & Johnson.
"We have a very strong belief that in order to effect and create opportunity, you have to do a damn good job getting price and quality right," Philip Guarascio, the general manager of marketing and advertising for G.M.'s North American Operations division, said yesterday in a telephone interview from Detroit.
Another crucial consideration, he said, was "creating proprietary advantages for our brands" -- in other words, the consolidation must avoid blurring the identities of G.M.'s six car lines and two truck lines. That was the reason media planning will remain unconsolidated, he said, as will functions like outdoor ad buying and direct marketing.
The decision ended an extensive review that had been followed closely by advertising and media executives since word began circulating in February that G.M. might make a further round of media consolidations. In 1986, the auto maker combined duties for various broadcast assignments at three shops: Leo Burnett U.S.A., the agency for Oldsmobile; D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, which handles Pontiac and Cadillac, and Lintas Campbell-Ewald.
Interpublic, asked to participate in the review, developed a strategy of teaming two of its three agency networks, offering to combine the services of McCann-Erickson, which had no large G.M. media responsibilities, with those of Lintas, which has bought time for G.M. on cable television networks and during sports programming. The other two review participants went it alone: Burnett, which has bought time for G.M. during network prime-time and syndicated programming, and D.M.B.& B., which has bought time for G.M. during television news programming and on network radio.
If those divisions of labor seem confusing, they are models of clarity compared with the complexities of G.M.'s print-buying assignments among six agencies. For instance, rather than a single agency negotiating the best rates and placements with the three national weekly news magazines, three did. (Burnett has handled Newsweek; Lintas, Time, and McCann-Erickson, U.S. News & World Report.)
"Now, instead of having three people in the news weekly category, we'll have one person looking to put it all together with a consistency of point of view," said Louis M. Schultz, executive vice president, director of media services and chairman of the worldwide media council at Lintas U.S.A. He spearheaded Interpublic's presentation to G.M., which, like those of Burnett and D.M.B. B., were made last week.
Mr. Guarascio stressed that in deciding among the three, "it was not a question of A being better than B or C, but of which package best fits our needs." Still, the selection was a blow to Burnett, because its role as the buyer of prime time for G.M. was a significant one. A spokesman for Burnett in Chicago, Wally Petersen, said that the six employees handling the duties being ceded to the new national broadcast unit would be reassigned to other accounts.
The selection was a significant morale booster for both Interpublic agencies. McCann-Erickson is still morose over losing the lead creative role on its important Coca-Cola Classic account to the Creative Artists Agency, while Lintas's New York office has been battered by account losses including Diet Coke and the IBM PC Company.
How much of a boost the decision will provide to Interpublic's bottom line, though, is unclear. The trade publication Mediaweek reported last week that the presentations the three agencies made included "a description of a new compensation formula" because "G.M.'s cost-carving knife likely will slice into the winning shop's current commission" of 9 percent of total billings.
Mr. Schultz said he could not talk about details, "but it's safe to say G.M. understands people are in business to make money."

(Lintas Worldwide), will make national television and radio assignments.

HEADLINE: Belgium;
A High School Teacher For Every 6.8 Students

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK

 BODY:
If the sheer number of primary and secondary public school teachers is an indicator of good education, Belgium ought to be a standout.
The small Northern European country, with a population of about 10 million, employs 5.3 percent of its work force as teachers, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. That is more than twice the 2.6 percent for the United States and much higher than figures for the 11 other members of the European Community, which range from 2.4 percent in Britain to 3.6 percent in Ireland. 
 But there are extenuating factors behind the number of Belgian teachers, the most important being jobs.
Like most of the rest of Europe, Belgium faces growing unemployment, now in the politically uncomfortable neighborhood of 10 percent. This has helped produce an education system that seems designed to create teaching jobs. For example, school is compulsory from ages 6 to 18 -- longer than in the United States -- and children may start school as young as 2 1/2.
"Raising the age to 18 was done partly to keep students in school so they wouldn't wind up on the unemployment roll," said Lorette Moureau, a spokeswoman at the Belgian Consulate in New York. She agreed that it also increased demand for teachers.
In addition, Belgium's limits on class sizes result in one of the lowest student-teacher ratios in the world: 9.3 primary students and 6.8 secondary students per teacher. This compares with 15.5 and 15.9 students per teacher, respectively, in the United States. The comparable figures for Britain are 22.2 and 15.3 students per teacher.
What is more, Belgium's linguistic division has resulted in separate education ministries for French and Flemish speakers. This results in some duplication but also creates more jobs. Even so, Belgium spends less per student than the United States and the rest of Europe spend, an indication of its low teacher salaries.
On balance, however, the Belgian education system gets high marks from educators and parents.
Barbara Wellborn, an American librarian and teacher who has lived in Belgium for 11 years, sends her 12-year-old daughter, Laura, to the public schools in Waterloo, where instruction is in French, instead of to a private international school that caters to expatriates.
"I place a high value on a neighborhood school and continuity of friends and teachers," Ms. Wellborn said. "And we wanted Laura to be truly bilingual. Also, the basic academic instruction is ahead of the American system. She was taught the multiplication tables in the second grade." FRED BROCK

HEADLINE: PORTUGAL;
A Lack of Discipline Keeps Math Scores Low

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Like the United States, Portugal is trying to improve its students' achievement in mathematics. In both nations, scores on standardized math tests are significantly lower than they are in other developed countries.
Some reasons given by Portuguese high school teachers and university professors for the nation's low math grades echo those cited by their counterparts in the United States: a lack of discipline among students and teachers and very little support in the home. 
 Maria Idalia Silva, a consultant in the Ministry of Education, added that until recently math instruction in Portugal had concentrated on abstract skills like calculation and had failed to relate theory to practical uses.
Under an overhaul of the nation's mathematics curriculum introduced in 1991, a far greater emphasis is being placed on ways of applying math skills. The new curriculum for eighth grade, for example, includes statistics as well as functions, geometry as well as equations. Efforts are also being made to individualize teaching and to introduce computers into classrooms.
While many of Portugal's problems with math education are similar to the challenges faced by American educators, some of the causes are uniquely Portuguese.
In the 1960's, after generations of elitist education and widespread illiteracy, schools were finally made universally accessible, causing an explosion in enrollments. But Portugal's leftist revolution in 1974 was followed by social and political upheavals that were reflected in volatile curriculums and a lack of direction in the schools. At the same time, financing remained low.
In the 1987-88 school year, compulsory schooling was extended to nine years from six, resulting in overcrowded public schools, scarce money for books and equipment and a shortage of teachers.
"We've been trying out reforms for years," said Jaime Reis, a former economics professor at the New University in Lisbon, "but Portugal still spends less per capita on education than other European countries." Among the problems he cited were a serious shortage of math teachers, particularly in the provinces, and poor management of public schools.
"It is common knowledge that private schools in Portugal function infinitely better than public schools," Mr. Reis said.
In 1990, the Government declared education reform a top priority. With the economy generally improving and with support from the European Community, new primary and secondary schools have been built, but teacher training has not improved, and average levels of education have continued to drop. MARVINE HOWE

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Ads Attack Democrats on Tax Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Radio advertisements paid for by the Republican National Committee in 15 Congressional districts on Wednesday attack House Democrats who voted for President Clinton's tax increases but against $90 billion in spending cuts.
The party also unveiled another radio advertisement singling out Representative Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky, a Pennsylvania Democrat who cast the deciding House vote for Mr. Clinton's budget and deficit-reduction package. 
 The advertisement is timed to discredit Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky as Mr. Clinton prepares to visit her suburban Philadelphia district on Monday for an economic forum, a visit that he promised to make in exchange for her vote.
Democrats wasted no time in counterattacking. In a letter to the Republican national chairman, Haley Barbour, the Democratic national chairman, David Wilhelm, cited an array of improving economic statistics and suggested that Republicans were desperate.
The advertisement said the House Democrats had voted for $260 billion in new taxes as part of Mr. Clinton's deficit reduction legislation. "But spending went up, not down," the commercial said.
All 15 of those targeted by the advertisement voted for Mr. Clinton's budget package and against $90 billion in cuts proposed late in the Congressional session by Representatives Timothy J. Penny, Democrat of Minnesota, and John R. Kasich Republican of Ohio.

HEADLINE: DEATH ON THE L.I.R.R.: The White House;
Moved by Killings, Clinton Urges Action on Gun Legislation

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he had instructed the Attorney General to review a proposal by Mayor-Elect Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York that would set up a national uniform licensing system for gun buyers that would include background checks, tests and required renewals every two years.
Talking about the New Yorkers shot at random by a gunman on a Long Island Rail Road train on Tuesday night, Mr. Clinton said that he hoped that this "terrible human tragedy" would "give some more impetus to the need to act urgently to deal with the unnecessary problems of gun violence in the country." 
 The President himself raised the chilling Long Island shootings at the start of a lunch at Blair House with reporters and talked about it again in the White House driveway afterward. Saying there are more licensed gun dealers than service station owners in America, the President said, "Let's get about the business of making our country safer."
A Justice Department official had called the District Attorney's Office in Nassau County to gather facts for the President about the make, manufacture and purchase of the 9-millimeter semiautomatic gun used in the random shootings. And Mr. Clinton said he had told Janet Reno, the Attorney General, to give him a recommendation after she reviewed ideas for tougher gun licensing suggested by both Mr. Giuliani and Richard Riordan, Los Angeles' Mayor-Elect.
He said he was intrigued with Mr. Giuliani's idea, which the two men talked about in a meeting at the White House earlier on Tuesday, that guns could be handled like cars at the state level, but with national standards.
"It is interesting that, you know, we regularly have requirements, for example, for driving cars that don't apply to the use of guns," Mr. Clinton said. "When I was a boy and first started to hunt, one of the first things I was told was that you have to learn how to use a gun safely and responsibly and it's something I think we ought to look it.
"And in a state like New York, a city like New York City where there are quite restrictive licensing requirements locally that may affect who can open a big store, but it doesn't have anything to do with the Federal licensing. So one of the things we need to look at is whether this should become more like some other forms of regulations like clean air regulations, where the state and local regulations are on top of the Federal regulations and all have to be complied with."
Mr. Clinton has clearly taken to heart polls that show a surge of concern about violent crime, as well as the lesson of the recent mayoral elections in New York and Los Angeles in which voters favored two Republicans who made curbing crime a central element of their campaigns.
A new poll by CBS News on crime showed that 64 percent of Americans did not believe that gun control laws could reduce violent crime, compared with 34 percent who said such laws could. But at the same time, nearly half of those polled, or 49 percent, said they approved of banning the sale of handguns, while 49 percent still oppose a ban. This is a distinct shift from a similar poll in March in which 41 percent favored a ban and 55 percent opposed one.
The President reiterated his support for the crime bill in Congress that features an amendment sponsored by Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, that would ban 19 semiautomatic assault weapons and large-capacity feeding devices that hold more than 10 rounds of ammunition at a time. The amendment has passed in the Senate, but has not yet been voted on in the House; President Clinton noted that the House "has generally been more reluctant" on assault weapons bans.
 
For Shooting Faster
 "They're not necessary for hunting or sports purposes," Mr. Clinton said of the multiround clips. "It simply allows you to shoot and wound more people more quickly."
The 9-millimeter handgun used by the gunman on the Long Island Rail Road held 15 shots. The man, who had bought the gun in California, had fired two clips and was loading a third when he was jumped and stopped by some passengers.
Mr. Clinton said the Feinstein amendment, had it been made law, might have saved some lives on the train.
"If you read the accounts, apparently, the rapid fire of the gun was something that almost paralyzed all the people on the car, but eventually when the guy had to change clips and was wrestled to the ground, that seems to me to be a pretty good argument for the Feinstein amendment," he said. "And I hope very much that when the Congress comes back, they will pass it."
But the President acknowledged that America might never be able to protect itself from the madness of someone with a weapon going berserk, as he put it.
"No one believes that there's anything we can ever do to solve every problem of someone who snaps mentally -- about something terrible like this," he said. "I mean we have to acknowledge that honestly. There are a lot of things that we're going to have to do in this country to get violence under control that relate to rebuilding our communities and healing across racial lines and economic lines, but we need to start with public safety."

HEADLINE: Dow Hits a High Again on Healthy Volume

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average set another record yesterday, pushed higher by big price jumps in shares of companies whose fortunes are tied to an improving economy.
Aside from these cyclical stocks, rising prices for a range of industrial materials were a boon for mining and commodity stocks. 
 "This was definitely a blue-chip, industrial metal-oriented market," said Thom Brown, chairman of Walnut Asset Management in Philadelphia. "The Dow went out and celebrated the basic-industry companies with a really sterling gain."
The 15.65-point rise in the Dow put the index at 3,734.53, surpassing Tuesday's previous all-time high of 3,718.88. Volume was a healthy 314.5 million shares, up from 285.7 million in the previous session.
 
Advances Outnumber Declines
 On the Big Board, advancing issues narrowly outnumbered declines. Prices were generally higher on the American Stock Exchange, but moved lower on the Nasdaq's over-the-counter trading system.
Among broader market averages, the S.& P. 500 fell 0.47, to 466.29. And the Nasdaq's composite index dropped 1.46, to 767.89.
With the exception of J. P. Morgan, the financial-services company, the rise in commodity prices like gold and silver sent prices of stocks sensitive to rising interest rates lower.
Morgan, one of the Dow's 30 blue-chip components, announced an increase in its dividend and a stock buyback yesterday. Its stock was up 1 1/2, to 72 3/4.
Other Dow stars were the Aluminum Company of America, up 3 1/4, to 72 1/2, and Caterpillar, the heavy-machinery manufacturer, which was up 1 1/8, to 85 1/8. Eastman Kodak also had a good day, rising by 1 1/8, to 62 1/2.
The rise in the price of precious metals and other commodities was somewhat anomalous, because oil prices, often seen as the bellwether indicator of inflation, fell again yesterday.
Holders of oil company shares reacted more predictably to the drop in oil prices, and sold the stocks.
Exxon fell 3/8, to 62 1/4. Amoco dropped 1, to 52 1/8. And Atlantic Richfield was off 1/8, to 103 1/2.
The rise in commodity prices failed to send shivers through the bond market, as interest rates moved a tad lower in advance of Government reports on inflation expected today and tomorrow. And analysts said the commodity price increases should not necessarily be equated with a coming surge in inflation.
"I think inflation will be somewhat higher next year than we have had this year," said James Solloway, director of research at Argus Research. "But this shift to cyclical stocks has more to do with a comeback for companies tied more closely to a turn in the economy."
Mr. Brown noted that "articles in the press have been talking about the coming boom in commodities. And prices in these companies have been so depressed that in theory they will pick back up, once the world economy starts to recover."
Other winners yesterday included Xerox, which rose 5 1/4, to 86, after the copier maker announced it would eliminate about 10,000 workers, or roughly 10 percent of its worldwide work force over the next couple of years to cut costs and improve productivity. USX, the steel and oil company, was up 1, to 38 3/4.
 
President's Signing of Trade Pact
 And on the day President Clinton signed legislation to put the North American Free Trade Agreement into effect, investors bid up shares in Telefonos de Mexico, the telephone company, to 61 1/4, up 1 3/4 on the day.
Gold mining stocks did well. Echo Bay Mines, traded on the American Stock Exchange, was up 3/4, to 13 1/2.
A big loser on the Nasdaq market was Microsoft, whose stock price fell 2, to 83 1/2, after reports that Goldman, Sachs had lowered earnings estimates for the company, citing concerns that a major project introduction may be delayed.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Names Albany Adviser As Budget Chief

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday named as his budget director Abraham M. Lackman, a man with a broad knowledge of New York City's finances gained from previous encounters with city administrations -- most of them adversarial.
For the last decade, Mr. Lackman has been a senior fiscal adviser to the Republican-controlled State Senate, which has often jousted with the Democrats who have long dominated City Hall. Now he will be the main official dealing with perhaps the most difficult problem facing the Republican-Liberal Mayor-elect -- how to close future budget deficits estimated at $2 billion a year. 
 Mr. Lackman said yesterday that he hoped to bring some new approaches to budget balancing. Among other things, he said, he wants to collect more unpaid parking fines so the city can avoid tax increases.
 
Working Out Solutions
 Mr. Lackman has long taken a skeptical view of Democratic solutions to the city's fiscal problems. When city officials went to Albany nearly three years ago, for example, to press for passage of Mayor David N. Dinkins's ambitious police expansion program, they met with Mr. Lackman. He told representatives of Mr. Dinkins and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, both Democrats, that to win support from the Republican senators they would have to promise to do precisely what the Mayor had said he would do in an earlier press release: hire a specific number of new police officers by a specific series of dates.
The deadlines, and the hiring targets, became part of the legislation that eventually authorized the program.
"Abe successfully made the city put its money where its mouth was," recalled Mark V. Shaw, the City Council's top fiscal adviser. "I thought that was a brilliant stroke on his part, an incredibly smart move by someone representing the Republican senators from New York City."
Among the many intriguing paradoxes in Mr. Giuliani's announcement yesterday afternoon that he had selected Mr. Lackman for the critical post of city budget director was that it would now be up to Mr. Lackman to help find the money to meet the hiring deadlines embedded in the state law he helped craft early in 1991.
And among Mr. Lackman's foremost political and governmental adversaries when he becomes the budget director on Jan. 1 will be Mr. Shaw, the director of the Council's Finance Division, its chief architect of fiscal policy and -- not insignificantly -- the other finalist in Mr. Giuliani's search for budget director. That Mr. Lackman and Mr. Shaw worked together for the State Senate for eight years in Albany and are very close friends just adds to the unusual complexities of the Mayor-elect's selection.
Many people familiar with the arcane world of fiscal politics said yesterday that Mr. Giuliani had made a good choice, and they described Mr. Lackman as energetic and knowledgeable. But some officials also cautioned that Mr. Lackman had not previously held an executive position with the huge responsibilities of budget director, who oversees the fiscal planning for dozens of city agencies and who often wields a power over commissioners and other agency heads second only to the mayor's. In an implicit acknowledgement of that authority, Mr. Giuliani said Mr. Lackman would report directly to him.
Many officials also noted the odd transformation that Mr. Lackman will now undergo. As director of the fiscal studies for the Senate Finance Committee, he often drafted the Republican strategy that sought to counter efforts by New York City Democrats to funnel more state resources to the city. Soon Mr. Lackman will be among those leading the Giuliani administration efforts in Albany, arguing the city's case to skeptical legislators.
"This removes from Albany a person whose primary function has been to limit the benefits for New York City," said Assemblyman Sheldon Silver, the Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee and who described Mr. Lackman as bright and personable. "He's going to now find out what it's like to have to deal with the Senate, from the perspective of the city."
At the same time, other officials said, his relationship with many lawmakers could serve Mr. Lackman well when he lobbies for the city in Albany.
Mr. Lackman said in an interview that he thought his standing as an outsider who was familiar with the city budget would serve him well in his new job. Because he is not an insider at City Hall, Mr. Lackman said, he might be more inclined to change the way the city budget is put together.
 
Broad Priorities
 Mr. Lackman declined to offer many details. He reiterated many of Mr. Giuliani's broad priorities -- eliminating the city's long-term structural deficit and stimulating the local economy by phasing out some taxes -- and he ruled out tax increases.
He said he hoped to find creative ways to close future budget gaps. One possibility, he said, was to collect more of the city's unpaid parking fines. Mr. Lackman also said he hoped to prevent the elimination of city jobs to balance the budget, but he did not rule that out.
"My first step will be to see how far I can get with creative ideas to close the gaps without the more difficult solutions," he said.
Mr. Lackman, who is 45 years old, was born in Belgium of parents who had survived Nazi concentration camps. The family came to the United States when he was 2 1/2 years old, and he was raised in the South Bronx, Far Rockaway and Flushing. He attended public schools and graduated from Flushing High School.
 
An N.Y.U. Graduate
 Mr. Lackman then graduated from New York University, majoring in sociology and religion. Later he earned a master's degree in economics from the State University of New York at Albany. He went to work in 1979 as an analyst for the Senate Finance Committee, and he was named director of fiscal studies in 1984.
Mr. Lackman's wife, Jeanne, is a first grade teacher, and the couple has two children, Jonathan and Aaron. Mrs. Lackman and Aaron, who is 15, were with Mr. Lackman at Mr. Giuliani's transition headquarters yesterday for the announcement of his selection.
Mr. Giuliani said that he was glad to meet the family, and, noting the rigors of the budget tasks ahead, he added, "This is a tremendous opportunity for them to see you for the last time."

HEADLINE: Productivity Up Sharply

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
American productivity increased at a 4.3 percent annual rate in the third quarter, the biggest jump in more than six years, the Labor Department reported today. The report was issued shortly after the Xerox Corporation announced that it would eliminate more than 10,000 jobs -- about 10 percent of its work force.
"The dark side of the scenario is that a lot of the productivity gains are coming through layoffs," said Stephen S. Roach, a Morgan Stanley & Company economist in New York. 
 The revised, seasonally adjusted increase in nonfarm productivity -- output per hour worked -- was the largest since it rose 4.3 percent in the second quarter of 1987, the Labor Department said. It was also the first increase since a 4.2 percent rise in the final three months of 1992 and was stronger than the department's initial 3.9 percent estimate last month. It followed drops of 1.8 percent in the first quarter of 1993 and four-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter.
Output in the quarter increased 4.4 percent, up from a 4 percent gain three months earlier. Total hours worked rose one-tenth of 1 percent, compared with 4.4 percent in the second quarter.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said today that supplies of unsold goods at wholesalers fell five-tenths of 1 percent in October to a seasonally adjusted $214.13 billion. The drop was the sharpest since April 1991. Sales by wholesalers also fell five-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $159.9 billion. In September, supplies were flat and sales fell a similar five-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
ITT Plans to Spin Off Forest Products Subsidiary

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Seeking to rid itself of a volatile business that was dragging down earnings, the ITT Corporation announced yesterday that it would spin off its forest products subsidiary to the company's shareholders.
ITT said the subsidiary, ITT Rayonier Inc., would become an independent company worth $700 million to $800 million. The division, which produces and sells timber, wood products and pulp, had income of $112 million on revenues of $719 million -- about 5 percent of ITT's total revenues -- for the first nine months of 1993. 
 The spinoff is part of a new direction at ITT, which had long typified the conglomerate, diversifying by buying up interests in automotive products, forest products, hotels, insurance and military operations in the 1960's and 1970's. ITT acquired Rayonier, founded in 1926, in 1968.
Analysts said that by shedding Rayonier, ITT would take another step in its campaign to increase return on equity to 16 percent or 17 percent by 1995 from 11 percent or 12 percent this year.
 
Concrete Programs
 Phua K. Young, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, said Rayonier's return on equity was less than 10 percent.
"There has been a long history at ITT of wanting to improve returns but not being able to," he said. "Now they have very concrete programs. They are taking the approach that nothing is sacred."
Under the plan approved by ITT's board, ITT shareholders will get a special dividend of one share of Rayonier common stock for every four shares of ITT common stock or one share of Rayonier common stock for every 3.1595 shares of ITT series N preferred stock. Shares of ITT rose $2.375, to $91.125, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
ITT said it expected that neither the shareholders nor the company would have to pay taxes on the transaction. About 30 million shares would be created in the new company, which will apply for listing on the New York Stock Exchange and change its name to Rayonier Inc. ITT, based in New York City, will have no ownership stake in the new company, which will be based in Stamford, Conn.
 
Improved Standing
 Rand V. Araskog, the chairman, chief executive and president of ITT, said in an interview yesterday that the spinoff would improve the standing of ITT on Wall Street because its earnings would no longer be linked to the forest products industry, which is very capital intensive and tends to undergo sharp swings in revenues.
"Rayonier is in a very cyclical business," Mr. Araskog said. "Our casualty insurance business is cyclical, but our other businesses are not particularly cyclical. They don't go the way Rayonier does, where all of a sudden you are producing pulp at a loss and you have to keep the pulp mill running."
He added that ITT had decided to spin off Rayonier, rather than sell it outright, because the forest products industry was just coming out of a prolonged recession and the price for the division might have been too low.
"Our most important goal is serving the shareholders of this company," he said. "There is a lot of residual value in Rayonier that is not being recognized in the ITT overall position. This is a way of putting that value out into the overall market."
 
Announcements Planned
 Mr. Araskog declined to identify the executives who would lead the independent Rayonier, saying they would be announced in the coming weeks. He said he first had the idea of spinning off Rayonier last summer. The company was advised by Lazard Freres & Company.
ITT, which has 106,000 employees in 63 countries, had total income in that period of $1.3 billion, on revenues of $15.4 billion.
Mr. Young at Lehman Brothers said ITT, like some other major conglomerates, was becoming more concerned with keeping shareholders happy.
"Competition now is a lot more global," he said. "To defend market share takes a lot more effort in terms of money and management time. ITT has eight businesses and it's tough to manage all that."

HEADLINE: NEEDIEST CASES;
A Quick Slide From a Good Job to a Soup Kitchen

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
When David R. worked in Manhattan as a data processing auditor, he used to feel a gulf between himself and the hungry, shabby, often desperate people he saw sleeping on the sidewalks or holding out their hands.
No longer. 
 "I used to be there, walking down the street and looking at these poor, poor people and thinking that there must be something wrong with them, that it must be their fault," he said recently in a room upstairs from a midtown soup kitchen where he eats breakfast and lunch.
"Now," he said, "I am one of them."
David R. is one of 330,000 New York City residents facing the holidays without a job. He is one of a growing number of people whose once solid economic security has been eroded by recession-driven layoffs and corporate relocations.
While the employment picture is beginning to improve nationwide, 10.2 percent of New York City's work force is unemployed. The number of jobless people in the city has remained higher than elsewhere in the region for more than a year, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. David, 34, has been unemployed for nearly two years, relieved only briefly by stints in part-time jobs.
 
Jobs Once Easy to Find
 After graduating from Brooklyn College with an accounting degree in the early 1980's, he moved from job to job with ease, eventually landing at the Mobil Corporation, where he was taking home $990 a week, he said. Long-term unemployment was about as far from his mind, as being drafted into the Army, he said.
"They flew me all over," David said. "To Dallas one day, then Virginia, then New Jersey. I once lived in Dallas for several months in a hotel suite."
But when Mobil told him that he would have to move to Fairfax, Va., where the company was relocating its headquarters, he decided to take a chance and stay in New York. It was a fateful decision.
After dozens of unfruitful interviews and dead-end, part-time jobs, David lost his apartment in Forest Hills, Queens. He sold his stereo, his television and his furniture. He lived with friends until he could no longer impose on them. He even sold some of the jewelry once owned by his parents, who died when he was younger.
Finally, he turned to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services in Manhattan, a beneficiary of the UJA-Federation of New York. The UJA-Federation is one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which has begun its 82nd annual appeal for donations.
 
Help With Welfare
 The fund helps the charities provide help not only to the unemployed but also to others like women in abusive relationships, children in gun-ridden neighborhoods and homeless families. This year's campaign ends on Feb. 28.
Because The Times pays for the fund's overhead, all contributions go directly to the charities.
The Jewish Board has helped get David a 7-by-15-foot room at a Y.M.C.A. in Queens and assisted him in negotiating the welfare maze. The board has also helped him pay small expenses that he can no longer cover, like repairing his glasses.
The longer he goes without a job, the harder it is to find one, he said. "People look at my resume and they think there must be something wrong with me," he said. "It's funny how I'm on the other side now."
But David still believes that as long as he is able and willing to work in any job offered him, he will eventually regain his footing. "I'm just 34," he said. "I can be trained to do anything. And I'm willing to do anything, any time. If they had an eighth day in the week, I'd work the midnight shift that day."

HEADLINE: Fed Upgrades Economy as Holidays Near

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve System issued an improved assessment of economic strength today, reporting a strong beginning of holiday shopping but warning of increases in the prices of raw materials in a few regions.
"Reports were generally more optimistic than those of this summer," the central bank said in its "beige book," a look at regional business activity. The report summarizes anecdotal material collected from the Fed's 12 regional banks before Nov. 29. It will be used by monetary policy makers when they meet on Dec. 21. 
 The Fed noted that California still suffered economically and that conditions in the Northeast were mixed. But over all, the economy "continued to expand at a moderate pace," it said.
That is an improvement over the "slow to moderate" phrase used by the Fed since June. Such slight changes in wording are regarded by economists as telling hints of the central bank's thinking.
The Fed report said consumer spending picked up in most parts of the country, particularly for automobiles and other durable goods like appliances.
"The holiday shopping season got off to a good start over the long Thanksgiving weekend with sales at or exceeding expectations," it said. Manufacturing activity was improving in most places, it added, "but few businesses reported new hiring."
Residential real estate was reported strong, and long-moribund commercial real estate markets "have begun to show a few signs of improvement," it said.
The report also reflected slightly more concern about inflation than previous assessments have.
"Wage increases and prices for final goods generally were said to be stable," the Fed declared. But it noted that the Chicago district bank reported signs that increases in raw-material prices were becoming more common. The Boston and Richmond banks said some manufacturers had increased prices.
 
Speculation on Interest Rates
 Some economists said that the report, coupled with recent remarks of top Fed officials, laid the groundwork for a slight increase in short-term interest rates to squelch any possibility of more inflation.
"We're closer to the day when the Fed will begin tightening again," said one of the economists, Mark Zandi of Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. "They want to be out ahead of any significant inflationary pressures."
The report said that overall economic growth, which slumped to 1.4 percent in the first half of the year, improved to 2.7 percent in the third quarter and was expected to approach 4 percent in the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: Whitman Seeks Extra Month to Prepare a Budget

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAWRENCE, N.J., Dec. 8

 BODY:
Gov.-elect Christine Todd Whitman said today that she would ask the Legislature for an extra month to introduce her first budget, giving her more time to find the more than $500 million in budget savings she will need to finance her promised tax cuts.
State law requires the Governor to give the budget to the Legislature by Feb. 15. But a delay until March 15 has become routine for new governors and was granted to both Gov. Jim Florio and former Gov. Thomas H. Kean. 
 "If Jim Florio can take an extra month to decide how to raise your taxes by $2.8 billion, I can certainly take an extra month to decide how to cut them," Mrs. Whitman said during a speech to employees at Bristol-Myers Squibb, a pharmaceutical company that has research laboratories in Lawrence Township.
Mrs. Whitman also said she would conduct a series of town meetings, radio and television call-in shows and round-table discussions over the next six weeks to find out from taxpayers what services they want protected and what they are willing to have cut.
"I am going to cut the state budget the same way I am going to govern," she said. "By consensus, not by decree."
The first television program will be broadcast live at 7 P.M. Dec. 15 on the Cable Television Network of New Jersey. On Dec. 22 Mrs. Whitman will be host of a second call-in program on WKXW 101.5, the radio station in Trenton that helped spawn the tax revolt against Governor Florio.
Mrs. Whitman has pledged to cut the state income tax for most taxpayers by 10 percent a year for the next three years, totaling about $1.4 billion over three years. The first cut would require trimming about $500 billion in the first 18 months of her administration, a combination of the final six months of the current budget and the budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1994. The state's annual budget is now $15.7 billion a year.
Mrs. Whitman said she intended to fulfill her campaign promise to cut taxes by reducing the size of state government and by asking taxpayers to rate state services.
"What is most important to you?" she asked. "If you had only 10 dollars to spend, would you spend it on roads or health care, emergency management or employment training?"
Mrs. Whitman said she would meet with state legislators from both parties on Friday to discuss the budget. Beginning next week, she said, she will have a series of round-table discussions on topics like economic development, human services and the environment. The town meetings will be scheduled for January.
Mrs. Whitman also asked taxpayers to send her suggestions for cutting the state budget. They should be mailed to: Our Tax Dollars, care of Gov.-Elect Whitman, CN 096, Trenton, N. J. 08625.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Surges Against Yen On Fed Official's Remarks

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar surged against the Japanese yen yesterday after a Federal Reserve official urged the Bank of Japan to aim for a weaker yen to spur domestic growth.
Wayne D. Angell, a Federal Reserve governor, said at a conference in London that the stronger yen was hurting the Japanese economy. He said its central bank should aim for a rate of 120 yen to the dollar -- far weaker than the dollar's recent range of 107.50 to 109.50 yen. 
 "His comments were not taken lightly," said Michael McKeever, assistant vice president at the Fuji Bank. "The dollar had a nice little rally."
Dealers said Mr. Angell's comments, which appeared sharply at odds with what many still perceive as an American desire for a weaker dollar against the yen, caught the market by surprise.
"They were the first comments from the Fed calling for a stronger dollar," a Japanese bank dealer in New York said.
The dollar drifted off its highs after Mr. Angell clarified his remarks, saying that 120 yen to the dollar was not an official American target. Still, in late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 108.95 yen, up from 107.53 yen on Tuesday
 
Remarks Are Discounted
Some analysts discounted Mr. Angell's remarks. "They were words of advice from a hawk on the way out," said Angelo Evangelista, vice president at the Bank of Boston. Mr. Angell, who will retire from the Federal Reserve early next year, is considered an "inflation hawk" and has repeatedly warned of the inflationary effects of a weaker dollar.
Mr. Evangelista said inflationary fears had accelerated now that the economy was growing more quickly.
European currencies were sidelined, with most attention focused on the yen. But the French franc firmed after Prime Minister Edouard Balladur indicated that Paris was inclined to accept a world trade pact under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
France is seen as a major stumbling block to a GATT pact and any progress is good for the franc, dealers said. The dollar slipped to 5.8395 French francs in New York, from 5.8560 francs on Tuesday. But it rose to 1.7052 marks from 1.7018 marks.
The British pound closed in New York at $1.4970, up from $1.4930 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Silver Hits a 4-Month High; Gold and Platinum Also Up

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Silver prices climbed yesterday to their highest levels in four months amid signs of strong economic growth.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, silver for March delivery, the most actively traded contract, rose 6.8 cents, to $5.013 an ounce. 
 The buying spilled into gold, with the February contract jumping $6.40, to $385.70 an ounce on the Comex.
Silver, widely used by the electronics and photography industries, has been bolstered by strong physical purchases of the metal, analysts said. It has risen about 12 percent in the last week; since the middle of September it has rallied more than 25 percent from less than $4 an ounce.
"It has been encountering tremendous interest from the funds and its low unit price as a metal makes it even more attractive than gold," said Rhona O'Connell, an analyst at T. Hoare & Company, brokers in London.
Investors have been buying silver on the heels of recent data showing that the American economy, after one of its slowest recoveries in memory, has finally been gathering strength. Ms. O'Connell said that investment funds began to take a special interest in silver last month when physical purchases by Saudi Arabia increased sharply.
 
Shipped to Saudi Arabia

"An enormous amount of physical silver was shipped to Saudi Arabia at the time, underpinning an already semi-speculative rally and giving it a more solid physical undertone," Ms. O'Connell said.
Platinum, another metal favored by industry, also rose at the New York Mercantile Exchange, with the January contract up $5.30 at $383.70 an ounce.
Also at the Nymex, oil prices eased and natural gas prices fell steeply. January crude closed 11 cents lower at $14.59 a barrel, while January natural gas fell 7.2 cents, to $1.982 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Inaction by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in curtailing output continued to depress the market, which has slid down to five-year lows. And the American Petroleum Institute trade group late Tuesday reported a rise in crude and oil product inventories in the last week, indicating domestic supplies remain ample.
"The market is just continuing in its downtrend and there is nothing to suggest a turnaround right now," said Shannon Burchett, an analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Success for Vietnam may depend on how well it copies China.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
BY most accounts -- including the World Bank's -- Vietnam is an odds-on bet to be the next Asian economy to wow the world with double-digit growth. Apparently the only unanswered question is whether embargo-hobbled American investors will be shut out by Japanese and European rivals.
But a panel of conservative American economists and Vietnamese expatriates, recruited by the Pacific Basin Research Institute and the Donner Foundation, aren't so sure. Their newly published report offers a cool-eyed view of a nation and economy hobbled by bureaucracy and divided by region. "The basis for a truly free market is not yet there," said Bui Diem, the director of the institute and once South Vietnam's ambassador to America. 
 Who has the better case? Much depends on whether Vietnam has the right stuff to mimic the Chinese, decentralizing the economy without freeing the political system.
While United States air power failed to return Vietnam to the Stone Age, the country's Marxist economic managers inadvertently made a good run at the task on their own. Vietnam currently ranks among the world's poorest countries, in the same league as Ethiopia, Bangladesh and Mozambique. It even shared a dubious honor with sub-Saharan Africa as one of the last places on earth in the 1980's where masses of people were at risk of starvation.
How could a nation that threw off the French colonial yoke and wore out the world's mightiest military machine find itself in such a fix? The panel's report makes it all too clear that an indefatigable will to sacrifice in the name of nationalism doesn't necessarily translate into economic success.
After unification in 1975, Vietnam collectivized agriculture in the south along with nationalizing all manufacturing and most services. By even the Government's admission, though, "socialism building" was a disaster that left the war-devastated economy barely able to feed the nation.
Economic liberalization followed in the early 1980's; price controls were eased and enterprises permitted to sell to private markets once they fulfilled state quotas. But while the reforms led to growth -- Vietnam has become a major exporter of rice -- they also widened income differences between the north and the commerce-minded south, leaving the warrior half of the country with little to show for decades of suffering.
According to the Pacific Basin Research Institute, average incomes in Ho Chi Minh City (once known as Saigon) are two and a half times greater than in Hanoi. What's more, the Government's inability to collect a big share of the bounty in taxes created runaway inflation that impoverished the nation's ponderous bureaucracy.
By the late 1980's, Vietnam's rulers found themselves in a trap not unlike that faced by the Soviet leadership. Going backward was unthinkable, given the utter failure of state ownership and central planning. Plunging ahead, however, was almost as perilous a prospect for the military and bureaucratic elites, who were not unaware of the fate of their counterparts in the Soviet Union. That is where the Chinese model, one in which the go-go south is given license to grow rich in return for political acquiescence and a financial tithe to the north, fits in.
Can Hanoi pull it off? David Dollar, the senior economist working on Vietnam for the World Bank (and one of the few dollars the World Bank has ever lent to Vietnam), is "cautiously optimistic." As in China, he said, liberalization of agriculture has produced gratifyingly rapid results. The unproductive state-owned industrial sector actually represents a lesser drag than in China since it employs a smaller fraction of the population. What's more, foreign investment is likely to make a tangible difference very quickly in a country with a relatively educated and disciplined work force. "It's not hard to grow if you are starting at $200 per capita," Mr. Dollar said.
But the Pacific Basin Panel suggests weakness in the parallels. Unlike China, Vietnam has yet to guarantee property rights or create a passably efficient commercial banking system. Unlike the Chinese, Vietnamese save relatively little; hence the rapid investment required for an economic miracle will depend on foreign capital as well as foreign technology. And unlike China's, the Vietnamese economy was until very recently closely integrated with (and dependent on aid from) the Soviet economy.
Last but not least, Vietnam starts in a position of relative fiscal weakness. While the Government managed to reduce the budget deficit to a modest 2 percent of national income in 1992 by savagely cutting enterprise subsidies, failure to keep state enterprise deficits in check or to collect revenue from the booming cities of the south could once again let the inflation genie out of the bottle.
The great imponderable here is the same one faced by China in the 1980's: whether liberal economics can coexist with authoritarian politics. "The root of the problem is political legitimacy," Mr. Diem said -- whether the country can tolerate the shock of rapid economic transformation without government of and by the people.

HEADLINE: NORTH KOREA SHIFT STIRS SPECULATION

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 9

 BODY:
In the midst of its nuclear standoff with the United States, North Korea said Wednesday that it had removed its most prominent advocate of opening its economy to the West.
By some accounts, the official, Kim Dal Hyon, is in line to become the country's next Prime Minister when the country's Supreme People's Assembly meets in Pyongyang beginning today. His ascendency would suggest a new direction for the country, one that moves away from the national mythology of "juche," a philosophy of self-reliance that has spurned contact with or help from abroad. 
 But other analysts, particularly in Japan, said they feared that his removal as chief of state planning and Deputy Prime Minister could indicate that Mr. Kim is being blamed for the economic contraction that has left factories closed and its workers hungry.
This morning, in a rare departure from the country's usually glowing propaganda about its economic performance, a communique issued from the ruling party's Central Committee concede that the economy faced a "grave situation" after "grim trials."
 
Failed to Reach Targets
 It said that the state had failed to achieve its industrial output targets -- a vast understatement, most outside economists would argue -- because of "international events and the acute situation created in Korea."
That appeared to be a reference to the end of barter trade with Russia and the disputes surrounding international efforts to investigate its nuclear program.
The North also announced that the younger brother of the "Great Leader," President Kim Il Sung, was appointed to the party's politburo, one of the country's highest offices. That was a surprise because the brother, Kim Yong Ju, has scarcely been mentioned for 17 years, and was long ago eclipsed by the "Dear Leader," Kim Jong Il, the son of Kim Il Sung and his designated successor as the nation's leader. In a directory of hundreds of North Korean officials published last year by the Central Intelligence Agency, Kim Yong Ju is not even listed.
The conflicting theories about Kim Dal Hyon's removal suggest how little is known about the inner workings of the North Korean Government, which has been under close scrutiny in recent months as the United States and other nations try to find out what it is doing at its nuclear plants. Western officials suspect that it is trying to build a nuclear weapon.
 
New Offer Studied
 The Clinton Administration is said to be preparing a response to last Friday's offer by North Korea to provide a limited opening to its nuclear complex at Yongbyon. Officials of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which monitors nuclear plants worldwide, have said the offer is insufficient, and American officials said it would do little to allay fears about how much nuclear material North Korea has produced or diverted to weapons projects.
In a statement, North Korea said only that Mr. Kim had been "transferred to another position." That alone is unusual; officials being purged in the North are usually never mentioned at all, and simply drop out of sight.
Mr. Kim is said to be a relative of Kim Il Sung and Kim Jong Il . Over the last two years he has become a familiar figure as North Korea has tentatively reached out for investment and trade with its capitalist neighbors, ending decades of virtual isolation. In July 1992 he made a highly publicized trip to South Korea, eliciting a promise from the Seoul Government to consider building a huge industrial complex at Nampo, just above the Demilitarized Zone that separates the two countries.
 
Seoul Suspends Dealings
 But so far, the project has gone nowhere. As it became clear that the North would refuse to accept international inspections of its nuclear sites, the South Korean authorities suspended all dealings on economic initiatives.
"It's possible that Kim Dal Hyon was blamed for the failure," a senior Japanese official said Wednesday.
But Mr. Kim appears to retain his posts on the Communist Party Central Committee, and some South Korean and American officials speculated that he might be in line for promotion. That would be a sign that hard-liners in the Government are losing their sway and that the country may be willing to negotiate access to its nuclear plants in return for an economic package.
There are also other indications that North Korea is making gestures to the West. On Tuesday it published extensive regulations governing new "free economic and trade zones" it is establishing in North Korea, announcing for the first time that foreigners entering the zones would not, under most circumstances, need a visa.

Clinton More Pessimistic
 WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (Special to The New York Times)
-- President Clinton said today that he could not be confident that a crisis could be avoided over North Korea's refusal to allow international inspections of its nuclear plants.
At a luncheon with reporters, Mr. Clinton sounded more pessimistic about the situation than he had in recent days. Asked whether he believed a full-blown crisis could averted, he said: "I hope we can avoid one, but I am not positive that we can."
The United Nations announced today that Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali would travel to North Korea this month.

HEADLINE: Mexican Candidate Pledges Campaign Changes

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Seeking to dispel doubts about the fairness of Mexico's political process, the governing party's new presidential candidate has promised to issue detailed fund-raising and spending reports and take other steps to insure the credibility of elections next year.
In an interview Tuesday, the candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio Murrieta, outlined a campaign strategy that seemed less about winning than about routing the memory of a 1988 vote that many Mexicans believe President Carlos Salinas de Gortari won by fraud. Mr. Colosio is the overwhelming favorite in the election, scheduled for next August. 
 For the first time in the 64 years that his party has governed, Mr. Colosio said, he would issue regular reports on where his campaign was getting its funds and how they were being spent. He said that he opposed foreign election monitors, but that he would propose a wider role for Mexican-born election observers and would accept an independent audit of the voter rolls.
"This is in the short term," said Mr. Colosio, a 43-year-old former Secretary of Social Development. "In the medium term, I would propose to continue the democratic transformation of the country so that future generations can be confident of the political process, so that there will be clear rules in politics as there are in the economy."
 
Changes Called Insufficient
 Most of the changes Mr. Colosio endorsed appeared merely an elaboration on steps already contemplated by the Government or on new electoral laws approved this summer. The leaders of several election-monitoring groups said that the changes were encouraging but that they considered them far from sufficient to guarantee a democratic process next August.
During his five-year administration, Mr. Salinas has made general pledges of greater democracy, but for the most part the results have failed to satisfy his domestic and foreign critics. The perceived flaws of the Mexican political system came under scrutiny in the United States Congressional debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Yet by the tone of his remarks and by his emphasis on the need for political change in Mexico, Mr. Colosio seemed to move beyond the positions taken by Mr. Salinas, his political mentor.
The President, who is barred by the Constitution from seeking re-election, has often said that as Mexico's economy develops, its democracy will gradually be "perfected." Mr. Colosio suggested a more active and immediate process of change.
"I am committed to the democratic transformation of the country," Mr. Colosio said several times. "I do not want, nor do I need votes that are gotten outside the law. I need only the votes of Mexicans who are convinced of my proposals."
 
Plans to Be Outlined
 Mr. Colosio announced his plans for campaign financing, election observers and the auditing of voter rolls in a speech tonight to the national convention at which his nomination was formalized by the Institutional Revolutionary Party. He did not, however, explain the ideas in any detail.
Since it was formed in 1929, neither the party nor its two predecessors have ever lost a presidential election, and it has given up only three state governorships.
In the past, the party's dominance over an almost token opposition was insured by coercion and fraud at the polls. As the opposition has grown more organized and vigilant since Mr. Salinas's tainted victory over Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, a leftist leader, in 1988, such techniques as stuffing ballot boxes and the use of state resources in the party's election campaigns have generally given way to more sophisticated strategies.
But a highly competitive election on Nov. 28 in the Gulf Coast state of Yucatan revived many of the opposition's complaints. After a governing-party campaign that was notably austere and well-organized, the vote itself brought claims of vote-rigging.
Mr. Colosio declined in the interview to discuss the Yucatan situation in any detail, saying he had been too busy preparing his campaign to study it carefully.
 
Goal of Clean Election
 He said he understood that he must take measures to reach his goal of a clean election. But Mr. Colosio was noncommittal when asked whether he might isolate or punish party members who had been involved in past frauds.
"There are vices and inertia that we must overcome not only in the P.R.I. but in other political groups as well," he said, referring to the governing party by its Spanish initials.
Mr. Colosio said he would pursue an agreement among political parties to extend the role of independent election observers to include the monitoring of more than the actual balloting. For example, he said, the observers might oversee the formation of regional election councils and the drafting of the voter rolls.
As "a guarantee," Mr. Colosio said he had assigned responsibility for his campaign finances to his campaign coordinator, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, a former Minister of the Budget and Education with a reputation for honesty.
Of the periodic financial reports that he said Mr. Zedillo would issue, he added, "We will be as specific as we have to be in order that there be no doubt or suspicion that the funds I receive for my campaign come from legitimate sources."
 
Supports Quick Count
 Mr. Colosio also said he supported a so-called quick count of the vote on election day, a process that has been increasingly used in Mexican state elections to provide an indicative sample of voting patterns. And as Mr. Salinas has before him, Mr. Colosio said he supported a private audit of the entire voter registry, a document that opposition parties say has been used in the past to exclude their supporters.
Citing recent opinion polls showing Mexicans overwhelmingly skeptical that next year's election will be fair, Robert A. Pastor, a political scientist at Emory University who closely follows the Mexican electoral process, said Mr. Colosio's comments struck him as "an acknowledgement that the principle challenge facing the Government today is gaining the trust of the Mexican people in the process."
"But that's a very large mountain to climb in a relatively short amount of time," Dr. Pastor added, "and some dramatic measures are probably going to be needed to increase the percentage of people who believe the elections will be free."
Mr. Colosio said he opposed any participation of international observers in the election, citing laws that prohibited their involvement. But leaders of Mexican observer groups also said that because of highly restrictive laws approved by the Mexican Congress earlier this year, significant changes would have to be made before even Mexican observers were assured of a clear role.
"We are not at all satisfied with his saying he will bring democracy if he is elected," the head of one citizens' group, Julio Faesler, said of Mr. Colosio's remarks.
"It is now that he must act forcefully with his party," said Mr. Faesler, the president of the Council For Democracy. "It is not enough for him to stick to the letter of the law. He must tie the hands of his party so there is no covert funding, no fiddling with the electoral lists, no stacking of the polling stations with PRI people. So far, the signs we are seeing do not point in the direction of a clean and democratic election."

HEADLINE: European Official Urges Cuts In Social Benefits to Add Jobs

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 8

 BODY:
In a clear statement that Europe's welfare state will have to change radically if an unemployment crisis is to be overcome, the European Commission today proposed lowering minimum wages and cutting non-wage labor costs like social security payments as a way to create 15 million jobs by 2000.
Presenting a long-awaited policy paper on Europe's soaring unemployment, which now affects 11.3 percent of the work force, close to double the United States rate, Jacques Delors, the president of the commission, made it clear that social welfare programs might have to be trimmed back. 
 "If we want to safeguard the principles that forged the current model of European society and its welfare state, we must adapt this model," said Mr. Delors, a French Socialist. "We are no longer in a world where everything is guaranteed."
 
5 Million Jobs Lost
 His report is expected to dominate discussion here at a summit meeting of European leaders this week. It clearly reflected a deep malaise.
The loss of more than 5 million jobs since 1990, the increasing competitiveness of a developing world with much lower labor costs and the long recession have prompted widespread questioning of Europe's social model.
Indeed, political debate is now increasingly marked by discussion whether heavy social security, health and pension payments have made labor costs too onerous, discouraging employers from hiring. Unemployment benefits paid in Europe this year are expected to total about $226 billion -- equivalent to the gross national product of Belgium.
In response, Britain has led a campaign for widespread deregulation of the European labor market, to bring it closer to an American model. But President Francois Mitterrand of France has argued that comprehensive social benefits are the crowning achievement of post-war European social democracy and cannot be dismantled.
In making his proposals, Mr. Delors clearly tried to tread a middle path. But he nonetheless suggested that the current European economic model has reached a point of exhaustion.
In sumarizing his report, Mr. Delors suggested that each nation aim to reduce non-wage labor costs by the equivalent of 1 percent to 2 percent of G.N.P.. Since 1970, these charges have risen 40 percent, twice the rate in the United States.

HEADLINE: MALAYSIA PREMIER DEMANDS APOLOGY

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec. 8

 BODY:
The brickbats are flying once again between two of the most outspoken politicians in the region and a result may be a multibillion-dollar trade war between Australia and Malaysia.
The feud is between Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, who refused an invitation from President Clinton to attend the Asia-Pacific summit meeting in Seattle last month, and Prime Minister Paul Keating of Australia, who referred to Mr. Mahathir as a "recalcitrant" for not traveling to Seattle. 
 Mr. Keating told reporters in Seattle that he "couldn't care less" about the Malaysian leader's absence from the summit, which was sponsored by the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation organization. "APEC is bigger than all of us -- Australia, the U.S. and Malaysia and Dr. Mahathir and any other recalcitrants," he said.
Dr. Mahathir, whose anti-Western stance has made him a hero in much of the developing world, has demanded an apology from the Australian over the remark and has threatened to reduce diplomatic relations and to review all trade links with Australia if he does not receive one.
 
'Buy Australia Last' Campaign
 The Malaysian Consumer Affairs Ministry has suggested that it will support a boycott of Australian goods, and officials have already begun speaking of a "Buy Australian Last" campaign.
So far, Prime Minister Keating has refused to make an explicit apology, and a letter he sent to Dr. Mahathir last week seems only to have made things worse.
While the letter has not been made public, the Malaysian Foreign Minister, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi, said it "did not come from a person who appears to be sorry and regrets what happened as a result of his own remarks, which went beyond extreme."
Trade between the countries amounted to nearly $2 billion last year. Australian exports to Malaysia have risen 14 percent a year on average for the last six years, and many Australian exporters are worried that they will be shut out of one of the fastest-growing markets in Asia because of Mr. Keating's comments.
"I can't understand these Australians," Dr. Mahathir, who was trained as a physician, told reporters here. "I cannot understand this condemnation, this vilification of my person."
Australia, he said, "talks down to Asia -- it tells the Asians how to behave themselves, even when the Australians themselves are not very well behaved."
The Malaysian leader has said that he stayed home during the Seattle summit because the United States and other nations in the region had offered only a cool response to creating an Asians-only trading group, a cause he has championed.
 
Asians Support Malaysia
 The dispute seems to have more serious implications for Australia than for Malaysia, since it could hinder efforts by Mr. Keating's Government to reorient Australia's foreign and trade policies towards the booming nations of Asia, and to portray Australia as an Asian nation.
Diplomats from other Asian governments are quietly lining up behind Dr. Mahathir, saying that Mr. Keating's remarks were unnecessarily rude and showed that Australia's leaders, used to name-calling in their domestic politics, are still not ready to operate among the nonconfrontational societies of Asia.
"In this part of the world, attacks cannot be personal, and the Australians must learn that," said an Asian diplomat in Kuala Lumpur.
The last serious flap between Australia and Malaysia came in 1991, when Mr. Keating's Government was forced to apologize to Malaysia over an Australian television soap opera, "Embassy," which portrayed scandalous goings-on in Ragaan, a fictitious Southeast Asian nation that bore similarities to Malaysia.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Another Round on TV Violence

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
When it comes to television, violence remains hot stuff, either as a component of entertainment programming or as a subject for hand-wringing special reports and documentaries, most of which are sure to insist that television alone cannot be blamed for all of today's violence, especially its escalation among the young. Other culprits are righteously invoked: family disintegration, poverty, overcrowding, hunger, drugs, easy access to guns. The numbing mantra goes on; the headlines about violence proliferate.
Don't misunderstand. Some of these television essays are valuable, if only as road markers indicating where we stand, or crawl, as a society. Tonight at 9 on MTV, for instance, "Generation Under the Gun" interviews teen-agers in New York, New Orleans and Omaha about the role of guns in their lives. 
 The report is hardly comforting. Increasingly, the attitude for too many young people on streets or in schools is "kill or be killed." Old-fashioned fistfights are deemed useless. "You beat somebody up," says one youth, "they go home and get a gun." Guns, all agree, are readily available everywhere. One student says, "It's easier to get a gun than an education."
Various vested interests appear to protect their own turfs. The actor Sylvester Stallone maintains fuzzily that television, as opposed to movies, does indeed desensitize. Dr. Dre, a rapper, insists that his provocative, even incendiary lyrics carry no message, that "I'm just interested in selling records." Meanwhile, Tabitha Soren, an MTV reporter, churns out statistics: 1 in 25 high school students carries a gun to school; a new handgun is produced every 20 seconds. MTV's amorphous conclusion: "Ultimate responsibility lies in your hands. There is hope." Well, yes, depending on education, the economy, parents and all that stuff.
This television approach has become fairly standard. Among the better entries in recent months were Linda Ellerbee's "Are You What You Watch?" on Nickelodeon, an intelligent discussion with youngsters who got Howard Stringer, the president of the CBS Broadcast Group, to admit that the impact of local-news sensationalism on children "makes me very nervous," and ABC's live "Kids in the Crossfire," moderated deftly by Peter Jennings out of a junior high school in Washington. "Kids in the Crossfire" opened with the gruesome statistic that there had been 13 shootings in the nation's capital the previous evening, three of them fatal.
And, as Ms. Ellerbee might put it, so it goes. More than 20 years ago, when I first came to television reviewing, NBC was ballyhooing a major study on the effects of television violence on society at large. After a flurry of panel discussions, open to the press, the project receded into the mist of network bureaucracy, not to be heard from until 10 years later, when its major conclusions were held to be inconclusive.
That's not surprising. Through the years, innumerable studies of television violence have come forth with impressive evidence that (a) it's of no importance whatsoever, or (b) it's an insidious blight on civilization. Learned arguments can be produced for whatever point of view is demanded at the time. It depends on the recruited experts, the songs they sing often being connected to whose bread they eat.
Hardly a year has gone by without some new solution's being promoted as the perfect answer to assorted social ills. For drug addicts, there was everything from halfway houses to "tough love" confrontations with parents at home. The last I heard, street sales of cocaine and heroin were brisk as ever. Currently being touted as a restraint on violence is the concept of "conflict resolution," the supposedly revolutionary idea of getting teen-agers to talk out their problems. But as one astute young man told Mr. Jennings, "In some schools, if you be a mediator, you can get hurt."
Perhaps television's role in all these tit-for-tat exchanges on blame and responsibility is being shortchanged. Perhaps television's influence stems not from specific programming content, but from its being a major component in the American, and indeed now the international, way of life. The commercial medium is designed to sell, everything from the audiences sought by advertisers to the expensive sneakers to sought by youngsters, many of whom will do whatever is necessary to get them. They have been insistently persuaded that their lives are nothing without these athlete-sponsored products.
One of the more defining moments captured recently on local newscasts featured a youth shaking his head in response to the shooting deaths of two of his friends, killed by a gypsy cabdriver they tried to rob. Their friend just couldn't believe the driver's stupidity. "Man," the boy told the television reporter, "he didn't go with the flow."
And there's the crucial question facing television and our consumer culture. Whose flow do we go with?
