HEADLINE: Jim Morrison's Fans Keep His Fire Alight In a Birthday Homage

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Gaelle Rabaste, who is 17, was not even born when Jim Morrison died of heart failure from an overdose of drugs and alcohol here on July 3, 1971. But on the day the lead singer of the Doors would have been 50, she crouched by his tomb, reading his poetry with tears in her eyes.
The grave itself was covered with flowers, love letters, poems and the inevitable bottle of whisky left by the hundreds of young Europeans and Americans who came to pay homage to him on his birthday. "Move on, move on," security guards kept calling out. "Give other people a chance." 
 Nathalie Roux had come from Switzerland for the occasion, carrying her guitar in the hope of singing her own tribute. "After I heard Jim Morrison, my life changed," the 18-year-old said. "He's like a Messiah to me. I know it sounds silly, but he has helped me see things the way he would see them."
Even on days of no particular significance to Morrison devotees, his tomb is the main attraction in the huge Pere-Lachaise cemetery in eastern Paris, easily outdrawing the final resting places of the likes of Moliere, Chopin, Bizet, Proust, Oscar Wilde, Isadora Duncan, Edith Piaf and Maria Callas.
 
Diverse Observances
 Yet if "Jim Lives," as myriad graffiti around his tomb proclaim, it is also because Paris has now embraced him as a cult figure: his birthday has been marked by film showings, photo exhibitions, concerts, radio and television specials, even a poetry reading at the Georges Pompidou Center.
Morrison moved here five months before his death, fleeing scandals provoked by his raucous performances and apparently hoping that he would be recognized as a writer in a city where Hemingway and other expatriate American writers had prospered. But "the end" he so often sang about soon came.
Not all Parisians are happy that he is buried here. Families who own nearby tombs have long campaigned for his remains to be evicted, complaining that his fans smoke marijuana, drink beer and liquor and generally behave badly. Indeed, two years ago, the 20th anniversary of his death turned into a riot when guards tried to close the cemetery at night.
Since then, a guard is permanently stationed at Morrison's grave, but messages continue to appear on surrounding tombs. One directly behind the singer's black marble headstone reads: "Adolf Hitler, who should be dead, is still alive . . . he lives in Miami . . . and you, who should be alive, are dead . . . but you are still among us. Frederic."
Other graffiti -- mainly in English, but also in French, Spanish, Portuguese and Italian -- are more direct: "Jim, you are the God," "Jim, we need you," "We love you and you make me feel alright," "Jim, Welcome to the Severed Garden" and, perhaps most appropriately, "Stoned Immaculate."
 
Portable Statuary
 A marble bust of the singer once stood on his tomb. First, fans began to chip off bits to take home as mementoes. Then it was covered with graffiti. Finally, in 1990, it was stolen. Now fans often carry their own busts or statues of Morrison to the grave as part of their tribute.
Fear of trouble brought extra security guards to the tomb today, but apart from discouraging beer drinking and keeping the crowds moving they had little to do. The visitors were in solemn mood, prefering to celebrate the creativity of the singer, poet and, to many, prophet rather than the violent self-destruction that marked his brief five years in the spotlight.
Among the fans were few contemporaries, proof enough that he is far larger as a myth than he ever was as a star. Indeed, those at his grave today were almost all in their teens and 20's, pilgrims who either were converted by older brothers and sisters or were led to Morrison by Oliver Stone's movie "The Doors."
Yet what is the appeal of his almost-nihilistic message to this generation? "He's not an example, but he's a legend," Florence Roger, a 14-year-old Parisian schoolgirl, said. "He wanted to die, to get close to death. Perhaps if he hadn't been so drugged up, he wouldn't have written such beautiful poetry."
Rene Beuttkus, a 25-year-old who installs central heating for a living, drove with four friends from Dessau in eastern Germany to be here today. Why? "Because Jim gives another dimension to life," he said. "It's the words of his poems and his life."
 
Lyric Symbolism
 A tall, bearded Frenchman who refused to give his name said the message came from "up there." And he tried to explain. "The song 'Riders on the Storm,' is not about a motorbike," he said, referring to a Doors hit. "It's about seeing a light ahead and moving toward it."
Christophe, a young Frenchman from Normandy, said he wished he had lived in the 1960's. And for him, Morrison's example was "to let things come the way they come." Asked if that wasn't passive, he said, "What else are we going to do when we're unemployed and there's nothing else in our lives?"
He and a friend planned to spend the day at Pere-Lachaise. And wandering through were a group of schoolgirls from Finland, four long-haired Germans in matching leather trousers, a middle-aged Spanish woman who said nothing as she lighted a candle at the grave, and many more.
Paul Will, a 24-year-old social worker from Wisconsin, said he came over from London because his Australian girlfriend, Shannon O'Hara, simply announced, "It's got to be done." And he was pleased he did. "Even Jimi Hendrix's grave in Seattle isn't this busy," he said.

HEADLINE: New York State's Two-Track Strategy to Improve Rail Service

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It's unfortunate John L. Rose ("Don't Hitch Faster Train Service to Fantasies," letter, Nov. 27) didn't bother to read your entire Nov. 10 news story on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposal to build the world's first magnetically levitated train system from New York City to Boston via Albany before concluding that the state was overlooking improvements to existing rail.
He would have learned that the Governor and I are pursuing a two-track strategy that includes $992 million for upgrading Amtrak rail lines between New York and Buffalo to achieve speeds of up to 125 miles per hour. We also support continued improvement of the Northeast Corridor rail lines from Washington D.C. to Boston through New York City. 
 The Empire Corridor rail improvements, to be completed within five to seven years, would reduce travel time between New York City and Buffalo from eight hours to less than six hours, and cut the trip from Albany to New York City by about 30 minutes, to less than two hours.
There's no doubt the United States has fallen far behind the Europeans and Japanese in the pursuit of high-speed rail, but critics who dismiss maglev as too "grandiose" are showing the same kind of shortsightedness that caused us to lose ground in the first place.
By investing now, New York State can become the world leader in the development of the next generation of transportation technology and reap enormous economic benefits. New York is a state with a proud history of transportation innovation. We had the foresight to invest in canals, trains, subways, airports and interstate highways like the Thruway, all of which stimulated our economy and created thousands of jobs.
While some have raised concerns about its cost, maglev can actually avoid more expensive alternatives for dealing with urban congestion, such as new road construction and airport expansions. In the Los Angeles area, for instance, the Century Freeway was built at a cost of $127 million per mile. In comparison, the cost of building a maglev from New York City to Albany is estimated at a maximum of $45 million per mile. Maglev offers other environmental benefits and energy savings through reduced fuel consumption and improved air quality.
At a time when defense industries are struggling to survive, maglev represents a promising defense diversification initiative for companies like Grumman Corporation on Long Island, which hopes to perfect a maglev design at the nation's first maglev test track proposed for Stewart Airport, near Newburgh.
As for maglev's viability, a recent report commissioned by the United States Department of Transportation, the Department of Energy and the Army Corps of Engineers concluded that the potential benefits from a maglev system are "sufficient to justify initiation of a development program." Furthermore, the study by the National Maglev Initiative found that the Northeast is the only market in the country in which fare revenues could cover capital, operation and maintenance costs.
With its world-class research institutions, advanced technology leaders and highly skilled work force, New York is better positioned than any other state to support the kind of partnership needed to develop this revolutionary new mode of transportation. Now is the time to climb aboard.
 
STAN LUNDINE
Lieutenant Governor
Albany, Dec. 3, 1993

HEADLINE: Administration Floats Proposal For Licensing All Gun Owners

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Reacting both to polls that show Americans ever more fearful of violent crime and to Tuesday night's carnage on the Long Island Rail Road, the Clinton Administration today tentatively embraced a proposal to require all gun owners to be licensed.
The plan, the details of which will not be settled for many weeks, was announced by Attorney General Janet Reno, who had been ordered by President Clinton to study the idea only on Wednesday. Other than signing the Brady bill mandating a waiting period for purchases of handguns and supporting a plan to restrict the sale of assault rifles, the President has so far moved cautiously on gun control. 
 Despite the new polls and the shooting spree in which a gunman killed five passengers on the railroad and wounded 18 others, the political equation makes sweeping changes in gun laws perilous.
 
Message From Voters
 Recent elections have sent a cautionary message to the White House. Although there were other important issues that helped shape the outcomes in races in New Jersey and Virginia. In both states, the Democratic gubernatorial candidates, who supported strong gun control measures, were defeated by more conservative candidates. The Republicans had argued that the way to control crime was to impose longer prison sentences and abolish parole.
Even though the National Rifle Association lost the Congressional fight last month over a waiting period for purchases of handguns, it remains a powerful force in Congress and warned that it would fight any attempts to pass other restrictions on handguns.
With the White House facing difficult battles over welfare changes and monumental health care legislation, battles that will require compromises with moderate and conservative lawmakers, it is far from certain how committed the President will be to broad gun control measures when they are actually introduced in Congress.
 
Clinton's Difficult Situation
 Still, the White House finds itself in the awkward position of looking for ways to show its toughness on violent crime by cracking down on the proliferation of guns without alienating those moderate and conservative lawmakers whose votes will be needed on health and welfare.
The awkwardness was evident when the White House spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, described a session Mr. Clinton had today with mayors and police commissioners.
She said: "What the President said was that the crime issue threatens the rest of his domestic agenda, that if we don't do something about crime it threatens health care reform, job creation and economic growth, welfare reform and a number of the other items that he believes are important.
"So certainly, crime is at the forefront of his domestic agenda, but it works in conjunction with many of the other issues that he feels very strongly about, and he's going to certainly be talking about it and working with members of Congress, working with the local mayors and police chiefs and people around the country to try to do something about not only crime but the decaying social structure that is some of the underpinning causes of crime."
In recent days, Ms. Reno, Mr. Clinton and the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Louis Freeh, have all called for tighter control over weapons. In the meeting with mayors and police commissioners today, Mr. Clinton reaffirmed his commitment to support a ban on assault weapons.
"I think we can do something," he told the group, without discussing specifics. "I think the American people are tired of hurting and tired of feeling insecure and tired of violence."
 
Role for States
 Ms. Reno said that the licensing system should be handled by the states, just as they issue drivers' licenses, and that the Justice Department was in the process of reviewing options.
"I think it should be at least as hard to get a license to possess a gun as it is to drive an automobile," she said today at her weekly news conference. "I don't think somebody should have a gun unless they can demonstrate that they know how to safely and lawfully use it, that they're capable of safely and lawfully using it, and that they're willing to safely and lawfully use it."
But Democratic legislators and their aides today expressed caution about Administration support for specific gun-control proposals. They noted that when separate versions of the crime bill passed the House and Senate last month, the White House and Justice Department were nowhere in sight. The two bills will have to be reconciled next year if they are to become law.
A poll published today by The Los Angeles Times said that despite the adoption of the Brady bill, 64 percent of Americans think gun-control laws are not strong enough, while 7 percent say they are too strong and 24 percent find them adequate. The poll, taken of 1,612 adults nationwide, was conducted from Dec. 4 to Dec. 7 and its results have a margin of error of 3 percentage points.
A study to be made public on Friday by the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press found that 57 percent approved of the President's attempts to limit the use of handguns, while 29 percent disapproved.
By a margin of 51 percent to 45 percent, they opposed a law to ban the sale of handguns, although 57 percent said controlling guns was more important than protecting the right to own guns. Still, only 41 percent of those polled thought stricter gun control laws would significantly reduce violent crime. The survey of 1,479 adults was conducted from Dec. 2 to Dec. 5 and had a margin of sampling error of 3 percentage points.
Ten states, including New York and New Jersey, already require gun owners to have permits. An 11th state, Minnesota, requires either a permit or a seven-day waiting period.
Ten days ago, Mr. Clinton signed the Brady bill, which imposes a waiting period of five business days for handgun purchases so that local law-enforcement authorities can check the background of the prospective buyer for evidence of a criminal past or mental instability. The bill was named for James S. Brady, the former White House press secretary who was wounded in the 1981 attempt to assassinate President Ronald Reagan.
Supporters of gun control legislation said that it was only a first step and that its effect on controlling weapons would probably be limited.
 
Push for Licensing
 On Wednesday, Mr. Brady, joined by his wife Sarah and Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, announced his intention to push for new gun-control legislation next year. The measure would require all handgun buyers to get a license that would be issued after a background check. It would also limit purchases to one handgun a month and require the registration of all handguns, including used ones that are resold.
A group from the Conference of Mayors presented Mr. Clinton with a report today that recommended gun registration, banning semiautomatic assault weapons, imposing waiting periods on purchases of all firearms and new taxes on weapons and ammunition.
Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, today proposed that a 30 percent sales tax be imposed on handguns, assault weapons and ammunition for both. Under the proposed legislation, revenue from the tax and from a steep increase in Federal gun dealers' licensing fees would go toward health care costs. Under the plan, dealers would pay $3,000 for a three-year license.

HEADLINE: Bank Official Gets Reduced Term Over Iraq Loans

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS

 BODY:
A Federal judge gave a reduced sentence yesterday to an Atlanta bank manager who had granted more than $5 billion in secret loans that were used to arm Iraq.
Judge G. Ernest Tidwell of Federal District Court in Atlanta sentenced the banker, Christopher P. Drogoul, to 37 months in prison, saying he was giving a reduced sentence because the United States Government had encouraged economic aid to Iraq. Mr. Drogoul has already served nearly 20 months of that sentence and could be freed in less than a year. 
 Mr. Drogoul, who was the manager of the Atlanta branch of the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, which is based in Rome, had pleaded guilty to three felony counts earlier this fall, precluding a trial on his role in arming Iraq. Before that plea, his trial was to serve as the main stage for accusations that President George Bush and others in his Administration had secretly armed Iraq and then sought to cover that up when Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait in August 1990.
Mr. Drogoul was charged by the Justice Department under President Bush with defrauding his superiors in Rome in making the loans to Iraq. In his defense, Mr. Drogoul said that in covertly funneling the loans to Iraq, he was acting with the implicit understanding of his superiors in Rome who had been asked to help Saddam Hussein by Bush Administration officials.
But Judge Tidwell ruled that Mr. Drogoul's lawyers could not present evidence as to Washington's policy toward Iraq. With that ruling crippling the defense, Robert Simels, Mr. Drogoul's lawyer, said there was little hope of an acquittal.
Nonetheless, Judge Tidwell said United States policy toward Iraq was a factor in his deciding Mr. Drogoul's sentence. The Federal sentencing guidelines would have required Mr. Drogoul to be sent to jail for 46 to 57 months, but Judge Tidwell said from the bench that he was departing from the guidelines, an unusual procedure.
In explaining his reasons, Judge Tidwell said, "The Government actually pursued a policy of economic support to Iraq even though the creditworthiness of Iraq would not have justified such credit and such information was readily available."
Many of the loans that Mr. Drogoul processed was money guaranteed by the United States Government.
John Hogan, a senior aide to Attorney General Janet Reno, told Judge Tidwell that the Justice Department was still investigating the arming of Iraq.

HEADLINE: PENTAGON FIGHTS BUDGET OFFICIALS OVER $50 BILLION

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
After drafting an ambitious post-cold-war strategy, the Pentagon finds itself $50 billion short of what it needs to carry out the plan and in a skirmish with the White House budget director over the money.
The dispute has been going on behind the scenes for weeks. But it broke into the open today, when Leon E. Panetta, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, confirmed that the Defense Department would be short $40 billion to $50 billion over the next five years. With President Clinton trying to cut the Federal budget, Mr. Panetta said he did not expect a change would be made in next year's Pentagon spending request. 
 Defense Secretary Les Aspin plans to ask for the extra money anyway when he meets with Mr. Clinton next week to discuss his budget, leaving Mr. Clinton to arbitrate the fight. The shortage stems from faulty inflation estimates and the decision by Congress to raise military pay.
 
Tough Spot for Clinton
 That puts the President exactly where he least wants to be: in a dispute between his budget director and the Pentagon and potentially in a standoff with Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee and supports the Pentagon's push for additional money.
This latest episode is the opening round of the annual infighting over the budget. This year's debate is especially heated, however, because Mr. Clinton is trying to protect the United States role as a military power while honoring his promise to shift the nation's priorities more to domestic programs.
Also at stake are the White House's relations with the uniformed military. "Something will have to give if we don't get the funds," a Pentagon official said. "We will either have to cut the forces and throw the strategy overboard, give up some weapons modernization or get the funds we need from domestic programs."
 
'This Is a Real War'
 One general said: "This is a real war. It is a war with O.M.B. and a war among ourselves."
From the start, some critics questioned whether the Pentagon had the resources to underwrite its strategy of being able to fight two regional wars that begin nearly at the same time.
The Pentagon says it needs to maintain this ability to deter attack by third world countries. For example, if the American military had the ability to fight only one regional war, a conflict on the Korean peninsula could encourage countries like Iraq or Iran to seize the opportunity to strike.
Thus, the already-tight Pentagon budget was further squeezed when Congress decided to ordered a payincrease for military personnel that the Clinton Administration had not sought. That and other personnel decisions added $14.5 billion to the Pentagon's five-year plan.
In addition, inflation estimates that were too optimistic also mean that the military budget is underfinanced by $33 billion, Pentagon officials say.
As a result, Pentagon officials say they are faced with a five year shortage of almost $50 billion.
Senator Nunn predicted this problem in March. He said then that he had been assured by the White House that it would support increases in military spending if they were needed.
"I have been assured that the Administration will not permit higher inflation in the future to damage our defense capability," Senator Nunn said in a speech on March 5.
 
Speech by Senator
 He also said then that the White House had told him the military budget would be protected if Congress voted to give the troops a raise over the Administration's objections.
But now many Federal agencies expect to be short of money and the White House budget office is trying to hold the line against increases in military spending. Mr. Panetta said today that agency heads throughout the Government were asking for $20 billion more than they were going to get for next year, adding to the pressures to make tough-minded budget decisions.
Amid all this, the budget office and the Pentagon have staked out their positions.
Mr. Panetta told reporters today that he supported the new strategy but added he did not anticipate increasing next year's military spending request to make up the difference.
Asked if the White House planned to forgo any adjustments in the Pentagon spending request for next year, Mr. Panetta said, "Yes."
Referring to the five-year $1.2 trillion Pentagon spending plan announced in March, Mr. Panetta said, "The President has pretty much made a commitment that he wants to stick to those numbers."
 
Pentagon's Understanding
 Pentagon officials also say there was an understanding between the Defense Department and the White House that money to cover inflation and the pay raise would be provided if they they were needed.
"We're still sticking to the agreement," a Pentagon official said, adding the military does not believe that Mr. Clinton had made up his mind.
If the White House rejects Mr. Aspin's appeal for more money, senior Pentagon official say, the Defense Department will have reopen its comprehensive bottom-up review.
After Mr. Panetta's comments became known at the Pentagon, a spokesman for the budget official sought to play down any suggestion that Mr. Panetta had prejudged President Clinton's decision.
"It is the director's view that we are staying on the path we have established in the President's economic plan," a spokesman for Mr. Panetta said. "The specific issue of whether there will be any adjustments in relations to these issues will be decided in the budget process."
But the spokesman declined to comment when asked if Mr. Panetta wanted to amend his earlier remarks that suggested he did not expect to make an adjustment in the Pentagon's spending proposal for next year.
Military spending has gone down steadily since the height of the Reagan Administration's buildup in 1985, after adjustment for inflation.
Still, with a budget this fiscal year of $262 billion, the Pentagon spends more than the other agencies, making it a tempting target for budget cutters.
 
Comprehensive Plan
 As part of a comprehensive plan to develop a military force for the post-cold war world, the Defense Department announced in September that it planned to field 10 active Army divisions, 12 aircraft carriers and 20 active and reserve Air Force wings and a sizable Marine Corps.
Even that plan, which was approved by Mr. Clinton, initially posed problems for the Pentagon. The price tag for the force was $13 billion more than the Pentagon had planned to spend over five years, requiring offsetting cuts.
Deeper cuts, experts say, could prompt a wide-ranging debate over the wisdom of the Pentagon's strategy of preparing for two regional conflicts, its multibillion dollar decision to build a third Seawolf attack submarine to preserve the military industrial base and its decision to proceed with other costly weapons programs, including new nuclear tipped submarine missiles.
Some critics say the Pentagon can afford to make deeper cuts.
But the Clinton Administration is reluctant to drop the two-war strategy, which was also endorsed by the Bush Administration, in part because it does not want to be seen as retreating from American military commitments.
Further, the pace of American military operations around the world is already putting the operations and maintenance accounts under strain.
Another concern is that many of some of the savings through more efficient operations anticipated by the Bush Administration may not materialize.
"I am concerned that D.O.D. not be penalized if the Clinton Administration inherits phony assumed savings from its predecessors," Mr. Nunn said in March.

HEADLINE: Mediators Cancel Meeting of Bosnian Foes After Government Balks

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The international mediators trying to end the conflict in Bosnia today abruptly canceled a meeting between the warring parties that they had planned on Sunday in Greece after the Bosnian Government said it would not attend.
But diplomats reported that Lord Owen, the European Community's mediator, and Thorvald Stoltenberg, who represents the United Nations, hope they can bring Serbian, Croatian and Muslim leaders together for another meeting about Dec. 20 that could produce a peace settlement. 
 The decision to cancel the meeting, planned in the northern Greek city of Salonika, came after the two mediators met today in Belgrade with Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia, and Radovan Karadzic, leader of the self-styled Serbian Republic in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
 
Hopes for Breakthrough Rise
 Details of today's Belgrade talks are not yet known, but diplomats said hopes of a breakthrough had risen in the last day or so after an earlier round of talks in Geneva broke off inconclusively just over a week ago.
Part of the reason for the renewed optimism that the three parties might finally accept a settlement splittting Bosnia into three ethnically based states are signs of a possible agreement giving the Bosnians access to the Adriatic Sea through the Prevlaka Peninsula, on the border between Croatia and Montenegro. The area is a demilitarized zone controlled by United Nations forces.
The Bosnians had been pressing for a corridor to the sea either through the Croatian port of Ploce or at the seaside town of Neum, in Herzegovina. But these solutions would separate two Croatian cities, Split in the north and Dubrovnik in the south. So the Croatian side proposed Prevlaka.
 
Militarily Sensitive Area
 But a Muslim corridor to the town would have to traverse Serb-controlled territory. Moreover, Prevlaka is militarily sensitive because it is within artillery distance of the Yugoslav naval base at Kotor Bay.
Officials say the Serbs may consent to the proposal, however, in an effort to obtain a relaxation of international trade sanctions, which have destroyed the economy of Serbia and Montenegro, the other republic in the rump Yugoslavia.
Today, the United States, France and Britain rejected a Russian request to send large quantities of natural gas to Yugoslavia this winter to heat homes, schools and hospitals, and set tough new conditions for supplying any extra energy during the winter.
The United States, France and Britain said they were opposed to granting any general exemptions from the trade embargo for energy this winter. But they agreed at a meeting of the Security Council committee overseeing the sanctions to allow limited deliveries of energy to specified needy groups if the United Nations thinks they should be given help and the energy supplied is carefully monitored. Because decisions of the sanctions committee must be unanimous, these countries can impose their terms.
 
Warning of a Catastrophe
 As a first example of this new policy, the committee gave permission today to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to import 20,000 tons of fuel for refugee aid programs and 7,000 tons for distribution to mental hospitals, orphanages and other institutions denied fuel by the Belgrade Government.
Supporting Russia's request for permission to sell about 130 million cubic meters of natural gas monthly to Yugoslavia, Moscow's United Nations representative, Yuli Vorontsov, told the committee that the country faced "a real humanitarian catastrophe" this winter, with only enough fuel to meet 20 to 30 percent of its needs.
While Mr. Vorontsov did not deny the need to maintain sanctions as a way of forcing Belgrade it to end the fighting by Serbs in Bosnia, he said they should not overstep certain "humanitarian limits," contending that the shortage of medicine, fuel and many basic goods now "constitutes a real threat to the health and survival of hundreds of thousands of people."
But a United States official said, "We want to continue bringing the reality of the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina home to the Serbs in Belgrade while avoiding excessive humanitarian suffering."

8 Killed in Sarajevo
 SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dec. 8 (Special to The New York Times) -- Fighting increased in this besieged capital today, with 8 people killed and 26 wounded by artillery and sniper fire from the Serbian positions ringing the city.
Two of the people who died were picked off by sniper fire, which has increased since the lifting of a fog that had blanketed the city for most of the week. One of the artillery victims was the head of a local health center, who was hit while unloading baby milk sent by Unicef.
Heavy shelling was also reported in Mostar, leaving at least one dead, Bosnian television said. Artillery fire and firefights were also reported in a number of other towns.
Serbian forces shelled areas where relief supplies were being airdropped by parachute, a United Nations spokesman, Lieut. Col. Bill Aikman, said this morning. United Nations officials have complained in recent days that the Serbs have been blocking relief truck convoys despite several agreements that they should let the supplies pass unhindered.

HEADLINE: Panel Urges Expanding Aid for Two-Parent Homes

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
In an effort to encourage family stability, the Clinton Administration's task force on overhauling welfare has proposed to make it much easier for families to collect welfare even when the father is present.
Administration officials said the recommendation, described in a confidential draft of a report to President Clinton, is meant to correct the welfare system's much criticized tendency to divide families by cutting off benefits when the father lives in the house. 
 "We need to send the signal that two-parent families are vitally important," said David T. Ellwood, an assistant secretary of Health and Human Services, who is one of three leaders of the task force.
But as is often the case in the welfare system, the effort to correct one problem could create another. Conservative analysts asserted today that allowing fathers to collect welfare could significantly increase the program, which already covers a record 14 million Americans, and would weaken the incentive for fathers to work.
"It runs counter to what we're tying to encourage here," said Representative Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, a sponsor of a Republican welfare bill. "It says, 'Don't bother working.' "
Mr. Ellwood conceded that the proposal would increase the number of people on welfare but called the expansion "very modest" and short term. He said he did not know how many families that would be affected or how much the proposal would cost.
Private analysts were in sharp disagreement, with estimates ranging from a few hundred thousand to more than one million new welfare recipients.
"My fear is that, if this passes, five years from now we will be trying to reduce the number of welfare fathers as well as welfare mothers," said Douglas Besharov, an analyst at the American Enterprise Institute.
The recommendation is part of an Administration effort to fulfill President Clinton's campaign pledge "to end welfare as we know it" by imposing a two-year limit on benefits. After that, Mr. Clinton said, welfare recipients will have to work.
Last summer he appointed Administration officials to translate his popular campaign pledge into legislation. After months of research and public hearings, they have revised their recommendations, which are now summarized in a 31-page paper dated Dec. 6.
 
Shoring Up Families
 Mr. Ellwood said the proposed rule changes were part of a larger strategy to shore up the American family, including a proposal that President Clinton lead a campaign against teen-age pregnancy.
The paper also recommends that teen-age mothers on welfare be required to live with their parents rather than set up homes on their own, noting that such young mothers "are rarely ready to manage a household or raise children on their own."
It proposes letting welfare mothers satisfy work requirements by serving as mentors who would discourage teen-agers from becoming pregnant.
And the officials studying that matter may propose allowing all states to deny extra payments to women who have additional children, as New Jersey and some other states are now doing as an experiment.
 
Hurdles for Fathers
 There are now about five million families receiving Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main Federal welfare program.
But only about 350,000 of those families are households where both parents live together. Such families, the paper said, "are subject to much more stringent eligibility rules than single-parent families."
That is because the A.F.D.C. program was originally intended for widows during the Great Depression, when the expectation was that families with healthy fathers could support themselves.
But in the subsequent decades analysts began to fear that the restrictions on aid to fathers encouraged families to break up, and the rules have been slowly changed since 1961.
Under current law, two-parent families can collect welfare but only if the father has a substantial work history, defined as having been employed in six of the previous 13 months. That is meant to reserve aid for fathers who are temporarily unemployed, rather than terminally idle.
And 13 states, including Florida and Texas, provide aid to such families only for six months a year.
The panel's recommendation, which would need Congressional approval, would abolish the work-history requirement, and extend welfare year-round to any two-parent family poor enough to meet the income requirements, which vary by state.
"We don't want there to be incentives that favor single-parent families, if at all possible," said Mr. Ellwood. "This is all in the context of promoting parental responsibility."
A two-parent family is defined as a mother and father living together, married or not.
The panel also proposed abolishing another rule that restricts aid to two-parent families. Such families now cannot collect aid if one parent works more than 100 hours a month. Mr. Ellwood said that rule discouraged recipients who want to work. .
 
How Big an Expansion?
 While Mr. Ellwood said the changed rules would bring "a very modest expansion of people on the welfare rolls," he predicted that their stay would be short term.
That is because, under the Clinton proposal, most welfare recipients would be required to seek job training to improve their skills. And those without jobs within the two years would be required to enroll in a Government-financed work program.
While Mr. Ellwood cited no numbers, another member of the panel predicted that the changes would bring roughly an additional 250,000 families onto welfare.
But Mr. Besharov called the proposal "a sharp break from past welfare policy" that could extend welfare to as many as one million fathers who are now indigent and living away from their children.
Though potentially unpopular with conservatives, the proposal is likely to enjoy favor with many advocacy groups, which fear that current rules push families to break up.
Mark Greenberg of the Center on Law and Social Policy, a Washington advocacy group, praised the Administration proposal, saying it "sends a clear signal that it's all right for the father to live with his children."
As in previous drafts, the 31-page report was silent on how much the program will cost. It reiterated that the cost of the expanded training and work programs would be offset by cuts in other programs.

HEADLINE: M.R.I. Scanner Industry Faces a Shakeout

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
When Alan Winakor first got into the business of owning and operating magnetic resonance imaging scanners in New York during the 1980's, the machines -- which can take sophisticated pictures of the brain and other body parts -- were a sure-fire way to make money.
Private insurers gladly paid more than $1,000 for the test, which recent studies have suggested can cost only $300 to perform. And doctors were liberally ordering this risk-free exam to diagnose an ever-growing range of medical conditions, from brain tumors to knee cartilage tears. 
 
 
Shakeout in Industry
 The result was a proliferation of the machines, which cost from $1 million to $2 million. Today, in one square mile of Long Island, there are now 13 scanners, more than in Canada's most populous province, Ontario, which has four times as many people as Nassau and Suffolk counties.
But today, as more patients have moved into health maintenance organizations and the nation is looking hard at reining in the cost of care, investors in M.R.I. scanners and other profit-making medical ventures are finding the bloom is wilting.
"I don't think we'll all survive," said Mr. Winakor, president of Medical Marketing Developments, which manages and markets seven M.R.I. centers in the New York area. "A couple of borderline facilities have already closed and I think you're going to see tremendous consolidation in the next year or two."
Spurred often more by the promise of profits than by medical necessity, the United States has accumulated a vast supply of privately owned medical technology, from M.R.I.'s to cholesterol testing labs to nuclear heart scanners -- far more than the country needs, many health economists say. And perversely, this abundance -- combined with the willingness of private insurers to pay top dollar for certain tests -- has in many cases kept prices high: since many M.R.I. machines are busy only half the day, their owners must charge high rates in order to cover their overhead.
But economists say that the era of freewheeling investment in medical technologies like M.R.I. scanners is now waning, especially with the rise of managed care, a trend that President Clinton's proposed health care reforms seem certain to accelerate. As a result, thousands of private businesses like Mr. Winakor's are scrambling to arrange contracts with unions, insurers or hospitals -- anyone that can promise a steady market for their products.
Many health economists and patient advocates say the shakeout will be a boon for patients. They say many M.R.I. operations are inefficient and overpriced, and that their aggressive marketing practices and sometimes shady arrangements with doctors have led to many unneeded scans, sometimes for more than $1,000 each. A 1992 General Accounting Office report concluded that it costs efficient M.R.I. centers only $262 to $399 to do the test. And so many experts expect that the coming consolidation will lead not to a shortage of scanners but to greater efficiency and lower prices among those that survive.
"The situation with M.R.I.'s is symptomatic of the tremendous excess capacity in our health care system: hospitals in the Sun Belt are half full, M.R.I. machines and mammography machines can operate less than half the day," said Dr. Uwe Reinhardt, a professor of health economics at Princeton University. "No airline can be profitable with a 50 percent load, but these facilities can do it because private insurers pay ridiculous prices -- they have shoveled out the money."
 
H.M.O.'s Seek Discounts
 But others warn that the consolidation will involve some hardship for patients. These machines, they point out, have allowed doctors to safely and simply diagnose conditions that previously required risky and invasive testing.
"I think that access to the scans is going to be drastically diminished and I think its naive to think that only the unnecessary scans will be eliminated and the necessary ones will still occur," said Dr. Jeffrey Newhouse, professor of radiology at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, who added that an insured person who can now be scanned the same day the test is ordered, and within a mile of his home, might in the future have to wait longer and travel farther.
Although no one knows exactly how many M.R.I. scanners there are in New York City, estimates range from 100 to 200, with a vast majority being in neighborhoods where the well-insured live, with a relative shortage in poorer areas.
In the 1980's with private insurers paying more than $1,000 and Medicare paying more than $700 a scan, even scanners that sat dormant much of the day could turn a good profit.
While private insurers may pay handsomely per scan, H.M.O.'s and other managed-care plans are likely to negotiate severely discounted rates -- some already pay only $400 a scan -- or to pay a flat fee to a radiology center for as many scans as may be needed. Also, H.M.O. doctors will probably be far less likely to order the test than private doctors. H.M.O.'s are generally paid a yearly fee for taking care of patients, and ordering expensive tests will quickly eat up the annual fees.
 
Changes Affecting Business
 "Managed care stands the economics of these machines on its head," Dr. Reinhardt said.
Already, in anticipation of great changes, orders for new machines in 1993 were only half of the number in 1992, said Philip Drew, a medical technology market analyst with the Concord Consulting Group. New laws that limit doctors' ability to invest in medical testing operations have also dampened enthusiasm for such ventures. During the late 80's neurologists and orthopedists were frequent investors in new M.R.I. machines, but studies showed that physicians with such investments tended to order more scans, raising ethical questions.
Traditional economic theory holds that such an excess supply should have brought prices for M.R.I. scans down, but the opposite occurred: Studies showed that in states with few scanners, the cost of the procedure was low, but in states with an abundance, the charges were high, said William Reis, who evaluated the economics of M.R.I.'s for the General Accounting Office.
Moreover, because the owners of scanners outside hospitals often need to charge high fees to survive, most do not take Medicaid and are far too costly for the uninsured.
 
Poor Often Denied Access
 "You find yourself in the idiotic position of having to deny poor people access to technology because you have too many machines," said Dr. Reinhardt. The same situation exists with mammography centers, he said.
From the medical perspective, M.R.I. scans are virtually no-risk procedures. The machines, normally run by technicians, create detailed images of the body's inner organs using only magnetic fields, and involve no radiation; the only significant drawback is that some patients become claustrophobic when slid into the tunnel-like apparatus.
As a result, health experts say, many doctors have taken to ordering them at the slightest hint of disease -- at least for those patients with conventional insurance plans. In an age of heightened malpractice fears, some doctors ordered scans for every headache to make sure the cause wasn't a tumor and for every new back pain to rule out a ruptured disc.
"Right now, if the patient is insured with fee-for-service insurance, there's no down side," said Dr. Roger Hyman, chairman of the Department of Radiology at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. "The patient will get reimbursed. The doctor will get information -- or no information if it's normal."
Financially, M.R.I. scanners have little risk. Most are bought or leased from one of three major manufacturers, and economists say that with prevailing private insurance rates, the machines can make profits doing as few as five scans a day.
"Even if you took all Medicare patients you'd be breaking even if you did 2,000 patients a year," Mr. Drew said. "And for scanners that take mostly private, the break-even number is about 1,500."
 
Circumventing Regulations
 In an effort to limit the number of scanners, most states declared in the mid-80's that before a hospital installed a new machine it would have to apply for a "certificate of need," showing that there was enough business to support the purchase. There are now 31 certified scanners in New York City, which as part of their contracts must agree to take all patients regardless of insurance type.
But New York and most other states do not regulate scanners outside hospitals, and investors quickly saw an opportunity, so that there are now far more machines outside hospitals than in them.
"They put in place this program to control costs and the number of scanners and it backfired," Dr. Hyman said. "The hospital couldn't have one, so the physicians and investors put in one across the street and not only did they not prevent the opening of another scanner, but costs actually went up." The private offices tend to skim off the patients with good insurance, leaving the poor for the hospital scanners. As a result, while privately insured patients or those on Medicare can often be scanned at a moment's notice, those on Medicaid, with the lowest reimbursement rates, may wait weeks.
There are now 2,500 to 3,500 scanners nationwide and perhaps 10 percent of those are in New York State, with most of those in the New York metropolitan area, Dr. Hyman said. But these are just ballpark guesses, and the handful of manufacturers carefully guard the number of machines they sell and service in a given region as a trade secret.
After several Government reports concluded that insurers were paying too much for scans, Medicare reduced its reimbursements from about $700 a scan five years ago to $550 now.
The declining payments in and of themselves will not drive centers out of business. But there is more trouble at the door. Many managed care organizations have specific protocols for dealing with conditions like back pain: under the protocols, M.R.I.'s are postponed until conservative treatment -- generally bed rest, exercise and medicine -- has been tried and has failed. Because most patients respond to this treatment, many scans are avoided.
But there has been a decrease in ordering scans from traditional private doctors as well, said Mr. Drew, who speculates that all the recent political attention on excessive health-care costs has caused doctors to hesitate before ordering expensive tests. Doctors say that in the last year, the number of M.R.I. scans ordered locally is down 15 to 20 percent, Mr. Winakor said.
 
Economics vs. Medicine
 The question of how many scans need to be done and how many scanners are required to do them is more of a political and economic decision than a medical one, Dr. Hyman said. "You get information from each scan but when you add in the cost factor it may not always be worth it," he said. "In a managed-care environment you say this is an $800 test, am I likely to get that much worth of information?"
Preparing for the future, M.R.I. owners like Mr. Winakor are undertaking aggressive marketing campaigns, contracting with unions, insurers and hospitals to provide discounted scans in return for "a measure of exclusivity." But he and others worry that the big H.M.O.'s, which control the movement of vast numbers of patients, will be able to bargain for rates that will drive them out of existence.
At the same time, medical economists like Dr. Reinhardt look on with a certain amount of glee. He says that medical technology has long escaped the controlling pull of market forces.
"The Clinton plan is designed to demolish excess capacity," he said. "Medical manufacturers think it's the Government that's going to be the devil at their neck, but I think its the little H.M.O. managers who are going to be an army of little devils at their necks."

HEADLINE: NO MORE OFFERS, NORTH KOREA SAYS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 9

 BODY:
North Korea said today that its offer to the United States to open a limited number of sites to nuclear inspection was the "largest concession" it could make, and warned that if it was turned down the North would conclude that Washington "no longer has the intention to continue dialogue."
The statement by the North Korean Foreign Ministry seemed to heighten the standoff with the Clinton Administration. At the same time, though, the North seemed to offer hope of some further progress, saying that once the two countries agreed on a "package solution" -- shorthand for economic aid and moves toward diplomatic recognition -- it would agree to full inspection of the sites it had declared to the International Atomic Energy Agency. 
 [In Washington, a State Department spokeswoman, Christine Shelly, said the United States was "not unduly" upset by the latest statement from North Korea, Reuters reported.]
 
Some Urge Softer Line
 So far, the Clinton Administration has refused to be lured into such an agreement, insisting that the North first comply with its inspection obligations under the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons and begin to hold serious talks with South Korea. But some officials in Washington and Seoul are already arguing for a softer line, one that would give the North much of what it has demanded in return for a solution to the impasse.
"We have encouraged the United States to show some flexibility," an official of South Korea's Foreign Ministry said today. Washington has not presented a new offer to North Korea's delegation to the United Nations.
Resuming normal inspections of North Korea's nuclear plants would not include its two major nuclear waste dumps, which the United States believes may provide evidence of how much plutonium the North has produced in the months when inspections were forbidden. That issue, officials say, would come later, during talks on resuming more normal relations.
 
Economic Problems
 North Korea's statement also included a lengthy review of the country's faltering economy, and acknowledged for the first time that the situation is growing increasingly dire. It said that the collapse of some of its main allies, all socialist nations, "caused big losses in our economic construction," and that "we have to divert a big proportion of the economy to national defense in order to increase the defense capabilities of the country."
A reformist member of the government, Kim Dal Hyon, who was removed earlier this week as the state planning chief and Deputy Prime Minister, was not listed today when the North Korean Government issued a list of names of its politburo. There had been speculation that Kim Dal Hyon was in line to become the next Prime Minister, and some analysts said his removal suggested he was being blamed for a disastrous year in both foreign and economic affairs.

HEADLINE: Level Producer Prices Show Inflation at Bay

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Despite a spirited surge in the economy, inflation remains at bay.
Prices obtained by American producers for finished goods showed no change in November, the Labor Department reported today, as increases for food and cars were about offset by declines for energy and tobacco. 
 Only one month since April has shown even the slightest increase at the producer, or wholesale, level -- a two-tenths of 1 percent rise during September. The index that shows consumer price movements is scheduled to be issued on Friday.
"Inflation still looks comfortably low," said Allen Sinai, chief economist for Lehman Brothers Global Economics.
If food and energy, two large and typically erratic components, are excluded from the calculation, the Producer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent, the most since April. Most economists, however, considered this increase in the so-called core rate a temporary blip, mainly reflecting a 2.1 percent jump in car prices after a drop of 3.9 percent in October.
The gyrations in automobiles reflect the introduction of new models and adjustments the Government makes for changes in quality; air bags becoming standard equipment, for example.
Financial markets thus took the report in stride, with the Federal Reserve still expected to make no change in monetary policy -- though it could incline toward tightening -- at the meeting of its Open Market Committee on Dec. 21.
Strongly expanding economies tend to generate inflationary pressures and many investors and analysts have grown wary of late that the Federal Reserve, which has been holding to an accommodative policy, will seek to dampen an economy widely expected to grow at a rate of 4 percent or more in the current quarter.
Indeed, some of its officials have said that short-term interest rates, which the central bank has held steady for the last 15 months, will need to rise. They have avoided, however, giving any indication of timing nor have they cited evidence of any speed-up in inflation.
The Clinton Administration and some Democrats in Congress have been emphasizing what they regard as a very encouraging outlook for a check on inflation, in particular the sharp decline in oil prices this fall.
Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, whose members buy from producers, said that since the Producer Price Index did not change last month, neither should Federal Reserve policy.
"Despite recent signs of economic growth, including stronger retail sales and gross domestic product, the threat of renewed inflation is minimal," Mr. Schreibman said.
Various analysts, in fact, find little historical relation between growth and inflation. "We ought not to assume that because the economy's growing so rapidly that this means inflation has to rise," said James W. Coons, economist for Huntington National Bank in Columbus, Ohio.
Pointing to data for the gross domestic product and the Consumer Price Index from 1950 to 1993, he found that "inflation in the next year bears no statistically significant relationship to economic growth in the current year."
But while agreeing about the record, H. Erich Heinemann of Ladenburg, Thalmann told clients this week that he rejected what he said had become the "conventional wisdom of a new era of low inflation."
He predicted a rise based on a 50 percent spurt in bank reserves over the last three years and on what appears to be a lack of anti-inflation political commitment in Washington.
Today's report on producer prices showed that the lack of current price pressure was about as favorable for goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production as for finished goods.
Intermediate goods, like a sack of flour, eased two-tenths of 1 percent in November, the best performance since May, while crude goods, such as a bushel of wheat, rose four-tenths of 1 percent after a 1.4 percent jump in October.
Among finished goods, those ready for sale to the final individual or business user, food prices rose eight-tenths of 1 percent as beef and veal, fresh and dry vegetables and fruits and melons turned up while the price of milled rice soared 29.3 percent after a 21.4 percent October jump.
Prospects for exporting rice to the Far East have brightened lately.
 
Energy and Tobacco Fall
 Energy goods fell 2.7 percent, paced by a 5.8 percent drop for gasoline that nearly offset a big October rise. Tobacco prices fell 1.3 percent after two straight gains, the report also showed.
For intermediate goods, where food and energy paralleled finished counterparts, prices firmed three-tenths of 1 percent for durable materials used in manufacturing, like cold rolled steel. Prices eased three-tenths of 1 percent, however, for nondurable factory goods, like chemicals.
The Producer Price Index for construction materials climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in November, surpassing a five-tenths of 1 percent October gain.

HEADLINE: U.S. Specifies Highways Eligible for Upgrading

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Hoping to stop Congress from using Federal transportation money for pet projects, the Clinton Administration today identified 159,000 miles of highways as strategically important and said only those roads would qualify for more than $14 billion in improvements through 1997.
The proposed system, which requires Congressional approval, includes the 45,000-mile Interstate highway system, highways deemed necessary for defense and those that serve regional travel and provide access to airports, Amtrak stations, public transportation systems, water ports and freight terminals. 
 Four million miles of roads criss-cross the nation, but the designated highways carry more than 50 percent of the nation's traffic and 70 percent of truck traffic, Administration officials said.
 
Formula of 1991 Act
 The 50 states and scores of regional planning commissions will determine which of those highways will receive the Federal money distributed in accordance with a formula in a 1991 act that required the Administration to designate a National Highway System.
The system is the first step toward a national plan intended to integrate all methods of travel and enable local officials to determine the best way to move their people and products. Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena said that with all its maps of highways, airports, ports and shipping lanes, the agency had no map that showed how the systems were linked and interact "or fail to do so."
In the past, Mr. Pena said, local officials asked, "How can we extend or widen a road?" or "How can we add a new subway?" By so doing, he said, the officials lost sight of their goal of serving people who are "trying to get to work or to get home for the holidays, people trying to get raw materials to their businesses and ship goods to their customers."
As the former Mayor of Denver, he said, "I can tell you that in the past, the first question was, 'Where's the money?' Mr. Pena said the city's transportation policy was driven more by the availability of Federal dollars than by the travel needs of citizens. "Those were the projects we went after."
"We can't afford to make decisions as we did in the past," Mr. Pena said.
Asked about President Clinton's offer of highways, bridges and other transportation projects to gain Congressional votes for the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mr. Pena said the President had merely promised to "expedite and facilitate projects already in the pipeline." Some of those projects were mired in the bureaucracy, Mr. Pena said, noting, "Sometimes it was our fault."
 
Hearings Are Planned
 Congressional leaders joined representatives of many transportation organizations in expressing enthusiasm for the proposal. Congress is set to begin hearings in February.
In the New York City area, the system includes the West Side Highway, the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, Broadway, the Belt Parkway, the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, the Long Island Expressway, the Cross Bronx Expressway, Bruckner Expressway, Cross Island Parkway, Interborough Parkway, Northern and Southern State Parkways and the Hutchinson River and Bronx River Parkways.
They are among thousands of highway projects that will qualify for the more than $3 billion earmarked for the National Highway System each year through 1997. An additional $2.5 billion annually is available for maintenance of the Interstate system, along with $3.5 billion annually for city streets and rural roads. Another $2.5 billion is available for bridge maintenance.
"This will help rebuild America," said Rodney E. Slater, the Federal Highway Administrator.
 
New York's Share
 Under the Federal formula, New York State is eligible for $180 million this year under the National Highway System, as well as for $102 million for maintenance of the Interstate system, $142 million under the city street and rural road program, and $255 million for bridges.
New Jersey is eligible for $87 million under the highway program, $31 million for Interstate maintenance, $118 million for bridges and $90 million for city streets and rural roads. Connecticut is eligible for $57 million for highways, $35 million for the Interstate, $68 million for bridges and $84 million for city streets and rural roads.
Secretary Pena noted that the United States spends nearly $1 trillion a year on transporation -- 17 percent of the gross domestic product. "That means that any gains we can register in systemwide efficiency will have large and rapid payoffs," he said.
In addition to the Interstate system, the National Highway System includes 21 corridors Congress designated for the system totaling 4,500 miles, including a stretch of U.S. Highway 219 south of Buffalo that was championed by former Representative Henry J. Nowak, a Democrat who was a senior member of the Public Works and Transportation Committee.
There are also the Strategic Highway Corridor Network, which comprises 15,700 miles of highway designated by the Defense Department, and 1,900 miles of roads linking major military installations and related sites.

HEADLINE: Budget Director Looking For a Budget Cuts

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration needs to squeeze more than $30 billion from department spending requests to hold next year's Federal budget below the limits allowed by law, Budget Director Leon E. Panetta said today.
Mr. Panetta said the Federal departments had requested $20 billion to $23 billion more than allowed by the spending ceiling established in the deficit-reduction package approved last August. 
 In addition, he said the Administration needed to cut $10 billion from the budget requests to allow for salary increases mandated by Congress for some Federal employees and to compensate for an inflation rate that is lower than the Administration had predicted. Lower inflation means the spending caps will be less than anticipated.
 
Suggestions for Cuts
 Mr. Panetta, who made his comments in a meeting with reporters, said that he and directors of nine Federal departments had meetings in recent days with President Clinton in which the agency heads defended their budget requests while Mr. Panetta suggested ways that some of the agencies could trim spending.
"These caps are extremely tight," Mr. Panetta said. "It's going to force some tough decisions."
For instance, he said the Pentagon's request for next year is about $5 billion more than the President had envisioned in his military spending plan, while the State Department's budget request exceeded the targets set by the Office of Management and Budget.
Making the Administration's efforts harder is Mr. Clinton's desire to increase spending in areas that he calls investments in the future, including Head Start, job training, education and technological research. This, Mr. Panetta said, means the White House has to make deeper spending cuts in some areas to finance greater spending on "investment" programs while staying within the budget caps.
Mr. Panetta said the Administration had not yet decided what many of the spending cuts would be, although he said some of them would come from Vice President Al Gore's plan to streamline Government. Specifically, he cited a recommendation by Mr. Gore to consolidate more than 30 existing education grant programs, a move that is expected to save $515 million from 1994 through 1999. He also said the Administration would propose savings on a Federal program that stockpiles helium.

HEADLINE: Health Cost Rises Are Less Steep

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Reflecting rising political and economic pressures, the growth in spending for health care will slow dramatically in 1994, large employers and insurers said yesterday.
Pressure from the Clinton Administration and employers is forcing an increasing number of health maintenance organizations to hold their rate rises to 4 percent or 5 percent. After experiencing double-digit rate gains over the last five years, some companies are even seeing rates climb below the 2.8 percent inflation rate. 
 Nationally, the 1994 H.M.O. premiums are increasing an average of 5.6 percent, down from 8.1 percent in 1993, the Group Health Association of America, an H.M.O. trade group, said yesterday. A dozen employers, insurers and H.M.O. executives reported similar increases in interviews.
The cost of traditional health insurance is rising about 7.5 percent, although many traditional health plans are still expecting increases in the high teens, following double-digit rises in recent years.
Both proponents and critics of President Clinton's health care program jumped on the latest numbers to argue their cases.
"One reason this is happening is because people see reform coming," Walter Zelman, a senior White House health policy adviser, said. "If the President abandoned health care reform, these trends would slow down measurably."
 
Clinton Would Set Ceiling
 Another reason, he said, is that more people are joining H.M.O.'s, whose costs typically rise at a slower rate than traditional coverage. The Group Health Association said 45 million people were enrolled in H.M.O.'s in 1993, a gain of 3.6 million from 1992.
Mr. Zelman said the cost trends would make it easier to meet the President's health care budget targets without invoking the budget ceilings, which are under attack by physician and hospital groups.
The President's plan would place a ceiling on increases in the cost of basic health coverage at 1.5 percent above the general inflation rate in 1997. The limit would be lowered over three years and held to the consumer price index in 2000, Mr. Zelman noted.
Critics of the Clinton proposals seized on the flattening of the spending trend to argue for delay. "The changes in prices in the private sector are changing the political dynamic," said Paul M. Ellwood, chairman of the Jackson Hole Group, which favors managed competition, a less regulated approach than the Administration's proposals.
"People may want to take more time to get the private sector completely changed around" before going ahead with a new Government program, he added.
In the most dramatic example of lower H.M.O. costs, the California state employees' health plan, Calpers, is demanding a 5 percent decrease in 1994, which would cut $80 million from the $1.6 billion that it spent to cover 980,000 employees, retirees and their families in 1993.
Tom Elkin, a Calpers executive, said the cut had been accepted by some California H.M.O.'s and that others had even offered not to increase premiums. The largest California H.M.O., Kaiser Permanente, has not responded yet, he said.
Dan Danzig, a spokesman for Kaiser, which covers seven million people across the country, said it was taking the Calpers request "very seriously." He said Kaiser's rate increases would average 4.1 percent nationally in 1994, down from 6.7 percent this year and 9.6 percent in 1992.
 
Xerox's Costs Down
 The Xerox Corporation said its most cost-efficient H.M.O.'s would have increases of 3.6 percent, down from 5.5 percent in 1993. The average increase for all Xerox employees in H.M.O.'s will be 5.3 percent, and for traditional coverage, 16.8 percent, a Xerox spokeswoman said.
But even smaller employers have been able to slow costs. Ron Dix, a vice president at Badger Meter Inc., based in Milwaukee, said costs for its 750 employees would decline by 5 percent this year. In 1994, he said, the company expects there will be no increases at its doctor and hospital networks, which are not part of an H.M.O.
And Thomas S. Kalbrener, benefits manager at the Waldorf Corporation, a paperboard maker based in St. Paul, said he hoped to hold increases to "the 2 to 3 percent range" in the fiscal year beginning next July.
Joe Maginnis, a vice president at Prudential Insurance, which provides health coverage for 14.5 million people, said its H.M.O. premiums would rise 6 to 7 percent in 1994. He said rates for physician-hospital networks, called "preferred providers," would rise by slightly under 10 percent, and for traditional coverage by 16 percent to 20 percent.
David Simon, a senior vice president at the U.S. Healthcare Corporation, an H.M.O. based in Blue Bell, Pa., with about 1.6 million enrolled, said, "We're looking at 4 to 6 percent increases." In New Jersey, where the company has a strong presence, the increase will be "less than 5 percent," he said.
The New York H.M.O. Council, a trade group, said increases in the state would average 5.7 percent, a sharp drop from 12 percent in 1993.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
So, Let Your Cursor Do The Walking

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS

 BODY:
An electronic yellow pages that will allow computer users to find all the shops in Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau County that repair cellular telephones, for example, or all the Mexican restaurants in the Bronx and Westchester County where dinner for two is less than $50 was announced yesterday by the Nynex Corporation and the Prodigy Services Company.
The service, expected to be available in the fourth quarter of next year, will combine in one vast listing all 300 volumes of classified ad pages from Nynex's service area of New York and New England. It will, for instance, enable banks to change interest rates in their ads daily, and it allows for the use of headline type, color and photos in the ads. 
 "The most important thing is the ability to use processing power to sort through the listings," said Gary Arlen, of Arlen Communications in Bethesda, Md., an information services consultant.
Not so long ago, the prospect of electronic yellow pages would have sent shivers through the newspaper industry, which feared the loss of classified advertising. But in recent months, newspaper companies have announced alliances with local phone companies to put various services on line for computer users.
 
A New Area for Enterprise
 Local phone companies have only recently been freed to enter such non-telephone businesses, having been barred from doing so when the Bell System was broken up a decade ago.
Prodigy, which is owned by I.B.M. and by Sears, Roebuck & Company, has about two million subscribers nationwide, who pay fees to use the system. About 180,000 of them are in the Nynex area.
A computer user connects to Prodigy with a telephone modem. After entering the yellow pages, the customer can specify what topics are to be searched for; the resulting list can be printed or stored in the computer.
Prodigy and Nynex declined to put a dollar value on their alliance. Ross S. Glatzer, president and chief executive of Prodigy, said only that they were equal partners, but that in the early stages Nynex had made the bigger contribution.
And Kathy Ives, director of On-Line Services for Nynex, added: "We don't care what the platform is; we just want to get our product out there. Right now, there's no other advertising platform out there; Prodigy is the only advertiser-supported on-line service."
Initially, she said, Nynex would list all current yellow pages advertisers on its electronic service without charges, hoping to sell them display advertising in the future. She said ad rates had not yet been established.
Ms. Ives said Nynex would at first concentrate its marketing of the new service within its region, perhaps later expanding to nearby areas like New Jersey and Connecticut. She also said that Nynex would try to help Prodigy sign up more subscribers in the Nynex area.
 
Monopoly Question Raised
 Nancy Jones, a spokeswoman for the Newspaper Publishers Association, said the industry continued to fear that telephone companies' monopoly position over local phone service gave them a competitive advantage over other media.
She said her group would push for Federal legislation requiring phone companies that offer electronic services to create independent subsidiaries to prevent them from using their phone business to subsidize the electronic services and to assure all providers of information equal access to telephone networks.
Executives at Nynex and Prodigy said the alliance had been in the works for more than a year. Cox Newspapers and the BellSouth Corporation have already said they will jointly offer newspaper classified advertising and the yellow pages; Newsday and Nynex said they would electronically deliver local information like sports scores from Long Island high schools.
Mr. Glatzer said yesterday that he expected more such alliances, expressing the hope that Prodigy would become a national platform for yellow pages and classified ads. "We've mapped out several dozen papers we were interested in," he said, "and we've asked how long before the BellSouth-Cox relationship is replicated. I think we'll see a lot more papers, and telephone company-newspaper alliances, within 24 months."
