HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Argentine Notes Draw Investors

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Far from Mexico -- where the North American Free Trade Agreement is rousing markets -- there was business being done yesterday that signals that many investors are already betting on what might be the next Mexico in Latin America.
On Wall Street, and in Europe and Asia, portfolio managers and institutional investors yesterday snapped up $1 billion of 10-year notes issued by the Republic of Argentina. 
 The notes were marked by several firsts, including the first global issue by a Latin American government as well as, apparently, the first global junk bond, or below investment grade issue, ever sold.
A global issue is one that is sold and can be traded in markets around the world at the same time. Before Argentina, the global market was the place for rock-solid credits like the World Bank.
Barbara L. Kenworthy, a portfolio manager at the Dreyfus Corporation, knows the checkered financial history of Latin America. Still, she bought about $15 million of the Argentine bonds, a large purchase for her, and put them in three different Dreyfus funds.
She acknowledges that the bonds are risky and that she normally does not buy below-investment-grade securities. But, she said, "You can put a little bit of high risk in a portfolio, if fundamentals and momentum are in your favor."
The rush for the Argentine issue seems to reflect many of the trends that have pushed investors all year: the demand for higher yields has forced investors to buy bonds with higher credit risks and longer maturities.
Emerging markets have been one of the sweeter flavors of the year because they offer higher returns. And investors are looking in Latin America for the next Mexico, a below- investment-grade issue that has a chance to be raised to investment grade, which is what many analysts and portfolio manager are betting for Mexico.
The success of the Argentine issue also shows how much the view on Latin America has changed in such a short time. It was just over 10 years ago that Latin American countries began defaulting on their debt, causing a major international financial crisis.
And it is just since 1989 that a solution to this crisis began to unfold. In fact, Brazil, the largest debtor in the developing world, has yet to make final a deal on its debt with its bankers worldwide. And Brazil has yet to agree on an economic reform program with the International Monetary Fund.
Ms. Kenworthy of Dreyfus said the positive fundamentals for Argentina included the opening of its markets. Much of the momentum, she added, comes from the North American Free Trade Agreement, which has made more and more investors look favorably on Latin America.
She said the size of the issue would make it a "benchmark" and mean that it would be easy to trade. So a lot of managers getting into Latin America for the first time will think one simple way is to buy the Argentine bonds, in the same way that the Latin American telephone companies have been bought in the past. In addition, she said that she was expecting credit agencies to upgrade the rating on Argentina, which would increase its price.
James Quigley, managing director of the global debt syndicate at Merrill Lynch, the coordinating manager of the issue, said that the market had already priced the issue as if it were rated at the "strong" BB level. It is currently rated BB- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and B1 by Moody's Investors Service.
The $1 billion in 10-year notes were priced to yield 8.47 percent, which was 280 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the yield on the 10-year Treasury note.
Mr. Quigley said that there were orders totaling between $1.4 billion and $1.5 billion at the time of the pricing yesterday. He said that in the end underwriters in the syndicate had sold about $1.2 billion worth of notes to customers with only $1 billion available.
This short position helped increase the demand when the issue began to trade and is one of the reasons that it ended trading higher on the day, with the spread over the 10-year Treasury note narrowing to about 277 basis points.
Of the $1 billion in bonds, about $600 million were sold in North America, mostly in the United States, about $300 million in Europe and about $100 million in Asia.
 
Treasury Market
 Prices and yield in the Treasury market were little changed for the third day in a row yesterday, despite the release of relatively positive inflation data. The wait for today's release of the more important November Consumer Price Index could have restrained buying.
The price of the 30-year bond inched up 3/32 as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 6.15 percent, from 6.16 percent Wednesday. The price of the two-year note fell 2/32 as the yield rose to 4.17 percent from 4.13 percent.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods in November was unchanged while the so-called core rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, jumped an unexpected four-tenths of 1 percent.
But while the jump in the core rate unsettled the market a bit, Richard Berner, the chief economist for the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said that any near-term inflationary fears should be eased by the recent drop in oil and gasoline prices and the price restraint in the health care industry.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
At Citibank, More No-Fee Credit Cards

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Citibank plans to drop annual fees on seven million credit card accounts in a bid to capture a larger share of the $200 billion industry, according to company filings with the Government.
In addition, Citibank will lower the minimum payments card holders are required to make each month and charge them higher penalties when these payments arrive late, under a plan outlined in a Form 8-K filed Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
 Analysts said Citibank, the largest credit card issuer in the country, was taking the steps to retain present card holders, attract new ones and increase the number of charges customers make.
The bank is betting that the increased spending that accompanies the recovering economy, along with efforts to lower credit losses and fraud, will offset the decrease in annual fees, they said.
James Bailey, executive vice president of North American consumer banking for Citicorp, the parent of Citibank, said: "When you have the economy improving and lower funding costs and lower fraud losses, you have an opportunity to increase your market share by being more aggressive. This is us going on the offensive."
 
A Trend Toward No Fees
 The plan also represents a change in direction for Citibank, which is one of the last large credit card issuers to still charge annual fees. Citibank's decision to eliminate the charge for roughly half of its 20 million credit card accounts -- 4 million have already received this benefit -- may signal that annual fees have become obsolete.
"This will accelerate a trend that is has already been in place: the phasing out of annual fees on bank credit cards," said Robert McKinley, president of the RAM Research Corporation, which tracks the bank card industry.
But changing the credit card operations carries a risk for Citibank because the business has been one of its steadiest sources of revenue. The annual fees alone generated revenue of about $500 million each year, Mr. McKinley said. A Citibank spokeswoman declined to confirm the figures.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances Broadly, But Eases Against the Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar edged higher against most European currencies but slipped against the Japanese yen in quiet trading yesterday following the release of flat November producer prices.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose slightly to 1.7055 German marks, from 1.7052 marks on Wednesday. But it slipped to 108.66 yen from 108.95 yen. 
 Meanwhile, gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery, the most actively traded futures contract, dropped $1.30, to $384.40 an ounce.
A slightly bigger-than-expected increase in the core Producer Price Index failed to lift the dollar. Over all, producer prices were unchanged in November from the previous month, but the core rate, which excludes the volatile food and energy components, rose four-tenths of 1 percent.
 "There is not a lot of interest in the P.P.I.," said Andrew Larkin, foreign exchange trader at Postipankki Bank. "If anything is to stir this market, it will be the Consumer Price Index tomorrow."
 Higher American interest rates would make dollar-based assets relatively more attractive than foreign investments, encouraging dollar purchases. With evidence pointing to strong United States growth in the fourth quarter, many are wondering if the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates early next year to quell inflationary pressure.
 "The question is whether or not the Fed will tighten," said a United States bank dealer in London. "Consumer inflation will be more closely watched in that regard."
 Dealers were also watching continuing world trade talks as international negotiators worked furiously to conclude the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade before the Dec. 15 deadline.
 Any trade friction tends to roil the foreign exchange market, but dealers said listless year-end trading could limit any reaction to GATT developments.
 "The market is totally lethargic," said Al Soria, foreign exchange manager at Kansallis Osaki Pankki. "People are waiting for GATT to pass, but even that won't move the market much.".
 The British pound closed in New York at $1.4935, down up from $1.4970 late Wednesday. Other late dollar rates, compared with Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.4660 Swiss francs, down from 1.4665; 5.8465 French francs, up from 5.8395; 1,668 Italian lire, up from 1,666, and $1.3287 (Canadian), up from $1.3231 (Canadian).

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Yankees Deal Owen To Angels

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
The Yankees took a step toward trimming their payroll yesterday when they traded their overvalued shortstop, Spike Owen, to the California Angels for a minor league relief pitcher. But it was only a small step in this arduous economic process because they also agreed to absorb an undisclosed amount of Owen's contract as a condition of the trade.
Conceding that they made a mammoth blunder when they signed him to a three-year, $7 million free agent contract last December, the Yankees will now pay a portion of the $4.25 million Owen will receive over the next two years to dismiss him and save some important cash. It is doubtful the Angels would have made the deal unless the Yankees assumed at least $2 million of Owen's contract. 
 Unloading part of Owen's hefty salary increases General Manager Gene Michael's flexibility as he continues pursuing a starter or an outfielder to bolster the Yankees. Michael said Wednesday that he must first dispose of a few contracts before he can get involved in chasing free agents or trading for high-priced players because he has been instructed to remain near a $45 million budget.
 
A Minor Dent in Budget
 Owen is scheduled to make $1 million in 1994 and $3.25 million in 1995 so his departure makes a minor dent in a budget that is already projected at about $40 million.
"If we can move two or three contracts," Michael has said, "I think it would be possible a lot of things could happen."
Owen lost his starting spot to Mike Gallego after the All-Star Game and became the highest-paid cheerleader in the Bronx, so it was pretty surprising that Michael found a new home for him. If the Yankees do not make another transaction involving an infielder, Gallego and Randy Velarde would be the likely candidates to start at shortstop. Both had career years in utility roles as Gallego hit .283 with 54 runs batted in and Velarde hit .301.
But Michael curiously mentioned Class AAA shortstop Dave Silvestri in the statement issued yesterday about the trade that brought Class AA pitcher Jose Musset to New York. It was curious because the 26-year old Silvestri was deemed so unimportant in September that the Yankees did not even recall him when their rosters expanded to 40 players.
"Spike Owen was a true professional and did a nice job for us last season," Michael said in the statement. "Moving him gives us a chance to move along some of our young players, and Dave Silvestri is one of the young players who should be given the opportunity now."
 
Could Velarde Go Next?
 Whether Michael was intimating that Silvestri should be given an opportunity to start is uncertain, and the general manager did not return a telephone message left last night. Silvestri, who batted .269 with 20 homers and 65 runs batted in for Columbus, has played 14 major league games and is considered a defensive liability. If Michael is serious about Silvestri challenging for the shortstop slot, Velarde could be traded next.
Owen, who is 32 and an 11-year veteran, began his Yankee career in promising fashion by hitting .419 in his first 12 games, but his production on offense and defense plummeted after that. His range was suspect, and his penchant for sliding to his knees to field grounders mystified observers. It grew more and more obvious that the Yankees needed a change, and Gallego and Velarde handled shortstop most of the second half as Owen made nine starts in the final two months.
For the season, he batted .234 with 2 homers, 20 r.b.i. and 14 errors in 96 games.
The 25-year-old Musset is a career minor leaguer who was 2-6 with a 5.49 earned run average and 21 saves in 59 games for Class AA Midland of the Texas League last season. In four seasons, the right-hander was 13-16 with a 4.43 e.r.a. and 29 saves in 124 games.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Consumer prices rose a modest two-tenths of a percent in November, restrained by declines in the cost of energy. The small November rise matched the average for the two preceding months and was seen as further evidence that inflation remains in check while the economy picks up momentum. [Page 39.]
President Clinton and the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, Lane Kirkland, agreed to end their bitter public debate over Nafta and will work together on health care changes. But the union said state and local chapters could still decide to punish supporters of the trade pact in the 1994 elections. [1.]
The Fed assailed the Treasury's proposed overhaul of the Community Reinvestment Act, saying it could lead to Government influence over loans and unsound lending practices. [39.]
 
Companies
Green Point Savings depositors voted to convert the mutual savings bank to public ownership through a $700 million stock offering. But state regulators must rule on the change and will hold hearings to determine if regulations were followed. [39.]
Nynex plans to reduce expenses sharply in its core local telephone business. But the Baby Bell refused to confirm reports that it planned to cut about 22,000 jobs over three years. [39.]
Paramount's board will meet Monday to plan an auction for the company after the Delaware Supreme Court ruled that it must consider acquisition bids other than Viacom's. [41.]
American companies should be allowed to export advanced fiber optic communications equipment to the former Soviet Union and to China, the Commerce Department recommended. [41.]
Canadian bank executives are paid far less than their U.S. counterparts, data released under new disclosure rules show. [41.]
Prudential Insurance's financial strength rating could be lowered because of the scandal in its securities unit. [50.]
 
International
American lawmakers, executives and lobbyists are pouring into Geneva hoping to influence the world trade talks. Their fervor may be a signal that any GATT agreement will face the same intensity of feeling in Congress that greeted Nafta. [39.]
European Community leaders backed a plan to create jobs by cutting labor costs and employer contributions to welfare programs. More than 5 million European jobs have been lost since 1990 and the unemployment rate is 11.3 percent. [5.]
The Japanese economy is still deteriorating and may not recover for a year or more from its two-year-old recession, a survey of the country's business executives showed. The executives indicated they planned to cut staff and spending. [40.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks rose to new records while broader averages continued to slide. The Dow industrials rose 10.89, to 3,740.67. [40.]
Interest rates rose despite a Government report that consumer inflation remained subdued last month. [48.]
Oil prices rebounded on technical factors, weather-related supply problems and producers' optimism on prices. [49.]
The dollar weakened against the German mark but gained against the Japanese yen. Gold prices rose. [49.]
 
Your Money
The urge to donate to charities rises during the holidays, but donors should scrutinize how groups parcel out their money. [36.]
Following a selling strategy can help investors maximize their returns when they want to liquidate stock holdings. [36.]
Keeping several retirement accounts at one bank is not wise because of new limits in Federal deposit insurance. [36.]
A special kind of trust for children with mental and physical disabilities can protect their inheritance and benefits. [37.]

SECTION: Section 1; Page 6; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 759 words

HEADLINE: European Community Backs Plan To Create Jobs by Reducing Costs

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Facing an unemployment crisis that is the main concern of their electorates, European Community leaders gave broad backing today to a plan to create jobs by cutting labor costs. But Britain and Germany balked at proposals that the community borrow billions of dollars to start major public works projects.
While the 12 leaders debated formulas to create $15 million in new jobs by the year 2000, negotiators in Geneva struggled to put the final touches to what many officials regard as the best long-term solution to the disappearance of European jobs -- a world trade agreement that is expected to stimulate business worldwide. 
 But Foreign Minister Alain Juppe of France said sharp differences remained with the United States over the Clinton Administration's demand that the subsidizing of the French movie industry through a box office levy on tickets be eliminated.
"We would not like to see the world trade talks fail because the Hollywood lobby turns out to be stronger than the French farmers lobby," Mr. Juppe said, alluding to the fact that an agricultural agreement has already been reached between the United States and Europe but the movie issue remains contentious.
 
'Hollywood Domination' Faulted
 "We cannot accept that Hollywood's domination of this industry became a total monopoly," Mr. Juppe added. "We will not budge from our system of support for our industry, and, if necessary, the audio visual sector will have to be excluded from any GATT agreement."
Peter Guildford, a trade spokesman for the European Commission, said no European decision on a General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade was now expected before a special foreign ministers meeting here on Monday.
The absence of a trade agreement has long worsened Europe's unemployment problem. With over five million jobs lost since 1990 as the continent's recession has persisted, and 11.3 percent of the work force now unemployed, political debate in Europe this year has centered on whether the answer lies in scaling back the welfare state to make job creation cheaper or increasing public spending.
 
Two-Pronged Plan Offered
 A 184-page plan put forward this week by Jacques Delors, the President of the European Commission, proposed a combination of both: lowering minimum wages and cutting the nonwage labor costs that finance Europe's comprehensive social welfare programs, while at the same time devoting $22 billion a year of community money to huge projects for roads, railways, energy and telecommunications.
Community officials said there was broad agreement that labor costs and rigidities must be reduced if Europe is to match the United States' ability to create jobs with growth -- an indication that Europe wants to borrow some elements from the American social model even as President Clinton looks to Europe for his health care plan.
With tax and social security payments adding an average of 40 percent to labor costs in Europe, compared with 30 percent in the United States, European employers have shown increasing reluctance to hire and have brought the welfare state to a point of unparalleled crisis.
But if there was general agreement that the welfare state has become too burdensome, there was sharp disagreement over proposals to use public spending to spur job creation. President Francois Mitterrand of France strongly backed the proposed public works program, calling for precise dates to be set for the projects "to give a signal of hope to our citizens."
 
Major Attacks Borrowing
 He was countered by Prime Minister John Major of Britain, who led a virulent attack on the proposed financing of the projects.
"It would be absurd for the European Commission to increase its borrowing when member states are taking severe action to reduce theirs," Mr. Major told the other leaders, referring to a proposal that the commission borrow about $9 billion a year through bond issues to finance new projects like a proposed high-speed train betweenLyons, France, and Turin, Italy, or a Berlin-Warsaw motorway.
Kenneth Clarke, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, was more outspoken in his criticism of the commission's proposal to borrow and spend, saying, "It's just nonsense to think you can wave a magic wand and produce 15 million new jobs by pouring in new money from some new borrowing facility."
Britain's position was backed by Finance Minister Theo Waigel of Germany. Both countries argued that the proposed borrowing could be inflationary and that investments should be led by the private sector.

HEADLINE: U.S. Politicians Turn Into Lobbyists Over GATT

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Congressional leaders, executives, lobbyists and environmentalists who fought for or against the North American Free Trade Agreement have been streaming here to fight shoulder to shoulder against proposed provisions of a new global trade agreement.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who wants to retain American limits on low-cost imports, and Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, the West Virginia Democrat concerned about limits on medical research subsidies, came last week. 
 The House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, arrived on Thursday. And Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Committee, also landed here Thursday, in an Air Force jet full of committee members and their aides; Mr. Rostenkowski wants to retain United States penalties on countries that restrict American exports.
 
Trying to Avoid Division
 The Clinton Administration is listening to the complaints about the proposals being negotiated under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade because it does not want Congressional consideration next year of a global pact to become a political brawl like last month's vote on the North American pact.
The deadline for the talks is Wednesday, and issues still to be settled include greater access for American movies in Europe, international banking, and rule changes that will determine whether existing American trade laws are gutted or retained.
"It is clear that there is enormous Congressional concern in several areas, particularly anti-dumping, financial services, aircraft and audio-visual," a senior Administration trade official said this morning after meeting with members of Congress on Thursday; the official insisted on anonymity.
The Administration is trying especially hard to make changes in the pact so as to preserve American trade laws. The laws are used to impose steep tariffs on foreign goods that are sold in the United States below cost or for less than in other markets, a practice known as dumping. The dumping law is popular in Congress, but widely disliked overseas, so the Administration has an uphill fight to get its changes.
"It is the issue where feelings run the deepest in Congress," said Jeffrey Garten, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade. But he acknowledged that other countries opposed the changes. "Most of the delegations are solidly arrayed against us on most of these issues, but from our standpoint, this is a central part of the proposal."
Mr. Gephardt said in an interview tonight that the global pact's prospects in Congress would depend on deals made here. "It will be contentious, but I think if the negotiators are able to do some things in the last hours of the negotiations, things like anti-dumping, 301, aircraft and audio-visual, then I think it can pass the Congress," he said.
He was referring to Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act, which allows the United States to retaliate unilaterally against foreign countries that restrict American exports.
 
Traveling Far

 
 While some American politicians are seeking broad changes in the proposed pact, others have more parochial concerns, and are willing to come a long way to express them.
Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, arrived here late Monday night from his ranch in Big Horn, Wyo., for one day of lobbying with American and European Community officials. He sought lowered European taxes on soda ash, which is used to make glass and detergents and is the basis of Wyoming's biggest export industry. The European Community imposes a 10 percent tariff on soda ash, but it promised American negotiators this week that the tariff would be cut to 5.5 percent.
That was still too steep for Mr. Wallop, who feared that his trip had had little effect. "I haven't noticed one yet, in all honesty," he said.
Senator Wallop, who has backed free-trade pacts in the past, said he was likely to vote for this one, but he then asked to take back the remark. "I'd rather not have the Europeans knowing that," he said. "I'd rather say that I don't know how I'll vote."
 
Broad-Based Opposition

 
 Labor and consumer groups that opposed the North American pact are also hostile to the 116-nation GATT deal. And five of the six big environmental groups that supported the North American pact announced last week that they wanted many changes in the global accord.
The Administration is pursuing only some of the changes now sought by various groups and is unlikely to prevail on all of them.
The goal is an agreement that will reduce average worldwide tariffs on manufactured goods by one-third and that will for the first time apply the free-trade rules of GATT to agriculture and services like insurance and tourism. The Clinton Administration supports all of these goals.
But Asian nations have been demanding changes in provisions of American trade laws that have been used to impose steep tariffs on their goods, and those demands have alarmed American companies that benefit from these laws.
A remarkably broad range of American manufacturers and service providers like insurance companies and banks are opposing the pact, saying it will help foreign countries more than the United States.
The result has been some odd political and commercial alliances. Mr. Gephardt, who fought the North American pact, and Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who supported it, last week organized a coalition of 11 American business leaders who share their hostility to rewriting American trade laws.
The group objects to the draft text's changes in Federal laws that now allow American companies to seek steep Commerce Department tariffs on imported goods made with foreign government subsidies or sold in the United States below cost or for less than in their home markets.
The coalition includes Curtis H. Barnette, chairman and chief executive of Bethlehem Steel; George M. C. Fisher, chairman and chief executive of Eastman Kodak; Andrew S. Grove, chief executive of Intel, and Jerry K. Pearlman, chairman of Zenith Electronics.
Mr. Gephardt has also seldom found himself on the same side of a trade issue as Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri. But Mr. Danforth is worried about how the pact will affect the heavily Republican grain farmers in Missouri. For his part, Mr. Gephardt, representing a blue-collar district in St. Louis, is worried that farm issues have already consumed too much time and that protections for factories may have been lost through inattention.
"Up until now, we've spent so much time for agriculture that we've left for last a lot of other things we're interested in," Mr. Gephardt said.
 
Environment Becomes Issue

 
 Environmental opposition to the pact could prove particularly important. The Clinton Administration won endorsements for the North American pact from the six big environmental groups after negotiating a side agreement with Mexico and Canada that will set up a special commission to investigate environmental abuses throughout the continent.
But duplicating that feat may prove difficult for the world trade pact. Five of the same six environmental groups sent a letter last week to Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, asking for extensive changes in the agreement.
Environmental groups want GATT to require for the first time that countries produce goods in environmentally sound ways, so as to eliminate current incentives for countries to produce goods in whatever country has the most lax environmental enforcement. But economic research has suggested that environmental regulations seldom determine where a company builds factories, and the Clinton Administration has not tried to inject this issue into the trade talks.
Not even Mr. Kantor is trying to organize an environmental side agreement among 116 nations. In an interview the day after the House approved the North American pact last month, he said that environmental and labor issues would have to wait for the next international round of trade talks, which conclude, on average, once a decade.

HEADLINE: NEEDIEST CASES;
Man's Job Is Gone, Not Self-Respect

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
Felix B. first started working at the age of 9, delivering prescriptions after school for a corner druggist in Brooklyn Heights to help support his sister and his mother.
In fact, for most of his life, there was hardly ever a time when he was not holding either a part-time or full-time job. He put himself through two years of business courses at the Fashion Institute of Technology by working as an office assistant. 
 For 10 years, he worked as a major-domo, or what he calls "a glorified housekeeper," for up to a dozen clients at a time. He cleaned their houses, did their tailoring, ran their errands and helped them manage their busy personal lives, a job perfectly in keeping with his punctilious nature. "My friends called me Felix Unger," he said, smiling.
When that work dried up in the early 1990's, Felix B. found a job with a company that created fabric sample books. It took him back to his love of fashion, first instilled in him by his mother's work as a seamstress. "It was a job that I truly loved," he said, "and one I hoped to stay at the rest of my life."
 
'The Work Was Drying Up'
 But one of Felix's tasks was to review weekly payroll checks.
"I realized after a while that I was seeing fewer and fewer checks and I knew that the work was drying up," he said. "Our business was completely dependent on the shirts and textiles companies. When they started to go out of business, so did we."
Felix, 48, has now been out of work for more than a year and has been living on public assistance since last Christmas. He has kept his apartment in Borough Park, Brooklyn, only by working as an unofficial superintendent in exchange for a freeze on rent increases.
One thing that buoys his spirits is his unpaid work as a computer operator at Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens. The position was arranged through the Work Experience Program, in which welfare recipients work off their grants by helping at city offices or charities. In turn, Catholic Charities has helped Felix with minor expenses and with his job search by printing his resume and buying him new shoes and clothes.
Catholic Charities is one of seven social-service agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which is conducting its 82d appeal through Feb. 28. The Times pays for all of the campaign's expenses so that all the money raised goes to the charities to help them provide direct services for unemployed, poor and disabled New Yorkers.
For Felix, the job at Catholic Charities does more for his peace of mind than for his financial situation. The charity has not been able to hire him because its resources are stretched thin. As he mails out resumes in search of part-time or full-time work, he is in a race to beat his bills.
Despite his frustrations, Felix said that he will not feel defeated by his circumstances unless he loses his sense of self-respect. "There's a certain way you conduct yourself no matter how poor you are," he said. "It's going to take a lot for them to take that away from me."

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up Modestly

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Restrained by declines in the cost of energy, consumer prices rose a modest two-tenths of a percent in November, matching the average for the two preceding months, the Labor Department reported today.
Analysts regarded the data, which were about as expected, as further evidence that inflation remains in check, though not nonexistent, even as the economy picks up speed. 
 The consumer inflation rate for the last 12 months stood at 2.7 percent in November. On Thursday, the Government reported that prices paid to American producers, a narrower gauge than consumer prices, were unchanged last month.
 
Consumers More Confident
 In a separate report today showing that consumers are growing increasingly confident about the economy, the widely followed University of Michigan index of consumer sentiment jumped 6.5 points in early December, to 87.7, according to subscribers to the survey.
This was the highest reading since January and it incorporated a 6.6-point jump in expectations about the future, one component of the Government's economic forecasting gauge. The results unnerved the bond market, pushing up interest rates, by indicating that consumers would continue to increase their spending, possibly moving inflation higher.
The inflation figures showed prices rising more slowly last month than in October in six of the seven main categories, apparel being the exception.
The so-called core, or underlying, rate of inflation -- excluding food and energy -- was performing only slightly less well than prices over all. It rose three-tenths of a percent last month, the same as in October, and now stands 3.1 percent above its level of November 1992.
 
 
 
Down 0.1% in New York
 In the New York metropolitan area, prices edged down a tenth of a percent to push inflation for the last 12 months down to 2.1 percent.
John E. Silvia, an economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, called the results released today "pretty darn good." But he took issue with those who seem to have concluded that inflation has been thoroughly, and more or less permanently, suppressed.
"Inflation's not zero -- it's 3 percent," he said, adding that this includes significant benefit from half a year of falling oil prices.
Food prices, still seemingly affected by the summer's floods and drought, climbed four-tenths of a percent last month as fresh vegetables, up 5.3 percent, took over from fresh fruits as a main source of upward pressure. Beef prices, which had been steady since April, climbed six-tenths of a percent.
Expenses for housing, which accounts for 41 percent of the Consumer Price Index, rose a scant one-tenth of a percent last month, a slight slowdown from the preceding two months, reflecting declines in the cost of natural gas, electricity and fuel oil. The cost of maintenance and repairs fell 2.2 percent, the report also showed.
 
 
 
Drop in Gas Price
 The transportation sector, where prices rose two-tenths of a percent, benefited from a 1.8 percent drop in gasoline and no change in new cars after a rise in October. But automobile finance charges rose for only the second time in 33 months. Used cars rose again to reach a level 8.3 percent higher than a year earlier, and airline fares spurted 4.1 percent.
Apparel rose four-tenths of a percent in November, but the fact that prices have averaged a small decline over three months indicated that merchants were still unable to raise prices and, in fact, are being forced to offer discounts to move merchandise.
Medical care rose a modest two-tenths of a percent, bringing the three-month compound annual rate down to 4.8 percent and the 12-month rate down to 5.5 percent. For the year that ended in November 1992, medical inflation was 6.9 percent.
Inflation was moderate in the categories of entertainment and other goods, with the former marked by 1.6 percent higher fees for participant sports.
 
 
 
Higher Average Earnings
 When the Consumer Price Index is divided into just two categories, commodities rose two-tenths of a percent, down substantially from October, while services rose three-tenths of a percent for the second straight month.
In a related report, the Labor Department calculated that real average weekly earnings moved up three-tenths of a percent in November but were unchanged over 12 months.

HEADLINE: Italy's Communists Come In From the Cold

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Their name has changed, their ideology has died and no one is talking class struggle anymore. But after decades of waiting for power, Italy's onetime Communists seem finally to reckon their moment has come -- too late to storm the barricades but, maybe, just in time to benefit from a different revolution.
Through the years of the cold war, Italy's Communist Party -- the largest in Western Europe -- was kept out of national office by an alliance of centrist parties who helped themselves to vast and illicit patronage from the state coffers. 
 Now, those same centrist parties -- the Christian Democrats, the Socialists and their allies to the left and right -- are in disgrace because of their involvement in Italy's vast corruption scandals and kickback schemes.
Even Achille Ochetto, leader of the Democratic Party of the Left, as the former Communists are now known, was questioned today by Milan magistrates investigating the corruption scandal. While he has admitted that his followers may have made "possible errors of judgment" in the country's huge graft, investigators have yet to bring any major charges of corruption on the ex-Communists.
The lack until now of formal charges against the former Communists in the nearly two-year-old corruption scandal helped them at the polls in last weekend's municipal elections in which they scored a major success. And as a result of their victory in those elections, the ex-Communists have emerged as the favorites in the national elections expected next spring.
Renamed and reconstituted, however, the Communists who swept into city halls across Italy last weekend are not the Communists of old. That much was evident on Monday night when Mr. Occhetto announced that the party's priorities in any national government would be to continue economic austerity, pursue plans to sell off state industries to private buyers and thus cut back the huge public debt -- platform planks that hardly smack of spendthrift socialism.
"From the political point of view, very little remains from the old days," said Salvatore Veca, a left-wing author and professor of political philosophy at the University of Florence. "There's a complete acceptance of the role of the market. In the United States, the position would be typically liberal."
In the elections last weekend, the former Communists and their allies won the mayoral contests in five big cities as well as in a slew of other municipalities, defeating both neo-Fascists and the federalist Northern League. Moreover, the Christian Democrats and their allies, virtually obliterated by the corruption scandal, were barely to be seen.
The dominance of the former Communists in the election last weekend was only the latest stage of a long process of change that began more than 20 years ago and culminated in 1991 when, after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the Communist Party of Italy changed its name to the Democratic Party of the Left.
"The change of name came at the end of a long process of self-analysis," said Prof. Gianni Vattimo of the University of Turin. "What it did was to distance the party from Marxism."
"The ideology has all disappeared," said Pietro Folena, a former Communist legislator in Sicily.
 
No Turning Back
 What that means for the former Communists is that there is no turning back to the class struggles of the past, particularly when the future is dictated by free market economics, not ideological division. "This is a party of order and efficiency, not radical transformation," Professor Vattimo said.
The view is not universal. For many Italians, the renamed party still represents a hazardous leap into the unknowns of left-wing politics.
"I, like many others, am afraid of the left," said Alessandra Mussolini, a candidate of the neo-Fascist Italian Social Movement who lost to a former Communist candidate last weekend in the race for the mayorship of Naples.
As evidence of such fears, right-wing politicians point to the strong showing of Ms. Mussolini's neo-Fascist party in Rome and Naples and the stranglehold of the conservative Northern League in parts of northern Italy.
While the former Communists emerged as victors, they did not win alone, securing their dominance only by forging alliances with other parties, notably Greens and in some cases hard-line ex-Communists and, in Trieste, even Christian Democrats.
It is partly to keep the so-called progressive alliance intact until national elections, that the former Communists are laying so much stress on their re-packaging as a responsible and credible candidate for government.
When, during the two-stage mayoral vote, financial markets took a dive on news of former Communist successes, Mr. Occhetto went out of his way to try to calm them. And, when the extent of the former Communist victory emerged this week, the markets responded in kind: the lira firmed and stocks rose.
The problem, though, is how far the former Communists can go without alienating its supporters with such policies as privatization, which automatically cost jobs. It is questionable, too, whether the progressive alliance will maintain support at its current level if a credible, conservative alternative emerges between now and next spring.
 
The Fringe of Power
 Italy's politics have always seemed to upend European stereotypes. While the Communists have not been part of a national government since the immediate postwar years, they ran some cities and labor unions and exerted powerful influence behind the scenes.
Defeated by the Christian Democrats in parliamentary elections in 1948, in which the United States played a behind-the-scenes role, the Communists were the main opposition party for the next 15 years. In the mid-1970's, they won over one third of the votes in national elections, running a close second to the Christian Democrats, and supported a minority government through their abstention on parliamentary votes in exchange for a voice in policy matters.
And, while the Christian Democrats ruled as a conservative force, their extensive spending on social programs and their penchant for state control of large sectors of the economy seemed more to resemble policies traditionally associated with the left.
Thus, if they do come to national power, the former Communists will inherit a topsy-turvy economy saddled with Europe's biggest debt and burdened by a kind of domestic protectionism that shielded private business from harsh competition. And it will fall to former Communists to privatize state enterprises, which provided the source of patronage for their conservative adversaries.
"In a sense, on the one hand we want a free market for the first time, while on the other hand we certainly have social concerns," said Gian Giacomo Migone, a senior legislator from the Democratic Party of the Left.
"What we have in mind is a government in this transitional period that does several things -- balance the budget, defend the lira and set in motion the economy to create more jobs," he said. "Of course, we would not do this like Margaret Thatcher or Ronald Reagan."

HEADLINE: Zagreb Journal;
Feminist Gadfly Unappreciated in Her Own Land

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia

 BODY:
The ornate turn-of-the-century Gradska Kavana on the central square here is one of those cafes that define the style of Central Europe. The lives of nations, and sometimes their fates, are played out at such places, and the relationships between regular patrons are dense and multi-layered.
Like many Croatian intellectuals, Slavenka Drakulic considers the Gradska Kavana a second home, and on a recent morning she made her way to an outdoor table with the confidence of a regular patron. She noticed an old acquaintance, a man she has known since she was a teen-ager, and acknowledged him with a smile and a wave. 
 The man ostentatiously turned his back, letting Miss Drakulic know that he is among those who consider her a virtual traitor to her homeland.
One cannot imagine a self-possessed figure like Miss Drakulic losing her poise, and the rebuff had no visible effect on her.
 
'I'm Not Popular'
 "I'm more popular outside Croatia," she said with a shrug after ordering a Coca-Cola. "I'm known here, but I'm not popular. We are living through a moment when if you're attacked in the press, people don't want to talk to you."
A founder of Croatian feminism, Miss Drakulic, 44, has become something of a literary and political sensation beyond the Balkans. Two collections of her essays have been widely translated and are selling briskly in many countries, including the United States. She has become a favorite guest on television and radio talk shows, reaching a level of international celebrity beyond what anyone here could have imagined a few years ago. Her writings and public appearances have made her perhaps the world's best-known Croat after President Franjo Tudjman.
The contrast between the two could not be greater. Mr. Tudjman is a dour, patriarchal nationalist who is uncomfortable outside his Balkan habitat. Miss Drakulic is vivacious, outspoken, freewheeling, cosmopolitan and fiercely individualist.
These qualities are not much appreciated in Croatia. A Zagreb newspaper columnist has asserted that Miss Drakulic is a "cheap and defective" writer who took up feminism as a way to "rape Croatia." Another scorned her anti-nationalist views and asked, "How can you call anyone a moral writer who, at a time when her people are suffering the most terrible tragedies, cannot identify with their interests either emotionally or intellectually?"
 
Denies Being a Subversive
 Partly to escape what she considers a psychologically oppressive environment, Miss Drakulic now spends only part of her time in Zagreb. But she denies being a subversive.
"I don't like to be pushed into the category of 'dissident,' because I don't think I am one," she said. "I am only reacting against a society that does not value the individual. People here have the feeling, inherited from Communism, that you should go along with everyone else, not stick out, do and say what everybody else does and says. They can't stand that someone is different, because being different or beating the system shows that the system can be beaten. I say and do what I want, and that is incredibly annoying to people here."
She continued: "Because I criticize official policies, and because I'm a feminist, people here say I'm a traitor, which is ridiculous. This Government considers people who write or speak against the Government to be anti-Croatian. This is a terrible manipulation, just like in Communist times.
"This Government is very much like a one-party system. If you want to have an important position in society, in schools, universities, social services, the economy, you have to be in the ruling party."
In 1979 Miss Drakulic and a handful of other female journalists and intellectuals founded Yugoslavia's first feminist group. She traveled to other Communist countries seeking, not always successfully, to find women who shared her frustrations and ambitions. She gradually made contact with Western editors, and her articles about the plight of women in Eastern Europe began appearing in the United States and England.
In this period she also wrote two novels, one of them based on her struggle with illness, in which she spent six years on dialysis and received a kidney transplant in 1986.
 
Feminist Critique of Marxism
 As Communism began to collapse in the late 1980's, Miss Drakulic's popularity abroad began to grow. She collected a series of her essays into a book called "How We Survived Communism and Even Laughed," and quickly emerged as the first critic to describe the failings of Marxism from a feminist perspective. She wrote with insight and wit about such outrages as ugly clothing and shortages of toilet paper.
That book and a more recent one, "The Balkan Express," about her reaction to the Yugoslav wars, were written in English, and neither has been translated into Serbo-Croatian.
In one essay, Ms. Drakulic writes: "Just how many 'iron curtains' still exist? What are they made of? Sometimes it seems to me they are made of a material stronger than iron itself: our memories."
Some of Miss Drakulic's friends in Zagreb say they detect something banal and even fraudulent in her writings, pointing out that there never were shortages of toilet paper in the former Yugoslavia, and that her laments about crowded streetcars and tiny apartments are hardly original.
 
'Everyone Envious of Her'
 But reflecting the grudging admiration for Miss Drakulic here, a journalist who worked closely with her but did not want to be identified said: "She always had the courage to say what she thinks. She is a very strong person, and she can fight with anyone. She has a great drive for success. Everyone here is envious of her."
Neither criticism from pro-Government ideologues or the skepticism of like-minded intellectuals has slowed Miss Drakulic. She has a contract to produce a television series for the BBC, and is hoping to produce others for American and Canadian networks. An Austrian foundation has given her a grant to research the lives of children of Communist leaders.
Miss Drakulic has not abandoned fiction, and is completing a novel that she describes as "a love story that ends with cannibalism."
"It's set in New York," she confided as she finished her Coke. "New York is the perfect place for a story about cannibalism."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Mark Trading But Gains Against the Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar weakened against the German mark yesterday but gained ground against the Japanese yen after a small increase in consumer prices in November tempered inflation fears.
"The dollar came down after the data was released because the market may have baked in a somewhat higher number," said Richard Koss, director of foreign exchange sales for the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. 
 Consumer prices edged up two-tenths of 1 percent last month as a modest rise in food and beverage prices was offset by a steep fall in energy costs, the Labor Department reported.
The consumer price data, along with Thursday's report showing producer prices unchanged in November, kept inflation fears on the back-burner.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.6960 marks, from 1.7055 marks on Thursday.
The dollar's slide was halted by technical support at 1.69 marks and by the report that consumer confidence as measured by the University of Michigan jumped to 87.7 for December from 81.2 in November.
"The market is still biased toward an up move in the dollar because it's optimistic about growth prospects in the U.S. versus European economies," Mr. Koss said. "But it's unable to move up because many people are already long and it's the year-end."
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery, the most actively traded futures contract, gained 50 cents, to $384.90 an ounce. The Republic National Bank quoted spot gold at $383 an ounce, up $1.
Currency dealers continued to watch world trade talks as international negotiators worked to conclude the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade before the Dec. 15 deadline, when President Clinton's fast-track negotiating authority from Congress runs out.
The dollar rose to 109.20 yen in New York, from 108.66 yen on Thursday, as several factors weighed on the Japanese currency. The quarterly tankan report on Japanese business conditions, released yesterday, suggested a poor economic outlook, as expected.
Moreover, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's difficulties in the wake of political wrangling over the volatile rice import issue were eroding confidence in Japan's Government.

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Issues Gain As Other Averages Fall

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The stock market turned in another good news, bad news performance yesterday, as blue-chip issues rose to new records, while broader averages continued to slide.
An unexpected jump in the University of Michigan's survey of consumer sentiment about the economy in early December, to its highest level since January, was noted by analysts and traders as the most important event of the session. 
 The news was yet another sign of continued strength in the economy, and it tended to lift stocks closely tied to turns in the economic cycle, a group that includes many of the issues in the Dow Jones industrial average.
But the report created worry in the bond market that a stronger economy and possible higher inflation might prompt the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates. Bond prices slumped and interest rates rose.
"There is concern about inflation," said Thomas Gallagher, chief trader at Oppenheimer & Company, even though reports issued yesterday and Thursday showed that through November price increases remained benign.
"But I don't think we will see any big negative reaction," in the stock market, he added. "Even though the market is acting sloppy, right now people are sitting, wishing this was the end of the year, and hoping nothing happens."
 
A Late Blue-Chip Rally
 Much of the spurt in blue-chip issues took place in the last half-hour of trading.
At the close, the Dow was up 10.89 points, to 3,740.67, surpassing the previous record 3,734.53 set on Wednesday. On Thursday, the Dow closed at 3,729.78. Volume on the Big Board slowed to 245.6 million shares, from 287.6 million on Thursday.
But the broader averages moved lower.
The S.& P. 500 index dipped a quarter of a point, to 463.93; the American Stock Exchange composite index lost 1.03 points, to 466.28, and the Nasdaq's composite index of over-the-counter issues fell three quarters of a point, to 760.74.
Much of the increase in the Dow was a result of a spurt in oil stocks, which rose yesterday after spot oil prices lifted off five-year lows.
Mobil jumped 2 1/8, to 76 1/8; Chevron rose 5/8, to 86 5/8; Exxon was up 5/8, to 62 7/8, and Texaco rose 1 1/2, to 64 3/8. With the exception of Mobil, all are included in the Dow Jones average.
Stocks with fortunes that are tied to a rebounding economy, a group that includes chemical, paper and steel companies, as well as the automotive sector, also did well.
Chrysler climbed 3 1/8, to 56 1/8, after Salomon Brothers raised earnings estimates for the company and said its market share could grow significantly.
 
Technology Stocks Slump
 Trading in Borden was also heavy. The stock rose 5/8, to 18 3/4, as investors reacted to news, announced late Thursday, that the chairman and chief executive of the company had resigned.
However, with the exception of the International Business Machines Corporation, technology stocks continued to slump.
Shares of I.B.M. jumped 1 5/8, to 55 1/4, in heavy trading after Dean Witter raised its profit forecasts for the company, noting healthy sales of personal computers and an unexpectedly good market for mainframe computers.
But Intel fell 1 3/4, to 56 1/4; Apple Computer lost 1 3/4, to 28 1/4, and Motorola dropped 2 1/8, to 88 7/8.
One of the session's biggest losers was Kurzweil Applied Intelligence, which fell 5 1/2, to 15, on the Nasdaq market. On Thursday, the company reported disappointing quarterly earnings.
"In my view, the reason the market has stalled out is the belief the economy is not yet strong enough, despite the good numbers, to easily absorb any rise in short-term interest rates," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.

HEADLINE: Bond Rates Up Despite Low Inflation

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Interest rates rose yesterday despite a Government report that consumer inflation remained subdued last month.
Analysts said Treasury prices retreated yesterday after an initial jump largely because of technical trading strategies, which had a disproportionate impact in light volume. Also prompting selling was a University of Michigan survey showing a jump in consumer confidence in early December. 
 The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond fell 22/32 of a point, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.20 percent, from 6.15 percent on Thursday.
Prices of shorter-term securities posted smaller losses.
The Labor Department reported that consumer prices rose modestly in November, restrained by declining energy costs. The Consumer Price Index increased two-tenths of a percent, half the October increase. The core of inflation -- excluding the volatile energy and food sectors -- rose by three-tenths of a percent.
 
Both Figures Expected
 Both figures were largely expected and did not change the general view that inflation was running at just below 3 percent this year.
The Labor Department's wholesale inflation report, issued a day earlier, also substantiated predictions that the economy's growth was not arousing a worrisome rate of inflation.
Yesterday's inflation report encouraged some initial buying, but the gains were short-lived as investors reacted to a University of Michigan survey showing consumers grew more optimistic about economic conditions in early December.
According to market analysts who saw the survey, which is not released publicly, the university's consumer sentiment index increased to 87.7, from 81.2 in November.
That prompted speculation that rising consumer confidence could accelerate economic growth and aggravate inflation pressures early next year.
Lending to that view was a jump in oil prices yesterday. The price rise led to a sharp increase in the Commodity Research Bureau index, a daily measure of overall commodity price changes that is considered a harbinger of inflation trends.
 
Technical Influence Cited
 Traders said the market's weakness also appeared to result from technical influences related to a decline in bond futures contracts, which are like other commodities contracts that allow speculators to bet on the future direction of prices.
"There was no real significance to the price action," said Matthew Alexy, market strategist for the First Boston Corporation. "The move we saw today is well within the realm of the trading range over the last couple of weeks."
Elsewhere in Treasury bond trading, short-term securities fell 3/32 point to 5/32 point and intermediate maturities fell 5/16 point to 9/16 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, fell 4.86, to 1,307.35.

HEADLINE: Migration of the 'Plain People' Revitalizes Farming

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PENN YAN, N.Y.

 BODY:
While farmland lies fallow in much of rural New York, an influx of Mennonite families is making agriculture a viable way of life once more in the central part of the state.
"Yates and Seneca Counties are the only two counties in the state to show an increase in the number of farms," said Charlie Elrod, a dairy specialist with Cornell Cooperative Extension. "That's entirely due to the Mennonites." 
 Many of them come from Lancaster County in Pennsylvania, famed for its population of "plain people." The greatest catalyst for their migration has been the price of farmland, which is much cheaper here.
While most of the Mennonites run dairies, some raise hogs, beef cattle and vegetable crops. Still others have opened support businesses, where they make harnesses and furniture, build and repair buggies or sell bulk food, shoes and dry goods.
 
Tripling Numbers
 Leroy Sensenig, a Mennonite who has a sewing-machine repair business, publishes a map pinpointing the home farms of his fellow church members in Yates County and neighboring Schuyler and Ontario Counties. He said that the influx began spontaneously in 1974 with two families, and more followed, with the population tripling in the last 10 years.
The April 1993 edition of Mr. Sensenig's map shows 186 Mennonite households, all affiliated with the Groffdale Conference of churches, a traditional group, although most local estimates put the present number of all Mennonites in the area at more than 200 families.
The community comprises perhaps 1,000 people, served by four Mennonite churches and 11 parochial schools. More than 20 families make up the nearby Crystal Valley conference, a less conservative group whose members drive cars, and several other area households are Horning Mennonites, also a less conservative group.
As one of the first Mennonite farmers to move to central New York from Lancaster County, Pa., Amos Horning, 76, helped many others follow. He was reluctant to draw conclusions about why his people are succeeding as farmers when many non-Mennonite farms are struggling.
"I don't want to brag or nothing," he said, "but maybe it's a little smaller way. Some of these extremely big operations may be too much. If you try to have everything at once, it costs a lot to operate."
Jim Capron, a field crops specialist with the extension, agreed the Mennonite farms were succeeding. "Stand on a hill in Penn Yan looking south and count the new silos," he said.
 
Lower Labor Costs
 Like Mr. Horning, Mr. Capron suggested that the Mennonites' economic success came from things other than the way they farm. The Mennonites do not necessarily differ from non-Mennonites in their use of purchased feed, seed, fertilizers or herbicides. Many use tractors.
But, said Mr. Capron, "If you buy $16,000 pickups and $50,000 tractors and choppers, you have to have a bigger business to support that. They continue to thrive and do well because they accept a simpler life style than the rest of us."
The Mennonites' labor costs are also a factor. "Every person on those type of farms is productively busy -- whether they're 4 or 40. Their labor costs are low because the workers are kids -- they're family," Mr. Capron said. "It's difficult for the existing community of farmers to compete."
Furthermore, he noted, the profitable sale of a Pennsylvania farm also meant a sound financial base in New York, allowing the Mennonites to remodel barns and invest in some fundamental agricultural improvements. "They've taken some poor farms that needed tile drainage, lime, crop rotation," he said, "and now that land's growing some pretty decent crops."
 
Buying More for Less

 Nancy Augustine, a real-estate agent in Lancaster County, Pa., whose grandparents were Mennonites, said a farm of 70 to 100 acres near Lancaster could cost $5,000 to $15,000 an acre.
"When you pay $15,000 an acre for a farm, you're going to have a hard time making that pay," she said.
Jim Moon, a Penn Yan real-estate agent, said a similar farm in sparsely populated Yates County would sell for $500 to $1,500 an acre. Often, he said, a Mennonite farmer who has sold a farm of 50 to 70 acres in Pennsylvania at a profit will buy a 200-acre spread in New York, then divide it for several family members.
As the Mennonites' numbers have grown, the prevailing local rumor has been that, through their strong church affiliations, the Mennonites did not pay taxes. But in answer to those rumors, Mr. Moon, the real-estate agent, said: "Tell me a tax they don't pay. They pay a lot of school tax dollars, but don't ask for schooling for their kids. They're building bigger and better buildings and barns, which adds to the property tax base. They use the roads, but they probably don't beat them up like we do -- and you won't see them down at the social services office looking for welfare."
The Mennonites are good neighbors, too, he said, adding, "If you have a problem, they're probably going to be the first ones there."
Mr. Moon cited the Mennonites' participation in the booming, six-year-old Windmill farm and craft market, a 26-acre cornucopia of farm produce, flea market finds and food, which draws thousands of visitors every Saturday from May to December and has brought dozens of new jobs to the areas. "I don't believe it would have happened without them," he said.
At the Penn Yan branch of the National Bank of Geneva, Jeff Franklin, assistant cashier and agricultural loan officer, said the Mennonites' farm accounts were in excellent shape. Although he acknowledged antipathy from some non-Mennonite farmers toward the newcomers, he said the Mennonites' presence was good for the area. "Economically," he said, "it's terrific."

HEADLINE: BOXING;
De La Hoya Puts Managers On the Unemployment Line

BYLINE: By TOM FRIEND, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Oscar De La Hoya has a new manager: himself. The former Olympic boxing champion, whose professional career is suddenly in knots, surfaced today with a cast on his left wrist and a game plan he utilized in the amateur ranks. It is called "All in the Family."
Charging that his former managers -- the New Yorkers Robert Mittleman and Steve Nelson -- were tardy with bonus payments and had practically moved into his house, De La Hoya officially fired them, in public, this morning. 
 "I'm in full control," he said at a news conference staged next to a Christmas tree.
The 20-year-old fighter was flanked by his father, Joel, and his childhood trainer, Robert Alcazar, and said he intended to restore the entire team that helped him win a 1992 gold medal -- right on down to his cook. He said he would never again allow outsiders to interfere with his career decisions, although in the last week he has established ties with a criminal attorney from Redondo Beach, Calif., and apparently will retain Bob Arum as his promoter.

 
 
March Fight Still Scheduled
 A March 5 bout against Jimmy Bredahl for the World Boxing Organization junior-lightweight title is still on, as is a $7 million-plus deal with HBO.
That is, assuming De La Hoya's left wrist cooperates. De La Hoya revealed today -- others are suspicious he is being overdramatic -- that he aggravated an old ligament injury while punching the heavy bag last week. It was the injury, he said, that forced him to pull out of last Thursday night's fight against Jesus Vidal Concepcion at the Paramount in Madison Square Garden. The managerial rift, he added, had "nothing to do" with the withdrawal.
Arum, who was the promoter of the bout, has called the injury "nonsense," and Mittleman, who was still a member of De La Hoya's camp as of last week, said this afternoon: "There was nothing wrong with him. He was punching the bag with both hands hard."
De La Hoya could have motivation for citing the wrist injury. As soon as De La Hoya pulled out of Thursday's bout, Randy Gordon, commissioner of the New York State Athletic Commission, threatened him with suspension. "The wrist thing came up after the fact, after the suspension threat," Mittleman said.
But De La Hoya and his new attorney, Michael Norris, are sticking to the wrist story, and Norris today even read a statement from a Los Angeles orthopedist, Dr. Kathleen Godzik. She said De La Hoya must wear the cast for six weeks and has relayed that information to Gordon in New York.
Not much else was certain this afternoon. If you believe De La Hoya, he was an impressionable teenager who was overwhelmed by a $1 million offer made to him by Mittleman and Nelson after the Olympics. But according to De La Hoya, the managers "broke their promises," tried to win him over by going through his father and generally hounded him.
The two managers, according to a person close to De La Hoya, answered the telephone at his house and intercepted letters mailed directly to him. When Mittleman moved a mile away from De La Hoya's home in Montebello, Calif., De La Hoya was said to have been beside himself. He bought a cellular telephone so he could make unmonitored calls.
"It bothered me a great deal," De La Hoya said of Mittleman's move to the neighborhood. "Because he was always at my father's house, talking to him, putting things in his head. It wasn't right. It wasn't right for Mittleman to be doing that. I guess what they wanted to do is get to him, so my dad could get to me. But I'll be 21 in February, and I can make my own decisions now."

 
 If you believe Mittleman and Nelson, De La Hoya is a great fighter who is in love with money and who does not know the first thing about loyalty.
"Hey, Rock Newman spends 200 days a year, 10 hours a day, with Riddock Bowe, and you don't hear Riddock complaining," Mittleman said. "But Riddock is an intelligent guy. He understands managers work for him."
Mittleman has admitted that he and Nelson had to borrow money from Arum but has maintained that they were late on bonus payments only once. The managers did give Joel De La Hoya 11 percent of their 33 percent earnings from every fight.
As for the accusation that they used Joel De La Hoya to control his son, Mittleman said: "We treated the father great; he loved us. But he's on whatever side has the money. He'll find a way to grab and steal from Oscar, too."
Joel De La Hoya, for his part, would not answer questions today, nor was it clear who hired Norris or who would buy out Mittleman and Nelson's five-year contract. Mittleman has asked for a settlement "in the millions," and De La Hoya apparently wants to pay them with money from the HBO deal -- a deal Mittleman and Nelson helped put together.
"To tell you the truth, if I get what I want, I'll be happy just to get away from the kid," Mittleman said.

HEADLINE: Canada's Health Care System Merits Copying

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your informative supplement on "The Health Debate" (Nov. 14) has generated considerable comment.
The article on the Canadian system contained a number of misleading statements. To begin with, it is not the case that health care spending in recent years is growing nearly as fast in Canada as in the United States, an assertion published elsewhere without documentation by an anti-single-payer think tank. 
 Morris Barer at the University of British Columbia, in the fall 1991 issue of Health Affairs, documented the fact that the growth in health care costs has moderated recently. In fact the average annual growth in health spending from 1971 to 1987 was 3.86 percent in Canada, and 4.18 percent in the United States. When later years are added in, Canada looks even better, and the United States worse: from 1971 to 1989, growth in Canada dropped to 3.65 percent a year, while in the United States it increased to 4.39 percent.
It is true that the federal Canadian Government, until recently controlled by conservatives, responded to the current economic recession by reducing federal transfer payments for health care to the provinces. To their credit, the provincial governments pick up the slack. Even in the face of an expansion of private insurance for services such as dental care, the public sector still pays 72 percent of health care bills (a minor drop from 77 percent in 1975).
Reductions in services are also misstated. There has been no change in the Ontario Health Insurance Plan's billing policies for laboratory tests: they still cannot charge more than the allowed rate for covered services, which include diagnostic laboratory tests. It was always the case the labs could bill privately for tests that are not covered, because they are considered harmful or unnecessary.
Similarly, like virtually every American health insurance plan, the Canadian system never covered employment-related physical examinations. In the past, some physicians billed the Government for these exams by identifying them as different procedures that were covered; the Government is now cracking down on that practice. However, this cannot be characterized as a reduction in benefits.
Contrary to the article, Ontario has not increased patient payments for drug prescriptions, coverage available primarily to those over 65. This option, once considered, has been flatly and publicly rejected.
It is true that the system has stopped payment for electrolysis, which uses an electrical device to remove unwanted hair. I challenge you to find a United States health plan that covers this or any other cosmetic service, or an American consumer who would support such coverage.
There are certainly problems with every health care system, including Canada's. What is remarkable is the tremendous effectiveness of the Canadian health system in identifying problems, holding them up for public scrutiny and coming up with popular solutions, even during times of economic hardship. This is reflected, as you accurately note, in Canadians' great pride in their system, and their nearly unanimous support for it.
As the chief sponsor of single-payer legislation in the United States Senate, the American Health Security Act, I suggest that we could learn much from our northern neighbors.
 
PAUL DAVID WELLSTONE
U.S. Senator from Minnesota
Washington, Dec. 2, 1993
