HEADLINE: Mickey Kantor

BYLINE: By Keith Bradsher; Keith Bradsher reports on international trade for The New York Times.

 BODY:
There are several things about Mickey Kantor that his friends have learned to accept.
His competitiveness. "If I took Mickey fishing with me," says Bob Doochin, a close childhood friend, "he made everything into a damn contest. If I didn't stop him, before you knew it he'd be counting the size of the fish, the number of the fish." 
 His temper. When he was an eighth-grader coaching a seventh-grade basketball team, a penalty so enraged Kantor he threw his shoe at the referee. His team was assessed a technical foul and lost the game. Kantor readily acknowledges his lack of sportsmanship. "I don't like to lose," he says. "I don't believe in the game for the game's sake. It's not interesting to me to go out and play a game for the sake of exercise."
His tendency to speak first and think later. Last February, it was widely reported that the Mexican state of Yucatan had helped set up a fund to buy American companies and move them there to take advantage of its low wages. Kantor quickly sought to remove this potential threat to the North American Free Trade Agreement. Without consulting his aides or the Treasury Department, he informed the Senate Finance Committee he would try to reach an agreement with Mexico barring such maneuvers. Advised by his aides that many state governments in the United States were also luring investors, Kantor quietly abandoned the idea.
These qualities show a man so driven and self-assured he has no time for social niceties and no compunctions about making a fool of himself. Armed with that bristling confidence, he has taken charge of setting the rules for the way America does business with the world even though he has scant academic or professional expertise on international trade.
He has approached trade not as an economist or diplomat but as a politically savvy lawyer seeking to strike deals for his client, the President. These deals have forced Kantor to break ranks with longtime allies in organized labor and have confused foreign countries accustomed to free trade rhetoric, if not free trade actions, from the United States.
The first critical item on his agenda was winning Congressional approval of Nafta, which will rewrite the rules for 27 percent of the nation's international commerce and gradually eliminate taxes on imports and other trade barriers between Canada, Mexico and the United States. As grueling as the battle over the regional trade agreement was, it probably counts as a warm-up for Kantor's next big challenge: the Dec. 15 showdown over strengthening international free trade rules.
Free trade regulations for most of the world's commerce in manufactured goods have already been set by GATT, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The regulations outlaw limits on the quantity of imports, restrict taxes on trade and prohibit countries from discriminating against imports. Representatives from 116 nations have been holding talks to reduce import taxes even further and to expand free trade agreements to cover agricultural goods and services. This would stimulate the global economy because free trade allows each country to specialize in products it makes most efficiently.
Kantor may be short on international trade experience but he is long on clout. He has been a friend of Hillary Rodham Clinton since the late 1970's when both served on the board of the Legal Services Corporation, which oversees legal assistance for the poor. And he was Bill Clinton's 1992 campaign chairman. Before taking the trade job, he had been a lawyer at Manatt, Phelps & Phillips, based in Los Angeles. Liberal Democratic politicians across the country routinely enlisted the help of the firm's senior partners in raising financial and political support among the affluent communities of Beverly Hills and Hollywood. Kantor met them all.
As the nation's top trade official, Kantor essentially looks at trade issues in terms of how many votes they would win in Congress or the next election. He brings to his job a lawyer's gift for memorizing the key points of a complicated case, as well as the shrewd negotiating skills of someone who spent almost two decades wheeling and dealing with California regulators on behalf of a succession of large corporations. The clearest instance of his penchant for horse-trading, even though it meant undermining the Administration's free trade credo, came during the final weeks before Congressional approval of Nafta last month.
Kantor had insisted in March to the Senate Finance Committee that special deals could not be negotiated for industries in key Congressional districts. He specifically told the committee he would not renegotiate the pact's provisions on sugar. But in the last two weeks before the House Nafta vote, he struck deals with at least a dozen industries that had opposed it, including sugar producers. He signed letters of understanding with the Mexican Government that reinterpreted the free trade pact's sugar and orange juice provisions and that would shield the American sugar and citrus industries from Mexican competition. This helped persuade several Florida and Louisiana lawmakers to support the agreement. Although consumer advocates like Ralph Nader criticized Kantor for restricting American access to cheap Mexican sugar, the Trade Representative defended his letters as necessary improvements.
Kantor's sharp tongue and legendary temper have alienated many. And his no-nonsense pragmatism has outraged some of the people he worked with and befriended when he was a young Legal Services lawyer closely allied with labor. More than any other issue, free trade separates New Democrats like President Clinton from the liberal wing of the Democratic Party and its bedrock support among unions.
Evelyn Dubrow, vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and a friend since the late 1960's, is appalled that Kantor fought for Nafta over the unions' objections. "I'm frankly disappointed in Mickey, who was a very liberal, concerned person when he was working for prepaid Legal Services," she says. "He is making a great mistake in not recognizing what Nafta will do to the high-skill, low-wage workers of this country."
Kantor, however, sees no contradiction in being a lifelong friend of labor and pushing for Nafta. He contends Nafta will help American workers by creating jobs. "One thing that always strikes me," he says, "any poll you ever see about trade, the American people by fairly large margins think we always do worse by trade agreements, in terms of jobs and the economy, than better. We've got a long way to go to convince the American people that we will act in their interest."
Those who have worked with Kantor and his predecessors say that his deal-making ability has allowed unusually quick progress in the GATT talks this year. Not tied to free trade ideas, he has shown a willingness to compromise on the last two Administrations' more ambitious demands for trade liberalization. The result has been a series of deals on everything from pharmaceuticals to distilled spirits, even though disputes remain on such issues as steel subsidies, the licensing of computer chips and the creation of a new organization to regulate international trade. This deal making has its price: It is more likely that the final agreement on Wednesday, if there is one, will be less far-reaching than what economists have hoped for.
CIVIL SERVANTS AT THE office of the Trade Representative were stunned when Kantor took over. His predecessor in the Bush Administration, Carla A. Hills, is one of the Republican Party's smartest lawyers. She was known in the agency for reading every memo thoroughly, highlighting numerous passages and asking so many questions that her aides felt like first-year law students.
Although Kantor displays similar energy, he is her opposite in many ways. She prizes formality; he does not. "This guy barely read briefing memos," says an official who has worked with both Hills and Kantor. "You'd go in there and he'd say: 'What are the big issues? What are the politics? Thanks.' " At interagency meetings and Congressional hearings, Kantor quickly developed a reputation for rambling comments that strung together a lot of facts and statistics with little analysis.
Over the last 10 months, Kantor has become more conversant in trade issues, although he remains the inveterate politician. Many working in the Trade Representative's office now admire Kantor's willingness to trust them with the fine print, contending that Hills's concern with detail made it harder for her to compromise.
Kantor's pronouncements on trade policy have also been more combative than Hills's. Early in a dispute he has been more ready to threaten trade sanctions. Although global trade war in the early 1930's is widely blamed for worsening the Great Depression, Kantor believes that the odds of a recurrence are very long because of changes in the global economy. "I can't imagine rational, reasonable people getting themselves into that position, given the extraordinary interdependence," he says. "We're too interconnected."
But despite the repeated threats of sanctions, so far he hasn't imposed any. The resulting combination of bluster and inaction has confused foreign trading partners. Foreign trade negotiators and even some American officials complain that it is often hard to predict Kantor's position on any given day from what he said the day before. Asked whether he does this to keep negotiating opponents off balance, Kantor cites a Chicago Bears halfback in the 1960's who was known for his broken-field running. "Let me just say that Gale Sayers was a great runner, and he did not find the shortest distance between two points was a straight line."
Soon after taking office, he threatened to limit bidding by European companies for Federal contracts unless the European Community canceled its new rules on public works contracts that hurt American providers of turbines and telephone switching equipment. On April 21, the European Community agreed to cancel some of the new rules. For the first time since the days of the Marshall Plan, Europe opened its market for power-generating turbines to full competition from American companies. Kantor, in turn, agreed to narrow American sanctions, but kept a few because the community did not agree to open its telephone switching market. The final settlement required no knowledge of trade law. Instead, it took the ability to build relationships with negotiating opponents and to divide the problem in new ways that would allow at least part of it to be solved.
WHEN MICKEY KANTOR TALKS, HE chops the air with huge, misshapen hands. Severe arthritis has swollen his knuckles to the size of small walnuts. The arthritis started 17 years ago -- he is now 54 -- and keeps him in nearly constant pain. For years, he countered the pain by running, swimming and playing baseball, basketball and tennis. The pain can nearly paralyze his hands and feet, especially in times of stress, but he never complains, even to close friends or family.
And there have been times of trauma. His first wife, Valerie, was killed in a plane crash in 1978. (Kantor is now married to Heidi Schulman, a former NBC news correspondent.) His elder son, Russell, died in a car crash in 1982, when he was 16. Soon after the death of his mother, in the late 1980's, his older sister, Sonia, was fatally injured when she fell and hit her head. This summer, two days after he concluded labor and environmental agreements with Canada and Mexico, Kantor was hurt in a freak accident. Out on a hotel rooftop to watch a fireworks display, he fell down an unmarked air shaft. He has had to wear a back brace since and will not be able to run again until next month.
Sports were important when he was growing up in Nashville. He, two brothers and his sister called their grandfather, Isadore, the Commissioner. Isadore Kantor lived with the family for many years. By day, he presided over the backyard baseball league at their two-story suburban home. At night, he regaled his grandchildren with stories of life as a bookbinder, union activist and Socialist in Brooklyn. Mickey's first exposure to current events came from his grandfather's political arguments with his father, Henry, who owned a furniture store across an alley from the Grand Ole Opry. "The big fight in the family," he recalls, "was between the Socialist Party and the Communist Party."
Mickey was an indifferent student. At Vanderbilt University, he played varsity baseball and seldom studied for his undergraduate major in business and economics. "In school, he was interested in nothing but athletics and girls," his father says with a sigh. The big change came during law school at Georgetown, after a stint as a Navy supply officer, when he met and married Valerie Woods, a fellow student who made him study every night while she fixed dinner.
Kantor's early support for workers was reinforced when he went to work in Florida. As a lawyer for the Office of Legal Services, he spent two years defending destitute migrant workers. After working on George McGovern's Presidential campaign in 1972, he moved to California and worked on Alan Cranston's successful run for the Senate in 1974. He then joined Manatt, Phelps. The change in legal clients, he says, was motivated partly by financial need and partly by a desire to have a job that allowed him to set his own hours and work on various political and civic causes.
During his 17 years in Los Angeles as a lawyer and corporate lobbyist, he worked on three more unsuccessful Democratic Presidential campaigns. In the Carter Administration, he served on the Legal Services board and met Hillary Clinton. He became a regular visitor to the Governor's Mansion in Little Rock in the 1980's and was one of the first people to join the Bill Clinton campaign in 1991.
As campaign chairman, Kantor showed the same tendency to steamroller friends and foes that he now exhibits in the trade office. His conduct in scheduling the campaign debates with President Bush helped solidify his reputation as the man nobody wanted for a colleague. At the three-day bargaining meetings, Kantor repeatedly threatened to walk out if the Republican team did not meet his demands, reminding them at every turn that President Bush was trailing by as many as 17 points in the polls. Near the end of the sessions, Kantor was pugnacious even toward Jack Quinn, a fellow Democratic negotiator who is now chief of staff for Vice President Al Gore.
"We were getting close to a deal," recalls a participant in the negotiating sessions. "Kantor was holding out on one point, and Jack began to speak. He slammed his hand down on the table and said, 'Jack, not now. I mean it!' I thought it was a gratuitous thing to do, particularly to someone on your own side. I don't know of anyone after the negotiations who had any desire to spend time with Kantor."
Kantor says the outburst was necessary because he wanted to move to another subject before the Republican negotiators could rethink their decision to allow a town hall debate with questions by everyday Americans. As it turned out, Clinton looked comfortable chatting with the guests in this format. President Bush seemed wooden.
For a while after the election, it appeared unlikely that Kantor would have a role in the new Administration, much less the prominent place at the President's side that he expected. He won the trade slot on Christmas Eve, in the final batch of Cabinet appointments, after organizing a successful economic conference for the President-elect.
MICKEY KANTOR disdains labels for his trade policy. "I'm not a theologian and don't intend to be," he says. "I think my job is to be an advocate, coordinator, facilitator, spokesperson and negotiator but not a theologian -- I'm secular when it comes to trade."
In an Administration that seeks long-range solutions for the nation's economic problems, he has no vision of a national trade strategy and no plans to develop one. "I think visionary is an overblown term -- I'll do what the President asks me to do," he says.
He started his term as the nemesis of free traders and the darling of protectionists and advocates of managed trade. His strong criticisms of Japanese trade barriers endeared him to labor activists and members of Congress who have waited for years for a trade confrontation with Tokyo. But after the inconclusive Tokyo economic summit in July, Nafta became the main trade issue and Kantor emerged as one of its most prominent defenders. Free traders began warming to him. Representative Marcy Kaptur, an Ohio Democrat who welcomed Kantor's tough stance toward Japan, became one of his most outspoken critics. She accused him of having been beguiled by corporate lobbyists.
Kantor's admirers in Congress and the Administration believe he has neither sold out nor served free trade but has found a middle ground. His detractors contend that he has lost an opportunity to put a fresh stamp on American trade policies that have changed little over the last two decades, despite widening trade deficits.
Kantor has been more willing to argue over policies than some of his colleagues in the Clinton Administration. But he has also been willing to subordinate his agency's interests for the sake of the Administration's efforts to pursue a coordinated economic strategy. His influence in developing Administration trade policy has gradually waned. This partly reflects his lack of interest in setting long-term goals and partly reflects President Clinton's creation of the National Economic Council, headed by Robert E. Rubin. Kantor's agency heads the Trade Policy Review Group, a secretive interagency committee that set the nation's trade agenda for many years. When Carla Hills was the Trade Representative, she used her agency's chairmanship of the group to dominate trade policy. But these days, the review group has been eclipsed by the National Economic Council.
The reduced status of the trade office has hurt Kantor's repeated efforts to help his allies in organized labor on small issues. He has sided with the United Automobile Workers, for example, in unsuccessful efforts to raise taxes on imported minivans -- by reclassifying them as trucks instead of cars, thereby raising the duty from 2.5 percent to 25 percent. He has also tried to block expanded trade privileges for Nissan's operations in Tennessee. Both times, he was defeated by shifting coalitions centered on Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who has tended to follow more traditional free trade policies. This has left Kantor, the old Democrat in a New Democrat Administration, trying with mixed success to keep his relations with labor leaders cordial on the big issues.
In the aftermath of the Nafta vote, as Kantor shifts his attention to world trade, he is trying to make peace with labor. The day after the House finally approved Nafta last month, Kantor arrived at the office at his usual hour, 7 A.M. He called officials in Australia and New Zealand to discuss beef and dairy issues pending in the GATT talks. He was cheerful but uncharacteristically calm, already focused on GATT issues. As always, he was also thinking about domestic politics and his friends in organized labor. Mickey Kantor, new-old Democrat, remained, above all, a practical man of politics. He already had a mental list of union leaders to call. "They're my friends and they remained friends during this whole process. There were good conversations. We disagreed. But today's the day we begin to work together on other issues."

HEADLINE: Y(oung) A(mericans in) P(rague)

 BODY:
Is Prague to the Nineties what Paris was to the Twenties? The number of YAP's (the local acronym for Young Americans in Prague) is hard to calculate; estimates run from 4,000 to 30,000. But their presence in the pubs and clubs of this ancient brooding city has become a cultural phenomenon, one of the most visible aftershocks of the fall of Communism.
Like the American expatriates who once gathered in the cafes of the Left Bank, the YAP's have a creative bent; but it's not just the literary life they're after. For every aspiring writer drawn by the ghost of Kafka and the playwright President Vaclav Havel, there's a budding entrepreneur. Computer programmers and investment analysts crowd the Repre Klub, a popular American hangout, along with poets and screenwriters -- the Hemingways of our day. There's an American-style Laundromat (Laundry King) and an American rock band (Dope). John Bruce Shoemaker, a former journalist, has opened two bars -- the Thirsty Dog and the Martini Bar -- in a turn-of-the-century building in the historic Municipal House, Obecni Dum. Jennifer Yeager runs a catering service and sells her wares to local bakeries and restaurants. "I'm a true capitalist," she explains. "I'll bake anything people want." Scott Rogers and Marketa Janku (American-born despite her Czech-sounding name) founded the Globe, an English-language bookstore and coffeehouse favored by expats. "It's just amazing all the things I've been able to do here," Janku says. "The opportunities are what really blew me away." 
 Not every YAP is a capitalist. Katie Michel, from Gladstone, N.J., works for a nonprofit organization that operates programs in English as a second language, AIDS awareness and journalism. What unites the bohemians and the business types, the poets and Peace Corps idealists is a conviction that history -- to paraphrase T. S. Eliot -- is now, in Prague.

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
A Lincoln With an Agit-Prop Subtext

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby

 BODY:
As much as it recalls the early life of a monumental man, "Abe Lincoln in Illinois," Robert E. Sherwood's 1938 play now in gigantic revival at Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater, recalls the era in which it was written and the manner by which the Lincoln legend has been shaped. It also recalls the economics of a long-vanished Broadway theater that could support a cast of 49 actors in a play that hasn't a single production number, bare leg or specialty act.
That sort of prodigality is both instructive and entertaining in a show that evokes a lot of fascinating history, not all of it having to do with Honest Abe, the Rail-Splitter and Great Emancipator. 
 Yet this "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" is one of those theatrical experiences that are far more interesting to ponder afterward than to sit through while they are going on. It is long (nearly three and a half hours) and stately, rather like a diorama. At its best, it is endearingly naive, but it may remind you of the critic Edmund Wilson's bracingly churlish remark in "Patriotic Gore": "The cruelest thing that has happened to Lincoln since he was shot by Booth has been to fall into the hands of Carl Sandburg."
Sherwood's approach to his subject seems to depend heavily on "The Prairie Years" (1926), Sandburg's highly romantic, poeticized biography of the young Abe Lincoln as a humble backwoods prophet and savior. It's an approach that spoke directly to pre-World War II America's need to believe in the kind of benign father figure that Franklin Delano Roosevelt was fast becoming.
The depressed 1930's were a time of awful despair. They were also a time when hope was offered by militant left-wing politics and by the schemes of F.D.R.'s excitingly named, ever improvised New Deal, whose purpose was to implement the promise of the unofficial Roosevelt campaign song, "Happy Days Are Here Again."
Even Broadway responded to the fervor of the New Deal. In 1938, Sherwood, Maxwell Anderson, Sidney Howard, S. N. Behrman and Elmer Rice, mainstream writers all, who were impatient with the way the Theater Guild was handling their work, formed the Playwrights' Company. The spirit of collectivism seeped upward to spawn a commune of aristocrats.
The first Playwrights' Company production was Sherwood's passionately felt "Abe Lincoln in Illinois," which was as much about F.D.R. on the eve of World War II as it was about Lincoln facing his own call to greatness. After all, 1938 was the year of the Anschluss (when Hitler annexed Austria), of Munich and, finally, of the partition of Czechoslovakia. Possibly because of its agitprop subtext, the 1938 production was not only critically acclaimed, winning the Pulitzer among other prizes, but also hugely popular with the public.
Sherwood's Lincoln is something more than kissing kin to Sandburg's. He's a man whose life is forever changed by the untimely death of Ann Rutledge, and who, like Jesus, reluctantly sacrifices himself to greatness for the greater good.
In the Sandburg-Sherwood myths, Ann Rutledge (about whom little is really known) is a paragon of sweetness, too good to survive in this world. The fiercely ambitious Mary Todd is God's strange way of telling Abe when to git a move on, as if he had no ambitions of his own. William Herndon, who was Lincoln's law clerk and then partner in Springfield, is a firebrand abolitionist and a drunk, someone you might not think could live much beyond 30. In fact, Herndon died at the age of 73 in 1891, having written a book of memoirs that outraged the keepers of Lincoln's flame by suggesting that Lincoln was a good deal more sophisticated and neurotic than the accepted legends would allow.
Wilson's impatience was not necessarily with Sandburg's emphasis on myth (except when the myths came from Sandburg's own imagination), but with the manner by which this myth-making obscures the dark contradictions within -- and the true complexity of -- the real Lincoln. Sherwood's Lincoln is a grand variation on the figure that can be seen at Disney World where, in the Hall of Presidents, through the magic of Audio Animatronics, a mobile plastic Lincoln speaks a few words from the Lincoln canon.
The lavish Beaumont production, which makes as much use as possible of all available stage space and stage machinery, suggests a Rodgers and Hammerstein musical that once was lost but now is found, though without the score. Rodgers and Hammerstein do not come to mind by chance.
There are moments when John Lee Beatty's stunning sets, especially his big open-air New Salem, Ill., seen on a Fourth of July in the 1830's, recall the work of the regionalist painters who were supported by the New Deal's Federal Art Project. These painters had earlier inspired Lemuel Ayers's designs for "Oklahoma!" Mr. Beatty, too, is paying tribute to an earlier theatrical tradition.
As directed by Gerald Gutierrez, with Sam Waterston in the title role that defined the career of Raymond Massey, "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" is not, as you might think, an old-fashioned play, at least not in the sense that it is well made. It breaks all the rules governing the construction of well-made plays. It has no strong story line. Supporting characters aren't characterized; they are labeled and move on. It assumes that we already agree about Lincoln's place in history. Thus his greatness needn't be dramatized so much as illustrated in the series of loosely strung-
together vignettes that make up its 3 acts and 12 scenes.
The best of these: the starkly staged debate between Lincoln and Stephen A. Douglas (Brian Reddy), for which most of the words were supplied not by Sherwood but by Lincoln and Douglas.
THE PLAY ENDS WITH THE famous 1861 farewell speech to the people of Springfield, spoken from the rear platform of the train that is taking President-elect Lincoln to Washington and, as they say, into history. The concluding note of prophetic doom is made suitably rousing by the singing of "John Brown's Body" and by Mr. Beatty's final, spellbinding theatrical effect, the sort of thing you might see in a Radio City Music Hall pageant.
Mr. Waterston, who looks reasonably like Lincoln, survives these circumstances with a modesty that is becoming but is not strong enough to dominate Mr. Gutierrez's physical production. Lincoln himself was 6 feet 4, but even he might have had difficulty looming large amid all of the stage effects. Then, too, Sherwood's Lincoln is most often seen as a shy, diffident figure, whether dodging history's demands or trying to escape Mary Todd's lethal embrace.
Mr. Waterston is very fine in isolated moments when he's allowed to play something other than Lincoln's impending martyrdom, that is, when he can find Lincoln's eccentric strength. Early on, there's a brief, enlivening moment when Mr. Waterston seems on the point of doing a buck and wing as he tells a comic story. Later, in Sherwood's most improbable but theatrically effective scene, Mr. Waterston catches something of Lincoln's formidable passive-aggressiveness when he returns to Mary Todd, whom he had abandoned earlier, to present her with the stewardship of his fate.
The moment invites speculation. It is mysterious and tragic. It's real theater. The rest of the time, "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" demands agreement, if not total obedience. It says over and over, in one way and another: This is the gospel. Believe.
 
'All in the Timing'
 O.K., here's the drop-everything-and-go note of the week: "All in the Timing," six delirious one-act plays now at Primary Stages, written by David Ives, a wizardly playwright who is new to me. Four of the plays have been seen in New York earlier, but this is the first time they have been presented, so to speak, in their own evening. Though the pieces are called one-act plays, they are more like sketches for some hilarious, celestially conceived revue. The writing is not only very funny, it has the density of thought and precision of poetry.
Take, for example, "Words, Words, Words." Three actors appear as chimpanzees, caged in a Columbia University lab that has been furnished with a rubber-tire swing, bananas, desks and typewriters. They are the monkeys who, if left long enough in front of typewriters, will one day write "Hamlet." One problem: they don't know what "Hamlet" is. In a few priceless minutes, Mr. Ives demolishes, among other things, academe, writers' workshops, the jargon of criticism and all the reverential guff ever written and spoken about the creative process.
Or, "Philip Glass Buys a Loaf of Bread," in which four actors somehow manage to reduce a piece of Glass-like music to the rhythms and cadences of speech. Magical and funny. Or my favorite, "The Philadelphia," in which it's revealed that "inside what we know as reality there are these pockets, these black holes called 'Philadelphias.' "
Being in a "Philadelphia" is to be exiled to another space-time continuum without leaving the planet. You go about your daily life as usual, but nobody pays any attention. Druggists say they don't carry aspirin and never have. A request for pastrami at a deli prompts derisive laughter; coffee shops don't serve coffee. To survive a "Philadelphia," you have to learn to ask for the exact opposite of what you want, which leads to marvelous, mind-bending reversals of thought and language.
Mr. Ives would seem to be a master of language. He uses words for their meanings, sounds and associations, spinning conceits of a sort I've not heard or seen before. He's an original. Jason McConnell Buzas directed the flawless cast: Daniel Hagen, Wendy Lawless, Ted Neustadt, Nancy Opel and Robert Stanton. Spread the word. Or words.
 
'The Loman Family Picnic'
 You might also check out the Manhattan Theater Club's elegant production of "The Loman Family Picnic," written by Donald Margulies, directed by Lynne Meadow and designed (beautifully) by Santo Loquasto. The bitter comedy, which was presented as a work in progress at the M.T.C. in 1989, could be described as a triumph for a play badly made on purpose, being part grim portrait of a dysfunctional Coney Island family, circa 1965, and part musical comedy.
The family: Mom (Christine Baranski), Dad (Peter Friedman) and their sons, Stewie (Harry Barandes), who's about to be bar mitzvahed, and Mitchell (Jonathan Charles Kaplan), the imaginative younger brother. The setting is a ghastly new high-rise apartment that also is a parody of Jo Mielziner's classic set for "Death of a Salesman."
The play begins more or less as Real Life, though the ghost (Liz Larsen) of Mom's favorite aunt appears. Bored Mom simultaneously overprotects her husband and sons and underrates them. Dad is overworked and exhausted. Each son itches in his own way to break loose.
The second act is something quite other. It's largely given over to monologues and fantasies that function like blackout sketches, and to young Mitch's musical adaptation of "Death of a Salesman," with himself, his mother, father and brother delivering songs that are funny, bleak and full of Broadway razzmatazz. David Shire wrote the excellent score.
Don't ask me how it works but it does, at least much of the time. Mr. Margulies deconstructs the conventions of the family play without destroying the genre. What's most surprising and heartening is that his off-the-wall concept could find such generous support at the M.T.C. and in Ms. Meadow's staging. Plays like this usually wind up in the basket marked Outgoing.
All the performances are good, but Ms. Baranski is superb, whether nodding her head vacantly as she listens to Dad's complaints, or robustly belting out a number in which she tries to sum up Dad's ordinariness. He's a "second-rate man," she sings with enthusiasm, "an in-between man," and the audience laughs its approval.
We're a long way from Willy Loman territory, where our hearts ache as Willy's gallant, threadbare wife cries out that attention must be paid.

Renting in Rome
 
Q. My husband and I would like to rent a one-bedroom apartment, studio or room in Rome for 10 days next February. Can you help us with the names of renting agents? -- Katherine Callahan, Prattsville, N.Y. 

A. There are a number of options available. One is to write to the Ente Provinciale del Turismo in Rome and ask for a copy of Alberghi in Roma (Hotels in Rome), which lists hotels, pensions and residences, with prices. Most residences are apartments with kitchens. The rooms are cleaned daily, and linens are changed twice a week. Prices vary, depending mainly on location. To receive the hotel guide, write to the Ente Provinciale del Turismo, c/o Signora Cinelli, Via Parigi 11, 00185 Rome; the telephone number, dialed in Italy, is (06) 488991, fax (06) 4819316.
Another option is to contact a rental agency like IDEC S.r.L., Via Angelo Poliziano 27, 00184 Rome; (06) 70454455 or (06) 704544074. (The first number accepts faxes after 5:30 P.M. Rome time and on weekends.) The agency has 20 apartments around Rome, ranging from about $215 a week for a studio and $920 a week for a spacious one-bedroom apartment near the Trevi Fountain. There is a one-week minimum stay, and everything is included except phone charges. The agency needs to know the date and time of arrival so arrangements for keys can be made.
Another possibility is the Residence al Velabro, Via del Velabro 16, 00186 Rome; (06) 6793450, fax (06) 6793790. The apartments are spacious, with a cooking area, answering machine and daily cleaning service. The price is about $150 a day.
If having a landlord who speaks English is important there is the Mallia Residence, Via Damiano Chiesa 8, 00136 Rome; (06) 301981, fax (06) 30198603. It is situated in a garden in a quiet neighborhood called Balduina, normally about a 25-minute ride by bus or taxi to the Vatican; if traffic is congested, however, the trip can take twice as long.<heart> The apartments have a large living room and one or two bedrooms and a kitchenette. There is a pool, gym and tennis court.
The smaller apartments cost about $105 a day, which includes cleaning, linens and heat, plus 9 percent tax. If one rents by the week, it is cheaper (about $430 plus tax for one week, $675 plus tax for two weeks).
 
Opera in Milan
 
Q. I have searched without success for a tour operator offering an escorted itinerary that would include attending an opera at La Scala in Milan. Can you help me? -- Mary Raftery, Brookline, Mass.
 
A. If you are interested only in attending an opera in Milan, it is doubtful that you will find a tour operator to help you. But if you have the time and money for a more extensive tour, there are several operators that include a visit to La Scala in a package of other cities. La Scala is one of the most difficult opera houses for a traveler to attend, mainly because of its large subscription list and the fact that available tickets do not go on sale very far in advance. Ordering by mail is sometimes possible and sometimes not, depending on the performance. At the box office, tickets are limited to two to a person.
Travelers on their own should plan a trip that will allow a stay of at least three or four days in Milan during La Scala's recently extended season, December to July, and take a chance on getting tickets at the box office or from a hotel concierge for an opera that one would like with a cast also to one's liking.
Among tour operators likely to have tours going to Milan are Dailey-Thorpe Travel, 330 West 58th Street, Suite 610, New York, N.Y. 10019, (212) 307-1555 or (800) 998-4677; Great Performance Tours, 1 Lincoln Plaza, Suite 32V, New York, N.Y. 10023, (212) 580-1400, and International Curtain Call, 3313 Patricia Avenue, Los Angeles, Calif. 90064, (310) 204-4934.
Dailey-Thorpe usually has three or four different escorted itineraries a year that include a stop in Milan. One tour, Deluxe European Capitals, is scheduled from March 13 to 26 and will go to Paris, London and Milan, where the group will see "Don Pasquale" by Donizetti and "Maometto II" by Rossini. The exact price has not been set, but a spokesman said most tours ran about $500 a day for one person in double occupancy and include economy air fare from New York, deluxe hotel accommodations and all meals.
Another Dailey-Thrope tour, Springtime in Italy, is scheduled from April 19 to May 1. It will go to Milan (for "Don Pasquale" and a ballet), Turin, Genoa, Florence and Venice. A third, as yet untitled tour is planned for July 13 to 25, and will go to Munich, Milan (for "Eugene Onegin" by Tchaikovsky) and Verona.
Great Performance Tours is planning a tour to northern Italy from April 28 to May 7 or 8. It will visit Milan, but participants will see a ballet rather than an opera, a spokesman said. Other cities on the itinerary are expected to be Bologna, Turin and either Florence or Rome.
Another tour is planned in July, and it too will take in a ballet in Milan, but there will be operas in Verona and probably Venice.
The approximate price of each tour will be $4,000 a person in double occupancy, including air fare from New York.
International Curtain Call offers deluxe, escorted tours to some of the music festivals in Europe as well as regular-season performances at various opera houses. Two tours planned next year will include Milan. Spring in Italy from May 20 to June 4 will offer "Rigoletto" by Verdi and "Elektra" by Richard Strauss, a choral concert with La Scala Philharmonic and possibly a ballet, all in Milan, a spokesman said.
Other cities on that tour will be Turin (for "L'Elisir d'Amore" by Donizetti), Florence (for "Salome" by Richard Strauss, the Verdi Requiem conducted by Zubin Mehta and a concert by the Oslo Philharmonic, all at the Maggio Musicale festival) and Venice (for "L'Orfeo" by Monteverdi). The price is expected to be between $4,200 to $4,500 plus $750 to $800 for air fare from the East Coast.
 
Staying in the Cotswolds
 
Q. I am interested in staying two weeks in a cottage in the Cotswolds in England next summer. I do not want to drive but want to be within walking distance of public transportation. Can you suggest places to write to? -- Richard F. Atnally, Wayne, N.J.
 
A. A list of a dozen agencies that rent out cottages in the Cotswolds is available from the Heart of England Tourist Board, Larkhill Road, Worcester, England WR5 2EF; (905) 763436, fax (905) 763450.
Another organization that has rentals close to public transportation is National Trust Holiday Cottages, Post Office Box 536, Melksham, Wiltshire, England SN12 8EA; (225) 705676, fax (225) 706209.
Both groups will send their brochures without charge, but a fee of $1.25 to cover postage is requested by National Trust Holiday Cottages. International postal coupons or a personal check are acceptable.
 JOHN BRANNON ALBRIGHT

LENGTH: 795 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
The Man Who Mocks Talk Shows Inherits One

BYLINE: By ANDY MEISLER

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
As the host of "Talk Soup," a daily cable program that samples confessional talk shows, Greg Kinnear has won a reputation as a deadpan satirist and perhaps the world's leading expert on bizarre on-screen behavior. But what is there in his background that persuaded NBC to choose him as the new host of "Later," the 1:30 A.M. show in which one-on-one conversation is everything?
Mr. Kinnear, at his table in a Sunset Boulevard hamburger restaurant, answers the question with a question: "Does the name Hart Bochner mean anything to you?" 
 From 1987 to 1990, he explains, when his on-air job consisted of introducing movie trailers on the now-defunct Movietime cable channel, he occasionally talked to real-life actors on his set -- which was located in a converted porno-film studio.
"Maybe once a month," he continues, "the talent booker would coax some foolish celebrity to come into the dark cavernous hell that was Movietime. I remember when we got Bochner. It was a huge deal! The building was in an uproar. Hart Bochner came by! And we did this little interview, and I'll never forget the horror in his eyes as he got into the studio and began really looking around."
Of such encounters, particularly in the irony-friendly Letterman era, is talk-show stardom created. To hire Mr. Kinnear, NBC had to top offers from the likes of Fox television and Disney. In the past six months the "heat" around Mr. Kinnear, as industry insiders say, has been intense.
"Greg is extremely telegenic," says NBC president Warren Littlefield. "He comes off as someone you want to spend time with."
Mr. Littlefield is a fan of "Talk Soup," a half-hour program run six times each day by E! Entertainment Television. In this, he has something in common with many other entertainment executives. "Talk Soup" collects particularly grotesque and outrageous segments from daytime talk shows like "Donahue," "Vicki" and "Ricki." The segments are pithily introduced and, afterwards, snappily summed up by Mr. Kinnear ("They're currently unemployed and living off the government," he said, updating a clip of a porno actress who appeared with her husband on "The Jane Whitney Show." "Who says that the system doesn't work?"). Often, after a particularly ridiculous excerpt, he simply stares dumbfounded into the camera. "Sometimes," says Mr. Kinnear, "even I can't believe what I'm seeing."
Mr. Kinnear's own life story probably wouldn't get him onto "Geraldo" as a guest, but it is certainly out of the ordinary. Born in Indiana, he moved to Washington at age 10 when his father went to work for the State Department. The family was posted to Beirut, where civil war broke out eight months later, and the Kinnears were evacuated to Athens. Mr. Kinnear spent his high school years in Greece; his only exposure to American television, he says, were once-a-week reruns of "Dallas" and "The Muppet Show."
Movietime provided him with his first television work, but in 1990, the channel was purchased by a consortium of companies including Time Warner. The new management renamed the network E! and promptly fired all of the hosts, including Mr. Kinnear.
In 1991, E! decided they wanted Mr. Kinnear after all, and he began "Talk Soup" on a shoestring. Mr. Kinnear says: "The first acknowledgment I had that anyone in the industry was watching was about a year ago. I got a call from my agent saying that Rob Reiner was a big fan of the show and wanted to talk to me. I nearly fell out of my chair."
The talks with Mr. Reiner were not fruitful. But other producers and networks waved offers at him, including Fox, which had to fill the time slot recently vacated by the infamous "Chevy Chase Show."
"I was a little nervous about that spot," Mr. Kinnear says. "I think anybody who tries to go in there after what happened will have a tough time. It's like building condominiums on an ancient Indian burial ground or something. I wanted something a little more low key for my first talk show."
Mr. Kinnear says that when he takes over "Later" next month from Bob Costas, who wanted to move on, the show will start to include short skits and comedy performances. So that he can continue to appear on "Talk Soup," "Later" is relocating from New York to Los Angeles. Mr. Kinnear insists, however, that one-on-one interviews will remain the backbone of "Later." "The show will live or die by them," he says. "If I can't do them, if I can't pull them off, if I can't draw another person out of their shell, if I can't develop a good rapport with random people, four nights a week -- well, pretty much, this ship is sunk."
He is, he says, looking forward to the challenge. "Hillary Clinton has already expressed strong interest," he says. "Mother Teresa won't stop calling me."

HEADLINE: Beneath Moscow, a Piece of Its Soul

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN; CHRISTOPHER S. WREN is a former foreign correspondent for The Times based in Moscow from 1973 to 1977. As editor of new projects, he supervises The Times's Russian-language edition.

 BODY:
THE turbulence afflicting Russia these days can disorient even a frequent traveler to Moscow. For one thing, you can't find Feliks Dzerzhinsky. The statue of the founder of the Soviet secret police was toppled by demonstrators against the failed coup in August 1991. His pedestal in Lub yanka Square is adorned now by a simple wood cross.
Once you could set your watch by the honor guard that goose-stepped to Lenin's tomb on the hour. The ritual has been canceled. And what about all those statues and other monuments paying public homage to Lenin and his Bolshevik cronies? They are vanishing even as the onion domes are being repainted on the old churches once closed under the Communists. Moscow's streets, whose names evoked a pantheon of Soviet heroes, have reverted to names that predate, and puzzle, the city's current inhabitants. But my favorite landmark has been left virtually untouched, and it's still affordable. The Moscow Metro, or subway system, survives as an island of rational continuity in the sea of economic and social upheaval. 
 I confess a fondness for subways, whose condition can reveal a great deal about a city to a traveler. I have sought out subway systems in Hong Kong, Montreal, London, Paris, Madrid, Lisbon and, not least, Boston and Washington, because they offer not merely rapid, cheap transport but also a chance to rub shoulders, quite literally, with the natives. Yet Moscow's Metro, short for Metropolitan, tops my list. During the four years I lived in Moscow as a foreign correspondent, I rode the Metro to visit Russian friends at a time when the K.G.B. labored to isolate Western journalists from our sources. In the Metro's underground passages, I discovered that the tails assigned by the K.G.B. to follow me were stocky middle-aged women with shopping bags. Today, the Russian Government doesn't seem to care where you go or whom you talk to.
On two trips to Moscow within the last 14 months, the Metro was my tunnel to those old memories. It assured me that a Moscow mired in commercial rapaciousness today no more reflects the Russian soul than did those fading three-quarters of a century under Communism.
Elsewhere in Moscow, I ran up against the kind of buccaneer capitalism that Karl Marx warned us about. I encountered it at the Metropol Hotel in June. My wife and I first stayed at the Metropol in 1967, back when you could still find a Russian willing to defend Marxism. Our double room at the Metropol was, I recall, cramped and dark, with two narrow beds, a grim reading light, a musty carpet and a view of what looked like a junkyard. We didn't complain. This was the Soviet Union, after all, and our room, I recall, cost about $35 a night with some meals and other perks thrown in.
When I checked into the Metropol again in June, the room they assigned me looked as small and gloomy as the other had 26 years earlier. True, the bathroom was new and my window framed the same junkyard from a slightly different angle. But I found myself again with narrow beds, a dim reading light, a drab carpet. The biggest change, beyond the refurbished lobby, was that the Metropol now cost $310 a night. I never paid so much for a hotel in my life, not even in overpriced cities like Tokyo or Riyadh. I shouldn't grumble since the Metropol favored me with its corporate rate. I eavesdropped on another arriving foreigner who timidly inquired about the price of his room. The clerk announced that his rate was $370 a night, which is more than most Russians could hope to earn in a month.
And meals were extra. Breakfast at the Metropol cost $22, though the buffet included fresh omelets and a harpist in attendance. My bill for three days' worth of laundry -- mundane shirts, underwear and socks -- ran $45. And the Metropol is not Moscow's priciest hotel; others like the Savoy and Penta can charge more.
In the old days, the Soviet regime segregated tourists for ideological motives, lest our bourgeois decadence derail the happy march of the Russian people toward Communism. With Marxism looking as dead as Lenin in his air-conditioned mausoleum, exorbitant prices now constrict the foreign visitor in a dollar cocoon.
When I lived in Moscow, Russians trafficking in American dollars risked being sent to a Siberian labor camp. Today, everybody does it. In fact, the dollar has replaced the ruble as Moscow's commercial currency. Taxi drivers ignore their ruble meters and the shortest ride can cost a foreigner $10. Before climbing into one taxi, I proposed paying in rubles. The driver took umbrage and went in search of a more malleable tourist.
That may be why I greet the Metro as an old friend. It still accepts only rubles, though the handsome brass tokens have been replaced by flimsy yellow plastic disks. And it still works when so much of Moscow does not. An electronic clock on the platform tells you precisely when the last train left. The wait between trains, once 90 seconds at rush hour, can stretch now to three minutes, not bad for a society in collapse. Each station and the next get announced over a public address system that is, yes, actually comprehensible.
It may be a cheap shot to compare the clean, safe Metro with New York's grimy, menacing subways. Moscow has 120 stations radiating out from a central ring, compared with 469 stations scattered across New York. The Metro closes from 12:30 A.M. to 6 A.M. for cleaning and repairs, while the subway runs around the clock. And the Metro has fewer decades to show its age, having opened in 1935 compared to 1904 in New York.
Yet the difference runs deeper. Muscovites, for all the disillusionment bred by Communism's collapse, display a proprietary pride in their Metro. Musicians, hawkers and beggars encroach on its subterranean approaches (though one of the best jazz combos I've heard in Russia performs nightly at the Metro's entrance off Red Square). But inside, panhandling, littering and graffiti seem not to happen because riders would not tolerate it. Seats are still reserved for elderly, disabled or pregnant passengers in every car.
Riding the Metro during rush hour a year ago, I found a middle-aged Russian glaring at me. I wondered whether he was xenophobic but, no, he pointed sternly to the floor under my seat, where some inconsequential receipt had fallen from my pocket. I dutifully picked up the paper and he nodded approval.
The art inside the Metro has survived the ideology that produced it. Perhaps the finest Stalinist architecture was built underground as Metro stations, sometimes with ornate chandeliers.
The official tourism agency Intourist used to market the Metro as evidence of the superiority of socialism. It dispatched tourists to marvel at bronze statues of workers, peasants and soldiers at the Revolution Square station, stained glass at Novoslobodskaya, mosaics at the Kiev station, and ceiling murals at Mayakovsky station. Today, these constitute poignant artifacts of that idealistic, savage epoch.
IN taking visitors for a ride but not ripping them off, the Metro still offers Moscow's best bargain. The Metro costs Russians more but not foreigners, thanks to the falling ruble.
When I visited Moscow five years ago, a ride cost only 5 kopeks, or about 7 cents at the prevailing official ruble rate of $1.45. Last June, I found the fare at 6 rubles; by October, inflation had pushed it up to 30 rubles. But with the ruble scraping around 1,200 to the dollar, this still works out to 2 and a half cents. A visitor can ride the Metro 50 times for the cost of a single trip -- $1.25 -- on the New York City subway.
Much of the old Moscow I do not miss, not the pretense and pomposity of a bankrupt ideology and certainly not Feliks Dzer zhinsky's statue. But the link between the old and the new that was severed elsewhere can be observed on the Metro. If you want to know what Moscow is really like, pass up the $22 breakfast at the Metropol and, for a fraction of the price, treat yourself to a ride on the Metro. Unlike most of what Moscow offers these days, it's an experience you can afford.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK'S FUTURE;
Waterfront Vision

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We write in response to Herbert Muschamp's essay "Fear, Hope and the Changing of the Guard" [Nov. 14]. While we share his hope that architecture and design will "play a more substantial role" in urban affairs, we believe his criticism of the city's new waterfront zoning is not well informed. 
 As members of the City Planning Commission, our charter mandate is to plan for the orderly growth and development of the city. We provide the basic framework within which other design professionals can work. Toward that end, and based on the Comprehensive Waterfront Plan prepared by the Department of City Planning, we adopted the city's first waterfront zoning regulations after an extensive public review process. This zoning text, as modified and approved by the City Council, will guide waterfront development for decades to come. Its vision for our shores enhances New York as a world city.
Most importantly, it establishes public access to our waterfront. It allows utmost flexibility for tomorrow's businesses and industries, and therefore challenges developers, architects, designers and investors to shape these areas. They now have the opportunity to recreate our city's edge.
Having created the rules and established the basic building envelopes for future development, we take pride in the commendation of The New York Times's lead editorial of Oct. 4, which hailed our work as an "ambitious step" that could make an "invaluable contribution" toward reclaiming the city's edge.
In our municipal democracy, criticism is necessary and appropriate. Informed criticism, however, is what is most valuable.
 
RICHARD L. SCHAFFER
New York
 
The writer is chairman of the City Planning Commission; the letter was also signed by all 12 members of the commission.

HEADLINE: School Integration: Summing Up the Case;
For the State: Legislature Has Met Constitutional Test

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

 BODY:
ON Thursday in Rockville Superior Court, Judge Harry Hammer will hear the final summations in the lawsuit known as Sheff v. O'Neill, which is seeking to overcome the segregation of poor Hispanic and black children in Hartford's schools by linking the schools with those in 21 surrounding towns.
The suit seeks to improve the education of Hartford children by breaking up the concentration of minority students in the city's schools, where the enrollment is more than 93 percent Hispanic and black, and by obtaining more state aid to overcome the educational obstacles posed by poverty. Judge Hammer, who heard opening arguments in the case on Dec. 16, 1992, is expected to issue his decision in the spring. After nearly three months of testimony earlier this year, each side has summarized their arguments in briefs submitted to Judge Hammer. 
 The state was defended by the office of Attorney General Richard Blumenthal, led by Assistant Attorneys General John R. Whelan and Martha M. Watts, and assisted by Alfred A. Lindseth, an Atlanta lawyer who has represented local governments in school desegregation cases. Here are excerpts from their post-trial brief.
 In the course of the proceedings, the one central issue on which the plaintiffs' case turns appears to have receded into the background: Have the defendants violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights? After all the educational and social theories have been debated, and after all the data has been analyzed, the answer to this question is clearly NO.
The principal constitutional provision on which the plaintiffs' claims rest is Article Eight, Section 1, of the Connecticut Constitution. That section provides: "There shall always be free public elementary and secondary schools in the state. The general assembly shall implement this principal by appropriate legislation."
First, the constitution directs the General Assembly to implement the principle that "[t]here shall always be free public elementary and secondary schools in the state." Without a doubt, the General Assembly has done this. It has established a comprehensive system of free public elementary and secondary education. The General Assembly has continuously concerned itself with the challenges and obstacles of offering a first rate educational system, including the challenges and obstacles of racial and ethnic concentration in urban areas and of the consequences which poverty has on education.
Second, the state has provided a fair and comprehensive system for funding its educational programs, which provides extra resources for cities like Hartford and which has passed constitutional muster.
Pursuant to the state's funding system, Hartford received 2.8 times more state aid per pupil in 1991-92 than its suburbs received.
Third, the state has helped cities like Hartford develop and fund special programs specifically designed to address the special educational needs of Hartford students which stem from problems such as poverty, health care, housing, and exposure to drug abuse. There is no reliable evidence that most Hartford students would perform better in suburban schools, which lack many of these programs.
Fourth, the state has never segregated any students or school systems by race, and there is no allegation in this case that the state has ever done so. Nor do the plaintiffs allege that the state has done anything to create the housing, transportation, or employment patterns which have caused the demographic shifts over the years and have resulted in the present racial, ethnic and socioeconomic complexion of the Hartford area.
Fifth, not only has Connecticut never advanced or supported segregation, the state has promoted racial and ethnic diversity in its schools.
Plainly, the state has done all, and more, than the constitution requires it to do. The plaintiffs have not proven that the state has violated their constitutional rights.
The plaintiffs cannot prevail unless the court accepts the strained and unprecedented interpretation of the state constitution that the plaintiffs advance. Under their theory, the existence of certain conditions, such as the racial, ethnic and socioeconomic patterns alleged here, even though not caused, and indeed combatted by the state, themselves constitute a violation of the constitution.
The evidence in this case shows that the problems faced by children in Hartford, like the children in urban centers throughout the nation, are the product of complex social and economic conditions. Children bring to school the problems of poverty, health care, housing, crime and drugs. Only the General Assembly has the constitutional authority to address those underlying problems and the educational challenges that flow from them.
As little as the plaintiffs have offered to suggest a standard for racial and ethnic balance, they have offered even less to establish that there is a standard of socioeconomic balance that must be read into the constitution.
Witnesses for the plaintiffs who are intimately familiar with the socioeconomic composition of the Hartford student body testified that they could not say how much of a reduction in the concentration of poor children in Hartford schools was necessary nor could they identify a specific point at which the concentration of poor students crosses the line from acceptable to unacceptable.
How best to serve children attending our public schools who are afflicted by poverty is one of the most important and complex issues being studied, debated and dealt with by educational experts, teachers, cities and states throughout the country.
The plaintiffs' implicit, if not overt, suggestion that achievement standards be read into the constitution is probably the most specious of all their legal claims.
The defendants share the plaintiffs' desire that all children perform at the highest possible level regardless of their background or the conditions which they bring to school with them. The defendants also share the plaintiffs' desire that all children reach the highest possible level of achievement in an environment that exposes them to the diversity of the people of our state.
The defendants do not, however, share the plaintiffs' assumption that a court can successfully order these ideals into place. Not only do the courts lack the legal authority to determine how to pursue these objectives because the defendants have not violated the constitution, the courts lack the breadth of power needed to determine and implement effective approaches to the many obstacles that interfere with educational achievement and the opportunity to be exposed to children of different backgrounds.
The real question presented by this case is what branch of government makes these decisions? The simple answer is that it cannot be the courts because the courts can never act on the broad social policy which need to be addressed. Only the General Assembly has the broad perspective and broad power needed to balance the many competing considerations and direct a comprehensive attack on the social problems that interfere with the ability of children throughout the state to take full advantage of the educational opportunities they are being offered.
In requiring the state to offer a system of free public elementary and secondary education, the constitution imposes no specific methods or standards that must be met, nor does it prescribe any particular course of conduct for dealing with the broad range of challenges and problems involved in educating the children of this state. Unless the discretion that must constantly be exercised by state and local officials - from the General Assembly to the classroom teacher - violates the constitution and thereby makes injunctive relief appropriate, the plaintiffs may not use the court to review and change these decisions.
The court should recognize the plaintiffs' case for what it is - a request by a small group of individuals for a writ of mandamus that would dramatically intrude upon the broad discretion which must be exercised by the General Assembly, the State Board of Education, the Commissioner of Education, 22 cities, towns and school districts in the Hartford area, and the citizens of this state through their elected representatives. No court has the authority to grant the kind of relief the plaintiffs are seeking under the facts of this case.

HEADLINE: ART;
The Tidy World of a New England Printmaker in Old Lyme

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

 BODY:
This week's action takes place at the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme and at the Lyman Allyn Museum in New London.
Once in a while, the Griswold undertakes a show proving that there is, too, life after American Impressionism. In the early 1980's, the example chosen was Thomas Willoughby Nason, a printmaker and, seemingly, the embodiment of New England values. Except in a television re-creation, where would an artist be found today who seriously wore three-piece tweed suits, smoked a pipe and kept a gun rack in his studio, a spaniel at his heels? 
 Nason is now back at the museum in force, thanks to recent acquisitions, including a gift from his niece, Janet Eltinge, and what might be called the tender loving care of Charles Price, professor emeritus of art history at Connecticut College. Professor Price, who cut an impressive figure earlier this year with "This Wondrous World," a show of children's book illustrations at the Lyman Allyn Museum, has done it again with "Thomas W. Nason: New England Virtues Aged in Wood."
It is a selection of Nason's prints -- mostly wood engravings -- interspersed with occasional contributions from contemporaries like Stow Wengenroth, Louis Lozowick and Asa Cheffetz. Accompanying the show is a catalogue set not in the ubiquitous sans-serif but, rather, in the dignified New Baskerville typeface and illustrated by prints and photographs.
In a sense, the production, -- which is as compact and well organized as the artist's life seems to have been, -- files him away in the slightly musty archives of printmaking as it used to be. Outside of "The Cove," a woodcut measuring 10 inches by 13 1/4 inches, "Maine Islands," a 7- by 22-inch engraving, and a few drawings of comparable size, there is nothing much larger than a postcard, nothing in color -- bar the prints with tonal values enhanced by tinted blocks -- and, above all, nothing the least bit experimental. Nason was the compleat Regionalist, as innocent of Cubism as he was of Surrealism, and in the heyday of Stuart Davis and the Precisionists, he belonged to no scene.
Indeed, as Professor Price tells the story, this clergyman's son appears not to have strayed far from his background -- he grew up on a farm near Lowell, Mass. Although Nason did not have a college education, he became a secretary to a successful Boston lawyer, Albert Burrage, and through him met his wife-to-be, Margaret Warren. It was also while working for Burrage that he became interested in art and began collecting prints, especially those by the 19th-century English masters, which may account for the whiff of Thomas Bewick that can be sensed in his work. As an autodidact, he conducted his studies mainly in the print department of Goodspeed's Bookstore, showing his early efforts to its director, Louis Holman.
After serving in the Army during World War I, Nason returned to Boston to settle, with Margaret, on River Street, in what passed for Bohemia. In 1931, Mr. Burrage died, leaving his secretary unemployed but free to concentrate on the art for which he had received some recognition, including first prize at a National Arts Club show in Manhattan. Life cannot have been too bad, for the two were able to buy land in Lyme and, with the help of architect friends, were living in their own house by 1938.
Despite the bleakness of the time, Nason received many commissions, notably those for illustrations to books of Robert Frost's poetry, as well as for editions of "Walden Pond" and "Poems by William Cullen Bryant," which were both bought out by the Limited Editions Club. The honorary Master of Arts degree bestowed on him by Tufts College in 1945 marked the peak of the artist's career and also the beginning of its denouement. As Professor Price points out, there was some room for Precisionism in the postwar era but none for Regionalism. "The consequence for an art as quiet and restrained as Nason's was almost total eclipse," he writes. Only now is it emerging from the penumbra.
The latest work in the show is a wood engraving of the Griswold commissioned by the Lyme Historical Society in 1962. There are no examples of the paintings he produced in later years, when his eyesight was failing. But then, neither are there signs of decline, although the artist had his off moments. In some of the early wood engravings he seems to have had trouble disengaging his burin from a groove, hence perhaps the ridge along the edge of the cloud bank in "Windswept" (1925). And in other images like "Summer Clouds" (1934), his predilections of different textures becomes obsessive. Generally he is at his best in chiaroscuro wood engravings like "Summer Storm" (1940), a rolling landscape with rain falling from clouds. This print is an example of the softening effect conferred by tinted blocks. He can also stop the eye with his studies of farm buildings, which, though close to Precisionism, reveal something like sensuality in the handling of solid form. But the animals and birds beloved of Bewick are absent from Nason's images, figures are few and far between. His was a tidy world seldom disturbed by bad weather but always infused by melancholy. This essay in perfectionism remains on view through Jan. 16.
Though billed as sculpture, the contents of the invitational at Lyman Allyn are, with few exceptions, crafts items. Rather than "Reflections of the Inner Light," the title should be "Reflections of Virtuosity." Nevertheless, some works are more sculptural than others, beginning with Gabriel Warren's relief that seems to be in the process of exfoliating its surface components. These are concave sheets of metal, probably aluminum, that are laid on in a kind of brick course with strips of contrasting metals instead of mortar.
Other examples are "Sanctuary" and "Spine," by Pat Smith. The first lies on the floor, a "hollow square" of white porcelain strips hedged by four short beams of raw wood; the second, a relief, consists of 36 porcelain "vertebrae" running down a background composed of eight slate rectangles. Robert Taplin commemorates Primo Levi with "Suicide," an open-sided bronze structure on legs that suggests an oven but contains three people seated at a meal. Ralph Bucci draws inspiration from prehistoric stoneworks but produces relatively small, smoothly modeled forms in clay.
Prizes for sheer complexity should go to Carol Kreeger Davidson and Jim Visconti, the first for sheets of bronze curled into roughly figural shapes or cut into strips and woven like baskets; the second for raku-fired porcelains that have the look of Torahs. Niki Ketchman has developed a reputation for sculptures that are tangles of black wires and valances of stiffened ropes. But the examples here take color from the company they are keeping. All in all, this is a case of inventiveness galore but precious little soul. The display remains on view through Jan. 2.
