HEADLINE: School Integration: Summing Up the Case;
For the Plaintiffs: At Issue, Lack of an Equal Education

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

 BODY:
ON Thursday in Rockville Superior Court, Judge Harry Hammer will hear the final summations in the lawsuit known as Sheff v. O'Neill, which is seeking to overcome the segregation of poor Hispanic and black children in Hartford's schools by linking the schools with those in 21 surrounding towns.
The suit seeks to improve the education of Hartford children by breaking up the concentration of minority students in the city's schools, where the enrollment is more than 93 percent Hispanic and black, and by obtaining more state aid to overcome the educational obstacles posed by poverty. Judge Hammer, who heard opening arguments in the case on Dec. 16, 1992, is expected to issue his decision in the spring. After nearly three months of testimony earlier this year, each side has summarized their arguments in briefs submitted to Judge Hammer. 
 The lawsuit was filed in 1989 on behalf of Milo Sheff, now a 14-year-old Hartford student, and 16 other children by a legal team including John Brittain, a professor at the University of Connecticut School of Law; Wesley W. Horton, whose Horton v. Meskill lawsuit in the 1970's led to more state aid for urban schools, and lawyers from the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union, the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund and the NAACP Legal Defense Fund and Education Fund. Here are excerpts from their post-trial brief.
 What is at stake in this case is the nature of the fundamental right that the Connecticut Constitution protects in insuring all children an education. Plaintiffs contend that it is the right to receive not just any education, but an equal education, a quality education and an education unencumbered by racial, ethnic or economic isolation. Plaintiffs have demonstrated through admissions, trial testimony, and the state's own documents: 1. that the educational system in Hartford and the surrounding suburbs is segregated on the basis of race, ethnicity and economic status; 2. that it fails to provide the equal educational opportunity to which each and every student in Connecticut is entitled; and 3. that it fails to provide Hartford students a minimally adequate education. The defendants have not attempted to deny the underlying facts. They cannot. As Governor Weicker candidly admitted in his State of the State message on Jan. 6, 1993:
"The racial and economic isolation in Connecticut's school system is indisputable. Whether this segregation came about through the chance of historical boundaries or economic forces beyond the control of the state or whether it came about through private decisions or in spite of the best educational efforts of the state, what matters is that it is here and must be dealt with."
The defendants nevertheless repeat the same legal argument that this court has twice rejected: that the court lacks the power to address the inequities and inadequacies in the public schools. Despite a strong constitutional mandate and this Court's prior rulings, defendants contend that this "court has never before injected itself into the process of addressing social and educational problems in this way." They protest that there are "no clear cut solutions." Stripped of its verbiage, the defendants' answer to the unconstitutional conditions in the schools is that either they are not able to, or they are not required to, address this situation. But solutions do exist for the pressing educational problems of Hartford, and this Court has the institutional responsibility to insure that these conditions are eliminated.
The daily reality faced by many Hartford children is one of poverty-concentrated classes in racially isolated schools with inadequate resources, substandard achievement levels, and gross educational disparities relative to suburban school districts. Even for high achieving students, the system's inequities have harmful effects; for the average child, the consequences can be devastating.
The educational environment of students in Hartford cannot be divorced from the social circumstances in which Hartford children find themselves. As they pass through the schoolhouse gates, they bring with them the overwhelming burdens of poverty and other socioeconomic factors which place them at risk and cause them to "start the race behind the starting line."
It is axiomatic that poor urban children deserve the same educational opportunities as middle-class suburban children. Each child is precious, and each is an important resource for our future. It is a profound responsibility of the public schools to help children overcome the disadvantages of poverty and achieve to their potential.
The significance of plaintiffs' evidence on the concentration of poverty in the Hartford schools is, first, as defendants have officially stated, "those who need more must receive more." However, in reality, poor children in Hartford actually are receiving less. Second, the concentration of poverty in the Hartford schools places an untenable responsibility on Hartford schools, teachers and administrators which they cannot meet given current funding and levels of resources. Third, the high concentration of poor students adversely affects educational outcomes for all students. Finally, the high concentration of poverty in the schools is closely linked to extreme racial segregation in the schools, which heightens the detrimental impacts of poverty concentration on Black and Latino students.
The Hartford School District is compelled to use a substantial portion of its limited funds to hire staff to address the special needs of Hartford's students, rather than in the traditional parts of the educational program.
In the past two to three years, the deficiencies of the Hartford school system have been exacerbated by budget cutbacks. In the 1992-93 school year, over 100 staff positions were cut, including 40 teachers, and a wide range of support positions, including nurses and other health staff, social workers and psychologists, administrators, and custodians. In the same year, over one million dollars in non-staff budgetary cuts were made, including reductions in planned maintenance expenditures, after-school programs, athletics, and textbook acquisition. Similar, but less severe cuts, were made in 1990 and 1991.
If, as plaintiffs contend, the state is under an affirmative obligation to provide equal educational opportunity to school children in Hartford, then it is abundantly clear from the evidence that the defendants have failed to act in a manner sufficient to meet the constitutional mandate.
Under the Connecticut Constitution, the importance of public education -- as a personal right, and as an affirmative state obligation -- is securely established, for it is "a fundamental right." Together, Article First and Article Eighth have been construed to impose an affirmative duty on the state to provide a substantially equal educational opportunity to every school child. It is the scope of this duty which separates the parties in this case.
Because the harm that would flow from the absence of any injunctive relief is immense, the court must grant plaintiffs more than merely a declaratory judgment. In Hartford alone, there are almost 26,000 children in a racially and economically isolated school system which is failng to provide an adequate education or opportunities equal to that of other children in this state. As plaintiffs' witnesses at trial indicated, "something very dulling happens to them when they stay in a negative environment, where lack of expectation gets lower and lower every year. They just don't grow, they don't blossom." As the detailed historical treatment of this issue has so repeatedly demonstrated, while the state has continued to talk, it has consistently failed to back its words with any significant action. This Court is a means of last resort to translate words into action.
As outlined below, any plan for the Hartford region must include the following seven components:
1. The remedial plan must be interdistrict in its design.
2. The plan must include mandatory and voluntary provisions.
3. Reduction of racial isolation and poverty concentration must be a major goal.
4. Bilingual education programs must be preserved.
5. Educational enhancements must supplement any desegregation goals.
6. Housing and other components must be addressed in the plan.
7. Timetables must be strictly enforced.
Decades of delay and neglect by state authorities have deprived the plaintiff children of their fundamental right to an equal educational opportunity. The continued concentration of the poorest students in the most racially isolated school district with the worst academic performance in the state creates a compelling and urgent need for this court to act. The time for judicial intervention is long overdue.

HEADLINE: Shopping for Ideas

BYLINE: By MARGALIT FOX

 BODY:
ON a gray afternoon earlier this month, a 23-year-old graduate student left the Rutherford, N.J., offices of the Academic Research Group, carrying a large white envelope.
"I have a 30-page term paper that's due," she said. "They sent me a catalogue and they had all the core information in one paper." 
 She had just gone shopping in the supermarket of ideas. At this season, as semester's end nears and research-company advertisements beckon from the pages of campus newspapers and magazines like Details and Rolling Stone, it is a time-honored ritual.
The student, who said she was in a graduate program at a local university, declined to give her name for fear that her professor would learn of her visit. She said she planned to use the $125 report on business in China that she had bought to augment her own research; indeed, research companies maintain that such reports are intended simply for reference and study. But many educators say the reports are little more than off-the-rack term papers created and sold for the convenience of beleaguered students.
The Academic Research Group occupies the basement level of a modest two-story brick office building in Rutherford. A small white sign on a window bears the name of the company; the blinds are drawn.
Founded in 1972, the concern, like many research companies, offers a wide range of services, including speech writing and preparing grant applications. It also offers a catalogue of about 20,000 research reports on a wide range of topics, like "The Role of Money in Inflation" and "Cosmic Imagery in 'Antony and Cleopatra,' " at $6.95 a page. In addition, the company offers custom reports, prepared to the client's specifications by a stable of anonymous freelance writers, starting at $28 a page.
Just what do students get for their money? A selection of Academic Research Group reports bought by The New York Times came in prose styles ranging from the shallow to the sophisticated. Consider report No. 26004, "The Amy Fisher Case." Dotted with small lapses in grammar and spelling -- the name Buttafuoco is rendered as Buttafucco throughout -- the 17-page account of the notorious crime uses such memorable phrases as "a de-ranged adolescent mind."
At the other end of the stylistic spectrum is No. 8183, "The Scarlet Letter," whose baroque syntax would hold its own at any Modern Language Association meeting: "Thus, viewed in a strictly moralistic context, 'The Scarlet Letter' provides less commentary on the nature of moral transgression or social indiscretion, depending upon one's own point of view, than upon the grimly nonmoralistic interpretation of an offense or act like Hester's as a psychologically traumatizing experience for participant or, even, unobservant bystander."
Whatever their style, the reports are not meant to be submitted as course work, the research firms say. "We have taken every step we can to make sure it is not an issue," said Diane M. Shaw, president of the Academic Research Group. "If you've read our literature, you've seen it's replete with references to the fact that if we know that's what's happening, we don't do it."
Laws in some states, including New York and New Jersey, prohibit the sale of papers to be submitted to meet course or degree requirements. Academic Research Group clients are asked to sign a disclaimer stating that they do not intend to submit their purchases to an academic institution. Catalogue reports are stamped on each page with the notation, "Prepared by The Academic Research Group Inc. For research and reference use only."
But still there's nothing to stop a determined student from recopying a report and handing it in, conceded Bart Lowe, owner of Research Assistance, a Los Angeles company. "Nothing more than stops them from going to the library and copying out of a book or copying out of Time magazine," he said. "If someone's inclined to cheat, they're going to do it. However, I would say with my clientele, that's pretty much of a rarity."
 CRITICS in the higher-education community say that students' use of research companies continues to grow. "The problem has been mushrooming for the past two decades," said Sheldon E. Steinbach, general counsel to the American Council on Education in Washington. "And now with the advent of fax and other methods of rapid transmittal, I'm sure that although not quantifiable, it could be reaching epidemic proportions."
The graduate student who was writing about China said that although the Academic Research catalogue lacked an up-to-date report on the specific topic of her paper, she bought an 18-page report titled "The Outlook for Sales and Direct Investment in China."
"It tells me all about China," she said. "I'll have to make a lot of changes, but it gives me their economy. It gives me everything that's going on."
To her, the report was worth the money. "It'll save me six or eight hours in the library," she said.
Prepared reports like this tend to appeal to both the best and the worst students on campus, said Gary Pavela, the director of judicial programs at the University of Maryland and an authority on academic ethics.
"The very best students have a drive for perfectionism that might impel them to hand in professional writing that would earn them an A," he said. "The student who has become disconnected from academic work panics at the end and tries to have someone else do the whole thing."
In Rutherford, several students said they wouldn't just buy a report and turn it in verbatim. "That's not right," said one student, 19, who dropped by the Academic Research office to pick up a catalogue. Dressed in a black sweatshirt, he said he was a criminal-justice major at a local college. He said he was looking for background material for a six- to eight-page paper on suicide.
"It brings me down every time I'm in there," he said of a course he is taking, on death and grief. "So I just don't want to spend that much time thinking about it."

Joanna Lynn Usher, the daughter of Drs. Michael and Marion Usher of Washington, was married there last evening to David Maximus Kennedy Silver, a son of Cathy S. Prince of White Plains and John Silver of New York. Rabbi Jeffrey A. Wohlberg performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

Simon, was Secretary of State of New York and a judge on the New York State Court of Claims.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 6; Column 5; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 629 words

HEADLINE: Lawsuits and Lawyering

 BODY:
Connecticut residents should be disappointed by John Williams's admission that he settles or wins only approximately half of his numerous police-misconduct lawsuit ("Relishing the Risks and Rewards of the Law," Nov. 7). With approximately a 31-month backlog for tort cases in our state courts and a 20-month backlog in Federal courts, it is astonishing to realize that a lawyer may file civil suits that have no more chance of winning than could be predicted by the flip of a coin. We must suspect that our judicial system is hopelessly capricious if plaintiff attorneys cannot distinguish lawsuits that have the intrinsic merit to be successful from those that have only the potential to tie up our courts for extended periods of time.
Whether Mr. Williams's record is typical for plaintiff attorneys in Connecticut is difficult to determine because the statistical branch of the Supreme Court of Connecticut does not compile data on whether plaintiff attorneys are winning or losing civil cases. It is noted by the Connecticut lawyer James Rosenblum, however, in his book "Malpractice Solutions" that fewer than 30 percent of suits alleging medical malpractice are ultimately successful. He reports that only approximately 25 percent of cases that go the full distance to a jury verdict are won by the plaintiff attorney. 
 For plaintiffs with legitimate complaints who are likely to win monetary damages, the lengthy wait for justice is not acceptable. For the numerous defendants who will eventually be vindicated, the system is unreasonably punitive. There is clearly a need for a comprehensive evaluation of the efficiency and the fairness of our system of judging liability.
Mr. Williams's practice of economically isolating police officers by suing them directly rather than the municipalities they work for deserves our condemnation. A town or an insurance agency can afford the ten's of thousands of dollars required to completely defend against a protracted lawsuit. A modestly paid public employee, however, may have to settle the most unworthy of lawsuits simply because he or she cannot financially afford justice.
While Mr. Williams finds trial law to be "a great deal of fun," there is a more sobering side to the story. As a doctor, I have treated a number of individuals, including police officers, who have found themselves as defendants in tort lawsuits. Frequently these patients experience anxiety and depression for years following the suit. They often express despair that they and their families have been subjected to public humiliation based on what they perceive to be exaggerations, half-truths and factually incorrect charges in the lawsuit. In some cases the successful defense of the lawsuit leaves the families of the defendants bankrupt.
All Connecticut citizens, including police officers, should suffer the penalties imposed by the civil and criminal court system if they are actually guilty of committing irresponsible acts. It is difficult to believe, however, that our founding fathers intended our courts to be a place where large numbers of defendants, would be psychologically and financially savaged prior to being found innocent by a jury. Social responsibility dictates that our publicly financed courts not be used to bully citizens who are innocent of wrongdoing.
It would be appropriate to have a judicial review of all unsuccessful civil lawsuits to be sure that every factual charge in the case was supported by the evidence, that the case was competently litigated and that there was a reasonable chance at the outset that the case would be successful. Attorneys who abuse the system should lose their courtroom privileges and should pay the legal expanses of the defendants.
 
PETER DODDS M.D.
Wilton

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Foreign Aid Leaves Nicaragua in a Bind

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Public cynicism about foreign aid is fueled when the press quotes "experts" who argue more aid is good, less, bad ("A Foreign Aid of Words, Not Cash," Week in Review, Dec. 5). 
 Your suggestion that a drop in aid may increase political instability in Central America is ironic, for nowhere has our aid been used more effectively to thwart the popular will by underwriting military repression.
Since the 1980's, the United States has conditioned aid to the region on the adoption of draconian economic policies designed by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. These "structural adjustment" measures have opened Central American economies wider to Northern commercial interests while undercutting the poor, small producers, devastating the environment and effectively denying citizens a voice.
In Nicaragua, three years of adjustment have left the economy moribund and the population in a desperate state. Led by the U.S. Treasury, the international community has rejected Managua's request for support for a new economic program emanating from a national dialogue. With foreign reserves running out, Managua is having to accept aid on terms it knows will only wreak more havoc and make it more dependent on foreign aid.
 
STEPHEN HELLINGER
Exec. Dir., Development Group
for Alternative Policies
Washington, Dec. 6, 1993

HEADLINE: 'Squeegee' Crackdown Displays Insensitivity

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As the screenwriter and executive producer of "The Saint of Fort Washington," now playing in New York City, I read with amazement the policy of the incoming Commissioner of Police, William Bratton, to "attack the largest crime problems by focusing first on the smallest," namely "to order a crackdown on 'squeegees,' the men and women who wipe the windshields of motorists waiting in traffic" (news article, Dec. 4). 
 In my movie, Danny Glover and Matt Dillon work hard as two of these homeless New Yorkers who try to earn enough money to rent an apartment by washing windshields with their squeegees. When I researched the movie years ago in New York, there was still some compassion about the plight of these homeless people and their struggle to gain an economic footing.
But Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani and his new Police Commissioner have the opposite point of view. To them these people wielding squeegees are common criminals and must be incarcerated. What a sorry commentary. Is all of New York City about to fall down the rabbit hole? I suggest the mayor-elect and police commissioner-to-be see my movie before taking office.
 
LYLE KESSLER
Santa Monica, Calif., Dec. 6, 1993

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (95%); CALIFORNIA, USA (79%); 

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (94%);

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
As Gunfire Gets Closer, Fear Comes Home

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

 BODY:
FANS of evolution, people who find that silver thread of adaptive progress in the darkest, most random events, might just as well focus on one particular passenger in last week's Long Island commuter train carnage who took out his cellular phone and tenderly approached the coherent among the bleeding gunshot victims waiting aboard the train for trauma aid. "Who can I call for you? Give me a number?" the man pleaded.
Good: Fight the national rage of 9-millimeter technology with electronic highway technology. Do something. Don't just wallow there in the mortal phenomena. Cling to the appearances of reasonableness, even as our latest gunman did. "Reasons for this" the stalker had thoughtfully jotted down beforehand in a pocket list of aggravations that seemed the usual welter of paranoid precision. At the end he punctiliously added: "In case of emergency, call. . ." and gave his phone number back in New York City where he lived alone and stoked his rage, preparing an emergency, indeed, for strangers not to be spared his sense of grievance. 
 The victims all are most precious losses, as with all this year's thousands across the national toll of violence by criminals and the criminally insane -- a working-class father and son shot side by side, an exemplary young immigrant lawyer taken from her husband, a little girl's doting father bestilled amid his new commuting routine. The pistol slayings stirred another national sensation that prompted the Clinton Administration to float another gun-control proposal, but the local politics of the issue remain as contrary as ever with each fresh shooting spree. This time the suburban venue was the key to freshening the news value of more gun deaths: the idea of innocent lives and hopes being smashed open amid a most vulnerable, lulling means of passage, a commuter train on its soporific nightly trundle back from high-risk urban America.
At the news, the rest of us took up our familiar spectator roles. How quickly the radio call-in shows adjusted, some people actually taking the topical bait and discussing "bias crime," as if a meticulous list of ethnic and institutional complaints should be taken literally. Driving back from the shooting scene, you could hear the usual mix of queries ("How could this. . .etc.?") and vicarious righteousness ("It's time that we. . .etc."). But mainly there was a sense of media poultice, of the surrounding innocents, wounded by fresh horrific news, needing to restore that chimera, the belief we can respond effectively to abnormality.
At the wheel came easy notions of menace ingrained. Menace? Well, look at the squeegee guys at the red light. Do they know they're being officially targeted by the new city administration, counter-menaced in a way by the rest of us who don't much like being hustled by the threat of filthy beggar rags and brigands' leers across life's hermetic windshield?
"Disorder is a precursor of serious crime," says George L. Kelling, a criminal justice professor at Northeastern University who has been studying squeegee beggars, as if they were urban fauna in the latest documentary on evolution. "More and more there is a demand to do something about this sense of disorder in the streets," the professor says, championing the current "broken window" thesis of New York City's Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani, which holds that if small incursions are tolerated, larger felonies are sure to follow.
So, a micro approach. The squeegee pests are to be arrested for their menace now, even as they are studied like antibodies in society's petrie-dish researches against crime. Who knows? Amid the urban anomie beyond the windshield, not so far away now from the commuter mayhem, the thesis seems no less fruitless than gun control. At a red light, a squeegee man named Matt begs to differ with the broken-window thesis. He says the real key to keeping life these days is in guessing precisely which ones among those of us who jut and mouth out from the general throng of angry Americans just might be armed for emphasis. "I mean, we got kids in this city packing 9-millimeter pistols, and the city ought to be figuring out how to stop them from moving on to assault rifles, am I right?" asks Matt, a man after Jules Feiffer's heart.
Feiffer long ago exhausted the satirical arts, in words and pictures and theater, of alerting the nation to its unspeakable criminal violence. Reality has outraced him, most awfully, lately, in instances of small-town and suburban kidnap-murders of children across the country that underline growing community frustration at violent crime's reach beyond the cities. In the St. Louis region, the bodies of two little girls have police hunting another serial killer -- modern America's haunting crime figure in real life, in entertainment movies and in popular docudrama pastiches of both. The statistics of violent crime may be dropping slightly, but the poignant detail of fresh depradations can stun the nation. In one of the Missouri murders, the young victim's parents had taken the precaution of giving her a personal alarm, a device that was found wailing and abandoned on the street.
Amid the high volume of murders, it seems to take lethal intrusion into previously secure situations, such as the suburban commuter routine or small-town home life, to heighten demands for remedy. This was the case with one horrendous California tragedy this fall, the kidnapping at knife-point of a 12-year-old girl from a slumber party. She turned up murdered, lost to life in Petaluma, a small town used for staging Ronald Reagan's now classic "Morning in America" commercials.
Thus can grisly incongruity grow, along with the toll. As it proceeds, the latest detailed news of random violence, whatever it will be (and it will), seems of value mainly for scraps of mercy amid the crimson woe. "They must have been asleep," says one commuter eyewitness in a gentle depiction of the three men she saw slumped in the blood- and tissue-smeared train.
The gunman, identified as Colin Ferguson, a 35-year-old immigrant from the island of Jamaica, had ridden out from the city, with a swath of angry institutional and ethnic grievances jotted on notes in his pocket, to stalk commuters as they neared Garden City.
While the public is plunged deeper into this grisly evidence of the prevalence and risks of gun play, legislators remain most wary of the political risks of gun control. The latest incremental idea to be talked about by the Clinton Administration, picked up from Mayor-elect Giuliani, is to somehow license the nation's legions of gun owners and make them prove their proficiency. There undoubtedly will be another burst of proposals at the next particularly noticeable volley of violent crime.
"I had strange thoughts the whole time," says a commuter who fled down the aisle. "Half of it didn't seem real. When it dawned on me it was really going on, this guy shooting -- pop, pop, pop -- I thought: 'Here it's only a minute before my stop. I was so close to freedom. Why couldn't this guy have done this a minute later?' " With such candor did the survivor describe not so much the surprise of the event but the familiar sense of removal he craved and normally has when the latest twist of violence comes down. Another passenger lost these critical bearings after he was shot and still wondered if this could be true. Before the pain swept him, the traveler remembers thinking: "This is a story in a newspaper like any other day. This is a sick story."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Is a Diplomacy of Dollars Really Enough?

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SHORTLY after the Clinton Administration took office, Secretary of State Warren Christopher told a gathering of American, Japanese and European businessmen that he saw himself as the America Desk officer at the State Department and that his top priority was "American jobs."
At a recent White House briefing, Secretary of Commerce Ron Brown introduced Mr. Christopher by commenting that the country "finally has a Secretary of State" who believes one of his prime tasks is "to promote American business abroad." 
 After listening to Mr. Brown and Mr. Christopher, it was tempting to ask: Would the real Secretary of Commerce please stand up?
President Clinton has deliberately blurred the lines between these two on the grounds that the only way to enlarge the American economy today and create more jobs is by expanding foreign trade. And with no over-arching threat from the Soviet Union to preoccupy diplomats, opening markets is as valuable a task as any for a Secretary of State.
Actually, American foreign policy has always been a blend of economic, political and security concerns. To fight the cold war, the United States built both a political-security alliance, based on NATO and an economic alliance based on the Marshall Plan, foreign aid and global trading rules. These two orders were mutually reinforcing, but the security side always dominated alliance politics and American foreign policy.
The President's effort to radically change that balance has set off a debate as to whether the Administration has not forgotten that there is more to foreign policy than trade policy.
 
'Gone Overboard'
 "I think we have gone overboard in looking at the world through the question of: 'Is it going to create more jobs?' only" argued Morton I. Abramowitz, former Ambassador to Turkey and now president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "We may be inadvertently conveying in our rhetoric that all our problems are foreign economic problems and that people should not worry about Bulgaria or Albania or Russia, because they are not creating jobs. The danger is that you may actually be encouraging American insularity."
From another angle, Human Rights Watch, an American monitoring group, said in its annual report last week: "Rather than articulating a vision of human rights as an essential element of world order, the Clinton Administration has only cautiously embraced the cause, jettisoning human rights when the going gets rough."
President Clinton was driven to emphasize jobs diplomacy partly because of the economic realities of the post-cold war world and partly because of the ideological realities. He clearly realized early on that the collapse of the "Evil Empire" has deprived his Administration of the sort of compelling threat that could galvanize the American public and justify devoting resources for an active, broad-gauged foreign policy. He needed a new way to legitimize engagement abroad, and it had to be something that average Americans could feel as viscerally as they felt the Communist threat -- not some abstraction that could only be explained to them by a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. His answer, in part, was: "Jobs, jobs, jobs."
But maybe this is just the lazy man's post-cold war ideology. "Jobs" is a mantra, not a vision. It represents not a foreign policy doctrine but an intellectual vacuum. The Administration still has not explained what is the proper relationship between security and economics and human rights in specific situations, such as relations with China.
Critics of the President argue that an overemphasis on jobs and trade also can give a very unrealistic view of the world to the American public, because it explains only part of a complex world. Passion and ideology still frequently overwhelm economic interests. The Serbs are not shelling Sarajevo in a mad quest for more jobs; Israelis and Palestinians are not still killing each other because of differing interpretations of the GATT agreement.
Also, a purely trade-driven foreign policy risks dulling the senses of the American people. Americans have always been enlisted into foreign engagements by a spirit of moral crusade. American boys have never gone off to war chanting "G.N.P., G.N.P., G.N.P."
Many American ambassadors agree that they must put more emphasis on economics and trade -- and that the President is justified in some overstatement in order to jar the bureaucracy into thinking differently. Their complaint is that he has not backed his dollar diplomacy with dollars: The State Department's budget is scheduled to shrink by 20 percent in real terms over the next five years. Consulates, which are also export promotion centers, are being closed all over the world. The American Consul in Bilbao, Spain, in that country's industrial heartland, now has a budget of $50 a year to entertain Spanish businessmen -- enough for one good lunch (without wine). Vice President Gore's proposal for reinventing government includes a call to close American libraries overseas. "Businessmen and students use those libraries all the time to learn about our products and our culture; they're not just there to read 'Moby Dick,' " said one senior American diplomat in Europe. "I still have a huge military section and a huge C.I.A. section in my embassy. It is still a cold-war embassy. In terms of export promotion, I am not even in a position to deliver on the President's rhetoric."
Administration officials counter that over time all of this will change. They also argue that, despite some overstatements, Mr. Christopher is actually running a very balanced foreign policy -- stressing economics and the balance of trade in Asia, and classic diplomacy and the balance of power in the Middle East.
The importance of the end of the cold war, they say, is precisely that it allows American policy to adjust to each region. Too often in the past, they argue, countries like Japan exploited the State Department's obsession with forging security alliances and bamboozled Washington into playing down trade differences for fear of alienating Tokyo. Those days are over.
J. Brian Attwood, head of the Agency for International Development, argues that the Administration's stress on economics in foreign policy is intended not only for profit but for prevention. The cold war has left behind a collection of failed states, from Haiti to Somalia. Providing them with a means for sustainable development -- which is the core philosophy in Mr. Clinton's revamping of A.I.D. -- is not a soft-hearted humanitarian gesture "but a way of dealing with specific threats to our interests and to world stability," he said. That is the essence of preventive diplomacy.
Indeed, at this moment, economic levers may be far more effective tools with which to influence other countries' behavior, or bring rogue states back from the brink of aggression, than the traditional political and military ones, said Jeffrey E. Garten, Under Secretary for International Trade. Cargo-ship diplomacy can, he seemed to be saying, replace gunboat diplomacy.
"It isn't just a question of jobs, jobs, jobs," he said. "It is what levers does the United States have in the post-cold war world that mean something. I think that the military option means less and less, except in situations where real national security is at stake. It will mean nothing if the 82d Airborne flew over Indonesia. So what? But if A.T.& T. wires the whole country -- that is a significant amount of influence."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
North Korea's Game Looks a Lot Like Nuclear Blackmail

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
WHEN historians and intelligence analysts search for the roots of North Korea's drive for atomic weapons, they are usually drawn back to a moment 43 years ago, when the Truman Administration contemplated the quick and decisive way to end the Korean War: a nuclear attack on Pyongyang.
It never happened, of course, but North Korea's leaders to this day throw Gen. Douglas MacArthur's plan in the face of visitors as a symbol of American imperialist savagery. The power of the bomb, even as a threat, made an impression that four decades later is coming back to haunt the White House. 
 The country whose frenzied Stalinist rhetoric became a joke even among its Communist allies, whose moribund economy made Cuba look like an entrepreneurial powerhouse, has suddenly found the formula for dealing with America as an equal. At 81, Kim Il Sung, the world's longest serving national leader, is trying out his theory that nothing makes Washington take you seriously faster than a pile of plutonium.
And it's working. In the last few weeks hardly a day has passed without the President of the United States -- who was 4 years old when the "great leader" faced off against America the first time -- talking about the importance of a deal with one of the world's most isolated regimes. After decades of refusing to speak directly with the North, officials of the State Department and the National Security Council are dangling the kind of carrots Mr. Kim once fantasized about: promises of trade, economic aid, an end to the biggest American-South Korean military exercise, even diplomatic recognition.
Washington will talk about all this as soon as international inspectors are allowed back into seven buildings at the heart of the North's nuclear complex. Needless to say, if there ever was much evidence of a bomb project inside, by now it has been moved someplace else. And Mr. Kim has played his few cards superbly. "Just think how much Kim has accomplished in the past few months," a senior Japanese intelligence official mused. "America is paying attention to him. Everyone else in Asia is afraid of how the North Koreans may overreact to too much pressure." The North, he suggested, hasn't gotten this much attention since it crossed the Han River in 1950, wiping out Seoul.
Indeed, even today, 40 years after the signing of the armistice, North Korea's greatest leverage arises from the fear it engenders -- not so much because of its million-man army or its artillery within easy reach of Seoul, but rather because of the regime's reputation for unpredictability. This is, after all, the country that a few years ago was blowing up commercial airliners and planting bombs to wipe out the South Korean Cabinet. That weighs heavily on Washington's strategists. "There is a fine line between persuading North Korea to do what needs to be done, and provoking a terrible reaction," Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said recently in Seoul.
 
Wavering
 Clinton Administration officials bristle, of course, at any suggestion that their proposed concessions prove that nuclear blackmail works. But that is the subtext of the whole drama intensifying in Washington, Tokyo, Seoul and Pyongyang.
It may also explain why Mr. Clinton seems to be wavering so -- brandishing economic sanctions one day, then wondering aloud if they would work, then trying to cool down the rhetoric, then insisting again on full inspections. Clearly, having backed away from stated goals in Bosnia, Somalia and Haiti, he is under pressure to show that, in at least one area of key American interest, military power can still be converted into diplomatic influence. But is it really worth the risk for a bomb that may not exist?
For Mr. Kim, American analysts and military commanders assume that there is only one agenda item: To save his reeling regime from imminent economic collapse. No one seems to think he or his mysterious son, Kim Jong Il, can pull it off, but then again a year ago no one thought they would get this far.
In this strategy, stage one is obvious: Rip down the blockades to doing business with America and Japan, since Russia and China have lost virtually all interest in dealing with Mr. Kim's bankrupt Government.
Stage two gets a bit more dicey. North Korean officials described to visitors last year an image of their country somewhat akin to Vietnam -- a Communist regime seeking to maintain rigid social controls while marketing a disciplined, cheap work force and natural resources to moneyed neighbors. Right now, this hardly seems like Asia's greatest investment opportunity. But last week, along with the usual threats, the North turned out a remarkably detailed -- and in some ways quite liberal -- set of regulations for free-trade zones.
Mr. Kim knows two things: As soon as he reveals all his nuclear mysteries they are worthless as bargaining chips, and he has very little time to make this high-wire act work. The economic desperation is now so deep that North Korean propaganda last week finally dropped any pretense of hiding it. Meanwhile the man presented last year as a champion of reform, Kim Dal Yong, the state planning chief, was mysteriously deposed last week, presumably because whatever he was doing didn't work fast enough.
What all this means is that while Mr. Clinton has no good short-term options on nuclear inspection, the long-term strategy is simply to try to assure the world of a soft landing as North Korea collapses. That helps explain why Japan and South Korea are generally advocating timidity on the nuclear issue. The Japanese are shy of confrontation, and fearful of a flood of refugees or unrest within their own big North Korean community. The South fears being stuck with the bill for the North's collapse. But both recognize that the current situation cannot last; already the International Atomic Energy Agency is saying its cameras have failed from lack of maintenance, and it can no longer ensure that nuclear material is not being diverted to bombs. Soon that alone may drive the West to seek sanctions, and prudence will dictate a military buildup to guard against retaliation. "The place is going to implode or explode," Gen. Gary E. Luck, the commander of American forces in South Korea, said recently. "I hope it's an implosion. Because I don't think the world would like to see what an explosion looks like."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Amid Joblessness, The Joys of Tenure

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN the halls of academia, only a few doctrines are as sacred as free trade. One of them, not surprisingly, is tenure, the almost ironclad guarantee of job security that most professors enjoy.
Curiously, many of the same arguments scholars make in favor of removing international trade barriers can also be used to make the case against their own lifetime job protection. 
 Like tariffs and quotas, tenure promotes inefficiency, inhibits competition and probably raises costs to consumers. Both systems are vestiges of a younger America. Trade protection was introduced to allow burgeoning American industries to grow solid roots; today, the arguments for it mostly involve salvaging jobs for unskilled workers. Similarly, tenure was instituted decades ago at a few elite universities to shield academic freedom; now a fixture on more than 90 percent of American campuses, it guards little more than the professors' paychecks.
Presumably, few of the 300 tenured professors of economics who signed a letter to President Clinton last summer supporting the North American Free Trade Agreement considered the connections.
But many politicians, especially those who opposed that trade agreement, spotted the link. Even some who favored Nafta resented what seemed to be the callous way many economists made their points. Like this argument: Sure, Nafta will cause hundreds of thousands of workers to lose their jobs, but even more jobs will be created. Or: The jobs that will be lost are low-skilled, low-wage jobs. We ought to concentrate on generating high-tech, well-paying jobs.
Here is how Representative David E. Bonior, a Democrat from Michigan, characterized such arguments in a passionate speech in the House in a losing cause the night Nafta was approved last month:
"The working people who stand against this treaty don't have degrees from Harvard. They don't study economic models. And most of them have never heard of Adam Smith. To them, Nafta isn't some economic theory. It's real life."
Some economist recognize the paradox. One is Jagdish Bhagwati, a tenured professor at Columbia who is one of this country's most prominent advocates of free trade but who is mindful of the pain expanded trade can cause some workers.
"Economists," Mr. Bhagwati said last week, "might not approach with such ferocity, without any understanding of the human cost involved, the view that flux and labor turnover promote economic efficiency if they themselves were subject to the same flux."
Few other Americans besides judges enjoy such lifetime contracts. According to the Department of Education, more than 60 percent of the nation's full-time faculty members enjoy tenure, and many who don't expect to earn it in the next few years. College teachers are on probation for five to seven years, after which they are dismissed or granted tenure. Once invested, professors can be let go only for serious misconduct or what their contracts generally call "financial exigencies."
The American Association of University Professors reports that in a typical year, 35 to 50 professors nationwide are discharged for offenses like plagiarism or sexual harassment. But professors are almost never let go for incompetence, and few if any are laid off for financial reasons, even though nearly every school in the country is cutting back in other ways.
 
Fossilization?
 The consequence, said Chester Finn, an Assistant Secretary of Education in the Reagan Administration who is now a tenured professor of education and public policy on leave from Vanderbilt University, "is the fossilization of any given department. You end up with people who haven't had an idea in 15 years. There is no room for energetic, fresh thinkers."
The provost of a large eastern university, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the tenure system made it practically impossible for him to make adjustments in the faculty when cost cuts were essential or when students' tastes changed. "Let's say, I wanted to substitute taped lectures for a particularly uninspired professor or reduce the size of the classics department and expand the department of Japanese studies," the provost said. "I simply could not do it."
Last year, Thomas Day, the president of San Diego State University, announced plans to dismiss more than 100 tenured professors and close nine academic departments to offset a cut in state financing. He was forced to back down after an uprising by faculty members. Afterward, he told The Los Angeles Times that the lesson he had learned was, "It's not your university; it's the faculty's university."
 
 
Academic Fashions
 Even the staunchest advocates of tenure concede that it is no longer necessary to protect professors' freedom to speak out politically. "If by academic freedom you mean that taking Marxist or fascist positions would be risky, that doesn't come up much any more," said Ernst Benjamin, general secretary of the American Association of University Professors. More of a problem, Mr. Benjamin said, are professors who antagonize their schools or communities by, say, flunking a football player. But he said the real importance of tenure was that it provided employment security against faculty overhauls every time fashions in education changed.
What Mr. Benjamin calls security others call rigidity. Robert Stevens, now in England as head of Pembroke College at Oxford, said that when he was president of Haverford College in Pennsylvania in the 1980's, a third of the faculty taught two-thirds of the students, largely because tenure tied administrators' hands.
But Mr. Stevens and many other academic administrators said alternatives to tenure might prove worse. At least, tenure involves a rigorous up-or-out probation period that, in theory at least, weeds out unacceptable faculty members before they get a lifetime appointment. Without it, inertia might lead to almost everyone's being retained. And financial saving from replacing expensive dead wood on faculties with a younger, lower-paid staff might be offset if professors demanded higher pay in exchange for loss of job security.
This is where tenure differs from trade protection. Eliminating trade barriers would no doubt make the economy more efficient. But as Milton Greenberg, the former provost of American University, observed, efficiency at universities can't be measured. "You don't get paid based on how much you are producing," he said.

HEADLINE: Job-Loss Anger: Age Bias Cases Soar in Region

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
At 57 years old and unemployed after 32 years with Merrill Lynch & Company, James Vincent Rooney has angry words for his former employer, the nation's largest brokerage concern.
"The thing that aggravates me the most is how happy they are to train the young people," he said in a telephone interview from his daughter's home in Pennsylvania. He moved there in November, a month after selling his Staten Island home to raise money, and 10 months after being abruptly dismissed from his $70,000-a-year position as a computer specialist at Merrill Lynch. His search for another job has proved so frustrating that he said he had given up. 
 One thing he has not given up on is the law: He is suing the brokerage firm for age discrimination.
 
Increasing Awareness
 Mr. Rooney is among a legion of displaced workers over 40 who, buttressed by a series of amendments to Federal equal opportunity laws over the last 25 years, are swiftly elevating age discrimination to a higher and more contentious level on the nation's legal, social and corporate agenda.
Lawyers, corporate executives and the older workers themselves say disputes over age discrimination have become far more frequent and have gained new urgency because of the economic slump and the restructuring of corporate America that has resulted in mass layoffs by hundreds of companies.
And while the economy is picking up, one abiding lesson of the recession is that many employers, seeking lower costs and increased productivity through computers and high technology, can get the work they need from a 25-year-old engineer or business school graduate rather than a company veteran and do so at a far lower salary.
"It doesn't take a rocket scientist to realize demographics are going to drive this issue," said Charles Fried, a law professor at Harvard University. Although age discrimination "has not caught the imagination of the academic world in the same way as race and sex discrimination, it is going to be the bread and butter of a lot of lawyers," he said.
 
Complaints Have Risen
 Since 1989, when economists say the nation sank into recession, the number of age discrimination complaints to the Federal Government has risen steadily each year.
The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the Federal agency that investigates discrimination in the workplace, said it handled 19,884 of the complaints in the 1993 fiscal year, which ended on Sept. 30, 32 percent more than in the 1989 fiscal year.
The region with the steepest increase in complaints has been the one with the nation's largest concentration of corporate employment -- New York City and its suburbs. The Federal agency said its age discrimination complaints in the city, on Long Island and in Westchester County more than doubled between 1989 and 1992, to 1,292, before falling back to 1,069 in the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30.
"We are dealing with white-collar factories," said James L. Lee, the chief counsel for the New York office of the Federal agency.
He attributed the unusually sharp increase in cases at his office to the huge number of corporate job cuts in the region and to few displaced workers over 40 having the protection of labor unions and seniority rights that are commonplace in the manufacturing centers of the Middle West and elsewhere.
The wave of recent complaints and lawsuits stems in large part from changes in Federal law that have all but done away with the concept of "mandatory retirement" in the American workplace.
The principal law, the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, was enacted in 1967. It made it illegal to arbitrarily dismiss workers from ages 40 to 65 on the basis of their age.
Amendments since then pushed the age-65 ceiling on the workplace protection higher -- to 70 in 1978. Then, in 1987, the ceiling itself was eliminated. Another change in 1991 eliminated a two-year statute of limitations on age discrimination lawsuits, giving broad channels of recourse to virtually all middle-aged and elderly workers.
People in only a handful of occupations are exempt from the Federal protections, including the police, tenured college professors and top-level corporate executives. And even those exemptions are being whittled away -- the law is to be extended to the police and professors on Dec. 31.
 
'Age Should Not Be a Factor'
 "The law recognizes that when you are in full command of your faculties and have something to offer, age should not be a factor in employment," said Todd Ryan-Millington of Ossining, in Westchester County, who may provide a model for the advocates of the rights of older workers.
Mrs. Ryan-Millington, 78, was dismissed in 1990 from her job as office manager in the Manhattan sales office of New Cherokee Corporation, a textile manufacturer. Not content to retire, she says she has "no intention of sitting down," complains that "the suburbs are boring" and is boning up on her French and German in the hope of starting a new career as a translater.
She has also won a judgment in her age discrimination complaint against her former employer. In November, after an investigation of her case and those of two other former New Cherokee workers over 40, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission threatened a Federal lawsuit, and the company agreed to pay Mrs. Ryan-Millington $99,000 in an out-of-court settlement.
Although Mrs. Ryan-Millington relied entirely on the Federal agency to act on her behalf, many other displaced older workers have turned to private lawyers, making age discrimination a growing area of the law.
"There is a deluge of cases," said Leonard N. Flamm, a Manhattan lawyer who has made age discrimination a specialty. And many of them involve class-action suits in which displaced workers join together as plaintiffs.
 
Class-Action Suits Favored
 Often, he said, the class-action cases are easier to pursue in court than those with only one plaintiff, particularly if the displaced workers can present statistical evidence showing that a single cutback or series of layoffs affected more people over 40 than younger workers.
That legal strategy is being employed by one of his clients, Sheila Rosen, a 60-year-old Manhattan resident who was dismissed in 1990 as a market research manager after 15 years with a division of the American Home Products Company.
She said she was dismissed abruptly, along with 100 colleagues who were over 40 years old, within weeks after the division was acquired by Reckitt and Colman, a British concern. Although layoffs were widespread, she said, only one of the division's employees who was older than 40 was offered a job by the new owner, while half of those younger than 40 were offered continued employment.
"The law was broken here, and I want to stand up and say, 'You can't do this to me,' " said Ms. Rosen, who has not found another job, and is hoping for a jury trial of her suit against Reckitt and Colman. The company, now based in Wayne, N.J., declined to comment on the case.
Among workers older than 40, Mr. Flamm said, awareness of the age discrimination has expanded.
"People are calling lawyers sooner, even before they are fired," he said. "Suing is no longer considered to be for wierdos. These people may never work again, so this could be their last hurrah."
 
A 'Lottery Ticket'?
 That sentiment, however, touches raw nerves among large employers and the lawyers who represent them. They maintain that the growing body of law against age discrimination has led to a flood of suits that are sometimes simply frivolous and more often resemble gambling bets by former employees who are driven by pride but have little legal rationale for their lawsuits.
For plaintiffs, "going to court is like buying a lottery ticket," said Felix Springer, a lawyer with Day, Berry & Howard, the largest law firm in Connecticut, who has represented many companies defending themselves in age discrimination cases. "It's a bit more expensive than the lottery, but your chances of hitting are somewhat better."
In many cases, he added, employers are entitled to dismiss workers who are over 40 for reasons that the workers themselves are not willing to acknowledge.
"It may not be at 45 or 65, but we all eventually slow down," he said. "People are often unwilling to look at themselves and say, 'I screwed up" or 'I've become inadequate.' "
Among employers, age discrimination may have become an even more intense area of debate and anxiety than among their employees.
"It is only in the last decade that this has showed up on companys' agendas, and now it's high on their agendas," said Ann Bartel, a business professor at Columbia University, who is a consultant to companies on how to avoid age discrimination.
Even if they have not been sued for age discrimination, few corporate executives are oblivious to the growing legal influence of older workers because of a string of charges against large employers.
The Equal Employment Opportunities Commission issued a finding on Nov. 23 that Sears, Roebuck & Company had illegally required its employees to waive all age discrimination claims as part of a voluntary early-retirement program.
In October a Federal court jury ordered the Long Island Lighting Company to pay $2 million in damages to a 57-year-old engineer it had dismissed in violation of age-discrimination laws.
Other companies that have been sued in major age discrimination cases this year include the Martin Marietta Astronautics Group, American Airlines, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and Kidder, Peabody.
 
Mostly Defensive Measures
 Ms. Bartel said the precautions that corporations have taken against age discrimination suits have so far consisted largely of making sure that when layoffs occur, no more employees over 40 years old are dismissed than under 40 years old.
But she said few of the companies have expanded the programs to retrain and assist veteran workers in keeping their skills and productiveness on par with those of their younger colleagues.
"Companies are not being pro-active," she said, adding that they will need to become more aggressive in helping older workers. "It is going to become more incumbent upon companies to retrain," she said.
In the case of Mr. Rooney, who charges that Merrill Lynch failed to offer him retraining as an alternative to dismissal, the company said on Friday that it routinely provides retraining to its employees, and that Mr. Rooney was offered such programs many times in his 32 years, although not as an alternative on the day he was dismissed.
"He did not seek retraining and found himself unprepared to fill other functions as his responsibilities became obsolete and diversified," said Bill Clark, a company spokesman.
Mr. Rooney, however, said he was hoping to take his case before a Federal court jury within the next year.
In the meantime, he said, his 57 years are not only a major issue in his case against Merrill Lynch, but in his futile efforts to find another job.
"You go into an interview, they take one look at the gray hair and glasses, and that's it," he said.

HEADLINE: CHINESE DISSIDENT WARNED BY BEIJING

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 11

 BODY:
In China's first attempt to silence the country's most famous dissident since he was released last fall from a long prison term, Wei Jingsheng said the Public Security Bureau has told him that he cannot write articles for publication at home or abroad.
The warning was reportedly given to the 43-year-old Mr. Wei last week and was related to a piece Mr. Wei wrote for the Op-Ed page of The New York Times, which was highly critical of China's attitude toward democracy and human rights. The essay, which appeared on Nov. 18, was the first article Mr. Wei has written for any publication since he was released last September from 14 1/2 years in prison. 
 Mr. Wei reported the warning in a telephone call to The New York Times bureau in Beijing. Mr. Wei said public security officials told him that his essay in The Times was a violation of his parole and should not be repeated.
It was the first warning Mr. Wei has acknowledged receiving since his release. In the past, Mr. Wei has dismissed suggestions that the Chinese authorities would try to silence him after his release.
 
Holding Back for Now
 But over the last several days, Mr. Wei has said he seemed to have little choice but to heed the warning for now.
Attempts to reach a spokesman for the Public Security Bureau today were unsuccessful. Prohibition against publishing abroad had not previously been spelled out as a condition of Mr. Wei's probation, according to statements by Ministry of Justice officials.
Mr. Wei's article was written for The Times on the eve of President Clinton's meeting in Seattle with China's President, Jiang Zemin. It urged the United States not to let up pressure on China to improve its human rights record.
In his essay, Mr. Wei said China's present leaders were "the most outspoken group of men, shouting their support of human rights and democracy before they ascended to power."
"But their subsequent dictatorship made clear that they have no intention of making good on the promises they once made to the masses," he wrote.
 
China Faces More Criticism
 The apparent attempt by China to muzzle Mr. Wei, who was known during his years in prison as a man of unbendable will when it came to expressing his views, is sure to draw further criticism from human rights organizations and the Clinton Administration.
The State Department is preparing to give an interim report to Congress next month. Last May Mr. Clinton stated that he would not renew China's most favored nation trade privileges in June 1994 unless Beijing showed "significant, overall progress" on human rights.
Winston Lord, the State Department's assistant secretary for East Asia, said on Wednesday that China has "got to understand that movement is required or we're all going to be in trouble come next spring." He likened China's looming confrontation with Washington over human rights to a prospective "train wreck."
Speaking to State Department employees with uncharacteristic anger, Mr. Lord lashed out at recent remarks attributed to a White House official suggesting that President Clinton is so focused on expanding American business interests in China that "we're not going to let something like M.F.N. stand in our way."
 
Human Rights and the Economy
 Mr. Wei, in his essay, had attempted to join the debate over whether a strong American human rights policy aimed at ending repression in China was worth risking a break in relations.
He asked whether the American Government was "controlled by rich capitalists" whose "consciences never stopped them from making money."
He compared the Communist Party leadership to an "old wolf" that might talk about changing its nature, but in the end would follow its natural predatory instincts.
Mr. Wei reported the Chinese Government warning at a time when the dissident is discussing with publishers in Hong Kong and New York the possibility of publishing his prison letters and of writing an autobiography.
Such writings are typically picked up and translated by Hong Kong magazines and newspapers that are brought into China by travelers.

HEADLINE: New Forest Chief Faces Test Over Alaska Timber

BYLINE: By By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
The new chief of the National Forest Service, facing his first major decision, is being pressed by conservationists to cancel a big timber sale in the Tongass National Forest in Alaska.
Jack Ward Thomas, who was appointed last month, must decide on Monday whether he will review the planned logging of a vast section of the Tongass forest on Prince of Wales Island in southeastern Alaska. 
 The sale of 267 million board feet of timber from 360,000 acres -- already approved by the regional office of the Forest Service -- is the largest disposal of public timber now planned in the national forests. Conservationists oppose it because they say the Forest Service has not taken into account the effects of the sale on wildlife.
Aside from the sheer size of the transaction, Mr. Thomas's decision is being closely watched by conservationists who have viewed his appointment as a signal that the agency is turning away from a long history of managing the forests mainly for the benefit of the timber industry. Many old-line forest managers in the agency had opposed his appointment, saying it would politicize the Forest Service. Mr. Thomas, a scientist with the agency, was a political appointee not promoted from the senior ranks of managers.
In a letter sent on Friday to Mr. Thomas, Representative George Miller, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Committee on Natural Resources, urged him to review the Tongass sale. Mr. Miller's committee is investigating the service's compliance with the Tongass Timber Reform Act of 1990, which changed the way the forest is managed.
"I know that you share my concerns about abuses which have occurred in the management of our national forests," Mr. Miller wrote. "It would be most unfortunate if, at the very outset of your tenure as chief, the Tongass sale would proceed without adequate review and policy direction reflecting the views" of the Administration.
Two weeks ago, the agency's Alaska regional forest manager turned down an appeal by conservationists seeking to halt the latest sale of Tongass timber to the Ketchikan Pulp Company, one of two logging concerns that have 50-year contracts to cut in the forest.
The conservationists are now urging Mr. Thomas to take the matter up for review. Although a decision to review it would not necessarily mean he would ultimately reverse the regional forester, it would put him into conflict with the timber company, which under the contract is guaranteed a continuous supply of wood from the forest.
"In the course of the last four to five years, we have been short in excess of 100 million board feet," said Martin Pihl, general manager of the company. "The real situation is worse than that, because we have depleted inventories. Further delay will only aggravate the situation. It will cause down time and put people out of work."
Conservation groups contend that Ketchikan Pulp and the other company, the Alaska Pulp Corporation, are not living up to the intent of the contracts, which was to provide stable, year-round jobs at mills making a raw material known as dissolving pulp. The market for that product is saturated, and there have already been layoffs.
The conservation groups, organized in a coalition called the Alaska Rainforest Campaign, say the companies want to cut trees under the contracts, which subsidize the costs of wood, so that the timber can be used in sawmills, which are profitable but employ fewer people.
The coalition is pushing not just to halt the sale of timber on Prince of Wales Island -- it also wants the 50-year contracts canceled.
The issue goes to the heart of the debate over the way the Federal agency is managing the forests.
A Forest Service employee, Bill Shoaf, who led a team that reviewed forestry practices on Prince of Wales Island, has asserted that the agency is deliberately overstating the level of timber harvest that can be sustained there in compliance with forestry laws.
The Forest Service is still developing what it calls a "viable populations strategy" for the Tongass forest, and Mr. Shoaf's accusations question whether the agency is considering the tough questions objectively.

HEADLINE: Optimism Buoys GATT Talks Despite a Rift Over U.S. Trade Laws

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Trade talks among 116 countries have become increasingly mired in a dispute that pits the United States against most of the rest of the world over whether American trade laws should remain intact.
Despite the slow progress, however, the mood here remains one of near-certainty that some sort of global trade agreement will be concluded in the next several days. Most issues have been resolved, including the most contentious fights over farm subsidies, European computer tariffs and American apparel tariffs. 
 In one of the few remaining disputes, the current draft text for a new global trade agreement would restrict the ability of the United States to put steep tariffs on many low-priced imports that hurt American industries. The Administration, partly at the urging of the steel and computer chip industries, is seeking changes to limit or remove those restrictions.
Some American exporters and many economists dislike the American trade laws, because other countries are adopting similar laws, raising tariffs and restricting free trade. But American industries facing heavy foreign competition defend the laws, saying they are necessary to combat foreign cartels that keep prices and profits high in their markets while cutting prices to gain market share in the United States.
 
Resistance to Changes
 Asian and Latin American countries, led by Japan, Singapore, South Korea, Brazil and other increasingly competitive trading nations, resisted American requests today for 11 changes in the draft text. The changes are aimed at protecting the American trade laws that allow companies and labor unions to ask the Commerce Department to impose steep tariffs on imported goods that are sold in the United States either below cost or for less than they are sold in other countries, a practice known as dumping.
The question of what happens to American trade laws is a contentious one in Congress. Most Democrats are reluctant to change them, while Republicans are split on the issue. The anti-dumping issue is also becoming the most acrimonious here in Geneva.
Jeffrey Garten, the Undersecretary of Commerce for international trade and the top American official on the anti-dumping issue, said the United States was insisting that all 11 changes be made. "There seems to be a sense on the part of many delegations that we have put out a proposal with many elements for the sake of negotiating a smaller package, but that is a serious misreading of our intentions," he said.
In separate talks today, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, and Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's top trade official, failed to reach a deal on movies, television programs and music recordings. They were expected to continue talking on Sunday.
 
European Pledges Sought
 The United States wants the Europeans to pledge that they will not limit the use of American programs and music or future technologies like satellite broadcasting to homes. The Administration also wants European countries to share with American companies a fee on blank video and audio cassettes, which can be used to make unauthorized copies. All these fees currently go to the European artists' companies.
The community has resisted restrictions on future technologies, and says it already pays full royalties for American entertainment even without the fees on blank cassettes.
Mr. Kantor also said in a statement that the United States was far from any deal on allowing banks and insurance companies to do business anywhere around the world.
The goal of all the negotiations here is a 116-country pact that would reduce tariffs and broaden the free-trade rules of the 45-year-old General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to cover agriculture, insurance and banking for the first time.
The issues still unresolved are disagreements over language rather than numbers, susceptible to being finessed through murky compromises.
The draft text could curb the anti-dumping laws and other American trade laws because it provides for binding international arbitration of trade disputes.
 
An Option for Review
 A country that lost an anti-dumping case in Washington could come to Geneva and ask a panel of trade experts to review the American action. If the panel ruled against the United States, and if three-quarters of GATT's member countries endorsed the ruling, then the Administration would have to cancel the anti-dumping tariff or allow another country to impose steep tariffs on American goods.
Some of these panels exist, but they have little power because GATT rules require that a panel ruling be endorsed unanimously, including endorsement by the country that lost the ruling. This rarely happens. The new requirement of a three-quarters or two-thirds vote would allow more panel rulings to go into effect.
The new rules make the panels very important. The panel's job is to decide whether each country has followed GATT rules. So, the United States is trying to insure that these rules more closely resemble American trade laws.
