HEADLINE: Family Drifts Through Death To Escape Hardship in Cuba

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Desperate to escape a deteriorating economic situation in Cuba, Diosdado Reyes, his wife, 1-year-old son and 10 other members of his family ventured out in a 15-foot, motor-driven wooden boat he had built.
In the first hours at sea, a storm swamped the boat's motor and swept most of the scant provisions and fresh water overboard and left the group adrift. They moved with the currents, scavenging for algae and small fish, and drinking salt water. 
 On the fifth day at sea, Mr. Reyes's older brother, Hermogenes, died of dehydration. The group slid his body into the water to make room on the small boat. On Tuesday, their 12th day since leaving Cuba, they were sighted by a fishing vessel off the Bahamas, but the rescue came too late to save Mr. Reyes's son, Diosnel. The boy was quickly flown by air-ambulance to a Miami hospital, but he died of dehydration.
 
Few Make 90-Mile Crossing
 Studies have shown that as few as one in four Cuban boat people, known as Balseros from the Spanish "balsa" for raft, arrive alive in the Bahamas or their final destination, South Florida. The United States Coast Guard and other groups have issued warnings to deter Cubans from risking the trip. Still, each year thousands like Mr. Reyes and his family weigh the risks and their dismal future in Cuba and choose to try the 90-mile crossing.
As for the Reyes family, "they haven't even realized yet what's happened to them yet," said Clara Del Valle, a director with the Cuban American National Foundation in Miami, which was assisting in efforts to fly the group to Miami.
Mr. Reyes's 6-year-old niece, Dalima Cardosa Reyes, also flown to Children's Hospital in Miami from the Bahamas, was unconscious and unable to breathe on her own when she arrived on Tuesday, said the hospital's administrator, Omar Montejo, but by Friday she had made "incredible progress."
Cristina Reyes, Dalima's mother and Mr. Reyes's sister, was treated for extreme dehydration and released on Friday from Pan American Hospital in Miami. Dalima opened her eyes and greeted her mother with a smile when Ms. Reyes visited late Friday afternoon, Mr. Montejo said.
Cristina Reyes's three other children -- Luis, 6, Daili, 2, and Mariorqui, 8 -- were treated for dehydration and sunburn at a Bahamian hospital. Also treated there were Mr. Reyes's mother, Anita Reinosa, 78; his brother, Alejandro, 23; Alejandro's wife, Maida Palma, and their 2-year-old son, Alejandro Jr. They were all released on Thursday. The seven have temporarily joined the 100 to 150 other Balseros that has sprung up in the Bahamas in recent weeks.
Fernando Rojas of the Cuban American Foundation in Miami said the Immigration and Naturalization Service was arranging humanitarian visas for the family.
Mr. Reyes's wife, Belen Zayas, 23, suffered a collapsed lung during the crossing and will remain under medical care at Pan American Hospital.
Mr. Reyes, who worked as a solderer and an auto body repairman in Moa in the northeast province of Holguin, said the group set sail at dusk on Nov. 22, expecting to need only 8 to 10 hours to reach Great Inagua in the Bahamas, where they had planned to request political asylum.
 
Sighted Ships in Distance
 After the storm damaged their boat and left the group adrift, some on board believed they had drifted near the coast of Spain, Mr. Reyes said in a news conference on Wednesday in Miami.
On Dec. 3, the 11th day at sea, the group managed to tie their boat to some buoys in water near Cay Lobos, one of the southernmost islands in the Bahamas chain. The next day the group sighted ships in the distance and, using bits of white cloth, frantically signaled for help.
When a fishing vessel finally drew alongside, Mr. Reyes said he held his "nearly dead" son up to the crew members before crawling aboard himself.
The fishing vessel notified the Coast Guard, which maintains a helicopter in Great Inagua. Within five hours, the six adults and six children had been transported to the airport in Nassau in the Bahamas, where they were met by ambulances that took them to Princess Margaret Hospital, said Dan Wald schmidt, a Coast Guard spokesman in Miami.
As of Friday, the Coast Guard said that 3,390 Cubans had reached South Florida shores this year, breaking the record of 2,557 set last year. The Coast Guard began tracking the rafters in 1981. Economic hardships and reports of increased repression on the island have spurred the recent exodus.
Jose Cardenas, a spokesman in Washington for the Cuban American foundation, said so many Cubans were trying the crossing and winding up in the Bahamas, the Dominican Republic or Mexico, that the group could assist only those inneed of humanitarian assistance.
"We don't encourage the Balseros to come, but we do try to help those that attempt the crossing," he said. "To a man and woman, they tell us, 'We'd rather risk death on the high seas than the slow death that Fidel Castro subjects us to.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Diosdado Reyes, right, lost his 1-year-old son and brother when he and 12 family members tried to escape from Cuba during a 12-day voyage in a 15-foot, motor-driven wooden boat. Mr. Reyes and his sister, Cristina Reyes, spoke at a news conference last week from a Miami hospital. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Europeans Back French Curbs on U.S. Movies

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 11

 BODY:
European Community leaders today gave full support to demands by France that its system of protecting and subsidizing its movie industry be preserved in any world trade agreement.
This subsidy system, bitterly contested by Washington and Hollywood, has become the chief remaining obstacle in a seven-year-old negotiation, known as the Uruguay Round, whose goal is updating and extending trade rules to stimulate the world economy. Four days remain until Wednesday's agreed deadline for the talks. 
 In a statement at the end of a two-day meeting, the leaders said considerable progress had been made in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks. But they said problems remained, including that of guaranteeing that "an exceptional and separate treatment be reserved for audiovisual products in the present and in the future."
 
New Rules for Film Sector
 The current trade talks deal with bringing the audiovisual sector, which includes movies but also valuable fast-developing technologies like cable and satellite-delivered services, under GATT rules for the first time.
In general, the rules are aimed at eliminating quotas and subsidies. Thus the "exceptional and separate treatment" called for by the European leaders would mean that these anti-subsidy and anti-quota rules would not be applied, now or in the future, to movies, television or future audiovisual technologies.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, has pledged not to yield on the movie question, a vow he also made on agricultural trade before giving way in part to French demands. He has argued that the French system deprives Hollywood of money and market access to which it is entitled.
The conflict pits two considerable forces against each other: a huge American export industry, the second largest after aerospace, with sales in Europe alone of $3.7 billion last year, and Gallic pride, viscerally attached to the notion that France is the sanctuary of serious cinema and to the argument that Hollywood is trying to move from a position of domination to one of monopoly in world entertainment.
As the European Community meeting ended, Sir Leon Brittan, the community's chief trade negotiator, and Mr. Kantor were engaged in potentially decisive talks in Geneva. A special meeting of European foreign ministers has been called for Monday to review the results of their negotiations.
 
U.S. Opposes Limits
 United States objections to current French practice center on a quota system used to limit the amount of American programming on television, and on a series of taxes on movie tickets, television movies and videocassettes that raised $350 million last year and was in turn used to subsidize production of about 150 French films.
Because the American movies account for about 57 percent of the French box office, the tax effectively takes money from American creations to pay for French films. But France argues that Hollywood already has 80 percent of the European market, while Europe has 2 percent of the American, so some protection is required to avoid extinction.
Despite brinkmanship on both sides, it appears that an irresistible momentum toward a GATT agreement has built up. But Jacques Delors, the President of the European Commission, said he still had "grave doubts about the audiovisual sector," and Alain Juppe, the French Foreign Minister, raised the possibility that it might have to be left out of a trade agreement.
But the exclusion of a huge export like movies from the Uruguay Round would probably be unacceptable to Washington.
The European leaders committed themselves to spending more than $130 billion of community money in the next six years on major public works projects like roads, railways and telecommunications.
But they said such projects, intended to create jobs, should be financed principally by the private sector. They rejected a commission request that close to $9 billion a year be raised through community bond issues.

HEADLINE: France Fears Fallout From Algerian Turmoil

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Still bearing the scars of its painful loss of Algeria more than 30 years ago, France is increasingly fearful of being drawn into the violent conflict between Islamic fundamentalists and a besieged army-backed junta in its former North African possession.
But with nearly one million Algerians living here and with Algeria still looking to France as its most important European partner, Paris is finding it difficult to shield itself from the repercussions of the violence tearing Algeria apart. 
 The Algerian crisis is "one of the most dramatic and difficult situations we have to face," President Francois Mitterrand has warned. The European Affairs Minister, Alain Lamassoure, noted this week that France was "very worried" by developments in Algeria.
On Wednesday, an elderly man became the third French citizen slain in Algeria since September. Three French diplomats were kidnapped there in October, supposedly by Islamic extremists, although they were later freed.
Angered by the kidnappings, France responded by rounding up 88 suspected sympathizers of the Islamic Salvation Front, the fundamentalist group that was poised to win Algerian parliamentary elections two years ago, before the authorities canceled them. And while all but one Algerian was released, the French Government warned the front against acting in France. This week, French police detained a dozen Tunisian fundamentalists for questioning.
With another militant Algerian organization, the Armed Islamic Group, now threatening to kill all foreigners, France has reluctantly urged its citizens to return home or at least to send dependents back to France. Of some 75,000 French citizens in Algeria, all but 8,000 also have Algerian nationality. So far, between 3,000 and 4,000 have left Algeria.
Alarmed by the attacks on foreigners, Russia, Germany, Italy, Spain and Britain have encouraged their citizens to leave. On Thursday, the United States said it was reducing its embassy staff in Algiers and urged Americans to leave if they did not have compelling reasons to remain.
Although 8 of the 11 foreigners slain by militants since September were not French, no country feels more vulnerable to events in Algeria than France. This is not only because of the large Algerian population living here now, but also because of historical and emotional ties.
France first established direct rule over Algeria in 1834. By the mid-19th century, tens of thousands of French families had settled there.
The Algerian war of independence, which began in the mid-1950's, was profoundly traumatic for France. While it was being fought, France was deeply divided between supporters and opponents of independence. And when it was lost in 1962, one million French Algerians fled to France.
In the years that followed, France slowly established economic and political ties to the secular revolutionary government ruling Algeria. And when this began to buckle under the pressure of economic crisis, rampant corruption and rising fundamentalism, France was forced to take a position.
In January 1992, after the Algerian Government canceled a second round of parliamentary elections that seemed certain to bring the Islamic Salvation Front to power, France reluctantly endorsed the move, hoping the junta could win some popularity by reviving the economy.
But, since then, more than 1,700 Algerians -- mainly soldiers and police, but also journalists and intellectuals -- have died in a simmering civil war in which the fundamentalists have displayed a growing level of military organization while the country's economic and political crisis has deepened.
Today, France has good reason to worry. It sees Islamic fundamentalists stepping up their proselytizing among the 3.5 million Muslims living here, it no longer believes the Algerian junta can crush the Islamic Salvation Front and it knows that an Islamic takeover in Algeria would bring a flood of refugees into France.

HEADLINE: Reluctant Peacekeepers: Many U.N. Members Reconsider Role in Conflicts

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 11

 BODY:
After rampant growth in recent years, United Nations peacekeeping is facing a crisis brought about by the reluctance of governments to underwrite new operations, especially those that put their soldiers' lives at risk.
Stung by the loss of 18 American soldiers in a Mogadishu firefight two months ago and the swell of Congressional anger that followed, the Clinton Administration has put a lid on discussion of all new peacekeeping operations while it reconsiders its policy. Most recently, Washington blocked efforts to send a force to Burundi, a tiny African state ravaged by civil war. 
The emerging American policy -- contained in a classified document circulating in Washington -- could lead to more frequent United Nations intervention by broadening what the United States considers actions that merit the Security Council's use of force. In addition to military aggression, these would include natural disasters, attempts to subvert democracy and gross violations of human rights. But the policy also sets tough new conditions to be met before Washington could support new peacekeeping missions, including requirements that the operations involve American interests and that the United Nations have a strategy for ending the intervention.
 
 
181 Unenforceable Resolutions
 So far this year, the Security Council has churned out a record 181 unenforceable resolutions and statements demanding, for example, a cessation of "ethnic cleansing" in the former Yugoslavia, or an end to fighting in Somalia. As the resolutions mount and are ignored, the Council loses credibility.
"The Council has no clothes because no one does what it tells them," Diego Arria, who served as Venezuela's representative on the Security Council until a few months ago, told a recent seminar here.
With the United States, France and Belgium committed to pulling their forces out of Somalia in the next few months, probably followed by other nations; and with France and Britain reluctant to keep soldiers in the former Yugoslavia for a third successive year of civil war, 1994 could see peacekeeping begin to shrink.
"Politically and economically the international community is now in retreat," United Nations Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali lamented in a recent speech.
For President Clinton "the United Nations simply cannot become engaged in every one of the world's conflicts. If the American people are to say yes to peacekeeping, the United Nations must know when to say no."
 
 
Not Threats, Just 'Tragedies'
 Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, went further, arguing that crises in Bosnia, Somalia, the Sudan and Angola are not real threats to international peace but just "tragedies" that did not require United Nations intervention.
This year's 48th General Assembly, now winding up, has been marked by complaints that the United Nations lacks the staff and expertise to manage a peacekeeping force of its current size efficiently and is taking on more than it can handle or its members are ready to pay for.
In 1987 the United Nations was running just five operations with a combined manpower of some 10,000 soldiers and an annual budget of about $233 million. But as the cold war ended and East and West began working together through the Security Council to settle regional conflicts, the number of operations shot up. Today the United Nations has 18 peacekeeping operations and has deployed some 75,000 troops at an annual cost of more than $3 billion.
These operations are more complex and dangerous than classic peacekeeping -- in which United Nations forces supervised an agreed truce, giving the politicians time to negotiate a solution.
 
Blurred Distinctions
 Increasingly, such "second-generation operations," as the Secretary General has called them, require peacekeepers to intervene directly by disarming guerrillas, monitoring elections or escorting relief convoys, activities that could compromise their impartiality.
Moreover, it is often unclear whether they are operating with the consent of all the parties to a conflict. A new study by Mats Berdal of the International Institute of Strategic Studies in London says United Nations forces now operate in a less "permissive" environment amid "myriad paramilitary groups" who often disobey their leaders' orders. As a result, the distinction is becoming blurred between impartial peacekeeping and enforcement actions.
For many, the lesson of the operations in Somalia and the former Yugoslavia and of President Clinton's decision to turn back American peacekeepers from Haiti in the face of dockside riots, is that the kind of military enforcement the Security Council ordered against Iraq in the Persian Gulf war is likely to remain a rarity.
"After a brief post-cold-war honeymoon, the United Nations is once again suffering from the inability to enforce its decision in critical situations, this time without the excuse of the obstacles created by the Cold War" writes Sir Brian Urquhart, a former Under Secretary General in charge of peacekeeping, summing up the new sense of disillusion with the United Nations in "United Nations, Divided World" a study published by Oxford University Press.
 
'There Is a New Reality'
 In a recent address in Washington, Mr. Boutros-Ghali said: "I am firmly committed to the concept of peace enforcement. It is essential if we are to strengthen international peace and security. But there is a new reality: member states are not ready for it. I must accept reality. I also must continue to give you my view."
Meanwhile, some countries are working quietly to strengthen the ability of the United Nations to run military operations more effectively and to win public backing for them.
Member countries have now provided the Secretary General with a military headquarters staff of some 70 professional officers, as well as with better communications and intelligence equipment. By the end of this year they should also provide him with lists of military units they can furnish at short notice.
The Clinton Administration, which took office vowing "assertive multilateralism," is also quietly striving to build domestic support for a more interventionist United Nations. The Administration plans to seek Congressional agreement early next year on criteria for assessing American support for, and possible participation in, new military operations.
The as yet unsigned Presidential Decision Directive broadens the definition of what constitutes a "threat to international peace and security" requiring Security Council intervention to include: "one or a combination of the following -- international aggression, a humanitarian disaster requiring urgent action coupled with violence, a sudden and unexpected interruption of established democracy or gross violation of human rights coupled with violence or the threat thereof."
 
The Question of Command
 It also provides for American forces to serve under a foreign commander, although their participation must be necessary from a military standpoint. On hazardous missions, Washington would want an American officer in overall command or near the top of the command.
But the document says new operations must have a clear objective and a strategy for bringing them to an end. They must also have widespread political support and serve national interests.
The Administration also plans to ask the Defense Department to share the cost of Security Council peace enforcement operations with the State Department.
Before there can be any more peacekeeping operations, however, Congress must replenish the United Nations coffers by finding up to $950 million in a supplemental appropriation next year to pay America's overdue portion.
Meanwhile, with the United Nations increasingly short of money and troops, attention is shifting to what different regions can do to promote local stability with a little help from the West.
In Africa, a continent with large armies but little money, the Clinton Administration now plans to help Zimbabwe, Tanzania and Uganda send soldiers to assist Nigeria in overseeing the fragile peace agreement in Liberia, providing them with military equipment they cannot afford themselves.
In the same way, the United States, France and Britain are thinking of asking the Security Council to make Russia responsible for order in its former empire by formally authorizing the peacekeeping missions its army is carrying out in Georgia, Moldova and Tajikistan and asking other countries to help with the bill.

HEADLINE: Mexico Raises Minimum Wages as Pledged

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Fulfilling a pledge made during the fierce debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Mexican Government is raising minimum wages by 7 percent, taking into account for the first time worker productivity and the rate of inflation.
The increase is the smallest rise in nominal terms since 1989. But government officials say that because the rate of inflation for 1994 is expected to be 5 percent or less, purchasing power for workers at the bottom of Mexico's wage scale will increase for the first time in years. 
 Still, the minimum wage -- earned by about 16 percent of Mexico's labor force -- will stay low. There are actually more than 200 minimum wages, with the country divided into three geographic areas and with different levels set for over 80 categories of work.
The standard for general labor will increase to about $5 a day in Mexico City and other urban areas, about $4.60 in Guadalajara and medium-sized cities, and $4.15 in rural areas.
The leader of Mexico's primary labor confederation, Fidel Velazquez, said that the increases were less than labor had asked for but that they marked the beginning of a recuperation of purchasing power that has eroded substantially since the mid 1980's.
It was in September, while the trade agreement's supplementary accords on labor and the environment were being completed, that President Carlos Salinas de Gortari told President Clinton that he would increase the minimum wage and, for the first time, take into account increases in worker productivity. The promise was seen as a way to placate officials in the United States who opposed the trade agreement because Mexico's low wages could entice businesses to relocate, taking American jobs with them.
In October, President Salinas announced an economic stimulation package in which he outlined how minimum wages would rise. He included in the package a series of tax cuts and authorization for contract negotiations between unions and private businesses to use measures of increases in worker productivity to determine wage increases and salary bonuses.
Previously during the Salinas administration, a commission set a ceiling on contract wage increases that generally coincided with the inflation rate.
On Friday, the central bank announced that inflation in November had risen 0.4 percent, the smallest increase since 1971. Since January, the rate of inflation in Mexico has been 7.19 percent. The Government hopes inflation will be kept to 5 percent in 1994.

HEADLINE: Zaire Is in Turmoil After the Currency Collapses

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire

 BODY:
They call it "Wall Street," and as in its celebrated counterpart in New York bank notes with a face value of hundreds of billions are exchanged daily in what amounts to this country's only truly functioning currency market. Trouble is, most of the money being traded here is virtually worthless.
Nothing so unusual about that, a stranger might think, given that Zaire's economy has been virtually bankrupt for nearly a decade, a result of endemic official corruption and monetary ineptitude. Indeed, average real incomes here are now a fraction of what they were in the early 1960's, though under current circumstances comparative statistics, too, are probably worthless. 
 But by any accounting, since mid-October conditions in sub-Saharan Africa's second most populous country have taken a dramatic turn for the worse, a result of what is now widely regarded as a major misstep by Zaire's President, Mobutu Sese Seko, and Prime Minister Faustin Birindwa.
For the third time in two years, the Mobutu Government has introduced a new currency in an effort to solve its chronic liquidity crisis. This time, however, it has taken an even more drastic step by trying to withdraw the old bank notes from circulation. But the tactic appears to have backfired, as the new currency has plunged against the dollar on the black market and its circulation has sent prices sharply higher across this huge central African country of 40 million people.
 
110 Million to the Dollar
 And the ensuing chaos, foreign diplomats, analysts and many ordinary Zairians say, threatens to plunge the nation into its gravest crisis since the nightmarish turmoil that followed the country's independence from Belgium in 1960.
One illustration of how precipitously the economic situation has deteriorated in recent weeks is to compare the value of the national currency, the zaire, against the American dollar. At the beginning of October, the zaire traded at about eight million to the dollar; today, the rate is about 110 million and is still rising.
"Things have gone from the ridiculous to the truly absurd," said Atondoko Ngefa, the president of Zaire's Association for the Defense of Human Rights. "It was hard to believe that things could actually get worse here, but they have."
A Western economist here said: "Frankly, I haven't the faintest idea of how most people get by. It defies all logic. But eventually, it will all come tumbling down. It must."
 
Sure of Nothing
 In Washington, George Moose, the Assistant Secretary for African Affairs, said at a Congressional hearing last month that the Mobutu Government's currency manipulations were "wrong-headed and could incite a new round of pillaging and military unrest."
Those are the forecasts. But then diplomats, business people and officials also acknowledge they can be sure of nothing.
What is most frustrating, analysts and foreign diplomats here say, is that the current crisis was altogether predictable and probably avoidable. In recent years, prices here have risen fortyfold, partly because of a huge budget deficit that developed after the Government abandoned an economic recovery program devised by the International Monetary Fund early in 1990 and increased spending. And with foreign exports, Government revenue and industrial production at record lows, there was nothing to buttress Zaire's money. At that time, the zaire traded at about 300 to the American dollar, but rapidly depreciated.
Since then, vast segments of the economy have shut down. In the stalls of the street markets here, the price of a sack of manioc, Zaire's staple food, has quadrupled. Relief workers report that malnutrition, virtually unknown here until recently, is spreading. And with the price of food beyond the reach of much of the population, there has been a growing exodus from urban areas back into the bush, where food is still plentiful.
"It's all a matter of supply and demand," said Peter Rosenblum. a senior lawyer with the Human Rights Law Group, who has written extensively on Zaire.
"Zairians are in terror of the new bills," he said. "They know that each time a new bill is introduced, the old bills become virtually worthless, and inflation takes another galactic leap."
 
Violence Is Feared
 There is plenty of evidence, moreover, that if the situation continues to worsen, it could cost the lives of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of people through violence it might engender.
Indeed, twice in this decade Zairians have suffered through outbreaks of violence and rioting provoked by the Government's ill-advised attempts to introduce new currencies. In July 1991, Zaire Army soldiers mutinied because they had not been paid. A week of looting and violence spread throughout the country, eliminating most of what remained of the modern productive sector, outside of mining. In the Kinshasa area alone, 90,000 jobs were lost and at least 240 people were killed.
The rioting also led to the evacuation of virtually all foreign workers -- about 20,000 people, mostly from Belgium, France and the United States. They included most of the country's university professors, teaching staff at hospitals and geologists in the vital mining industry.
Rioting erupted again last February when soldiers discovered that the new five-million-zaire bank notes used to pay them were impossible to spend. They seized control of the Parliament building and held several hundred lawmakers hostage, demanding that they order local merchants to accept the new bank notes. Hundreds, including the French Ambassador, were killed.
Nonetheless, in yet another effort to prop up the economy artificially, on Oct. 22 President Mobutu introduced yet another new currency, with each note supposed to be worth three of the old bills, and set at an official rate of three to the dollar.
 
Traders Are Arrested
 But traders on Kinshasa's Wall Street, a narrow alley across the road from the United States Embassy here, quickly devalued the old money. The Government first responded by raiding Wall Street, arresting traders and seizing banknotes.
But the money changers soon returned. Oto Nbongo, a spokesman for the dealers, told Zaire television that they had come back "because among the money changers there are fathers and mothers of families who depend on this practice."
Left unsaid, many Zairians say, is that many of the Wall Street traders are relatives of senior Government officials and soldiers who depend on the market for their main source of income.
More ominously, the new notes have already caused scattered rioting. In late November, soldiers went on a looting rampage in the central Zaire town of Kananga where opposition parties have been leading a boycott of the currency. Three Roman Catholic priests were reportedly killed in the rampage.
In any event, Etienne Tshisekedi, Zaire's main opposition leader, who despite being dismissed by President Mobutu last year still considers himself Prime Minister, has called the new notes a "criminal swindle."
"This operation is pure piracy," Mr. Tshisekedi told reporters at a news conference, "The people will agree with me in the end."

HEADLINE: Europe to Defy Greece on Ties to Macedonia

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Despite a long campaign by Greece to isolate the tiny Balkan country of Macedonia until it changes its name, the rest of the European Community is likely to establish diplomatic relations with Macedonia by the end of the year, diplomats say.
Britain, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and Denmark are preparing to establish full diplomatic ties as soon as next week, the diplomats say. 
 Greece's 11 fellow members of the European Community have become increasingly frustrated with the campaign by Athens to make the world withhold recognition from Macedonia, a former Yugoslav republic that declared independence in November 1991. Greece wants to force the country to change its name, which Athens sees as implying a territorial claim on the northern Greek province also called Macedonia.
The European Community members say offering diplomatic recognition to Macedonia is a useful gesture of support for the Government of President Kiro Gligorov that may help stabilize an ethnically mixed country in one of the most turbulent regions of the world.
The last complete census, conducted in 1981, showed that 64 percent of the Macedonian population were Macedonians of Orthodox Christian background, while 22 percent were Albanians of Muslim descent, with smaller numbers of Turks, Serbs and Gypsies.
Formal ties would also make it easier for European Community countries to provide economic aid and to encourage companies to invest there.
Earlier this year, Macedonia was admitted to the United Nations General Assembly under the compromise name of Former Yugoslavian Republic of Macedonia, which Greece still rejects. This is the name the European countries planning to establish diplomatic relations with Macedonia will continue to use for official purposes. Those wanting full diplomatic relations are in a hurry to do so before Jan. 1, when Greece assumes the presidency of the European Community for six months.
More than 40 countries have recognized Macedonia so far and about a dozen have established formal diplomatic ties.
This month, the Clinton Administration upgraded the United States Information Office in Skopje to a Liaison Office. At the time, the State Department said this "does not change the United States Government's position on recognition." Washington has not recognized Macedonia although there are 300 United States peacekeeping troops there, along with 700 Scandinavian soldiers, in an effort to stop the Balkan war from spreading.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Credit Twist: Fun Is Back For Consumers

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
AMERICANS entered the holiday season charging at a record rate. And as a Christmas present, the people who provide the credit are asking less in return.
"We're seeing a 20 to 30 percent increase in the charges on each card this holiday season," said James L. Bailey, an executive vice president of Citibank, the largest issuer of bank credit cards. 
 Credit cards are still profitable for banks, but the competition is getting stiffer. Price cuts have been common in the battle for market share, especially among those highly desirable consumers who are foolish enough, or poor enough, to keep substantial balances on their cards. Luring such a customer is known as "balance piracy," noted Robert McKinley, president of Ram Research in Frederick, Md. Citibank now joins the trend toward canceling annual fees for most customers, other than the ones who are tied into groups with side deals, such as cards that provide airline miles or car discounts.
The implications of this competition in credit are bullish for economic activity, at least for the time being, and mixed for bank profitability. It is one reason that consumer credit is booming again, growing at the fastest rate since 1989. But consumers may regret taking the generous terms being offered.
Consider a customer who has a $2,000 balance on a Citibank Visa card. Until now, that customer had to pay a minimum of $55.56 a month. Now, thanks to the friendly folks at Citi, that is down to $41.67. The interest rate remains the same, ranging from 9.9 percent to 19.8 percent a year.
We wondered how long it would take, assuming minimum payments at the end of every month, to pay off that $2,000 balance. The answer, at a 19.8 percent interest rate, is 22 years. During that period, the interest charges will total $4,919. And if that hypothetical customer sometimes is late making payments, it gets even worse. Citibank has raised the penalty for missing a monthly payment to a minimum of $15.
Mr. Bailey figures the change will both reduce delinquencies -- by making it easier for customers to make required payments -- and raise bank profits -- by increasing the overall interest payments.
A few years ago, such an easing of credit terms would have aroused talk of an increase in defaults for the banks. Now, Wall Street is more likely to focus on the possibility of increased profits from those who maintain high balances. Worries about credit quality have largely vanished, whether it concerns strapped Visa cardholders or Latin American governments. Argentina last week sold $1 billion in 10-year bonds yielding only 8.47 percent, as buyers dismissed as irrelevant the junk ratings given the bonds by stodgy credit agencies. It was only last year that Argentina renegotiated its debt, forcing the banks to take losses.
Credit binges are fun while they last, and this one will produce a merry Christmas for retailers. It will be interesting to see how long it lasts after that.

HEADLINE: Profile: Albert E. Sindlinger;
Kill-Joy at the Recovery Ball

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WALLINGFORD, Pa.

 BODY:
TIRED of all the happy talk lately about how business has begun to perk up -- but not for you? Looking for a fellow skeptic about the nation's economic course?
Albert E. Sindlinger may be your man. The 86-year-old pollster, who was born during the financial panic of 1907 and came of age during the Depression, finds little to cheer these days. It's not that he's a natural sourpuss -- in fact, critics over his long career have as often complained of over-optimism, notably after the '87 crash -- it's that he says things have fundamentally, perhaps permanently, changed for the worse. 
 "We're not in a business cycle. We didn't have a recession, and we don't have a recovery," contended this opinionated, acutely informed pioneer in probing consumer attitudes. "We're in a structural change."
Before long, he maintained, either the economy will have to be put back on course or the stock market will dive. And while he doesn't buy stocks himself, for fear of impairing his judgment, he said a market drop is much more likely.
"He sees the fundamental forces that are fracturing the economy," said William Dunkelberg, dean of the business school at Temple University, who surveys small business for a trade association.
To Mr. Sindlinger, who runs a survey and consulting business with revenues of about $1 million a year, the main cause of the changes is what he calls the export of American jobs.
"Forty percent of the people in this country are worried about their jobs -- normally it's 4 or 5 percent," he said in an interview in the office wing of his modest suburban Philadelphia home. "You can't run a decent economy when 40 percent of the people get up in the morning" wondering if they'll get their next paycheck.
This view is grounded not in Government statistics, which show an unemployment rate of 6.4 percent, but in telephone polls of a random slice of the American public since he began polling nationally in 1955.
The questions, which never change, produce a reading of what Mr. Sindlinger calls household liquidity, based on whether respondents answer "better," "worse" or "about the same" when asked about their incomes and jobs, both now and six months hence.
For three years, he said, household liquidity has been mired in a narrow range, with around 30 percent of those polled giving neutral or positive answers to the Sindlinger questions. That's about half the 1988 average.
The survey has shown little of the sharp recent improvement uncovered by Sindlinger & Company's better-known rivals in gauging "consumer confidence" -- a term that Mr. Sindlinger not immodestly claims to have coined. The main rivals are the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center and the Conference Board.
The moderate Sindlinger rise from a low just under 27 percent around the 1992 elections is nothing more than "bouncing along the bottom," Mr. Sindlinger said, and is certainly not the harbinger of resumed prosperity signaled by a host of recent statistics.
SINCE Congress approved the North American Free Trade Agreement last month, Mr. Sindlinger's results have rebounded, but he dismissed this as being temporary and confined to people who own stocks. Consumers, he said, are "feeling the pressure of weak income growth, high debt levels, job insecurity and weak home prices."
What sets his work apart, he said, is that he asks consumers about their personal financial and job situations.
Mr. Sindlinger said he faulted the late George Katona, his highly reputed rival, who founded the Michigan survey, for asking householders to make broad evaluations more appropriately addressed to economists. Their answers, he said, can do little but reflect what people have read.
In response, Richard T. Curtin, now director of the Michigan survey, said that while he does ask about things like inflation and unemployment, consumers consistently "have a remarkably good grasp" of them.
One striking result of Sindlinger interviewing, which is contracted out to a telephone teams operating from nearby Broomall and in Arizona, with Mr. Sindlinger's wife, Nellie, 59, often pitching in to make follow-up calls, is that consumers almost invariably find inflation higher than is shown by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
This, Mr. Sindlinger contended, is because the Government fails to adequately capture the full brunt of property and other taxes and the cost of things like insurance and tuition.
HIS own cost-of-living index now shows an annual rate of increase of about 8 1/4 percent after being between 9 and 10 percent much of the year. These rates are three to five times the increases shown by the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index.
The Government indexes do not technically measure the cost of living because the baskets of goods they cover rarely change. "What they're measuring is financial inflation," Mr. Sindlinger declared. "The real inflation is what it costs you to live."
Mr. Sindlinger also denigrates the Commerce Department's gross domestic product calculation, saying it overstates national output and thereby has missed two or three negative quarters since the latest recession's official end in March 1991.
Judged by household liquidity, Mr. Sindlinger now lists 4 states in depression (California, New Jersey, New York and West Virginia), 13 on depression's doorstep, 25 states and the District of Columbia in mere recession and 6 Western states not in recession. He does not poll in Alaska or Hawaii.
Another household problem these days, Mr. Sindlinger said, is that returns on certificates of deposits and other savings have withered to virtually nothing. And while many families have gained buying power by refinancing mortgages, this also implies a cut in someone else's income.
To be sure, households have been pouring money into the stock and bond markets, often through mutual funds, and have generally been well rewarded. But Mr. Sindlinger said people don't generally tap such gains, especially when worried about their jobs: "you don't go to the store and spend the value of the stock."
But at the same time, he said, people are highly likely to spend dividends and other earnings that their investments generate. This led to one of the seemingly odd distinctions his survey has made since its beginning -- between respondents who own stock and those who don't.
Stockowners, he determined in the late 1940's, buy bigger and more expensive cars. Though the intentions of stockholders no longer predict the economy -- and the stock market now seems to be dominated by interest rates -- Mr. Sindlinger said he has no plans to change the methods he's used for 2,012 weeks straight.
He said the economy started to veer in the wrong direction shortly after World War II, when various union contracts were linked to inflation. But the real trouble began in the 1970's, and was marked by two price tempests in oil, when the United States began to hemorrhage money abroad, bloat on debt and set itself up for what Mr. Sindlinger considers ill-advised Reagan-era tax cuts.
The result, he said, is a country that has relinquished its preeminence in manufacturing, a decline that will be aggravated by the free-trade accord. "We ceased to produce major things that we consume, and we buy on borrowed money."
One way or another, Mr. Sindlinger has been involved in communications since he learned Morse code as a boy by hanging around the telegraph office at the railroad station in Gnadenhutten, Ohio, where he went to pick up the Pittsburgh and Columbus newspapers for his morning route.
Before long, he became the country's youngest ham radio operator, and at age 13, invited to Pittsburgh to attend the inauguration of radio, wound up filling in for a drunken announcer and broadcasting results of the 1920 election on KDKA for an hour or so.
But it was as a movie-theater manager while working his way through Ohio University that Mr. Sindlinger began his surveying career by interviewing customers about what they most liked to see.
After graduation, he used his engineering degree to get a job as an electronics troubleshooter and theater manager, supervising the replacement of theater sound systems in cities throughout the East and Midwest -- all the while honing his surveying skills.
"I put hidden microphones in the ladies' rooms and the men's rooms," Mr. Sindlinger recalled with a certain glee. And when he went into the lobby to interview moviegoers, he asked questions not only about the show but about economics as well.
This led him to Time magazine, where his research job was quickly transformed into running the newsreel March of Time, then to replacing David Ogilvy, the advertising pioneer, and to a not entirely happy association with George Gallup in a company called Audience Research.
In 1948, concluding that "the only honest way to do opinion research is by telephone," Mr. Sindlinger set up his own business, polling mainly for clients making cigarettes, gasoline and movies.
For the last 38 years, the weekly telephone surveys have generated the material for a newsletter that now has about 640 subscribers. The basic fee is $300 a year, but a few dozen people pay more -- as much as $60,000 -- for consultation privileges.
What with low household liquidity and the eerie parallels Mr. Sindlinger sees with the late 1920's, it's not surprising that he thinks today's stock market is headed for a fall. And his own money? "In C.D.'s," of course. "Safety first."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Albert E. Sindlinger has conducted his distinctive daily surveys since 1955. (Bill Cramer for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Just How Bad Is It For Airline Workers?

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
WHEN American Airlines reported on Tuesday that last month's five-day strike by flight attendants had cut its earnings by more than $160 million, it was one of the few uncontested facts to emerge from the dispute. The two sides have agreed on little else in their battle over the terms of a new contract.
American, for example, contended that the flight attendants' real wages rose by 32 percent after 1983; the union said the base pay of its members declined 40 percent, that nearly half earn less than $20,000 a year and that their median salary of $23,000 is below that of mail carriers and security guards. The dispute is heading toward binding arbitration. 
 Wading into such disagreements can be treacherous, considering the myriad truths that can be derived from the industry's arcane work rules and complex labor contracts. Nevertheless, the claims of each side raise a question that is likely to surface again and again as carriers continue to look to labor to help lower costs: Just how bad is it throughout the industry for the attendants and the two other major groups of airline workers, the mechanics and pilots?
Lumped together, the workers seem not to have fared well since deregulation took effect in 1978. The airlines dropped from being the third highest-paying industry in 1979, behind financial services and railroads, to No. 17 in 1989, according to the most recent Transportation Department study.
That ranking hardly tells the whole story, however. Because of the industry's rapid growth, the influx of new workers has dragged down overall wage levels. But many veteran mechanics and flight attendants, not to mention pilots, remain fairly comfortable.
"It's almost a tale of two cities," said Jerrold Glass, a Washington-based labor relations consultant for many airlines.
Among those who have fared best are senior unionized employees who were fortunate enough to start their careers at big airlines, like United and American, that got even bigger under deregulation. These employees have seen their real wages decline no more steeply than the pay of the average worker in the United States.
Employees at smaller carriers like Republic actually saw their pay go up when bigger airlines, like Northwest, took them over and brought in higher wage scales.
But many have felt the pain as the competition set off by deregulation put relentless pressures on costs and ultimately claimed such casualties as Pan American and Eastern. Employees at those carriers had to scramble for other jobs, losing their seniority and their higher pay levels.
Entry-level, unionized workers have also fared worse, as starting wages have dipped sharply since deregulation, often creating a wider gap between new and senior workers, according to a recent study by Nancy Johnson, a management professor at the University of Kentucky.
And nonunion workers, who make up the bulk of airline employees, have been hit worst of all. "They took every cut that everyone else took, and didn't get anything back in return," like an equity stake in the company, said Peter Cappelli, a professor at the Wharton School who wrote the Transportation Department report.
If nothing else, it is clear that airline workers -- like those in telecommunications, trucking and other deregulated industries -- have lost the sense of security they enjoyed when the Government helped smooth the rough edges of the marketplace.
"Nobody has a real cozy situation," said David Swierenga, chief economist at the Air Transport Association, the industry's trade group in Washington.
Like the industry itself, some airline jobs have evolved in dramatic ways, creating new tensions between management and labor. Twenty years ago, stewardesses faced girdle checks and were required to quit their jobs when they turned 30, or sooner if they became pregnant. But there are no more stewardesses. Now there are flight attendants, who can earn more than $40,000 a year at large carriers and who often make the job a career. Yet they are still treated, they say, as second-class citizens.
That is one reason the crippling strike at American was described by labor leaders and attendants as a battle for respect, not simply a fight for better pay and work rules.
Mirroring the widening disparities in pay under deregulation, some aspects of the work itself have retained their allure while others have dimmed.
To be sure, many airline employees still enjoy their jobs. The attendants and pilots, in particular, appreciate the flexible life style and valuable perks that their jobs provide. Most employees, for instance, receive flight passes for themselves and their families. At American, an employee's spouse, parents, children and siblings can fly anywhere at a nominal fee if space is available. The perk even extends to a sibling's spouse.
The very nature of the work schedule of pilots and attendants, especially at the senior level and on coveted international routes, gives them freedom to pursue other businesses or hobbies. A senior pilot flying regularly to Japan, for example, might make three three-day trips a month, with the rest of the month off.
AND that does not include vacation time, which can be extended because of a provision in many contracts with pilots and attendants that was held over from the days of regulation. It works this way: If the last day of a three-day trip is also the first day of a previously scheduled vacation, the employee gets to skip the trip and add the days to the vacation. Nor would the employee work any days of a second three-day trip if that assignment overlaps the last day of the vacation. The result is that some pilots and attendants wind up with two months a year in which they work just three days.
Many senior employees, who have a large measure of control over their schedules, play this provision for all it is worth, airline executives say. The provision has come under fire in many recent contract negotiations.
"The flexibility we have in terms of being able to stretch vacation is a quid pro quo for the fact that the airlines run 24 hours a day, 365 days a year," said Randy Edwards, a spokesman for the Association of Professional Flight Attendants, which represents American Airlines attendants.
While entry-level workers earn far less money and have much less control over schedules than do senior workers, they are coming into the cyclical industry during a time of growth, a period that offers long-term opportunities to move up. Pilot retirements are expected to peak shortly after the turn of the century, which will push everybody up the seniority scale.
For all the benefits that remain, airline jobs are arguably more difficult now than they were before deregulation. The emotional stress created by the industry turmoil is felt by all employees, but by pilots especially. Although they are the best-paid, they also have the most to lose if they are laid off and have to start over at entry-level wages. And because most pilots come from the military, where life is more ordered, talk of buyouts and restructurings can be distressing.
"Until they live through a cycle or two, it is quite unnerving," said Kit Darby, who runs Aviation Information Resources, an Atlanta-based job clearinghouse for pilots.
FLIGHT attendants also say they have been asked to do more with less. Mr. Edwards said that when he joined American as a flight attendant 17 years ago, a Boeing 727 had 96 seats. That 727 now has 138 seats and is staffed with the same number of attendants, or fewer. Flight crews also switch planes more frequently these days, meaning they are often dashing to make connections along with passengers.
The rise of the hub-and-spoke system in the 80's and the chaotic bursts of activity it creates when planes converge for connecting flights "add a lot of pressure to workers we represent," said Bill Scheri, airline coordinator for the International Association of Machinists.
With fare wars like last year's 50-percent-off bonanza, many flights are packed. And because the hub-and-spoke system has increased the number of connections, more people bring baggage on board, sometimes creating a near free-for-all. Some airlines have cut back on such amenities as food, and then have complained to flight crews that customer satisfaction ratings are slipping.
In response to all the changes, many labor groups are trying to gain more control over their fate. Workers at United, for example, are seeking a majority stake in the company to avert a restructuring that will likely result in asset sales and layoffs. And pilots at American recently hired a consulting firm to suggest ways to better run the airline.
But because labor is management's largest controllable expense and the industry upheaval is far from over, many employees will continue to face uncertainty.
Despite the unpredictability, though, working for an airline "is still a good profession," Mr. Scheri of the machinists union said.

HEADLINE: Workers Face Loss of Tax Break on Flexible Health Plans

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
MILLIONS of workers would lose Federal tax breaks averaging several hundred dollars a year under a little-noted provision of the Clinton Administration's health plan. And even if the plan does not pass, the breaks could well be eliminated.
Flexible health spending accounts, which allow workers to deduct out-of-pocket medical costs from their incomes for tax purposes, are about to go the way of another popular tax break that was sharply curtailed, the individual retirement account. 
 The Administration says $30 billion in tax revenues over six years is at stake here, money it wants to use to help finance its health care plan.
Basic coverage, including the bulk of doctor and hospital fees, would continue as a tax-deductible expense for both employers and employees under the Administration's proposals. And tax deductions for flexible-spending accounts like child care and life insurance would also continue.
The new tax rules would apply to the 14 million workers who have money set aside in flexible accounts for medical expenses like insurance co-payments and deductibles as well as dental and eye care coverage.
Employers and Washington experts on benefits do not expect the tax advantage for flexible medical accounts to survive no matter what happens with the Clinton health proposal. The $30 billion is too tempting to Congress.
MOST large companies, including General Electric, Hughes Aircraft, Kansas City Power and Light, Procter & Gamble and Union Pacific offer the flexible-spending plans, as do many small companies. The plans are usually the centerpiece of an array of benefit options from which employees are allowed to choose. For example, workers can choose a lower level of health insurance and use the savings for other benefits like child care and life insurance.
Employees at Quaker Oats in Chicago, for example, estimate what their annual costs will be for health care deductibles, co-payments and other medical costs not covered by their company-provided insurance. The total is deducted over the year from their paychecks and reimbursed to them as those costs are incurred. Credits not used by the end of the year become lost income.
Brian Svenkeson, a 33-year-old financial planner at Quaker Oats, estimates each year what his health care expenses will be for the coming 12 months. After adding estimates for his wife and two small children, he decided this year to switch from his company's health insurance to a health maintenance organization, which "reduced my out-of-pocket costs," he said. He then allotted $1,000 of his salary to a flexible account to cover those costs. The benefit: Mr. Svenkeson does not pay income tax on that $1,000.
Mr. Svenkeson calculates that, given his tax rate, the tax deduction cuts about $300 a year off his tax bill. Losing the tax benefit would be "very unfortunate," he said.
Mr. Svenkeson can get more benefits from Quaker by earning credits. He can earn up to $250 a year in credits by joining his company's healthy living program, which includes 20 minutes of daily exercise, a checkup for weight, blood pressure and cholesterol levels and a no-smoking pledge.
Mr. Svenkeson said he also added to his credits by "selling back" three vacation days to the flex plan. He then used all his credits to buy company-sponsored life insurance. These types of credits seem unlikely to be affected by the changes under discussion in Washington.
The Bell Atlantic Corporation also uses credits. Nonunion employees who select the lowest level of medical coverage get a credit of about $425 a year that they can use, tax-free, for other benefits, including dental and eye care and life insurance. Or they can add the amount to their salary, in which case it is taxable.
Most employers adopted the flexible provisions because forcing employees to make decisions about their benefits would make them more conscious of the cost. With the tax advantage adding to their luster, the provisions helped to wean workers from freely using benefits for which they had paid little or nothing.
"They wanted to back their employees off of health insurance that included an open-ended free choice of doctors and hospitals," said Alain C. Enthoven, the Stanford University health policy expert who is one of the architects of the Clinton program.
He contends that the tax advantage is "a subsidy for inefficiency" because the Government absorbs part of the cost.
By installing the flexible plans, benefits experts said, employers reaped another reward. They reduced their average spending on health by 5 to 7 percent as workers chose lower-cost coverage and tried to use it less.
Kevin Meehan, a vice president of the Wyatt Company, a benefits consulting firm, said some companies, like Merck & Company, the pharmaceuticals giant, preferred to increase their benefits and "had zero savings from flex."
But a number of shrinking military- industry companies have used flexible plans to jettison elaborate benefits they can no longer afford. Some slashed their costs for employee health care by 15 percent, Mr. Meehan said.
MANY labor unions abhor the flexible approach in health coverage. "It is a way to whittle down the benefits," said Louise Novotny, an economist at the Communication Workers of America.
She said the choices offered by the plans divide a work force into older employees, who need comprehensive coverage, and "young healthy folks who think they are immortal and unbreakable."
For many employers, the added after-tax costs that workers would pay for flexible health benefits may not be very important. Executives at several large companies said they would continue the plans even if employees were taxed. "It doesn't impact the cost to the company," Robert C. Penzkover, benefits director at Quaker Oats, said.
While employees like Mr. Svenkeson worry about losing a tax benefit, Patricia M. Nazemetz, benefits director at the Xerox Corporation, said employees in discussions at her company said that "the important thing to them is access to company funding and getting the benefits," not the tax advantages.
Clinton Administration officials said their program would promote cost-conscious behavior. "If you are paying, you'll think twice about it," Roger C. Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said. With the tax benefit reduced for employees, he said, "employers will substitute higher wages."
The wages would, of course, be taxable, contributing to the Administration's $30 billion estimate of added tax revenues. But the arithmetic has been challenged.
Gail R. Wilensky, who administered the Medicare and Medicaid programs under President Bush, said the $30 billion estimate was inflated. "Employers will increase their benefits for other things -- child care, pensions, elder care" -- that are tax deferred, she said.
"When the choice is 45-cent dollars after taxes or dollar-dollars, people will do anything rather than take it as taxable income."

HEADLINE: Year After Devastating Storm, Nature Offers Not-So-Gentle Reminder

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HIGHLANDS, N.J., Dec. 10

 BODY:
Everyone who lives near the ocean learns the signals of a big storm moving on the coast.
Low-flying clouds fuse into a dark blanket to blot out the morning sun; rainbursts slash against the windows; crashing waves claw high on the sandy face of broad beaches. 
 Mary Kowalski used to love the excitement of such moments.
No more.
One year after the great coastal storm swept across the New York metropolitan region, causing serious flooding, beach erosion and hundreds of millions of dollars in property damage, she and thousands of others in the region now know intimately the great damage and loss each new storm can bring.
"We can't afford to go through this all over again any time soon," she said, expressing the sentiments of most people who live on the Atlantic from Montauk Point on eastern Long Island to Cape May in southern New Jersey.
 
Biggest in 30 Years
 The three-day storm that began on Friday, Dec. 11, was the most powerful northeaster to strike the region in 30 years and spared few people from loss or at least inconvenience.
Hundreds of shorefront homes, particularly on Long Island, were damaged or washed out to sea, while many more, like Mrs. Kowalski's, were flooded miles inland; parts of the New York City subway system ground to a halt; millions of tons of beach sand were lost to the powerful waves, and 500,000 people lost power, many for several days.
Although much has been done during the last 12 months to patch up and restore beaches and buildings, two intricate questions remain: What can be done to minimize the damage from the storms of the future? Who should bear the costs of holding back the sea or, failing that, pay for picking up the pieces afterward?
Nature may force the question quickly.
 
Exposed, Vulnerable Areas
 The barrier beaches in the region were so badly scoured by erosion last December that many areas lie exposed and vulnerable to lesser winter storms, the experts say.
"Even when dunes have been replaced there is no reservoir of sand in front of them to provide an extra buffer," said Dr. Norman P. Psuty, associate director of the Institute of Marine and Coastal Sciences at Rutgers University.
As a result, he said, "It won't take a northeaster on the magnitude of last year's storm to damage structures and coastal infrastructure."
Gerard Stoddard, president of the Fire Island Association, a homeowners' group, and publisher of Coastal Reports, a newsletter for shoreline property owners, agrees.
"The shoreline today is in a far more precarious position than it was before the December storm," he said.
Fearing that another big storm would tear away expensive improvements, in fact, some of the more than 70 beachfront communities in New Jersey, like hard-hit Belmar, adopted a wait-and-see attitude and did little reconstruction of splintered boardwalks and other structures at the edge of the sand.
Nor are future storms a worry only for those who live on the edge of the ocean.
The reach of last year's storm was felt far inland, in pockets of modest weatherbeaten housing on low-lying land. The Kowalskis rent their small frame house in Highlands, on the Raritan Bay side of Sandy Hook in Monmouth County, and when they returned to it after floodwaters had forced them to evacuate for four days, they found a sodden lump of ruined appliances, carpets and other furnishings.
They were not covered by insurance and did not qualify for assistance programs, they said. The costs of getting back on their feet came out of their own pocket, Mrs. Kowalski said.
Those who had coverage offered by the National Flood Insurance Program did much better. Some $300 million was paid out of the Federal fund to 8,796 claims in New York and 16,304 claims in New Jersey. An additional $36 million went to Connecticut policyholders.
Still, the storm may end up costing the taxpayers more than $600 million in direct or subsidized assistance in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Hidden or uncovered costs directly related to the storm may add another $1 billion in the three states, officials said.
The storm prompted some private insurance companies to raise premiums on windstorm policies in some exposed coastal areas, to cancel existing policies and to seek higher mandatory deductibles on new ones.
The debate was also rejoined on whether taxpayers should continue to subsidize Federal flood insurance for homeowners who choose to live in flood hazard areas or have second homes there. "They expect taxpayers to bail them out when things go bad," said Beth Milleman of the Coast Alliance, a group of environmentalists based in Washington.
Some in Congress would permit existing homes and businesses to continue in the program but would not allow new development to take advantage of bargain premiums.
New Jersey and New York appear to be on divergent courses on beach restoration policy, with New Jersey determined to hold the shoreline against whatever the ocean can throw at it, and New York considering whether to reject extraordinary measures to preserve the shoreline in some sections of eastern Long Island.
Officials in Trenton have endorsed the view that the Jersey Shore and its $8 billion a year in tourist activity are too important to allow the Atlantic to overwhelm the intensely developed oceanfront and inland estuaries.
The state is pouring money into United States Army Corps of Engineers beach replenishment projects along the coast in Monmouth County, from Sandy Hook to Manasquan Inlet, that are expected to cost $1.2 billion or more over the next decade. The state's 30 percent share of the costs, with contributions from municipalities, will be paid from money allocated for the Economic Recovery Act, at least in the initial stages.
The Corps of Engineers will begin the first $100 million phase of the project early next year by pumping offshore sand into an area in front of a five-mile-long seawall in the adjoining towns of Monmouth Beach and Sea Bright, where nearly all the beaches washed away years ago.
"It's going to start moving the minute after it's pumped," said D. W. Bennett, director of the American Littoral Society at Sandy Hook, a national group.
"The project will end up costing twice as much and lasting half as long," he said.
In New York, the Corps of Engineers in October unveiled a $28.8 million public works project to pump 2.3 million cubic yards of sand along a 3.5-mile stretch of Coney Island, as well as to construct an 850-foot seawall to protect the beach and the low-lying community of Sea Gate.
The Corps completed a $7 million project last month to close a half-mile breach opened by last December's storm along a Town of Southampton barrier beach. On the east side of the breech, about 85 homes are left standing of the 300 homes that once dotted the beachfront.
An erosion task force created by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo this year is about to make recommendations for the state's Atlantic coast. An important decision will be whether to limit the spending of public money for shoreline protection to the densely populated areas in the west, such as Coney Island and Long Beach, and not the less-developed summer resorts to the east, like Fire Island and the Hamptons. Public parks and beaches lying east of the most populous zone, such as Robert Moses State Park and Jones Beach State Park, would still be protected.
Another recommendation is whether to force communities and people who derive the most direct benefit from the waterfront to pay a larger share of maintaining the coastline.
Joe Feder, owner of a home on the Southampton beach, deplored what he says is a a hardening position about aiding the stricken coast.
He said Government action, not a natural event, had caused the severe erosion at the point of the breech. Opposition to extending a line of jetties, already installed to the west, caused an erosion problem that hadn't existed before, he said.
"How can anyone point a finger at me and say I don't deserve Government help when Government created a disaster for me?" he asked.
