HEADLINE: Business Diary: December 5 - 10

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Bank or Mutual Fund? Suddenly, the Line's a Lot Fuzzier
Should you buy a certificate of deposit or put your money under the mattress? These days, it's a toss-up: depending on your car's make and model, the pennies in interest may or may not buy enough gas to get you to the bank. As banks know all too well, the deposits of yesteryear are sprinting to mutual funds, so many banking companies have faced the music and ventured into the fund business. But none have done it on the scale that Mellon Bank did last week when it bought Dreyfus, the nation's No. 6 mutual fund company, for $1.85 billion in stock. Dreyfus manages $80 billion in 130 or so funds; no other bank exceeds $20 billion. But a word of caution: as banks rush into peddling mutual funds, will half-informed consumers keep up? Or will they, conditioned to think any money taken to the bank is Government-insured, be misled into ignoring mutual funds' risks? 

At Borden, It Didn't Add Up
When Anthony S. D'Amato took charge at Borden two years ago, its shares fetched $32 each. By this past June they had slipped below $20. Mr. D'Amato's response? He renegotiated his contract, assuring himself at least $900,000 a year, plus homes in Ohio and New York, plus 100,000 new stock options (his old ones, at $32 and up, clearly had a future as wallpaper). Shareholders, not surprisingly, felt they'd paid for a party but hadn't been invited. For all the talk of changes at Borden, one big investor said, he kept hearing about "funny pay plans." And, as they tend to do these days, investors made themselves heard. Last week, Borden dismissed Mr. D'Amato.

QVC, Viacom: On Your Marks!
Brace yourself: The bidding war is about to get lively again. Upholding a lower court's decision, the Delaware Supreme Court ruled last week that Paramount did, indeed, snub its shareholders by blocking a bid from QVC, which is offering $1 billion or so more than Viacom, the preferred suitor. Under the ruling, Paramount does not have to judge a bid on price alone but get the "best value," all things considered. You can bet shareholders will keep a sharp eye out. And they smell a higher price: the stock jumped $2.75 after the ruling, ending the week at $81.125.
 
Xerox Takes Itself to the Gym
It's the corporate battle cry of the 90's: You can't be too lean or too rich. Big companies have been announcing vast job cuts lately (a fine holiday gift). And whenever one does so, the boss, a million-dollar paycheck folded neatly in pocket or purse, invariably talks of becoming "lean." But while, say, G.M. and I.B.M. are in dire need of shedding flab, Xerox is doing just fine. Before special charges, it made $600 million last year. Still, last week it said it was cutting more than 10,000 jobs, nearly 10 percent of its work force. And sure enough, there was Paul Allaire (1992 pay: $1.5 million, roughly 175 times the minimum wage) speaking of the need to be "lean and flexible." Investors sent the stock up more than $5 in a day. But in a company that prides itself on worker harmony, will those remaining stay loyal?
 
Putting the Carl Back in Carl's
It's hazardous to put your name on a chain of restaurants: if the chain ever tosses you out, you still see your name all over, a mocking reminder of your lost power. Carl Karcher may have felt this in October when he was ousted as chairman of the Carl's Jr. fast-food chain. He'd had a dispute with other directors, and he couldn't vote his shares -- 34 percent of the company -- because they'd been pledged as collateral for a loan. Last week, though, having straightened out the loan problem, he returned as chairman. While his spokesmen termed it a "triumphant return," others said his new role will be largely ceremonial. In any case, he probably won't wince when he passes a Carl's Jr.
 
Wait! We'll Take Apple's Jobs
The final score: economic reality 1, "family values" 0. A week after rejecting a tax abatement for Apple Computer because it gives benefits to employees' unwed partners, Williamson County, Tex., reversed course and gave Apple nearly $1 million in incentives to build an office complex. Why the shift? Gov. Ann Richards twisted some arms, and the economic benefits were overwhelming. But dissenters were still out in force. "An Apple a day," one slogan went, "will take family values away." One intriguing footnote: gay couples cannot, legally, have much besides benefits; homosexual acts are illegal in Texas.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Celestial Optometrists
The Hubble fix-it crew finished its heavenly house call last week, and after five space walks and numerous complex repairs, sent the space telescope off on its rounds again. Inside their space suits, the astronauts had their fingers crossed, hoping that now, at last, the $1.6 billion contraption would see straight into the vast unknown. And down at NASA, amid the elation at the mission's success, a lot more fingers were crossed: the agency badly needs to wipe Hubble's blurred vision off its record. But though Al Gore called the mission "a symbol of NASA on the way back," the answer won't come till after weeks of testing.
 
Fake Violence, Real Outrage
Last week, a man walked calmly through a Long Island Rail Road car shooting people. Also last week, who-knows-how-many teen-agers, and even younger children, calmly decapitated their hapless victims. The shootings were real -- five people died -- but the children were playing "Mortal Kombat," a Sega video game. But even pretend violence -- especially when young children are involved -- provokes real outrage, so last week the Senate held hearings on the impact of video-game mayhem. Just before the hearing, though, some big game makers and retailers -- Sega, Nintendo, Sears, Toys "R" Us -- made a pre-emptive strike, disclosing plans for game ratings comparable to movie ratings. Details weren't given, but one current Sega label shows an interesting assumption: "Mature audiences -- 13." Of course, any 6-year-old who saw that label on her mature older brother's game -- assuming she could read -- would instantly say, "No, not for me."
 
Dissenting Voices on Trade
After Europe and the United States came to terms on a number of sticky issues, trade negotiators in Geneva insisted last week that they would actually meet this Wednesday's deadline for completing the seemingly endless talks. But one discordant note crept in: Asian and Latin nations made loud objections to some deals, saying they favored businesses and farmers in the United States and Europe. Trade experts cast a realistic eye on this assertion, as one admitted that, yes, "the big markets dictate the trading rules." So much for one big harmonious world.
 
Feeling Confident? Charge It!
A more puritanical society might consider high debt a sign of hard times. But no, this nation is built on borrowed money ("leverage," if you want to be fancy); rising debt is a sign of vigor. When people feel good, the theory goes, they get out those plastic cards and spend money they don't have -- and that's what they're doing now, the Federal Reserve says. Last week it reported that installment debt rose an unexpectedly large $8.1 billion in October. . . . All the while, some say this "recovery" is a mirage -- like Albert Sindlinger, at 86 a pollster with a past. [Page 9.]
 
Another report last week showed that more people can handle their debt -- mortgage delinquencies, the Mortgage Bankers Association reported, fell to a 19-year low.
 
Go Ahead, Make a Banker's Day
Rumor has it that a few people actually pay for gifts -- no plastic. Last week, the Consumer Federation of America gave them a bit of advice: Don't make a gift to your bank by writing bad checks. Last year, the group said, banks collected $4.35 billion in fees for bounced checks; $3.67 billion of it was profit.
 
Community Lending: Prove It
In 1977, Congress passed the Community Reinvestment Act to try to get banks to make more loans in poor neighborhoods, but that law, which consumer groups call too lenient, has had only limited impact. Minority applicants still have a harder time getting mortgages. But the Administration wants tangible progress, and last week it came up with a new set of tests. Basically, banks now have to show they're trying, but the Administration wants them to show results -- in lending, in services offered in poor areas, and in community investment.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Rice: From Icon to Import
Japan's rice industry is like America's flag: Mess with it at your peril. No matter that Japanese eat a lot less rice as they grow richer. No matter that Japan's rice farmers are wildly inefficient, leading to prices six to eight times the world level. Rice is a national symbol, harvested by the Emperor in an annual palace ritual and offered to the gods. The idea of opening the rice market to foreigners -- unthinkable. But in the new, rapidly shifting world order, the unthinkable happens daily -- and last week Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa said Japan, reluctantly, would open its doors to imported rice. He was pushed to do it by pressure for a world trade pact, but only time will tell what political price he'll have to pay. . . . In one depressed corner of the world, the rice news is good news. California could end up selling as much as a quarter of its annual two-million-ton rice crop to Japan.
 
Next: A Trans-Atlantic Bridge
Send Shakespeare to rewrite. The sceptred isle, the fortress built by nature, has been stormed by engineers. The Channel Tunnel is reality. Last week the builders handed the 31-mile tunnel, the world's largest engineering project, over to the company that will run it. Tickets go on sale Jan. 12, and service begins in the spring.

LENGTH: 1901 words

HEADLINE: How a Staid Electric Company Becomes a Renegade

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
ON paper, the LG&E Energy Corporation of Louisville, Ky., seems the model of the traditional regulated electric utility -- a money-machine monopoly that has annually increased its shareholders' dividend for 39 years running. So why is LG&E, whose profits are up 26 percent this year, intent on overhauling itself?
Simple, explains Roger W. Hale, the company's 50-year-old president and chief executive: sooner or later, the clubby utility industry will be a brawling marketplace. 
 "It's going to be just like competition in telecommunications," said Mr. Hale, a former Bellsouth marketing executive. "And we intend to be a low-cost provider."
Because of impending regulatory changes and pressure from many big corporate buyers for lower-priced electricity, Mr. Hale and his counterparts at the Central & South West Corporation in Dallas, Northeast Utilities in Hartford and some other utility companies are bracing for a market in which corporate customers will shop around for power companies the way they now select long-distance carriers, computer vendors and providers of other big-ticket business necessities. Electric bills often constitute 5 percent of a corporation's operating costs in general manufacturing, and as much as one-third in power-intensive processes like aluminum smelting or steel making.
LG&E, expecting a competitive electricity market to emerge within the next few years, split itself into two broad divisions last month. One will oversee the traditional activity of selling electricity to the company's 325,000 business and residential customers in Louisville and the surrounding counties. This unit will look for ways to keep operating costs low for LG&E, which already has one of the power industry's lowest cost structures, according to a survey by the National Regulatory Utilities Commissioners.
The other new division, LG&E Energy Services, will also have some traditional responsibilities, including operating the company's four Louisville coal-fired power plants and coordinating the wholesale exchange of electric power with all the other utility companies plugged into the national "power grid." But Energy Services is also designed to pursue a venture much more radical in the power game -- devising ways to enter other utility companies' home territories and to compete for their most lucrative corporate customers.
With power it produces itself, buys wholesale from other utilities or draws from 19 independent power plants around the country that LG&E has acquired or is building, the company intends to reach into the rest of Kentucky and into other states to offer lower prices than local utilities.
Such competition would shatter the longstanding "natural monopoly" model of electric-utility regulation, and only a few states are yet seriously considering allowing it. But Mr. Hale and a few of his industry counterparts believe it is only a matter of time before they will be able to buy power in bulk from each other and other nonutility sources in order to parcel it out to retail customers outside their traditional turf, paying a fee to use the transmission lines of the local utilities.
This concept, "retail wheeling" in utility jargon, has caused intense debate within the industry and among regulators and lawmakers over whether it will ever come about and, if it does, whether it will cause more harm than good.
Some analysts and industry executives regard LG&E as a model of what many other utilities will have to become to survive in a competitive future. "Sooner or later, utilities will have to focus on the fact that retail wheeling is a possibility," said Debra Bromberg, a utility analyst for Standard & Poor's. Power companies that have higher rates and a big base of industrial customers, she said, have been trying to bring their rates down and offer more pricing options to retain their big customers.
But other experts argue that companies like LG&E may be risking their financial stability and their ability to provide affordable service to their traditional ratepayers by mobilizing for a competitive market that may never develop.
"They're making a big mistake," said Ralph Cavanagh, the director of energy programs at the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environment group that monitors power companies and recently completed a study of the financial, consumer and environmental impact of retail wheeling.
"They're going to be in trouble," Mr. Cavanagh said of LG&E. "They are restructuring for a market that is not going to exist."
If the market does materialize, however, state regulators, who traditionally have set utility prices, would face a problem that they are still wrestling with in the telephone industry. Rates paid by large industrial customers have often enabled utilities to keep prices down for their residential customers. If local utilities begin to lose big customers to far-away competitors, rates would probably rise for the residential and small commercial customers whose business might seem too small to interest the interlopers.
Mr. Cavanagh also worries that retail wheeling would shift utilities away from their current emphasis on conservation and into a new focus on selling as much electricity as possible -- setting back the considerable environmental clean-up efforts the industry had made in recent years.
EVEN within the utility industry, most companies oppose the idea of direct competition and have lobbied against it.
"There is very intense debate about retail wheeling because there is evidence that retail wheeling does not offer the benefits that some say it does," said David Owens, the senior vice president of the Edison Electric Institute, a trade group that represents most of the investor-owned utilities in the United States -- including LG&E, which seems to be a renegade on the subject of retail wheeling.
The prospect of retail competition in the power industry is a result of the Energy Policy Act of 1992. Under this Federal law, state legislatures or regulatory agencies are free to take steps that would for the first time allow a utility to compete for the customers of another.
Within a single state, that state's lawmakers or regulators could set up the ground rules for such competition. Between states, reciprocal rules would need to be put in place. In all cases, the idea is to have a utility provide transport for the outside power company, which would pay regulated fees for access to the local utility's customers.
THE concept is being pushed by major corporate customers who want to reduce their costs by buying power from alternative sources -- including industrial companies that operate generators for their own use and often have excess power to sell.
So far, however, only one state, Nevada, has passed a law authorizing competition. The state Legislature hoped the law would lure large industrial corporations, of which the state has few -- which may be precisely why no retail wheeling has materialized so far in Nevada.
Elsewhere, only a few states, including Michigan and New Mexico, are actively studying retail wheeling. And in Kentucky, LG&E's home state, the Legislature so far has not taken up the issue.
But action by industrial companies could force many states to embrace competition. Big users of power including the General Motors Corporation, the Dow Chemical Company, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, Anheuser-Busch and 19 other companies have formed a lobbying group, the Electricity Consumers Resource Council, to push for retail wheeling.
"Electricity is the only thing that corporations don't buy in a competitive market," said John Hughes, the group's director of technical affairs.
The lobbying group wields tremendous clout, because its members can influence entire state economies. Mr. Hughes predicts retail wheeling may come within a few years -- much sooner than many experts, both in the utility industry and outside, believe possible. And some Wall Street utility analysts, anticipating market competition, have come up with new ways to rate utility companies to reflect the potential impact of retail wheeling.
Standard & Poor's, for example, now rates utilities by considering a variety of factors, including the company's management and financial performance, rates, customer base, regulatory climate and fuel availability. Among those that Standard & Poor's sees as vulnerable to competition is the Detroit Edison Company in Michigan, which has many power-hungry industrial customers that might be attractive to jealous outsiders willing to offer cut-rate electricity.
By contrast, Standard & Poor's places LG&E among the top 25 utilities that S.& P. deems well positioned to cope with impending competition because of their low operating costs.
Mr. Hale, however, intends to do much more than cope with competition by defending LG&E's home territory. He's eager to take his company on the offensive by "consolidating sources of supply and then going after the customers of the high-cost producers."
 
 
 
WHY LG&E BROKE THE MOLD
IN turning to an outsider from the telephone industry four years ago, the board of LG&E faced a delicate task.
Its president and chief executive since 1978, Robert L. Royer, was soon to retire. There was a consensus that new management was needed to prepare the utility for a more free-wheeling era.
"Ours was viewed as a progressively managed company," recalled David Grisson, an outside board member who was chairman of the search committee. "The last thing we wanted to do was to disrupt that."
The choice: Roger W. Hale, now 50, a veteran of the old Bell System. After the A.T.& T. breakup in 1984 he had been a vice president of marketing at one of the Baby Bells, the Bellsouth Corporation.
Mr. Hale took over as LG&E president in June 1989 and became chairman the next year, when he formed a holding company, the LG&E Energy Corporation.
What Mr. Hale inherited at LG&E was a well-run utility with 4,500 employees. Marketing was rarely a priority, and competition almost unheard of.
Mr. Hale, hearing the demands of big customers and perceiving that regulatory changes lay ahead, cut costs and jobs. He trimmed management by 175 positions and the overall work force by about 25 percent, bringing total employment to the current 3,000.
To help gain experience in wholesale energy marketing, LG&E bought a partnership in the Natural Gas Clearinghouse of Houston, the largest independent gas marketing company in the country, with revenues of over $2 billion. LG&E has also made some key acquisitions, buying independent power plants from the Hadson Corporation of Irvine, Calif., to give LG&E supplies on the West and East Coasts in addition to its home market in Louisville, Ky.
All of these moves have involved only about $100 million in cash, while adding little debt to the company. For the first nine months of this year LG&E had revenue of $890.2 million -- 15 percent higher than in the comparable period last year -- and net income of $88.6 million, an increase of 26 percent.
With the main pieces of his strategy falling into place, Mr. Hale must now wait to see if his notion of the industry's wheeling-and-dealing future proves to be a sharp-eyed vision, or a mirage. Either way, he says, he is certain of one thing: "There will be pressure by which the industry will become more competitive -- and more efficient."

HEADLINE: Police Wonder at Silence in Suicide-for-Hire

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SUMMIT, Ill., Dec. 11

 BODY:
Susan Potempa was battered to death in her garage while her husband and son were out of town for a Thanksgiving football game. At first, the police called her death a random act of violence.
Then an even more disturbing story unfolded. Investigators say that the 50-year-old woman, wracked by pain after a mastectomy for breast cancer, asked at least four neighborhood men about arranging a murder before finding an unemployed 18-year-old who killed her for $2,100 in cash. 
 The teen-ager, Reginald Williams, is in custody. But even as they pursue the criminal case, the police are wondering why neighbors of this blue-collar Chicago suburb who knew Mrs. Potempa well did not realize how desperate she was, and why the men who refused to help her find a hit man did not come forward.
"I've seen murders for 36 years," said Chief Anthony Corbo of the Summit Police Department. "I've seen bloodier and more gruesome murders, but never a murder like this with the 'for hire' aspects and so many people had inklings of it and not come forward. I find it hard to believe that people would keep to themselves and not pick up the phone."
The police learned of Mr. Williams, who lives less than three blocks from the Potempas, after he told a friend he had killed Mrs. Potempa.
The friend contacted the police and agreed to tape a conversation with Mr. Williams, leading to his arrest on Monday. The youth is in jail on a charge of first-degree murder in lieu of $350,000 bond.
"The victim's willingness to be murdered is irrelevant," said the Cook County State's Attorney, Jack O'Malley.
The police said there was no evidence that Mrs. Potempa's family knew of her plans. Nor is there evidence that Mrs. Potempa arranged the killing to preserve insurance benefits, Mr. O'Malley said. Life insurance policies of suicide victims are often automatically canceled.
Mrs. Potempa and her husband, Robert, lived in a split-level house on Selma Street for more than 20 years. They always greeted people with a smile and a wave, neighbors said.
 
'Bump Someone Off'
 A year ago, Mrs. Potempa was found to have breast cancer. She had a mastectomy, but the surgery left her in excruciating pain, said neighbors who often drove her to the hospital when she was too sick to drive herself.
Bob Ingram, who lives a few houses away, said Mrs. Potempa asked him several months ago if he knew anyone who would "bump someone off."
"She didn't mention who it was," Mr. Ingram, 20, told The Daily Southtown newspaper. "I just kind of blew her off. Anytime I'd see her I'd say, 'Yeah, I'll find someone,' but I didn't want nothing to do with it."
The police said that Mrs. Potempa drove Mr. Williams to her house on Thanksgiving night and that Mr. Williams tried to strangle her and left with the $2,100 after she lost consciousness.
But she survived and tracked him down so he could finish the job, the authorities said. The police said Mr. Williams succeeded the second time, strangling her with an electrical cord and hitting her over the head with a power drill.
Mrs. Potempa was found two days later when her son and husband returned from an out-of-town football game. They have refused to talk with reporters.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Australian Director Is Thinking Globally

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Australian baseball has a long way to go to reach the level of play in this country, but it has something major league baseball doesn't have: a commissioner.
He is John Ostermeyer, and his role as executive director of the Australian Baseball Federation makes him the equivalent of major league baseball's commissioner. It also gives him a platform from which to speak about baseball around the world, and he has been doing that fervently and eloquently in his effort to drag major league club owners into the 21st century of world sports interest. 
 "The world no longer is flat," Ostermeyer said, echoing the title of a talk he gave to the Players Association executive board in Scottsdale, Ariz., last week. "A lot of the baseball hierarchy in the United States has the mentality that baseball stops in New York and Los Angeles. Baseball in its future has to be an international game. We're in deadly combat with soccer and basketball and we're losing the battle."
The battle, Ostermeyer said, is for television opportunities, sponsors, fans. The major leagues, he said, have given the other sports an uncontested shot at those economic elements.
 
Who's Dykstra?
 "Internationally," he said, "baseball is running a poor last to these sports. Ask people in Europe and Asia who Michael Jordan is, who Magic Johnson is, and everybody knows. You say to them, who is Lenny Dykstra, and they don't have an idea."
The large Australian, a businessman himself, criticized the major leagues for "a lack of leadership and vision," adding: "Major league baseball has no global vision, no global plan. I'm not even sure they have a comprehensive plan for themselves."
Ostermeyer found the seeming absence of an international plan especially peculiar in light of the owners' lament that their national television revenue will be slashed to less than half of what it was this year. If they seek other sources of revenue, he said, they should look beyond this country's borders.
"There are more opportunities offshore than in the U.S.," Ostermeyer said. "If you develop the game as a global game, you can double, triple your revenue. You have enormous potential. I strongly believe the future is going to be Europe and Asia. We should be saying where do we want to be by 2005. I don't think the owners think about it. They think about what are we going to do in spring training."
Four years ago, the major leagues created Major League Baseball International to open markets, but Ostermeyer said the subsidiary's bottom line is commercial.
"It seems to me major league baseball is more interested in short-term commercial gain than long-term development," he added.
 
Widening the World Series
 Baseball has developed well enough in other countries, said the former Australian rules football player, that the major leagues should shed what he called the arrogance of playing the World Series with teams from only two countries.
"We should have both a World Series of clubs and a World Cup of Nations," he said. "It would be bigger than the Olympics."
A World Series-World Cup, he suggested, could include the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, Venezuela, Cuba, Mexico and Japan with other countries added later. Asians generally, he said, "are improving themselves dramatically."
"Most people see baseball as an American game played internationally," Ostermeyer said. "You should strive to make it an international game played in America. That's when baseball will be successful."
Australia, he said, is probably 10 years away from reaching the level of play other countries have achieved. His federation is an amateur group but also operates a semipro league that eventually will be a full-scale professional league.
If major league clubs haven't discovered international opportunities, they at least have discovered budding talent in Australia. Three or four years ago, Ostermeyer said, maybe three or four Australian players a year would have been signed by major league clubs. But 35 have been signed in the last two years.
Five Australians played in the majors this year: pitcher Graeme Lloyd and catcher Dave Nilsson of Milwaukee, infielder Craig Shipley and pitcher Mark Ettles of San Diego, and pitcher Mark Hutton of the Yankees.
"Australia is the most scouted country outside Latin America," Ostermeyer said.
 
Benes Resigns Himself
 Andy Benes is one-half of an endangered species, but he doesn't want to hold that distinction for long. He was one of only two players -- Tony Gwynn was the other -- who earned more than the major league average salary and finished the season with the San Diego Padres.
"Right after the All-Star break, Randy Smith asked me if I was interested in signing a long-term contract," Benes said, referring to the Padres' then newly appointed general manager. "If I was, he said they would try to come up with something. They said they'd like to sign me but not for what I would be worth in the market. I said that's not what it's about; it's not about money. It's about a commitment to winning. There has to be a commitment to winning, and I haven't seen that. I don't think anyone else has seen that commitment."
The team's No. 1 pitcher, Benes has been sought in trades this off season, but no one has acquired him because no one has been willing to pay the Padres' price.
"We weren't looking to trade the guy," Smith said. "If somebody wanted to come in and knock us over, we'd consider it. But we haven't talked to anyone on Andy in at least three weeks."
Benes, who needs two more seasons before he can be a free agent, recalls that it wasn't long ago that the Padres were close to being a contender, how entering the final month of the 1992 season they actually had a chance to win.
"We had five All-Stars and we didn't have a bad pitching staff," he said. "It's going to be real hard to recover."
Gone are Fred McGriff, Gary Sheffield, Benito Santiago, Tony Fernandez, Darrin Jackson, Bruce Hurst, Greg Harris. In their place are players who earned the minimum salary this year; in fact, 14 of the 28 players on the Padres' roster and disabled list Aug. 31 earned the minimum of $109,000.
"I don't buy the fact that we just want to be competitive," said Benes, a right-hander who had a .500 record (15-15) for a team that had a .377 record (61-101). "They're asking an awful lot out of the personnel we have to play .500, and .500 isn't going to be close to the top of the pack. It doesn't matter if there are eight wild-card spots. That's not going to cut it."
Benes has resigned himself to remaining with the Padres for now, although he would like to pitch for a team with an opportunity to win.
"I won't sign for more than a year," he said. "I thought I was going to be traded during the winter, most likely to the Orioles or the Yankees, but now maybe I'll be traded during the season. I'll be in a situation like McGriff and Sheffield. I want to be in an environment where they will make every effort to win. That's what it's about."
 
Sign of the Times
 Teams aren't the only entities affected by off-season player movement. The Players Association, whose legal efforts created free agency 18 years ago, convened its executive board meeting in Scottsdale, Ariz., last week, and more than one-sixth of the players present, 7 of 39, either had already changed teams since the end of the season or were unsigned free agents.
Charlie O'Brien, the Mets' player representative last season, was at the meeting but not representing the Mets because he has signed with the Atlanta Braves. Rich Monteleone, the Yankees' representative, was there, but he now is a member of the San Francisco Giants.
Casey Candaele (now with Cincinnati) and free agents Scott Sanderson, Walt Weiss, Greg Cadaret and Dennis Rasmussen also are no longer with their 1993 teams.
 
Cuomo's Cap Not in Ring
 With Bud Selig refusing to run if nominated and serve if elected, the owners' search committee presumably continues its search for a commissioner -- 15 months after the owners forced Fay Vincent to abdicate. The committee has not asked Mario M. Cuomo to be a candidate. Cuomo has discouraged any discussion about his being a candidate.
The name of the governor of New York has arisen because he has not declared himself a candidate for re-election next year. But now he has declared himself a noncandidate for the baseball job. In so doing, however, the former minor league center fielder raised a series of relevant questions. The answers or lack of answers to some of them might explain why no eye-catching names have surfaced as candidates.
"There are some important questions anybody would have to ask," Cuomo said. "Do you really want a commissioner? What is a commissioner? What does he or she commission? What is the authority? What is the mission? Are you to be Landis or what?"
"That's the basic problem, if there is one," Cuomo added. "As with most of life, you endanger the chance of success if you dont define the mission."

HEADLINE: Unfair, Jordan

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor:
It was difficult for me to contain my outrage after reading that Michael Jordan would receive his full $4 million salary for the 1993-94 season from the Chicago Bulls. Certainly, Jordan has given us great moments, but this is certainly not "a gesture of gratitude" by the Bulls but another instance of sticking it to the public under the guise of generosity. 
 While jobs are scarce and bringing my three children to a sports event becomes ever more financially difficult, and greater numbers of homeless are lining the street, what am I being spoon-fed? A retired player (his choice to cease "entertaining" his adoring public) will receive $4 million this year and probably an additional $11.7 million for the remainder of a broken contract.
We've had to deal with huge salaries and skyrocketing ticket prices in a dwindling economy, but when the rich get richer while doing nothing and giving nothing back to the community, the time is right for a more dramatic editorial statement. Maybe the headline should have read: JORDAN $4 Million, Homeless 0.
 
MARC MAISLEN
Brooklyn

HEADLINE: Just Another Innocent Abroad?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am astounded by Scott McNealy's naivete. He praises Singapore's low taxes, its mandatory savings instead of social security and says he's "more of a capitalist than ever."
His political outspokenness, however, would not be tolerated in Singapore, whose citizens pay for their economic miracle with a lack of free speech. 
 Believing in some social welfare does not make one an advocate of a centralized socialist government like China's. Yet this seems to be the parallel Mr. McNealy draws. And having no capital-gains tax does not a democracy make. Nor indeed is the freedom to make money the only freedom worth having.
 
ALANA ERICKSON
Manhattan, Nov. 28
 
The writer is a doctoral candidate in American history at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: Recent Job Gains Conceal a Harsh Truth

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your description of recent hiring trends (Business Day, Dec. 2) requires an important caveat. 
 As you note, job gains have been concentrated among managers and administrators, a category that experienced heavy layoffs in this "white-collar recession." But accumulating evidence indicates that the people being hired are not the same people who were let go. Among white-collar workers, layoffs have centered on older men, and to a lesser extent, older women. So far, these men do not appear to have benefited comparably from new job openings.
The sharpest piece of evidence comes from the Census Bureau report on annual earnings. In 1989, 45-54-year-old men with four years of college had average earnings of $42,590, the equivalent today of $47,507. In 1992, similar men averaged $41,898. The 1992 statistics, the latest available, fail to capture changes of the last nine months.
Because the statistics are drawn from national samples, they may contain random error. But they describe a decline in purchasing power -- 12 percent in three years' time -- that is both absolutely large and is far larger than earnings declines among younger, college-educated men and women.
Many recessions in the last half-century were temporary interludes in which the economy before and after the recession looked the same. That is obviously not the case today. While the economy is now replacing many of the white-collar jobs it recently shed, the holders of those jobs appear to be quite different.
 
FRANK LEVY
RICHARD MURNANE
Cambridge, Mass., Dec. 2, 1993
 
The writers are, respectively, professor of urban economics at M.I.T. and professor of education, Harvard U.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NOHO;
Extra Place: Losing All Traces of a Street That Is Barely There

BYLINE: By Bruce Lambert

 BODY:
Extra Place is a flyspeck on the official map of New York City. Indeed, it helps to have a magnifying glass to detect the tiny inlet, on the north side of First Street between the Bowery and Second Avenue. Extra Place is hard to find on foot, too: no signs identify it, nestled behind a row of buildings and looking very much like a driveway.
One legend has it that Extra Place is a leftover sliver of the 110-acre farm of Philip Minthorne, which was divided among his sons after he died in 1802. 
 Now its days are numbered. City officials are "demapping" the street in preparation for the Cooper Square urban renewal project, although it is not going without a fight. Community Board 3 voted on Oct. 26 against demapping Extra Place and the adjacent block of First Street, reflecting opposition to the urban renewal program. The board's vote is not binding.
The City Department of Housing Preservation and Development's $33 million plan calls for renovating 430 apartments and building 560 new ones by 1998 as a mixture of market-rate and subsidized units for people of low, moderate and middle incomes.
Extra Place is just one of the streets periodically added to or subtracted from the official map by the City Planning Commission. Streets were created, for example, when Battery Park City was developed on landfill. And the construction of Lincoln Center eliminated parts of several side streets.
"Street changes are one of the most important things we do, and the process is quite involved," said Lonnie Soury, a commission spokesman. Like other proposed changes, the demapping of Extra Place will have to be reviewed by city agencies, including the police, fire, ambulance and sanitation departments, and checked for complications involving sewers, water lines and other utilities.
The next step, a uniform land-use review, takes at least seven months, after which the commission votes. The City Council has the right to overrule. Once a change is made, it is logged into a computer and incorporated into printings of the city's evolving map.
 B.L.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Trying to Revive La Marqueta

BYLINE: By NINA REYES

 BODY:
A generation ago, the enclosed marketplace straddling Park Avenue between 111th and 116th Streets was vibrant. Crowds surged through the aisles of the five big buildings known collectively as La Marqueta, haggling over the price of platanos. Vendors trumpeted in Spanish the freshness of their eggs, the tenderness of their pork.
Today, only about a dozen merchants, including two butchers, a clothier, a fishmonger and a perfumer, are housed in the single market building that remains open. On a recent Saturday afternoon, the market's busiest time, only a handful of shoppers strolled the cavernous corridors. But now there is hope in El Barrio that La Marqueta will have a new beginning. Three community organizations are vying for a $5 million contract with the city to rejuvenate the site, and a decision is expected this week. 
 "It has to be redeveloped," said Donald J. Cogsville, the president of the state-financed Harlem Urban Development Corporation, which has urged renovation of the market for nearly a decade. "La Marqueta was the center of life, not only shopping life, but also the social life and other interactions within that community."
In the mid 1980's, a developer proposed a $7.5 million renovation of the market, but the project fell through, as did another plan two years ago. Most recently, the Economic Development Corporation, which manages La Marqueta, spent $850,000 on renovations required to keep open the only market building operating.
In their proposals, the three organizations competing for the rehabilitation contract call for spending $12 million to $15 million, including city money and, they hope, state and Federal contributions.
The phoenix that the community organizations propose to raise from the ashes of La Marqueta includes a movie theater, a day-care center, a catering hall, a two-tiered parking lot and space for public meetings. The open-air concept of the Quincy Market complex in Boston is regularly invoked, as is the appeal to tourists of a Hispanic market. One proposal has even suggested that Metro North, which roars by overhead, make La Marqueta a regular station stop.
"You're talking about a major redesign so that La Marqueta becomes the center of commerce," said Yolanda Sanchez, the director of the Puerto Rican Association for Community Affairs, one group under consideration for the contract.
But cynicism runs deep. "The chances of this even being renovated in my lifetime are poor," said Bernard Lifschultz, who has operated a deli there for more than 40 years, and who represented merchants on a task force sponsored by the Economic Development Corporation studying La Marqueta.
Mary Colon, a clothier whose stall is flanked by an unoccupied, gated booth on one side and by a dry-goods grocery on the other, said she had taken in just $13 the whole day.
"It's busy for meat, but not for clothes," she said, gesturing toward the butcher chopping a rack of ribs across the way. "I don't know how I'm going to pay my rent."
 NINA REYES

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Hillary Rodham Clinton Strikes a New Pose And Multiplies Her Images

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT was a running joke among reporters during the 1992 Democratic convention in New York: If you really want to get your head bitten off, go ask Susan Thomases, Hillary Clinton's friend and adviser, what fashion statement Mrs. Clinton wanted to make.
"Clothes," Ms. Thomases told one reporter, with a contemptuous laugh, "are not something I think about." 
 Hillary Clinton was billed in those days as a woman who bought dresses from sale racks and didn't give a fig for fashion. (Her wedding dress was plucked from a rack on the eve of the ceremony.) Substance was all. She came across during the campaign as someone who simply wore whatever Linda Bloodworth-Thomasson, her Hollywood pal, suggested, while she worried about saving the world. As Sarah Phillips, a designer who worked with her, told the Los Angeles Times: "There are more pressing things for her to do than dress up like Vogue."
Yet here is Hillary Clinton dressed up like Vogue in the December issue of that fashion magazine. The Annie Leibowitz photos feature a dishy, dreamy First Lady posing -- head tilted over and blonde hair draped -- like the old Catherine Deneuve perfume ads Johnny Carson loved to mimic. ("Bee-kawz I ehm Catherine Deneuve.")
At the same time, the White House has unveiled the pricey new decor chosen by this First Lady of simple tastes: a swagging and swathing by Kaki Hockersmith of Little Rock, so ablaze in color, texture and pattern that even Belle Watling might feel at home.
So what gives? The Vogue pictures have provoked much comment. Do they help shatter old prejudices in this male-dominated capital that women who are stylish cannot be taken seriously, and that power, in women, is not as alluring as it is in men?
Or do they revive old-fashioned assumptions that even accomplished women secretly want to be desired as beautiful objects?
The pictures hark back to the flap five years ago when first Diane Sawyer in Vanity Fair, and then Meredith Vieira in Esquire, vamped for the camera. The two women were scolded by various pundits for hurting the cause of women in broadcast journalism by encouraging sex-object stereotypes.
"I thought it was a phony issue then and I think it's a phony issue now," Ms. Vieria, an ABC correspondent, says. "Maybe women are more secure now, and being good at one thing doesn't mean you can't be equally good in some other area."
Certainly, Mrs. Clinton's pictures are not overtly sexy; she even refused to wear the $975 Donna Karan black velvet number off-the-shoulder, as it was meant to be worn, and insisted on draping it high like a turtleneck.
But they are, as pictures of First Ladies go, sensual. Britain's Economist magazine ran a story last week on the American First Lady's new "pussycat" look with the headline "Come up and vote for me sometime." In The Irish Times, Conor O'Cleary wrote: "This is Hillary the sex goddess. . . . In one picture she parts her lips suggestively; in another the first lady gazes at the camera with bedroom eyes."
Some people hail the pictures as the pinnacle of Hillary Clinton's campaign to prove that modern woman can be all things -- flinty policymaker and velvety fashion plate. "She could be selling rouge or moisturizing cream, eye liner or hair coloring," Suzanne Fields raved in her syndicated column. "She exudes confidence, competing with models who (like her) can be frivolous, serious, saucy, bossy, testy and temperamental."
Others find Mrs. Clinton's latest incarnation slightly jarring. Having flair while exercising power is a clear step forward. But some regard sultry poses in Vogue as trivializing for a First Lady who has so dramatically outstripped her title.
"It just seems kind of odd," said Michael Deaver, the Reagan imagist, about the concept of a Vogue fashion spread. "Now that she's proven herself as an individual and been tough, why then get back to an image strictly based on femininity?"
THE pictures prove once again that politics and show business are inextricably linked. Lisa Caputo, Mrs. Clinton's spokeswoman, shrugs off complaints that there is an aura of Hollywood pretension in posing for the celebrity photographer who snapped Rosanne Barr and Tom Arnold mud wrestling and Bette Midler naked in roses.
"Annie Leibowitz photos are works of art," she says. "Comparing them to any other photos is like comparing apples to oranges."
The total effect of Mrs. Clinton's many makeovers -- from the frumpy, hippy, bespectacled look of the 70's to the sleek blond movie star look of the 90's -- has the inherent fascination of one of Hollywood's favorite stock scenes: The hero asks the mousy bookworm to take off her glasses and let down her hair, and then marvels: "Why, Miss Jones, you're beautiful!"
Naomi Wolf argued in her first book, "The Beauty Myth," that women were burdened by trying to live up to impossible expectations about good looks promulgated by a greedy beauty industry. But now, her tune changed, she says that the glossy Vogue shots put the First Lady at the forefront of "a spontaneous uprising" among women who refuse to let men define their sexuality.
"Women are eager to affirm the fact that female sexuality should no longer be perceived as undermining female authority but complementing it," said Ms. Wolf, who publicizes her new book, "Fire With Fire," with glamorous photos of her own. "Now women are beginning to define power and eros as being interlinked in women. Women won't be reading the many faces of Hillary Clinton as an impossible image to live up to, but as a liberating affirmation of how multi-faceted the female consciousness is."
Proving that power, for women, can be as much of an aphrodisiac as Henry Kissinger always claimed it was for men was the effect that Donna Karan sought in her magazine ad featuring a female political candidate riding through a ticker-tape parade with her suit open and a black lace undergarment peeking beneath an unbuttoned shirt.
Lisa Schiffren, a former speechwriter for Dan Quayle, objects to the whole trend. "To use sexuality that way is totally inappropriate in public office," she said.
Those who like the Vogue pictures marvel at Mrs. Clinton's Madonna-like ability to offer a kaleidoscope of images, feeding the short attention span of a channel-surfing, celebrity-hungry electorate. Her admirers say that she has adroitly helped the country adjust to the notion of a First Lady sharing power with her husband by periodically doling out softer, more traditional images like hostess, mother and wife.
But some complain that her cascading images -- changing hairstyles so many times, testifying on the Hill about health care one minute and chatting happily about Christmas baking the next, now adding Rodham to her name, now posing for fashion layouts -- are dizzying and unsettling, and suggest that the 46-year-old First Lady still wakes up every day struggling to create a persona.
"It doesn't feel genuine," said Sheila Tate, who worked as an aide to Nancy Reagan and George Bush.
SOME strategists who know Mrs. Clinton say that she is going through a natural evolution, as she is compelled to pay more attention to her style by a country obsessed with the First Lady's style.
On the campaign, Rosalynn Carter washed her drip dry suits and hung them in the shower to dry; she arrived at the White House with a sewing machine, and the fashion photographer Horst P. Horst once said that when he took Mrs. Carter's portrait for Vogue, her skirt hem was so uneven that he had to ask her to hold a bunch of lilies in her lap to disguise it. Soon she was having her hair done every day and asking her friends where she could get Oscar de la Renta wholesale.
The Vogue article notes that Mrs. Clinton asked to buy the black velvet designer evening gown she wore in the pictures. Vic Gold, who wrote speeches for George Bush, observed approvingly that Mrs. Clinton "has realized there is a certain glamor to her, and she likes it."
There are plenty of historical precedents. When she was 80, Golda Meir was sitting for an official portrait. Eager to find a pose that was dignified and noble, the artist shyly asked, "Madame Prime Minister, how would you like me to paint you?" Equally shyly, the matriarch of Israel suggested: Try to make me look pretty.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Julia Roberts, After the Layoff and With Lyle

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Between wildfires, earthquakes, race riots and a debilitating recession, the city of illusion has been looking a little sad of late. So there is a palpable cheer around Hollywood now that the highest paid actress in the world -- for the moment -- is back in town, generating all kinds of economic activity, grist for the professional gossips and old-fashioned movie star incandescence.
Two years after she made her last film and fell into a tabloid twilight zone over her personal life, Julia Roberts is starring in three new productions, the first of which is Alan J. Pakula's adaptation of John Grisham's legal thriller "The Pelican Brief," opening on Friday. 
 Her face is all over billboards and bus stops this month, the dark, tentative eyes of a woman who is on the run from bad guys in the movie and predatory paparazzi in real life.
At present, she is somewhere in the fortress of International Creative Management, where her agents are giving her last-minute tips on what not to say to a reporter. Which is a bit incongruous, because she has spent the last month and a half trying to learn how to ask questions like a reporter, in the role she is now filming as a Chicago newspaper writer opposite Nick Nolte in "I Love Trouble."
(Tip to Ms. Roberts: Always carry an extra set of batteries for your tape recorder and never believe what publicists say, especially if it's off the record.)
A wall to the office of the I.C.M. agent Elaine Goldsmith slides open -- a very secretive, James Bond kind of door -- and there is Ms. Roberts, in cutoffs, moccasins and modified ponytail, all of 26 years old. Her agents disappear, the sun goes down, and for the next two and a half hours she talks about life as a media caricature and as a new bride to the singer Lyle Lovett. The formerly reticent star seems eager to talk.
Considering that she has been working 12-hour days virtually nonstop for the last half-year, she looks, well . . . vibrant. Her skin is as clear as one of those High Sierra streams where the rare golden trout still swim, and her legs stretch from here to eternity. She volunteers a hair color -- chestnut -- to describe the mane that drove men crazy in "Pretty Woman," the film that made her a global star with more than $400 million in worldwide ticket sales.
One of only a handful of actors who can make or break studio heads, Ms. Roberts is now getting more than $8 million a picture. That sort of price comes with the status of being able to "open" a movie, which means that no matter how bad the film may be, enough people will buy tickets in the first few days of its release to guarantee cost recovery. But the downside is that she exists at a celebrity level where gas station attendants are supposed to care about the tiniest details of her personal life. In that sense, she is both a victim of all the hyper-press that reached a frenzy when she canceled her wedding to the actor Kiefer Sutherland two years ago -- and a beneficiary.
"They say I can open movies, and that's nice in that it puts it into people's minds that women can do it," she said, her legs curled in a chair. "It's not just Kevin Costner, not just Arnold Schwarzenegger. Not just the guys."
She is less comfortable with the public-property aspect of her rarefied status.
"People talk about this Julia Roberts almost like it's a thing, almost like it's a cup of Pepsi," she said. "People think Julia Roberts is something they created. The fact is, 26 years ago there was this scrunched up little pink baby named Julia Roberts." She was actually born Julie, but never mind. "I am a girl," she said, "like anybody else."
Her father, who died when she was 9, was a vacuum cleaner salesmen, and her mother was church secretary. At home, they staged and acted in plays, infusing the three Roberts children with a love of entertaining. She was only a few years out of high school in Smyrna, Ga., when the modest 1988 film "Mystic Pizza" made her a celebrity of the promising variety. It took some getting used to.
"I was in the bathroom somewhere, and this girl followed me and said, 'Excuse me, girl in stall No. 1.'
"I said, 'Yeaaah?'
"She said, 'You were in Mystic Pizza.'
"I said, 'Yeah?'
"She said, 'Can I have your autograph?'
"I said, 'I'm a little tied up right now.' "
For her next film, "Steel Magnolias," Ms. Roberts received an Academy Award nomination. The director of that movie, Herbert Ross, has since criticized her work as one-dimensional, suggesting she should take formal acting lessons. She fired back, but has now decided to call a truce.
Another Oscar nomination came with "Pretty Woman," the fairy-tale story of a Hollywood hooker who spends the weekend with Richard Gere. It was followed by "Sleeping With the Enemy," where she is brutalized by an obsessive husband. Some critics laughed at the premise, but the film drew a huge audience. Then came "Dying Young," a disappointment, and "Hook," which was widely dismissed as a mess, though the blame was laid on the director, Steven Spielberg.
In 1991, Ms. Roberts went through what Ms. Goldsmith refers to as her "Fellini summer," in which she was variously reported to have had a nervous breakdown, been on drugs and romanced several men, all the while feuding with Mr. Spielberg on the set of "Hook." None of it was true, Ms. Roberts said. She played Tinkerbell, but some of the gossip columns referred to her as Tinkerhell.
It was not her most pleasant acting experience; much of the time she was strapped into what she calls "industrial bicycle shorts," which was hooked up to a wire so she could fly. When they shrunk her for the film, she looked at times like a confused horsefly.
"I felt like I had a nice rapport with Steven, yet his depiction of it makes me feel like I'm mistaken," she said with a sigh. "I guess that's just too bad. You know, it may be too much to ask to be in a harness and creative at the same time."
Now, with a cushion of rest between her and that summer, she says she is not at all bitter or angry.
"What people perceive that summer to be is for me a tale of fiction spun way out of control," she said. Yes, she was going to marry Kiefer Sutherland on the Fox Studio lot and three days before the wedding called it off. From then on, her every footstep was monitored, analyzed, speculated upon.
The last two years, she said, "have been two of the most incredible years of my life." She traveled extensively, read more books than screenplays, nurtured old friendships, and -- six months ago -- married Mr. Lovett, a Texas crooner with an original haircut.
"He's really a tremendous man, and he's shown a great deal of courage in marrying me," she said, a dimpled smile spreading across her face. Ms. Roberts said he has had to endure the glare of the public eye. "That's part and parcel of my life, and he's done it with great, distinguishing effort." The butt of jokes that compare him to Woody Woodpecker and sustain David Letterman monologues, Mr. Lovett, 36, has also found a wider audience for his music.
"We're pretending to be a normal couple," Ms. Roberts said. "We get up in the morning and go to our jobs. He goes to the studio to cut a record, I go to the studio to make a movie." On Thanksgiving, she cooked a turkey in Los Angeles for his family, who came up from Texas.
They consider New York home. "We can be walking down Sixth Avenue early in the morning and people will come by and say, 'Hey, congratulations!' But then there are people who talk about my wedding dress looking like a tablecloth, too."
Her role model in the celebrity game is another New Yorker -- Jacqueline Onassis. "How this woman has kept her composure, with what the tabloid shows have done to John F. Kennedy, is unbelievable," she said. "This woman is nobility personified."
By contrast, Ms. Roberts has to fight her own sense of defiance and outrage. "I've become very irate watching the news," she said. "It has gotten so bad here in L.A. The other night, they kept running these blurbs: Tonight at 11, Kiefer Sutherland responds to 'Pretty Woman' 's talk with Barbara Walters. They were setting this up to such a point I started to get nervous. And of course it was just a clip from Kiefer's press junket of 'Three Musketeers,' him commenting on the state of publicity."
She works with Denzel Washington, the actor best known for his appearance last year as "Malcolm X," in "The Pelican Brief." He plays a dignified, heroic investigative reporter who follows up her character's theory about the assassination of Supreme Court justices. Mr. Pakula said it was Ms. Roberts's idea to cast Mr. Washington, who also stars with Tom Hanks in "Philadelphia," which opens later this month.
In "The Pelican Brief," Ms. Roberts plays a Tulane law student named Darby Shaw, the girlfriend of an alcoholic professor played by Sam Shepard. In the book, Mr. Grisham introduced Darby's character this way: "For two brutal years now, one of the few pleasures of law school had been to watch as she graced the halls and rooms with her long legs and baggy sweaters. There was a fabulous body in there somewhere, they could tell. But she was not one to flaunt it."
Nor does Mr. Pakula flaunt it. "The Pelican Brief" makes only minimal use of the physical attributes of the star. Instead the movie follows a tangled plot, bound by a long, conspiratorial rope.
Mr. Pakula owned the rights to the book even before it was written, he said. Ms. Roberts agreed to do the part after reading galleys. Filming in New Orleans and Washington last summer was as close to a perfect experience as she has had in show business.
"I'm telling you, this was a dream," she said. "Everybody. Denzel, Sam, Alan. You feel justified in holding out for something that pays off."
Mr. Pakula, who has directed such stars as Warren Beatty, Harrison Ford, Robert Redford and Dustin Hoffman, said he found it very easy to work with Ms. Roberts.
"She gave everything," said Mr. Pakula. "By the end, she had earned the respect of the entire crew. Julia responds to the other actors, which is what the best people do."
She is midway through filming "I Love Trouble," a romantic comedy about rival Chicago newspaper reporters. In the movie, which is an attempt to re-create some of the sexual tension of films like "Woman of the Year," with Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn, Ms. Roberts trades one-liners with a crusty, older newspaperman, played by Mr. Nolte. Of course, this sort of thing goes on all the time in the newspaper business.
Like other actresses who have played opposite Mr. Nolte, Ms. Roberts has had to get used to his sometimes crude behavior. "From the moment I met him we sort of gave each other a hard time," she said, "and naturally we get on each other's nerves." While he can be "completely charming and very nice," she said, "he's also completely disgusting. He's going to hate me for saying this, but he seems go out of his way to repel people. He's a kick."
Charles Shyer, who is directing the film, is aglow over working with Ms. Roberts. "We were looking at film the other day and our editor said, 'She's got it,' " said Mr. Shyer. "I think Julia would have been a movie star in the 30's, 40's, in any era. There is a magic there with her. You just go, 'Wow -- this is what it is all about.' And she looks unbelievably great. We wanted her to be very stylish, like Julia hasn't looked in any other movie."
A THIRD NEW FILM, "MARY Reilly," a period movie based on Valerie Martin's novel about a maidservant to Dr. Jekyll (of Mr. Hyde fame), is set for production next spring. (Think "The Remains of the Day" meets "Frankenstein" in the 1800's.) Stephen Frears, the British film maker whose work ranges from "My Beautiful Laundrette" to "Dangerous Liaisons," will direct. For those critics who say Ms. Roberts tends to play wide-eyed victims in mainstream films, a prestigious project like "Mary Reilly" will throw them a curve, she says. "It's not exactly a day at the Venice Mall," she said.
Ms. Roberts has been somewhat typecast by "Pretty Woman," a character who is most appealing when her hair is big and her laugh is deep. Such pigeonholing doesn't bother her. "I started out being Julia-Eric Roberts-Sister," she said. "Then I was Julia-Mystic Pizza-Roberts. So getting saddled with 'Pretty Woman' is not the worst moment of my life."
Nor is she upset by criticism from feminists who say she glorified prostitution in the movie. "What are you going to do? You can't please everybody. That movie was a fairy tale. We did everything but put a glass slipper on. And I'll tell you something else: For $3,000 a weekend, Richard Gere got a bargain."
The pressure on Ms. Roberts will begin to build again with "Pelican Brief" opening this week. "Unless you open with a huge first weekend, they say you're a flop," she said. "It's unfair to a lot of movies."
She passed on "Sleepless in Seattle," which boosted the star status of Meg Ryan. But she says she has no regrets. The same hold true for the last two years.
"I'm not a big regretter," she said. "I always say, 'Worries many. Regrets none.' "

HEADLINE: Smaller Architects Find Their Niche

BYLINE: By David W. Dunlap

 BODY:
NEIL MURPHY is not the first architect who has been asked to do something extra to please a client. But he is probably one of few who has ever been asked to scratch a client's tongue.
 The client in question was a young beluga whale at the Aquarium for Wildlife Conservation in Coney Island, where Mr. Murphy is working on a permanent tent-like structure to cover the 180,000-gallon oceanic tank. Greeting the architect, the whale opened its mouth wide. 
By the time Mr. Murphy learned that this was a request for a scratch, it was too late to oblige. But he looks forward to getting another chance. After all, the firm for which he is a consultant, Goldstone & Hinz of Manhattan, takes a whale's needs very seriously. It should. Two-thirds of its work is devoted to zoos and aquariums.
 Goldstone & Hinz is one of numerous specialized architectural offices that bring a particular strength to the drafting table -- and comfort to anxious clients -- in a day of proliferating regulations and computerization. They must be conversant not only with esthetics and engineering, but with technology, sociology and, in some cases, biology as well.
 "You have two sets of clients: the animals and the people," said Theodore V. Hinz, a partner in the Manhattan-based practice. "Animals will tell you right away if they like the exhibit. Many times, we call in a biologist to discuss the animals' characteristics, how they live in nature."
 Robots come into the picture, too. For instance, Shepley Bulfinch Richardson & Abbott of Boston is looking at automatic retrieval systems that could increase by 10 or 20 times a library's storage capacity, with robotic devices pulling bar-coded storage bins off shelves up to 30 feet high.
 Unfortunately, there goes browsing.
 "This is highly controversial," allowed Geoffrey T. Freeman, a principal at Shepley Bulfinch, "but because of the costs of brick and mortar, space has to be for people. We've got to be inventive as to how we house these collections."
 Tracing its lineage to the office of Henry Hobson Richardson, the late 19th-century giant of American architecture, Shepley Bulfinch can claim to have been designing libraries since 1877, when Richardson's Oliver Ames Free Library was begun in North Easton, Mass.
"They really know how university libraries work and don't work," said Dr. Brian J. Byrne, vice president for administration at Fordham University, for which Shepley Bulfinch is designing a new library. "They were selected in a national search for firms that specialize in university library design."
 THE firm has a dozen such projects under way, including the renovation of Butler Library at Columbia University and Sterling Memorial Library at Yale University.
 In fact, with so many projects, Mr. Freeman said, Shepley Bulfinch sometimes has to reassure potential clients at interviews whose first comment is, "You're obviously too busy to work on our project."
 Clients are not the only ones who seek specialized architects. Sometimes, firms with more general practices will ally themselves with offices whose focus is more concentrated. That is what happened on an expansion project for the Duchess County Detention Center in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.
 In that case, the firm of Gruzen Samton joined with Ricci Architect, a five-year-old office headed by Kenneth Ricci, which devotes about 30 percent of its practice to jails and prisons and 40 percent to courthouses.
 "The reason I asked Ken Ricci to join us," Jordan Gruzen said, "was to supplement our extensive background with his up-to-date experience with technology and codes.
 "I think clients generally look for an expert," Mr. Gruzen continued. "They often get well-known design firms combining with an expert. It's happening in the court field and it's happening to some degree in education."
 Medical buildings also require a high level of technical expertise.
 "Health care is so codified and regulated, it requires not only preliminary footwork but ongoing education with new medical procedures and code requirements," said Lenore Lucey, executive director of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
 "Magnetic resonance machines became a whole new question," she said. "Where do you put them, how do you shield them, how do they relate to the rest of the building?"
 There has been a movement within the architects' group to create a specially certified class of hospital architects, but Ms. Lucey said that would pose problems.
 "It's been a hotly debated subject -- specialization," she said. "There are a lot of people who feel it makes you too narrow, too focused. There are a lot of people who don't want there to be a credential, i.e., 'I'm a certified hospital designer,' because they feel that would be anticompetitive. The A.I.A. has to be very careful about anything that might restrain trade."
 If the American Institute of Architects created a hospital-designer category, it might put at a disadvantage smaller firms that had neither the time nor the staff to go through the required training.
 "In theory," Ms. Lucey said, "any architect you have should be able to solve any problem you have."
 However, she also noted, "The firms that have been least devastated over the last two years are probably those with the largest backlog of educational, criminal justice and health-related work."
 "Institutions have a different kind of funding that allows them to continue to build, even if the commercial real-estate market has gone down the tubes," she said. "There is an insulation in being involved in the institutional aspect that's probably helpful."
 IN the last year, Goldstone & Hinz has finished two of the biggest jobs it has ever done, Mr. Hinz said, for NYZS/The Wildlife Conservation Society (the renamed New York Zoological Society).
 One is the new Sea Cliffs exhibit at the Aquarium for Wildlife Conservation (formerly the New York Aquarium) in Coney Island. The other is the renovated Prospect Park Wildlife Center (formerly the Prospect Park Zoo) in Brooklyn.
 Sea Cliffs is a 340-foot long series of pools for walruses, harbor seals, fur seals, sea otters and black-footed penguins. What looks to be a natural landscape around the pools is, in fact, sprayed-on concrete that has either been carved, embossed or molded into rock-like form, complete with fissures. "Sea Cliffs doesn't look like a building," Mr. Hinz said, "but there's a building under there."
 Understanding the animals, Mr. Hinz said, means knowing that fur seals spend most of their lives in water and do not need much in the way of beach, or "haul-out area." On the other hand, he said: "Walruses like to sun themselves on big, rocky coasts, so we give them a lot of haul-out area. The same with penguins. They like a lot of beach."
 And dolphins have to go to Florida for the winter, Mr. Hinz said, which is why the aquarium asked for a tent-like structure to cover the oceanic pool, so they can be kept at Coney Island year-round.
 One of the advantages in building during a depressed period is that contractors are willing to cut overhead and take less profit.
 But Mr. Hinz said, "We've found, quite honestly, that not-for-profit institutions that do this sort of work are going to build when they need to, whatever the economy is."
 Asked about the state of the market for his specialty, Mr. Freeman said: "There seems to be a resurgence of commitment to libraries. It's wonderful for libraries and it's great for us." (In dollar volume, academic projects do not even account for a majority of Shepley Bulfinch's work, about 50 to 60 percent of which is in the medical field.)
 Is this the last round of major library expansion? "With electronic access and the wiring of campuses," Mr. Freeman said, "a lot of trustees will say, 'Why do we need more space in the libraries?' "
 To which he provides the answer: "Libraries will have technology that will never be in the dorms. People are going to libraries because more and more study is collaborative. The library is also a social center and you've got to recognize it."
 Traditionally, too, libraries have been physically at the center of campus, an important symbolic role. But new libraries cannot always be placed at the heart of the university. "Generally," Mr. Freeman said, "spaces in the center of campuses aren't available."
 Fordham's new library, for example, had to be placed at the southwest edge of the Rose Hill campus in the Bronx. In that place, it had to play two roles.
 "WHEN you approach the campus from that side, it looks like a public park," said Ralph T. Jackson, a Shepley Bulfinch principal. Fordham officials, he said, "were looking for the library to provide the edge of town and gown while, on the campus side, to provide a form that would welcome people in." In plan, the L-shaped building seems to open its arms to the campus.
 Its tower not only marks its presence on campus but "is very important symbolically because it has to do with the revitalization" of the surrounding area, said Alexander Howe, another Shepley Bulfinch principal.
 When designing or renovating libraries, Mr. Freeman said, Shepley Bulfinch begins with the notion of a railroad-like hub from which users can be directed quickly and efficiently to stacks, reading rooms, reference areas and special collections.
 There are any number of tensions to be resolved. While natural lighting enhances reading rooms, for example, it is inhospitable to the proliferating computer screens. And architects try to keep the size of study areas to fewer than 20 students. Otherwise, Mr. Howe said, "it tends to become a party."
 To cope with changing technology, Mr. Freeman said, "the building has to be spatially flexible -- that's our first line of defense." At the same time, he said: "There still has to be a sense of awe to a library. This is not a dispensary."
 "We're trying to design around the activity of using information, rather than the storage of information," Mr. Freeman said. "In the past, you would design a library with its stacks and then put in readers. As the collections expanded, readers went out. We're going to see, over time, readers expanding at the expense of the collection."
 A key, he said, was to determine how large a core collection was needed for ready reference and "browsability."
 Planning is also critical to jail and prison design, Mr. Ricci said. When county commissioners ask the architects how big a jail will have to be --visions of community opposition and budget overruns no doubt in mind -- he might answer, "We can make it smaller if you improve court administration."
 "We try to control costs based on our knowledge of the inmates," Mr. Ricci said. "Where inmates are present but under close scrutiny, you need medium security. Only in the areas where inmates are along for long periods do you need high security."
 THE cost implications are considerable. High-security windows --glass-polycarbonate-glass sandwiches in heavy steel frames -- can cost five times as much as simple tempered glass. High-security ceilings -- two-and-a-half inches of portland cement and wire mesh -- can cost four times as much as a laid-in tile ceiling.
 "I'm a firm believer in hiring a criminal-justice architect," said Raymond J. Klein, the assistant warden at the Westchester County Department of Corrections complex in Valhalla, N.Y., for which Mr. Ricci designed the multipurpose building.
 "When you hire a criminal-justice architect, you don't have to waste your time -- or money," Mr. Klein said. "What if the architect doesn't know the difference between a Folger Adam paracentric lock and an Air Teq pneumatic system? I'm not paying him to go to school."
 Inexperienced architects may err on the side of too much security. Mr. Klein recalled a project in which a local architect had specified "windows that looked like San Quentin -- in a women's prison."
 There are many specific concerns in this field of design. For example, Mr. Ricci looks for ways to allow maintenance crews to reach plumbing, heating and ventilating systems without going into secured areas, "where they might misplace a tool or leave a door open."
 In one project, this was accomplished through a basement tunnel. In another, it was done through a catwalk under the roof.
 One of the cardinal dimensions in the design of jails and prisons, Mr. Ricci said, is five-and-a-half inches for any opening.
 "That is the dimension below which 99 percent of the inmate population cannot fit their craniums," he said, even if they can contort the rest of their bodies to squeeze through the opening. "The study of phrenology is still alive and well," Mr. Ricci added.
