HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PULSE: The Great Plains;
Plains, While Still Bleak, Offer a Chance to the Few

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILD HORSE, Colo.

 BODY:
Survival has always demanded ingenuity in the Great Plains, where 19th-century settlers, making do without timber and nails, used mud and grass to build their homes.
 Today vast stretches of this region are about as lonesome as they were a century ago. But some small economic miracles, born of creative ideas and the willingness to take a chance, are thriving in the scrub and dust of America's least populated quarter. 
Farmers in North Dakota, who produce the bulk of the nation's durum wheat used for spaghetti, have pooled their resources and built a pasta-making plant, which opened two weeks ago near Jamestown.
 
Buying Cattle From Home
 A livestock dealership in Brush, Colo., using television satellite dishes, now broadcasts cattle auctions so ranchers can inspect heifers from the comfort of their living rooms.
 An outdoor-gear catalogue retailer, looking for ways to provide distinctive service from its headquarters in tiny Sidney, Neb., gives its customers a toll-free number to call with any question about outdoor sports, and requires all of its workers to pass a hunting and fishing test.
 Meatpacking plants in western Kansas are increasing production by relying largely on hard-working immigrants from Mexico and Vietnam. And the Sioux in South Dakota recently broke ground on a big gambling casino that will provide jobs for hundreds of unemployed Indians.
 
Towns Falling Away
 But for every economic boom on the Great Plains, there are far more little places, like Wild Horse, that are falling silent. Signs of recovery in the national economy, while raising some hopes here, generally loom as distant as the jets that streak the sky over this region on their way to someplace else.
 Wild Horse, about 100 miles southeast of Denver, was once a thriving town of about 200 people. Over the generations, it survived fire, dust storms and tornadoes. A picture taken in 1917 shows a town radiating with promise, faces smiling and hands clapping to a brass band blaring on Main Street. But in a national economy that has outgrown its use for such tiny, far-flung places, Wild Horse is not likely to survive much longer. Only 13 people live here now, and all but two of them are over 65 years old.
 Abandoned houses creak in the wind and boarded stores sit empty. Only a gas station with a flea market, the Unicorn, remains open. And the handful of survivors fear the day when the name of Wild Horse will be erased from the map.
 The Great Plains, the flat, shadowless sweep from Canada to Mexico, between the eastern foothills of the Rockies and the 98th meridian, a line that cuts just west of Wichita, Kan., covers one-fifth of the United States, but accounts for just one-fortieth of its population.
 And across much of the Plains, the numbers are shrinking. In Nebraska, for example, 83 of the state's 93 counties lost population in the 1980's, and almost all the winners were near Omaha, east of the Plains.
 A century ago, the Census Bureau marked an area "settled" when it had more than six people per square mile, and the historian Frederick Jackson Turner declared the American Frontier to be closed. But today, in about 200 counties on the Great Plains, the population density has fallen below that frontier threshold.
 
Rural America Writ Large
 "What is happening to rural America generally is writ large in the Great Plains," said Mark Drabenstott, a vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Kansas City, Mo. But unlike towns in rural regions like the Corn Belt of the Middle West or the dairy farms of New England, he said, many towns in the Great Plains sit in such isolation that further decline means they risk disappearing.
 Mr. Drabenstott explained that if a school closes in Iowa, where towns are much closer, there is likely to be another school 10 or 15 miles down the road. But here in Cheyenne County, with a population of 2,400, the school in Kit Carson is already serving an area of 1,000 square miles. It is not uncommon for children in the Great Plains to spend two hours each way on the school bus. And when a school closes in such a remote place, families must move, rather than opt for an even more distant school, since a school bus ride can only get so long.
 "In many of these little towns on the Plains," Mr. Drabenstott said, "we're reaching the point where the noose has begun to concentrate the mind."
 Over all, population in the Great Plains has been slowly increasing, the result of the growth of a handful of cities. But in the rural counties, the population has fallen more than 15 percent since 1930.
 That decline poses a stark contrast to the current economic booms farther West. In the mountainous regions of western Montana, for example, movie stars and rich Californians are buying ranches and donning leather chaps and cowboy hats. But on the Plains in the eastern part of Montana, where real cowboys wear soiled and wrinkled hats, plenty of old ranch houses are sitting empty.
 "The celebrities only want country that's drop-dead pretty," said Diane Kuhlbacher, a rancher in flat-as-the-floor northeastern Wyoming, which has been untouched by the rapid growth of Jackson and other places across the state near the Tetons. "We think our Plains are pretty, too, but it's the kind of pretty that has to grow on you."
 
Images of the Steppes
 The Great Plains includes parts of 10 states: Colorado, Kansas, Montana, Nebraska, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oklahoma, South Dakota, Texas and Wyoming. But no one state lies entirely within the Plains. Two major cities sit at its edges, Denver and San Antonio. The biggest city that sits on the Plains is Lubbock, Tex., with a population of 186,000.
 The region starts where the rainfall begins to stop -- the average precipitation is less than 25 inches per year -- and where the tall grass of the prairies gives way to short grass. For its scarcity of trees and vegetation, Zebulon Pike and other 19th-century explorers dubbed the Plains the Great American Desert. It has also been called America's Empty Quarter and America's steppes. It has the hottest summers, the coldest winters and the shortest growing season of any section of the country. And its ceaseless winds have literally driven some people mad.
 Home for centuries to the Sioux, the Great Plains was settled by whites largely through the Homestead Act of 1862, which President Abraham Lincoln signed "so that every poor man may have a home." And the settlers came in covered wagons by the millions, only to learn that the 160-acre plots offered by the Government, enough land to support a farm family in the fertile soil of Iowa, were insufficient in arid western Nebraska.
 Citing the long decline of population on the Plains, two geographers at Rutgers University, Frank and Deborah Popper, caused a furor a few years ago when they called for the Government to sweep parts of the region clean of its last inhabitants and turn it into a wildlife park to be called Buffalo Commons.
 But Easterners have been making dire warnings about the Great Plains for more than a century. "What do we want to do with this vast, worthless area?" Daniel Webster asked in 1836.
 In the face of enduring pessimism about their region, the Plains men and women still struggle to carve prosperity out of their rocky soil and wind-whipped small towns, and in some cases they are achieving remarkable success.
 
The Farmers
A Bumper Crop Of Linguini
 Given a choice, most American farmers will plant corn or soybeans, crops that generally bring the most cash per acre. And most farmers in eastern North Dakota, stewards of the rich, black soil that characterizes the Midwest prairies, cultivate vast sections of those crops, along with wheat and sugar beets.
 But on the Plains of the rest of North Dakota, where the rain is stinting, most farmers do not have that choice. They generally stick with wheat, which fares better in the drier climate. The difference between the Plains and the prairies can be measured in crop yields. The average yield of wheat per acre in the far eastern counties of North Dakota is 40.4 bushels; in the central counties, it is 23.5 bushels; in the far western counties, it is 12.2 bushels.
 Like all farmers, the Plains farmers' income can soar or swoop, depending on market prices. In the 1980's, a time when farmers were being clobbered by high interest rates, prices for wheat fell to less than $2 a bushel. The double whammy drove many off the land. The farmers who survived are doing much better today, with rock-bottom interest rates and wheat prices that have fluctuated around $4 a bushel.
 But since the specter of another plunge in prices always haunts them, a group of 1,040 North Dakota wheat farmers got together two years ago to devise a way to cushion their risks. Until lately, the durum wheat produced here was shipped to big mills in Ohio and Pennsylvania and used for pasta. Some farmers had an idea: Since North Dakota has the wheat, why not make the pasta right here?
 They formed a cooperative and each invested $12,000 to build a plant. The Dakota Pasta Growers, based in Carrington, N.D., started production in early November. It has hired 100 workers from the region and plans to produce 120 million pounds of pasta in the first year.
 "It all got started with some farmers just kicking around some ideas," said Gary McIntosh, the head of sales.
 With the creation of jobs, real estate values have jumped in the Carrington area for the first time in years. New houses are being built. And an old furniture store, which had been empty for years, has a sign in its window: "Grand Opening."
 "Who says resurrection can't happen?" asked Larry Leistritz, an economics professor at the University of North Dakota, who said the Plains needed to create just such businesses to capitalize on farm production.
 "It's a bright spot," he added. "But there haven't been too many pasta plants."
 
The Winners
Mail Order From Heaven
 It's an old adage: Do what you want. The money will follow.
 Dick and Jim Cabela of Sidney, Neb., wanted to hunt and fish, or at least to be around the sporting life. So more than 30 years ago they started a small business selling gear to hunters and fishermen. Their catalogue sales have seen double-digit growth in every year since.
 A few years ago, the business grew beyond the capacity of the local telephone company to supply it with lines. But the Cabela brothers, like many other entrepreneurs in the Great Plains, rejected the idea of moving for one reason: this was home.
 They opened a second business site in another little town on the Nebraska plains, Kearney, a place that during the homesteader rush of the late 19th century waged a brief campaign to make itself the nation's new capital, but has been struggling since then to keep its population above 6,000.
 Combining its sites in Kearney and Sidney, Cabela's Inc. employs 1,900 people, making it one of Nebraska's largest businesses.
 "This is heaven," said Jim Beardsley, who left an advertising job in Illinois to move to Sidney, population 6,500, and become the director of the company's catalogue sales. "I can hunt and fish every weekend. I've got a 4,000-square-foot house with a hot tub on 18 acres of land that I paid $72,000 for. I can look out my window and see a herd of antelope trotting past. It's so free of crime here that I leave the keys in the ignition of my car. And my kids go to a school with a student-teacher ratio of 12 to 1.
 "Friends back East ask me how I can live in this little town. And I say, 'Yeah, right.' "
 Some scholars of the West say the usual barometers of a region's economic health, like per-capita income, paint a false picture of little towns on the Great Plains.
 "The standard economic assessments are not only inadequate in measuring the quality of life in these little towns, they're pretty much irrelevant," said Phil Burgess, president of the Center for the New West, a research group in Denver. "People say the average income in South Dakota is one of the lowest in the country. But do you know what it costs to buy a nice big house in South Dakota? I was talking to a guy in Southern California recently. He said he pays $1,900 for a alarm safety system. And I told him, 'The people in South Dakota don't have that expense. They don't need safety systems.'
 "The No. 1 issue that everybody in this country is so concerned about is crime. Well, they don't have to worry about crime in little towns on the Plains. If your kid is running around doing something wrong, some neighbor is going to call and tell you about it. So some of these places aren't growing. So what? They've got nice houses, good schools and no crime. Isn't that the kind of quality of life we all say we're looking for?"
 Paul Hoefs, a 44-year-old stockbroker who has lived in New York, Chicago and Miami, was told by his company that he could open a new office in the location of his choice, so long as it had a telephone, a modem and a fax machine.
 Intrigued with the idea of living in a small town on the Plains, Mr. Hoefs and his wife and children took a drive through Superior, Neb. They saw the charming Main Street and quiet neighborhoods of elegant Victorian houses with wraparound porches and leaded glass windows selling for $50,000.
 "As we drove through town, people waved hello to us," he said. "And the whole family said, 'That's it. This is the place for us.' "
 Mr. Hoefs and his family now live in one of those Victorians, and he walks a block and a half to work every morning. The Ranchers A Big Spread Far From School
 Along with her husband, Diane Kuhlbacher owns a 10,000-acre ranch on the rugged, open countryside of Rocky Point, Wyo., but spends most days in a cramped two-bedroom apartment in the town of Gillette, 60 miles away. Two of her sons are in high school, and she did not want them to spend four hours a day on the school bus.
 "Years ago, ranchers would just rent a place in town for their kids to stay by themselves," Mrs. Kuhlbacher said. "But there wasn't as much mischief to get into back then."
 Even in little towns in Wyoming, she said, there are problems with drugs, drinking and teen-age pregnancies.
 Two of her sons and another boy from Rocky Point sleep in bunk beds in one room, while she and her 4-year-old son stay in the other room. "It isn't big enough," said Mrs. Kuhlbacher, who works in a bookstore. "But it's all we can afford."
 Wyoming makes what it calls "isolation payments" to people like the Kuhlbachers to help pay for a second home. The payment of $250 a month covers the rent on the apartment, she said, but not the utilities. Living in the little apartment and spending so much time away from her husband, Jack, is one of the sacrifices required of ranch life in the remote parts of the state.
 The Kuhlbachers could sell the ranch and probably live comfortably on the profits. But the property has been in the family since the turn of the century, when her husband's grandfather settled it under the Homestead Act.
 "Since it belongs to the family, we don't really feel like it's ours to sell," Mrs. Kuhlbacher said. "Besides, we're ranchers. It's our life. And we just wouldn't want to trade it."
 The time spent apart from her husband poses a hardship on the family, she said, but it has also had its bright spots.
 Before Mrs. Kuhlbacher moved out, she said, her husband was "like a lot of other men" when it came to doing chores in the house. "We women have a saying up here," she said. "Wyoming: where the men are men and the women work."
 But since Mr. Kuhlbacher has had to fend for himself, he has mastered the washing machine and doing the dishes. Now sometimes, even when the family is together on weekends, he does the cooking. "He's gotten so he actually likes it," his wife said. "And he makes a mean pot roast."
 
The Survivors
The Sadness Of Empty Houses
 Behind a faded white-picket fence in one of the few lighted houses in Wild Horse, 75-year-old Leona Schrimp sits back in her living-room chair, beside a cast-iron stove burning with the sweet smell of cottonwood, recalling the past.
 "Oh, we had fun in this town once," said Mrs. Schrimp, her white hair pulled back and her eyes flashing like stars.
 "But now, almost everybody has gone away. The Blekebergs, the Kinnebergs, the Kopstads, the Johnsons, the Olsons. It gets so I don't even want to take a drive in the country anymore. Makes me too sad, looking at all those empty houses."
 The town sits on the bank of the Big Sandy River, which has been dry for years. The next town to the west, Hugo, is 34 miles away, a stretch that passes only two houses, one of them empty. Coyotes howl in the darkness, and the fields crawl with rattlesnakes.
 Mrs. Schrimp's mother, Marie, was a homesteader, an immigrant from Norway who came to the Plains in 1908. She took a job cooking for cowboys on a ranch, and the wranglers helped her learn to speak English. She fell in love with one of them, a young cowboy named Otto Goldberg, and they married.
 "There's my dad," said Mrs. Schrimp, pointing to a photograph that showed him and the other townspeople in a joyous spring celebration of 1917.
 "And there's my friend Judith," she said, pointing to a small girl in the photograph. "She was born in '09. Held out here as long as she could. She's in a retirement home now."
 Until 1979, Mrs. Schrimp ran Lee's Cafe in town, which is now empty. Her husband, Curtis, is a retired cattle truck driver. In his spare time, he ran the gas station next to his wife's cafe.
 The schoolhouse down the road closed nearly 30 years ago, and church services are now held in the building, "when we can find a preacher to come out here," Mrs. Schrimp said.
 Until a few years ago, the claim to fame in Wild Horse was the headquarters of the Loretta Lynn Fan Club, run by Loudilla, Loretta and Kay Johnson, who lived on a ranch at the end of a dirt road. But the Johnson sisters moved to Nashville a few years ago, taking most of the post office's business with them.
 The postmistress, Evonne Schallenberger, who plans to retire in June, said she had been assured that the office would be kept open. But the Schrimps have their doubts.
 On the wall hangs a painting of Mrs. Schrimp's mother's home, a little white farmhouse in a meadow by a fjord. The Schrimps have three children, and when they were young, they would gaze at the painting and wonder about their grandmother's life back in the old country.
 The Schrimps' son, Steve, now lives in Denver, where he works as a computer consultant. One daughter, Martha, runs cattle on a spread outside of town. The other daughter, Lee Ann, who went to college to become a teacher, took a trip 10 years ago to Norway to find her grandmother's house, the one in the painting.
 She found the place, and introduced herself to the young dairy farmer who lived there. And they fell in love. Now Lee Ann and the dairy farmer and their children live in her grandmother's old home in Norway.
 A Norwegian newspaper wrote an article about it. The reporter said Lee Ann must love Norway's deep green meadows, rolling hillsides and bubbling brooks, especially after a childhood on the bleakness of the American Plains.
 "Oh, where I come from," she told him, "you can see forever."

HEADLINE: Brighter Outlook for Construction Workers

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
At the site of a dusty and noisy shopping center construction project on Bloomingdale Road here, Livingston J. Walker was grateful to be driving a front-end loader again. Until recently, Mr. Walker had been out of work, like many of his fellow workers in Local 137 of the Operating Engineers Union.
"Every day during the last few years was a black Friday for me," the 38-year-old father of five said. "The recession took a devastating toll on my life." 
 Before the current project began five months ago, Mr. Walker took on whatever odd jobs came his way to provide for his family and meet his bills. Union leaders said stories like Mr. Walker's were repeated nationwide as the unemployment rate for the building trades soared late last year to 14.5 percent -- almost twice the rate for all workers, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. In June and September last year the unemployment rate for construction workers reached 17.4 percent.
 
A Decline in the Jobless Rate
 "I don't consider myself a macho kind of guy, but I wanted to be doing better for my family," said Mr. Walker, who lives in Port Chester. "Last year and the year before at Christmas, I had to borrow from Peter to pay Paul to buy presents, but the holidays still weren't like they should have been for the kids."
Now the picture is beginning to change for many in the construction trades. Their jobless rate declined to 11.7 percent nationwide last month. And in this city, the 830,000-square-foot shopping center, known as the Westchester, is expected to create 1,000 jobs over the next year for carpenters, teamsters and operating engineers -- many of whom have not seen steady work since the late 1980's. Several other projects, including a new Federal courthouse here, have also meant new jobs for idle union members.
 
'People Are Really Hurting'
 But the recent upswing has not come without concessions from union leaders and a more conciliatory attitude at the bargaining table -- which many have described as a trend born of economic necessity.
"Labor is humble right now, because we are trying to survive -- people are really hurting," said Nicholas Signorelli, business manager for Local 137 of the Operating Engineers, which includes 1,100 active and 750 retired members in Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties.
In order to put at least some of their members back to work, union leaders agreed to concessions for the shopping-center job here, which they would not have considered in the past, Mr. Signorelli said. The contracts of the operating engineers -- who run heavy equipment -- and of carpenters and teamsters allowed for a no-strike clause, a 40-hour workweek instead of 35 hours and time-and-a-half pay instead of double-time for overtime.
Representatives of the O'Connor Group, a New York City development organization overseeing the project, would not discuss contract negotiations, but they issued a statement through Paul F. Kastner, a senior vice president of marketing for the group.
"Although there may have been a perception that the unions in Westchester County were difficult, we were most pleased to discover just the opposite, which is perhaps due to the current economic climate and drought of construction activity in the area," the statement said.
The shopping center is to open in 1995. It will be co-anchored by two department stores, Neiman Marcus and Nordstrom's, and will include 150 specialty shops.
The unions' project agreement with the O'Connor Group represents a positive new trend in negotiations, said Edward Doyle, president of the Building Trades Council of Westchester and Putnam Counties and president of Teamsters Local 456 in Westchester and Putnam, which represents 35,000 working electricians, plumbers, steamfitters and ironworkers, among others.
"It's the answer to labor and management issues," Mr. Doyle said. "It's the wave of the future." He explained that no-strike clauses are important to the banks that are financing new building projects, and in the case of the Westchester, that concession was the key element in gaining an all-union contract.
John E. Nicholson, an assistant business agent for Local 53 of the Carpenters Union in White Plains, called the project agreement "a pot of gold, because finally we are working again." Mr. Nicholson's union is one of six in the county representing 3,300 carpenters.
The change in union attitudes locally reflects a trend being witnessed throughout the state and the country, said Edward J. Malloy, president of the New York State Building and Construction Trades Council, an umbrella organization affiliated with the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
"It is generated by the seriousness of unemployment, which in some cases is between 50 percent and 80 percent for the building and construction trades," Mr. Malloy said. "To compete on jobs, we have to be creative." He said that while the Bureau of Labor Statistics unemployment figures were lower than the 50 percent and 80 percent figures he had just mentioned, in Plattsburgh, N.Y., for example, there were no jobs for construction, creating localized higher unemployment rates.
Mr. Malloy said that a decision by the United States Supreme Court on March 8, known as the Boston Harbor agreement, has allowed cities, states and Federal agencies to enter into contract agreements in the same way as the private sector and negotiate agreements specifying that work will be done by union members.
He said that the decision in the Building Trades Council v. Associated Builders case -- which validated a union-only labor agreement for the $6 billion cleanup of Boston Harbor and was considered a victory for organized labor -- would open the door to new work for local unions. In Westchester, the New York Thruway Authority will be able to enter into its first pre-hire agreement (an agreement made ahead of time to hire union workers) for a new $125 million, five-year repair project on the Tappan Zee Bridge.
On Tuesday, it was announced that the United State Postal Service would proceed with its plans to build a $102 million, 489,000-square-foot processing and distribution center in Harrison. Although the contract has been awarded to a Connecticut firm, Morganti Construction of Danbury, Mr. Signorelli said, the local unions would be negotiating with the general contractor to use Westchester workers.
Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat from Harrison who obtained a directive from the Appropriations Committee to lift a Postal Service moratorium on new projects, including the one in Westchester, said that as the unions made concessions to gain work, they also had to be careful to protect basic benefits like health insurance.
"Our goal is to create jobs, but there are certain bottom-line benefits that cannot be negotiated," she said.
 
35 Stalemates Reported
 As the construction unions shifted tactics in recent months to compete for jobs, union employees and employers in the public sector have become more adversarial with deadlocked negotiations, often long past the expiration of contracts, said Richard A. Curreri, director of Conciliation for the State Public Employment Relations Board.
"More and more often these days, things come to an impasse," said Mr. Curreri, whose board administers the state's Taylor Law, which regulates collective-bargaining agreements between public-sector employees and their employers.
In Westchester, Mr. Curreri said, there are 35 instances in which public-sector contract negotiations have reached a stalemate. Those include police and library administrators in Yonkers, the police in Greenburgh and teachers and teacher aides in Mount Vernon, he said.
Because of fiscal constraints, including reduced state aid, many municipal governments are asking for more employee contributions to health-care benefits and a reduction in pay increases and leave time, among other concessions, Mr. Curreri said.
 
Job Security a Lesser Issue
 Laura Ginsburg, director of public policy for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in Washington, said: "Things are tough pretty much across the country. Employers are in a take-back mode, and we don't know if it is going to get much better in the foreseeable future."
In Elmsford, John F. O'Reilly, a lawyer who represents municipal employers in public-sector union negotiations, said the impasses were often a result of union leadership's "unwillingness to bring back to the members difficult proposals."
He also said that the issue of job security was not as pressing in the public sector, where employees were not subject to the vagaries of the economy in the same manner that, for example, construction workers were. Therefore, he said, they were less willing to make concessions.
But Thomas F. DeSoye, a White Plains lawyer representing public-sector union members, blamed some employers for withholding raises that they were often able to afford, despite their protests to the contrary.
"It's patently unfair to blame union leaders and lay the number of impasses at their feet," he said. "It takes two sides to strike a contract."

LENGTH: 822 words

HEADLINE: County to Offer Loans To Create New Jobs

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER will offer up to $27 million in low-cost financing to qualified applicants next year in a program to attract new businesses and help existing ones expand, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke announced late last month.
The new plan, called the Section 108 Loan Guarantee Program, is part of the United States Housing and Urban Development Community Block Grant program. But it is separate from the Federal block grant program that allocates money for downtown beautification projects to eliminate slums and blight, said Barry N. Sussman, director of planning and research for the county's Planning Department. 
 The Federal loan program allows the county to pledge five times its current yearly allotment from the Department of Housing and Urban Development -- about $6 million -- for long-term, below-market financing to qualified nonretail businesses.
Typical applicants for the new program could include someone who wants to build a factory and has obtained some financing from a bank but still needs a loan to complete the deal, Mr. Sussman said.
 
Review Committee Set Up
 Since a goal of the program is to create jobs for low- and middle-income households, an applicant would need to show how his or her proposal -- to acquire or rehabilitate property or to purchase machinery, for example -- would accomplish that, Mr. Sussman said.
Applicants for the fixed-rate Federal loan, which would be administered through the county's Industrial Development Agency, must be approved by a project review committee -- composed of commissioners from the county's Planning and Finance Departments, the chairman of the Industrial Development Agency and two outside financial experts. The proposals are also subject to a final review by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
An applicant's plan must fall within a geographical area that the county has designated as its 37-community urban consortium. That includes villages, towns and some cities countywide, but does not encompass Yonkers, Mount Vernon, New Rochelle or White Plains, which administer their own Community Block Grant programs.
Mr. O'Rourke said recently that if larger cities with their own programs were to adopt similar loan plans, another $47 million would be available for businesses and new jobs in Westchester.
 
'It Is Found Money'
 In Yonkers, Charles Schorr Lesnick, Director of Economic Development, said his city would present its loan program, which is almost identical to the county's, to a public hearing tomorrow, and the City Council would vote on the matter next month.
Mr. Lesnick said the Federal Housing and Urban Development loan program has actually been in effect since 1979, but many communities were not aware of it until recently, when the Clinton Administration started to encourage municipalities to use the program.
"In a way, it is found money," Mr. Lesnick said. The city will be able to lend $21.4 million a year -- five times its annual allotment for the Federal Community Development Block Grant Program -- to qualified applicants, through the Yonkers Local Assistance Corporation, a nonprofit organization affiliated with the city.
Under the county's program, which the Board of Legislators approved unanimously last month, 1 percent of each loan would be set aside to cover any defaults by applicants, reducing the county's liability for the annual debt service on the loan. In cases where there is a default, the county would seek another operator to take over the business.
Yonkers is setting up a similar default mechanism, Mr. Lesnick said.
Mr. O'Rourke said that the county's investment could be "multiplied by the influx of jobs and business to some of the areas of our county hardest hit by the current economic downturn."
Those areas include Peekskill, Ossining and Port Chester, for example, but not the four large cities that administer their own programs.
The loan plan is part of the County Executive's 10-point Comprehensive Economic Development and Jobs program, which he announced earlier this year.
Under that program, which is designed to create more than 32,000 jobs in Westchester in the next four years, Mr. O'Rourke is calling for the establishment of a county job center where worker counseling and financing advice for small businesses would be available.
Also under the job development program, the County Association, a business organization, would compile a resource directory containing information on types of businesses in Westchester and on support services available for job searches. In addition, Westchester Community College in Valhalla would offer training programs for unemployed workers.
Another part of the County Executive's economic development and job program calls for the establishment of a marketing plan by the Westchester Business Partnership, another business organization, to attract 20,000 new jobs to the county in coming years.

HEADLINE: YELTSIN'S REFORMERS SHOW WEAKNESS IN RUSSIAN VOTE; CONSTITUTION IS APPROVED

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Monday, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Initial returns from Russia's parliamentary elections on Sunday indicated an unexpectedly strong showing by zealous nationalists and Communists against disunited reformers, even while President Boris N. Yeltsin won approval for his new Constitution.
The results stunned reform politicians who had gathered for a gala night in the Kremlin to celebrate the "Political New Year," and they lashed out at Mr. Yeltsin and their own disunity for the unexpected success of what they called "fascists and revanchists." 
 Live television coverage of the increasingly embarrassing gala, which was to continue until 6 A.M. (10 P.M. Sunday Eastern time), was abruptly terminated at 3:20 A.M.
 
Constitution Is Approved
 Mr. Yeltsin made no public appearance after voting in the early morning, but his aides focused on the approval of the Constitution, on which the President had focused his only efforts in the campaign. The charter granted the Russian President considerable powers to issue decrees, appoint the Government and overrule the legislature.
Shortly after midnight, Mr. Yeltsin's spokesman, Vyacheslav V. Kostikov, announced on television that the Constitution had been adopted. "We live in a new state," he declared. "Democracy has triumphed in Russia."
Soon after, Mr. Kostikov announced that the President now firmly intended to remain in office through the end of his term in 1996, although he denied that this was connected with "certain successes" by the nationalist followers of Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky and his Liberal Democratic Party.
 
Resumpton of Arms Sales
 Far brasher and livelier than his opponents on television, Mr. Zhirinovsky, 47, registered a strong surge in the last two weeks of the campaign with his uncomplicated solutions and angry nationalism, a blend his opponents branded "fascist."
He has vowed to impose a strong central Government, to bring all former Soviet republics back into a Russian empire, to rid Russsia of American influences and to resume arms production and sales to old clients like Iraq.
Reports from around Russia indicated that the turnout would reach only about 55 percent of the 107 million registered voters, far less than in any previous Russian election.
As early voting results began showing successes by the Communists and extreme nationalists, official reports became increasingly limited. Announcers at the televised gala said this was happening due to "shortages of operative information," while officials at the Central Election Commission simply stopped giving information.
The last announcement over television at about 3 A.M. (7 P.M. Sunday Eastern time) gave partial results for four major regions of Russia, but did not explain whether these were representative of the entire electorate.
 
Results From Regions
 They showed Mr. Zhirinovsky registering 26.6 percent in the north European part of Russia, 18.3 percent in the south European region, 15.1 percent in Siberia and the Urals, and 14.4 in the Far East.
Russia's Choice, the pro-Yeltsin party led by Yegor T. Gaidar, had 21.2 percent in the north, 16.1 in the south, 20.7 in Siberia and 14.6 in the Far East.
The Communists got 8.6 percent in the north, 10.5 percent in the south, 12 percent in Siberia and 18.3 percent in the Far East.
A fourth group with relatively high ratings was another pro-reform bloc, led by Grigory A. Yavlinsky, which, respectively, scored 11.2, 6.6, 10.4 and 6.5 percent in the four regions.
Other blocs that seemed likely to clear the 5 percent hurdle and to gain seats in the new parliament included the Women of Russia; another reform bloc led by Deputy Prime Minister Sergei M. Shakhrai; the conservative Agrarian Party, and the centrist Democratic Party.
The pattern of the vote and the relatively low turnout pointed to a powerful nationwide reaction to the hardships and poverty brought on by the collapse of the Soviet state and two years of economic liberalization.
 
'Sweet, Pretty Lies'
 "We did not sufficiently appreciate the sweetness of simple promises to a tired country, to people who no longer want to hear the tired truth and are ready to believe sweet, pretty lies," said Mr. Gaidar, the architect of Mr. Yeltsin's economic reforms.
Mr. Gaidar declared himself filled with "foreboding" about the new parliament. He said the most important task was "to try at any price to create an effective democratic coalition" in the new State Duma, the lower house of the new parliament.
But apart from pointing to a strong showing by Mr. Zhirinovsky and the Communists, the figures were not sufficiently complete to predict the final distribution of forces in the new parliament.
Half the 450 seats in the lower house will be filled from party lists, and the other 225 will come from candidates elected directly in local districts. For the most part, their leanings will become clear only when the legislature meets in January.
While commentators suspected that reformers would not have sufficient numbers for a majority, neither would the opposition, since the Communists vowed not to work with Mr. Zhirinovsky.
But Government officials said that in any case, the new Constitution did not require ministers to resign unless a new President was elected. With Mr. Yeltsin now set to stay in office until 1996, a reform government could remain in office at least through the two years the first parliament will sit.
"The Government and the course of reforms will not change," declared First Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir F. Shumeiko. "Certain reshuffling in the Government is possible, but its composition will not change in general."
Though Mr. Yeltsin's aides tried to declare the adoption of the Constitution a victory for the President, the overall results were a blow. The President called the parliamentary elections and the referendum on the Constitution after he dissolved the Soviet-era Congress of People's Deputies in September and crushed armed resistance by his foes.
The old Congress had consistently worked to block the President, and he had acted in the presumption that the nation would now elect a more progressive and cooperative parliament.
That seems not to have happened. This time, however, the President will have the considerable powers granted him in the new Constitution, including powers to issue decrees, name Government officials and even dissolve the parliament.
But with the low turnout and a relatively weak vote for the Constitution, Mr. Yeltsin's mandate was relative, even if his powers were technically buttressed by the new charter.
 
Anger Directed at Yeltsin
 For now, Mr. Yeltsin's spokesman, Mr. Kostikov, tried to put the best gloss on the results, portraying the adoption of the Constitution as a major victory and suggesting that the President might find common ground with the new legislature.
"The President will respect the choice the Russians have made on Dec. 12," he said. The programs of Mr. Zhirinovsky and the Communists have many parts which, he said, "quite correspond to the social aspects of the President's policies -- that is the social policy of the state, patriotism, making Russia great."
But Mr. Yeltsin also now faced the ire of some of his former followers. Gennadi E. Burbulis, once Mr. Yeltsin's closest adviser, put the blame for the reformers' poor showing squarely on the President.
"This was the fault above all of Yeltsin, who took a sideline position that was uncalled for when he needed to side with the democrats and present a strong front against the fascists and revanchists," he said at the opulent headquarters of Russia's Choice in a former aristocratic palace.
Mr. Yeltsin stayed entirely aloof from the election campaign, appearing on television only once last week to make a strong appeal for the Constitution. Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin also stood aside, taking a "vacation" in central Russia.
Other reformers blamed the failure on the disunity of the reformers. Reform politicians with few basic differences formed three blocs in addition to Russia's Choice, led respectively by Mr. Yavslinsky, Mr. Shakhrai and Mayor Anatoly Sobchak of St. Petersburg.
"We will have to pay dearly for the democrats' failure to reach accord and for their leaving our appeals to unify hanging in the air," said Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly B. Chubais, the head of the privatization program.
Mr. Zhirinovsky appeared obviously elated at the televised gala, and at his headquarters on the fourth floor of a dilapidated building in Moscow, his aides spoke with obvious relish of entering parliament.
Random samples of voters showed that Mr. Zhirinovsky attracted a considerable following in the military and among young blue-collar voters, among people who disdain the Communists but have lost faith in reformers.
In a recent interview with Izvestia, Mr. Zhirinovsky said his program included raising living standards by 100 percent within six months by halting all aid to former Soviet republics, halting all conversion of military plants to other uses, exporting large amounts of arms and checking crime by liquidating "all 5,000 crime gangs on Russian territory."
He denied that his ambition to reconstitute the Russian empire would cause war. "All these territories, the Baltics, Bessarabia, the Caucasus, historically belong to Russia," he said.

HEADLINE: In Holiday Season, Rooms Are Scarce In New York Hotels

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
City sidewalks are crammed in New York. Stores and Broadway shows are selling out. And though the holiday season is traditionally the busiest time of the year for Manhattan hotels, a surge in pre-Christmas travelers is capping what travel watchers say is the strongest year in more than a decade for hotels in the city and across the nation.
In the last couple of weeks, Manhattan hotels from the Carlyle to the Best Western at Times Square have been booked solid. Spurred by a gently improving economy, lower air fares and the perennial draw of New York's holiday glitter, hordes of conventioneers, European travelers and sightseers have descended on the city, determined to shop at Macy's, gaze at Fifth Avenue window displays or marvel at the Christmas tree in Rockefeller Center. 
 "Our hotel usually requires two to three weeks' advance booking," said Thomas R. Civitano, vice president of marketing for the Plaza. "But during this time of the year, the amount of time doubles." At least 2,000 guests have been turned away since the beginning of the month, he said. Next weekend will be fully booked as well.
"This has definitely been a good year for the hotel industry," said Mark Lomanno, executive director of Smith Travel Research, a consulting firm. "This year, the number of people staying in hotel rooms is up about 4 percent from last year. That's about 65,000 to 70,000 more rooms sold each day across the country."
For New York City's hotels, which collectively boast one of the highest occupancy rates in the country, that means a tight squeeze, especially now.
Steven E. Trombetti, a spokesman for the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, said the number of hotel rooms has held relatively steady, at 65,000. But Stephen Brener, a Manhattan broker of hotel rooms, who also analyzes demand for rooms, said it has fallen to 58,000, in part because some hotels, like the Vista, devastated by the the World Trade Center bombing last February, are under renovation.
 
Firsthand Experience
 Marion and Andres Binnmyr from Sweden know that from firsthand experience. When the couple first arrived in New York City last week to enjoy the sights, their hotel, the Lexington Hotel had only one room left, one with only a lone single bed. "It was very small," said Mr. Binnmyr. "But after that they put us in a bigger room."
Kim Jung Dae, a traveler from Seoul, South Korea, was simply squeezed out.
Though he had carefully planned a 10-day tour of the United States to include a weekend with his wife in New York City, he arrived on Saturday and drove his rental car first to the Roosevelt Hotel, then to the New York Hilton, only to find the same answer. No room at the inns. Nothing.
"I always heard New York is beautiful during Christmas," a dejected Mr. Kim said in broken English as he headed out to New Jersey to look for rooms. "We planned this for a long time. But everybody else also."
 
An Annual Flood
 As travelers like Mr. Kim found, space in Manhattan's larger, upscale hotels was scooped up early by the annual flood of early December conventioneers and business groups, who combine days of shop talk with shopping. Among those competing for hotel space last week were more than 4,000 members of the American Society of Association Executives, as well as two dozen women from the Midland Symphony Guild of Texas and a group of Russian bankers.
"This trip has made lots of pleasure," said Valery G. Znayko, chairman of the board of Progressbank, a commercial bank in Moscow, as he stood outside the St. Moritz Hotel. After meeting with American bankers, he said, he went across the street to F. A. O. Schwarz to shop for Christmas toys for his nephews.
Mr. Trombetti of the convention bureau says business travel has been bolstered this year in part by the expanded efforts of his bureau, including an increase in the marketing budget from $7.2 million to $8 million and the addition of sales representatives in Canada.
But plenty of those who have hustled in and out of hotel rooms since Thanksgiving were simply in New York City for the bright lights and merriment.
"I come here to go shopping and to see my friends and to go to the theater," said Arthur Altman, a Boston lawyer, who arrived at the Essex House for breakfast. He said he and his wife, Rita, come to New York every year at the same time for a long weekend.
Many holiday sightseers are international travelers, coming from as far away as South Africa and the Philippines. This year, experts and hotel administrators say, besides more Venezuelans and Argentinians, the number of British, German and French travelers, who have had access to reduced air fares, seems higher.
As Thomas and Gabriella Haenseroth from Berlin stood in front of the Plaza, listening to a five-piece ensemble, the Native Spirit Inka Jazz Fusion Band, play New Age-sounding music, they said they had got a bargain on their plane tickets for their first trip to New York.
"Our tickets were only 800 Deutsche marks each," said Mr. Haenseroth as he pulled his fur cap over his forehead. "Usually they are 1,000 or 950 Deutsche marks.
Like other visitors, they said their hotel, the Washington Square Hotel in Greenwich Village, was bustling.
Bob Wiener, owner of the Hotel Consulate near Times Square, had less than 10 rooms available on Saturday morning."They come to New York this time of the year regardless of the economy, crime or taxes," Mr. Wiener said.
At the Pierre Hotel, more than 40 people were on the waiting list over the weekend. The Hotel Millenium and the New York Marriott in the financial district, as well as the New York Renaissance Hotel and Essex House, also had wall-to-wall guests this weekend, as did most of the city's less pricey hotels, including the Best Western and Howard Johnson Plaza Hotel, both near Times Square.
The Loews New York Hotel on the East Side in midtown was booked solid, as was the Lexington Hotel nearby.
But Mr. Trombetti of the convention bureau insists the city is never out of rooms. "It's the busiest year we've had in a while," he said. "But we don't want to discourage people from coming. We always say that there's always room for a last-minute visitor in New York." He said there were still rooms left over the weekend at several Manhattan hotels, including the Roger Smith Hotel on Lexington Avenue, the Holiday Inn downtown and a handful of others.
He said that after Dec. 19, the number of travelers is expected to decline, and the hotels are expected to begin to offer special cut rates. But several Manhattan hotels reported they were booked steadily through New Year's.
Such promises, however, were of little consolation to William Litsinger, 32, who stood anxiously at the front desk of the Helmsley Windsor Hotel this weekend.
"My lovely wife lost our confirmation number for another Helmsley hotel," he told the desk clerk, explaining that he, his wife, and friends had flown in from Baltimore Saturday morning to shop in New York City and spend the night. The clerks apologized but insisted that they were fully booked. There were about 20 parties on the waiting list, all in front of him. Mr. Litsinger said four of the six Helmsley Hotels had turned him away.
"What can you do?" Mr. Litsinger asked philosophically, turning away. "I guess I'll have to go to Jersey or sleep in the airport tonight."

HEADLINE: Film Issue Snags Trade Talks; Anti-Dumping Pact Reached

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Monday, Dec. 13

 BODY:
After more than a week of steady if uneven progress, world trade talks have run into a roadblock amid pronounced differences between the United States and France over the movie and entertainment business.
Although trade officials reported progress on several issues in the negotiations among 116 nations, two meetings on Sunday between Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, and the European Community's chief trade official, Sir Leon Brittan, failed to resolve a deadlock over the export of American movies. This left the fate of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks uncertain with three days remaining until an agreed-upon Wednesday deadline. 
 "We have very severe problems at the moment," Sir Leon said. "Things are not looking good. I think we have a bit of a crisis on our hands."
But Peter Sutherland, the Director General of GATT, said later that he believed unstoppable momentum had built up for an agreement, a view shared by American and some European officials. [News analysis, page D1.]
President Clinton called Prime Minister Edouard Balladur of France, Prime Minister John Major of Britain and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany on Sunday night from Washington. Details were not disclosed, but it appeared likely that the leaders were seeking an 11th-hour solution to the impasse.
 
 
A Mark of Progress
 But in one sign of significant progress, a GATT official said an agreement had been reached early today on the question of anti-dumping duties, which are used against imports that are sold at artificially low prices.
The United States had protested what it saw as an attempt in proposed new GATT rules to limit its ability to apply these duties.
The official declined to give details of the compromise that settled this dispute, but said Japan was the only nation not to give its approval.
An American official said that the United States had sought 11 changes in the draft GATT text on anti-dumping and had secured 8 of them. These changes, he said, would allow Washington to retain laws that permit the Commerce Department to impose steep tariffs on imported goods that are sold below cost or for less than in any other market.
But the Commerce Department's latitude in setting the actual level of tariffs was restricted, although it was not yet clear by how much.
The American official played down these limitations, but anti-dumping lawyers have said such constraints could make a significant difference in the tariffs resulting from cases brought by United States industries.
"A week ago, we were opposed by virtually every country, but this evening we managed to get three-quarters of what we asked for," said Jeffrey Garten, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade. Mr. Garten said on Saturday that the United States would settle for nothing less than all 11 changes.
Many American industries have been concerned that their ability to protect themselves from overseas competition could be undermined if anti-dumping laws were circumscribed by GATT.
Sir Leon's use of the word "crisis" was its first use by any of the main figures in the trade talks since the North American Free Trade Agreement was approved on Nov. 17. After that, the Clinton Administration decided to push hard for a world trade accord, and important breakthroughs began to occur, particularly on the long-divisive issue of agriculture.
Mr. Kantor was less pessimistic, saying that "crisis" was too strong. But he conceded that "there remain a number of difficult issues."
Chief among them, according to Peter Werner, a spokesman for GATT, was the impasse over limits on American-made entertainment products. "The crisis is the audio-visual issue," Mr. Werner said. "This is a highly sensitive question, for both the United States and the European Community."
The setback meant that a midnight target for a draft treaty was missed. Sir Leon, who will meet later today in Brussels with European foreign ministers, had hoped to present a draft to them. "We haven't actually met the deadline, but we got quite close to it," a GATT spokesman said.
Wednesday, the deadline day, is the last day on which President Clinton can use so-called fast-track legislation, allowing him to submit a trade agreement to Congress for approval without amendment.
 
 
A Major Test
 A GATT agreement would update world trade rules and extend them for the first time to services, which account for about $4 trillion in annual trade. Besides its importance to the world economy, achieving an accord is seen as a major test of the ability of the world's leading powers to avoid conflict in an age when economic power has assumed something of the place once occupied by military might.
Mr. Kantor, a former Los Angeles lawyer, has met a wall of objections from France and the European Community as he has sought to persuade the Europeans to ease a quota system limiting the number of American movies and television programs. He has also sought to persuade the French to lift or alter a range of levies on movie tickets and audiocassettes and videocassettes that raised about $350 million last year.
This money, which the United States says is collected unfairly because many of the films used to raise the taxes are American, goes to subsidize the French film industry, which made 150 movies last year and is by far the largest in Europe.
Jack Valenti, the president of the American Motion Picture Association and effectively the chief lobbyist for American film makers, said he had not slept for two nights in Geneva as he has worked for a compromise. "It ain't us bringing this thing down," he declared.
But French officials see Mr. Valenti as the incarnation of thinly veiled protectionism that has insured that Hollywood has about 80 percent of the European movie market, while European films take about 2 percent of the American box office.
 
 
'Invisible Protectionism'
 They have been particularly incensed by Mr. Valenti's often-repeated claim that dubbed European movies do not sell in the United States, while dubbed American movies have a huge success in Europe.
"There is invisible protectionism in the United States," said Daniel Toscan de Plantier, the president of Unifrance, and Mr. Valenti's counterpart in Paris. "Films circulate throughout the world, but not in the United States."
Officials close to the talks said Sir Leon appeared to have very little leeway after France toughened its stance over the last few days and European Community leaders endorsed its stand on Saturday.
In particular, one compromise -- that American movie makers would have access to some of the money raised through the French levies -- was abruptly dismissed by the French Government on Saturday, one official said.
"Sir Leon is going to need a more flexible mandate if we are going to have a Uruguay Round," said one leading United States negotiator who insisted on anonymity. He was referring to the current round of talks, which began seven years ago in the Uruguayan resort of Punte del Este.
Entertainment products are the United States' second-largest export item, after aerospace products, and the potential for growth in cable and other developing technologies is enormous. The Clinton Administration is therefore reluctant to yield much ground on this issue.
Negotiators said other problems also remained -- over financial services, shipping, American trade laws and subsidies to the European aircraft industry. But these were described as surmountable, provided the audio-visual issue is resolved.

HEADLINE: Canada's Morals Police: Serious Books at Risk?

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Canadians have been reading Marguerite Duras's stories of love, obsession and heartbreak for years. But when an American publisher, Blue Moon Books of Manhattan, tried to ship 30 copies of her novella, "The Man Sitting in the Corridor" to Trent University this fall, the books were seized at the border.
According to a form filled out by a customs official named Corinne M. Honey, several scenes in the book, in which a woman is beaten and eventually dies after passionate sex, put it in a vast category of material that is barred from entering the country because it is considered obscene or exploitive. Ms. Honey, making a judgment on the spot, checked off the box on a form next to "sex with violence," and the customs agency shipped the books back to the United States. 
 Seizures of books have long been countenanced under strict Canadian anti-obscenity laws. But a landmark Canadian Supreme Court decision last year expanded the definition of obscenity to include depictions of sex that degrades or exploits women and other groups, and bookstore owners say it has emboldened the customs agency to seize books that are mainstream and serious as well as sexually explicit pornography.
Customs officials are empowered to seize books that include scenes of rape; of bestiality, even if sex with the animal is just implied; of sex with the dead (people or animals); of sex with children; of anal penetration, and of incest, including "descriptions of any sexual activity among members of a family, whether or not they are genetically related."
 
Freedom of Expression
 Under the same memo, they can also seize seditious material and "hate propaganda," which includes material blaming any specific group for serious economic problems or for manipulating the media. The officials are also supposed to give weight to the writer's "freedom of expression," but it is by no means clear what that means, as Trent University found out in the Duras case.
The university wanted the books for a course on the works of Marguerite Duras, the acclaimed French author whose most famous book is "The Lover." When Trent consulted a lawyer and began complaining publicly, the customs agency abruptly reversed itself, declared that the book wasn't obscene after all, and let the next shipment through.
But many others have met a different fate. Hundreds of books, magazines and newspapers have been detained, often for months at a time, or banned outright by officials up and down the Canadian-American border.
Moreover, bookstore owners charge, it is books for gay and lesbian readers that are most often seized by the authorities. Material that has been stopped includes works that range from the fringe, like the lesbian comic book "Hothead Paisan," to the well known, like David Leavitt's book of short stories "A Place I've Never Been" and Albert Innaurato's "Best Plays of Albert Innaurato," which includes the Tony Award-winning "Gemini."
 
A Different National Philosophy
 Canada's policies, civil libertarians say, reflect a national philosophy very different from that of the United States, where the First Amendment stretches far to protect free expression. In Canada, by contrast, other rights can supersede the right to free speech, as they did recently when a judge banned press coverage of a murder trial and when another judge banned a television movie about sexual abuse of children in an orphanage.
The United States has anti-pornography laws and courts have long struggled to define pornography. But in Canada, owners of seized material must prove that it isn't pornographic, while under the American system the burden of proof is on the authorities making the charge.
"There is a greater willingness to intrude on freedom of expression in this country than there is in the United States," said Alan Borovoy, general counsel of the Canadian Civil Liberties Association. "The Canadian tradition is much more conservative and much more trusting of authority."
In last year's landmark case, Canada's highest court declared that the videos and magazines being sold by a Winnipeg man whose adult-video store had been raided by the police in 1987, were obscene, partly because they were degrading to women.
 
'Cutting Back' Individual Rights
 Kathleen Mahoney, who successfully argued on behalf of the Women's Legal and Education and Action Fund in the case, said that the reasoning underlying the decision was sound, even if customs officials appeared to be going too far at times.
"There's an evolving kind of recognition in Canada that the law has not treated women and other minority groups fairly," she said. "If we truly believe in democracy in the fullest sense of the world, then everyone should be able to participate. That means some sort of cutting back of individual rights as we've always known them."
Bans on obscenity extend to books produced and sold within Canada, too, and in Toronto, a special police unit is charged with rooting out pornographic material from stores. But while the police make sporadic raids on book and video stores across the country, levying fines and confiscating material, most of the confiscation takes place at the border by customs inspectors.
At gay and lesbian bookstores in Toronto, booksellers say the new customs policies have wreaked havoc on business. Some shipments are examined, and others aren't, said Kimberly Mistysyn, manager of Glad Day bookstore. She said that some shipments of books are seized even though they are readily available in other Toronto bookstores and that some periodicals are seized, held for months by authorities and then released when they are well out of date.
Michel Cleroux, a spokesman for Revenue Canada, which includes the customs department, said that the agency does not discriminate against gay and lesbian bookstores. But he said customs inspectors, who are required to look for any illegally imported goods, not just books, pay particular attention to materials from certain book companies.
"Importers who are known to have have previously imported material that falls within the confines of the Tariff Code may be subject to higher levels of scrutiny and examination," Mr. Cleroux said, speaking of the law governing imports. "We're just talking about logic here. For instance, if you were looking for child pornography and you came across a book entitled 'Kiddie Beauties,' you might go through it a little more closely than you would the latest issue of The New York Times."
American book distributors who say their shipments have been singled out in recent months include Blue Moon and Inland Books, a distributor based in Connecticut that does much business with gay and lesbian bookstores in Canada.
"They go after the small presses," said Bruce Walsh, a spokesman for Censorstop, a Toronto group that has been keeping track of the seizures. Mr. Walsh said shipments by larger publishers and distributors are usually left undisturbed, presumably because they involve too many books to oversee, except haphazardly.
Bookstores and distributors generally learn that shipments have been detained only when they receive a notice in the mail, often days or weeks later. And they say that since appealing the customs decisions is so expensive and labyrinthine, and since they have never been given any list of what titles are allowable, they have to work hard to censor themselves.
"If something has been seized before, I simply won't bother to re-order it," said Ms. Mistysyn, adding that about a quarter of the books sent to the store from the United States are seized. "They have in the past seized books that had been seized before and determined to be allowable. They've told us it's an individual decision that's basically up to whoever opens the box."

HEADLINE: Congress Cracks Down As Fish Stocks Decline

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It has been 17 years since Congress passed the Magnuson Fishery Conservation and Management Act, regulations intended to reverse the steep decline in the catches of the nation's fishing industry. But the slide continues.
Although the law imposed strict catch limits and shortened fishing seasons and all but banished foreign trawlers from American waters, fish stocks off every coast are under more pressure than ever from bigger and more efficient boats and nets. 
 Fisheries regulators, whipsawed by economic, environmental and political interests, are constantly struggling to minimize overfishing and, at the same time, maximize returns for boats and crews.
Worried about the outcome of this struggle, Congress has again stepped in and mandated still more fishing restrictions. In a last-minute vote before Thanksgiving adjournment, the lawmakers ordered a new set of rules imposing stricter limits and shorter seasons.
 
Focus on Atlantic
 An important difference in the new legislation is that it focuses not on the deep offshore waters regulated by the Magnuson Act but instead on shallow inshore waters, specifically the shoreline waters of the Atlantic coast that once teemed with fish. Many of the details of the new regulations will be decided by a compact of representatives of the Atlantic Coast states from Maine to Florida.
For the short term, as the new rules take effect, the fishing situation for many recreational and commercial fishermen will probably get worse before it gets better. The tighter limits and shorter seasons will mean even less opportunity for weekend anglers and even less money for already hard-pressed trawler owners and their crews. But if stocks rebound, the fun and the good times will return.
Can they rebound?
"The statistics are alarming," says Representative Gerry E. Studds of Massachusetts, chairman of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee.
Along the Atlantic Coast, the weakfish catch has fallen 85 percent since 1980, the summer flounder catch has fallen 70 percent since 1989, and the decline in landings of cod and haddock has left the New England fishing fleet foundering in economic woe.
In the Gulf, red snapper flourishes only in areas where wrecks prevent trawling.
On the Pacific Coast, there are still salmon, perch and bass to be had. But in many cases, particularly outside Alaska, now the nation's most productive fishing region, stocks exist only because hatcheries are producing fingerlings.
 
Widespread Overfishing
 "The nation's fisheries are at a crossroads," Diana H. Josephson, a top fisheries official in the National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration, recently told Congress.
Ms. Josephson said that 67 of the 236 species tracked by Federal scientists were being overfished and that 61 other species were being harvested to capacity. Some species have become so scarce, she noted, that the fishing season for them opens and closes on the same day.
"We can do better," Ms. Josephson asserted.
The Atlantic's shoreline, where the new Congressional action was focused, was once home to great schools of weakfish, sea trout, black sea bass, flounder, blues, spot, croaker, shad and herring. But in recent years, many species have become extremely scarce, partly because of pollution and unfavorable weather, but mainly because of overfishing.
Increasingly, East Coast recreational anglers have found themselves returning to dock with only a small fish or two in the cooler. And, just as many offshore Atlantic fishermen did in earlier years, many inshore commercial fishermen are now looking for jobs on land or have started trawling for sharks and other fish that previously were considered inedible nuisances.
"The stock of virtually every fish species on the East Coast is in terrible condition," said John H. Dunnigan, the executive director of the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, an interstate compact that Congress authorized a half-century ago to draw up and administer rules for Atlantic coastal fishing.
 
Stronger Enforcement
 While the aim of the new inshore regulations will be much the same as the older offshore regulations -- to halt overfishing and give fish stocks time to rebuild -- there is more.
Traditionally, it has been the states, rather than the Federal Government, that have regulated fishing in waters extending up to three miles from their coastlines. They have consulted and cooperated with each other, but some states have nevertheless been more lax than others in regulating.
Given that many Atlantic fish migrate, the disparity in enforcement takes on added importance.
The new Congressional mandate calls for the states to continue to consult with each other and to define common limits and seasons on various fish species. But to insure that enforcement is uniform, if a state refuses to go along with a particular restriction, the Federal Government will step in and declare a moratorium on the affected fish in that state.
"This provision gives the law real teeth and that will make all the difference in the world," said William J. Goldsborough, a fisheries expert for the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, a nonprofit conservation organization. "The only other time we've had that was with the striped bass law, and it's one of the great fish-recovery stories."
Striped bass had all but disappeared from the Chesapeake Bay and the Atlantic when, in the early 1980's, Congress pressured the East Coast states to impose strict fishing limits and, in some cases, fishing moratoriums. Federal agencies were authorized to step in and impose controls on states that refused to act.
There was almost universal compliance, and today striped bass are back in the bay and the Atlantic in large numbers and recreational and commercial fishermen are once more enjoying good -- though strictly regulated -- catches.
"There's no reason now why the same thing can't happen to shad and weakfish and blues and all the other depleted Atlantic coast species," Mr. Goldsborough said.
 
Voicing Doubts
 Robert West, a commercial fisherman from Buxton, on North Carolina's Outer Banks, has his doubts. So does his wife, Susan, who recently sent a letter to Congress warning that "devastating" consequences might result from tighter limits on coastal fishing.
"When it comes to fish," Mr. West said recently between forays into the wintry Atlantic, "our experience has been that government, especially the Federal Government, usually ends up doing more harm than good.
"First they said they were going to rebuild all the fish stocks way out to sea," he said. "It hasn't happened. Now they say they're going to rebuild all the inshore stocks. Any reasonable person knows that something has to be done to conserve fish. But this time, with all these new rules, I fear they're going to break us all."
