HEADLINE: Blacks Fighting Blacks On Plan for Dump Site

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MACON, Miss.

 BODY:
On the face of it, Noxubee County seems an almost perfect place for the Clinton Administration to investigate whether poor and minority communities have been targeted as dumping grounds for toxic waste.
In the last three years, two of the nation's largest waste-management companies have sought to build immense toxic-waste disposal plants in this eastern Mississippi county, where 70 percent of the residents are black, family incomes are low and unemployment is high. 
 Last month, after receiving a formal complaint from a group of local black educators who asserted that the decision to put the projects here was racially motivated and discriminatory, the Environmental Protection Agency said it would take a look. But when the Federal investigators arrive here early next year, they will discover that things are not so simple.
 
A Raw Struggle
 Noxubee County, it turns out, is a community riven by suspicion and mistrust, not just between blacks and whites, but within the black community as well. The question of whether to allow the dumping of hazardous wastes is just the latest issue in a raw and evolving struggle for political power between poor blacks and middle-class blacks.
Political leaders say that many of the region's poor black families supported one of the proposed waste projects because the company promised jobs and agreed to give minority-owned businesses a sizable share of its contracts for supplies, security and other services. Poor blacks said the jobs -- and the money and power they represented -- would help them expand their political influence after decades of rule by whites supported by educated, middle-class blacks.
"We have an opportunity to develop minority-owned businesses," said Ike Brown, a 39-year-old political organizer who has led supporters of one project. "We can give our young people something to help them. When you're poor and got nothing, you're willing to live with a little more risk."
 
Economic Desperation
 But middle-class black families say the companies are taking advantage of economic desperation at the expense of the environment and public health. They note that the geology that has attracted the waste-disposal industry is virtually identical in 13 eastern Mississippi counties, but that it was Noxubee County, with the highest percentage of black residents, that was chosen.
"In this region we have become a dumping ground for toxic wastes solely on the basis of the high percentage of blacks in this community," said John Gibson, the assistant school superintendent in the county. "I think we have a legitimate case."
The companies that proposed the projects, as well as state environmental officials, said there were scientific reasons for selecting the county as a site for hazardous-waste disposal. Lying beneath the region's piney woods and rolling pastures is a layer of impermeable chalk that the companies and the state say would enclose the solvents and other chemical wastes and prevent them from seeping into the soil, water and air.
 
Only One Site Per County
 Until late November, two companies were competing for a state permit to build a hazardous-waste plant in the county. Hughes Environmental Systems/Federated Technologies of Mississippi proposed an incinerator and waste dump in Brooksville, eight miles north of Macon, the county seat. USPCI, a subsidiary of the Union Pacific Corporation, wanted to build a toxic-waste dump in Shuqualak, which is 10 miles south of here.
State law allows only one hazardous-waste treatment plant per county, and late last month, the companies announced plans to build jointly an $85 million dump in Shuqualak (pronounced sugar lock).
If it is approved by the state, which receives Federal money for the environmental regulatory program, the dump would be among the largest in the South, capable of handling 200,000 tons of toxic waste a year. That is almost seven times the amount now exported by Mississippi's manufacturers to treatment sites in Alabama, Louisiana and other states.
Last year, the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People endorsed one of the proposed Hughes projects and accused a local environmental group, Protect the Environment of Noxubee County, of racism. The N.A.A.C.P. said the environmental group, which is biracial, was trying to prevent a new employer from altering the area's low-wage scale, thus keeping poor blacks "socially and economically oppressed."
 
Nasty Struggle
 Opposing the N.A.A.C.P. is a group of black educators and ministers who formed African Americans for Environmental Justice to protest toxic dumping locally. It is cooperating with some of the county's wealthiest white families, who have historically not participated in local efforts to improve schools, housing and other services for blacks.
In this increasingly nasty struggle, both sides say they represent the majority of county residents, and each accuses the other of dishonesty in representing its cases.
Opponents of the dumps make certain that a visitor knows that Mr. Brown, a leading proponent and an officer in the local N.A.A.C.P., was paid by Hughes/Federated Technologies as a consultant. They also say that in local elections last year anti-dump candidates won in more races than pro-dump candidates.
In an interview, Mr. Brown acknowledged being paid as a consultant, but said the company, a subsidiary of General Motors, had agreed to help blacks get jobs.
 
Bearing Scars
 The county's environmentalists also bear scars from the fight. The leaders of Protect the Environment of Noxubee County have acknowledged participating in a public relations campaign that a competitor of Hughes/Federated was financing in an effort to prevent any toxic dumping in Noxubee County. The competitor, Chemical Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest hazardous-waste disposal company, operates a competing toxic-waste site in Sumter County, Ala., about 40 miles east of here.
Martha Blackwell, a spokeswoman for Protect the Environment of Noxubee County, said her group participated in the campaign because it served their purpose and promoted their cause. "I wasn't happy about it," said Mrs. Blackwell, who lives on a catfish farm near Macon with her husband and two children. "But if you look at the results, there still is no dump in Noxubee County."
In accepting Noxubee County as a test case for applying civil rights law to environmental policy, Administration officials said they were fulfilling promises that Bill Clinton made in his 1992 Presidential campaign and again in a speech on Earth Day last spring to investigate instances of environmental injustice.
"It has become clear to all of us in the Administration that poor people and minority communities have been asked to bear a disproportionate brunt of pollution from modern society," said Carol M. Browner, the Administrator of the E.P.A. "What we want to do is look at how every one of the environmental laws affects a community and to make sure the poor and minorities are protected in the same way that all communities are protected."
The investigation here is one of two to be conducted by the E.P.A.'s Office of Civil Rights; the other is planned for Iberville Parish, La. Both investigations were prompted by complaints filed by the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund acting in behalf of local community groups.
According to Ms. Browner and other officials, the investigation here will focus on two questions: whether race was a factor in the state's efforts to permit a hazardous-waste project in Noxubee County, and whether the toxic-waste dumps would expose the predominantly black population to disproportionately high health and environmental risks, and thus be discriminatory under the 1964 Civil Rights Act.
 
New Rules?
 The Administration's work is supported by national civil rights and environmental groups that believe it could lead to new rules giving minorities much greater authority to intervene or stop projects that they did not approve.
But James I. Palmer, the executive director of the Mississippi Department of Environmental Quality, said the Noxubee County case illustrates just how difficult it will be to define what has come to be called environmental racism and then establish measures to provide protections.
"At the very least," Mr. Palmer said, "you have to first ask whether it's environmental racism when most of the black leadership in that county, and many of the black citizens up there, supported a site and wanted the development."

HEADLINE: MOROCCO TO WIDEN LINKS WITH ISRAEL

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
King Hassan of Morocco has decided to broaden his country's economic cooperation with Israel in a major step toward the eventual normalization of relations, senior Clinton Administration officials say.
The King told Secretary of State Warren Christopher in a meeting in Rabat on Friday night about a package of agreements he has reached with Israel that would begin in the "immediate" future, the officials said. An announcement of at least some of the measures is expected on Monday. 
 The package, officials said, includes these points:
*El Al airline of Israel and Morocco's national carrier, Royal Air Maroc, have reached agreement on flights between the two countries. The agreement is expected to increase the number of tourists traveling from one country to the other from about 10,000 to 100,000 within a year, a senior official said. There are about 650,000 Jews of Moroccan descent who live in Israel; about 8,000 Jews live in Morocco. The flights will not be direct, but will go through Spain.
*Morocco and Israel will open direct telephone and mail links.
*Morocco has authorized visits of religious leaders and businessmen between the countries. Morocco and Israel are poised to announce that Israel's two Chief Rabbis will travel to Morocco, a symbolic gesture that is expected to have political and religious resonance in Israel and among Jews around the world.
*The two countries will set up joint banking arrangements that could pave the way for bank transactions and increased trade. Last week, a delegation from Bank Leumi of Israel was in Morocco to discuss ways of operating there.
*On the political level, Moroccan and Israeli officials are expected to increase the frequency and the level of direct contacts, although in the beginning at least, those will be limited to economic and financial exchanges.
 
Host for Peace Talks
 Morocco will also serve as host of peace talks on economic and other issues by heads of the Israeli, Jordanian and Palestinian delegations in the first three months of next year.
King Hassan did not tell Mr. Christopher if or when his country would move toward establishing diplomatic relations with Israel, American officials said.
The King, who relies on a number of Jewish advisers and is proud of his country's tolerance toward Jews, is said to favor diplomatic recognition of Israel. Such a move move could bring extraordinary economic and diplomatic benefits to his country, which with its cheap labor, proximity to Europe and fast-growing population is ready for foreign investment.
But the King, who survived two assassination attempts in the 1970's, has no desire to fuel Arab nationalism or Islamic militancy is his country, and is unwilling to move too quickly. Although he believes that he has a special role to play in linking the Arab world and Israel, he does not want to be seen as betraying Arab claims to Jerusalem.
 
Rabin Thanked Hassan
 On his way home from Israel after signing a peace accord with the Palestine Liberation Organization in Washington in September, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel stopped in Morocco to thank King Hassan for helping in the peace negotiations.
The two men, and a number of their ministers, keep in contact by phone, despite the official absence at the moment of direct phone links, a senior Administration official said.
Except for Egypt, which made peace with Israel in 1979, Morocco historically has been the leading Arab country to reach out to Israel. Since the 1973 Arab-Israeli war, Israeli and Arab officials have used Morocco as a site for secret meetings.
Israeli officials often traveled to Morocco to prepare for the visit to Jerusalem in 1977 of Anwar el-Sadat, then the President of Egypt. Mr. Rabin secretly visited Morocco in October 1976, and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres paid two secret visits to the King in 1978 and 1981, before visiting publicly, as Israeli Prime Minister, in 1986.
In the last few years, Morocco and Israel have quietly expanded their trade, despite an Arab boycott that prohibits trade with Israel. Administration officials said trade between Morocco and Israel is expected to double next year.
But Israeli officials have no desire to push the King too quickly, and the words of Mr. Peres on the day that Mr. Rabin met the King are widely shared in the Israeli Government. "There must be a certain gradual approach in this development," Mr. Peres said.
King Hassan has gradually moved more and more into the role of a conciliator between Israel and the rest of the Arab world, a role that he told Mr. Christopher he feels comfortable with.
The King also pledged to Mr. Christopher that he would continue to urge King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, with whom Morocco has excellent relations, to ease the Arab boycott. The Moroccan King is also trying to persuade Tunisian leaders to follow his lead with Israel.

HEADLINE: Promises to Keep

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
In his words and actions, Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani has been busy telling New Yorkers recently what he will not do to solve the city's looming financial problems: he will not raise taxes or lay off thousands of municipal workers, and he will not rely on other tried-and-true methods used over nearly two decades by New York City's Democratic fiscal establishment.
Instead he has talked passionately about being innovative and optimistic. But while closing off those critical options, he has given few clues of precisely how he intends to tackle the budget shortfalls that will surely preoccupy him when he takes office in three weeks. 
 That has led some Democratic city officials and some independent fiscal experts to question whether Mr. Giuliani appreciates the depth of the city's fiscal duress, or whether, if he does, he has yet decided how he will address it.
To be sure, Mr. Giuliani has said often during the campaign that he would seize control of the city budget and would resolve, once and for all, the underlying fiscal problems that Mayor David N. Dinkins was often accused of ignoring.
Mr. Giuliani said he would use several means to eliminate the city's huge structural deficit, estimated at $1.7 billion to $2 billion next year: by cutting 35,000 jobs from the city's payroll, but through attrition rather than layoffs (Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani has been busy telling New Yorkers recently what he will not do to solve the city's looming financial problems: he will not raise taxes or lay off thousands of municipal workers); by reorganizing how the city delivers services, including contracting out some services, and by making municipal workers much more productive. He also has said he wants to stimulate the local economy by phasing out four particularly onerous and unusual city taxes.
 
What About Pain?
 He sought to reinforce his message this week, when he selected Abraham M. Lackman to be his budget director. Mr. Lackman, an economist who has been a fiscal aide to the Republican-controlled State Senate for the last 14 years, will bring fresh ideas for closing the budget gaps, several of Mr. Giuliani's advisers contended. And he will do so, both Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Lackman said, by moving beyond the conventional methods employed by Democratic mayors since the late 1970's.
But as he did in the campaign, Mr. Giuliani has sketched his ideas with broad strokes, skipping lightly over the pain that many fiscal experts think would surely accompany any serious reorganization of the city budget. Mr. Giuliani has insisted that his solutions will center on making local government more efficient, thus saving money and closing the budget gaps without seriously affecting the quality of city services.
But many experts, including some who are supportive of Mr. Giuliani, contend that no matter how important it may be to eliminate waste, fraud and inefficiency, that alone will not balance the budget. Even Mr. Giuliani hasn't yet put a dollar figure on the savings he might achieve or specified how he might achieve them.
Some experts say that to trim $2 billion out of the city's $31 billion annual budget Mr. Giuliani will have little choice but to consider reducing or eliminating some services, laying off municipal workers, and, perhaps, raising taxes or fees.
 
Looking for $2 Billion
 "It's going to be very painful," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit advocacy group that monitors the city budget. "Basically, what you're talking about is taking $2 billion out of some pockets that are receiving $2 billion now. Those pockets are labor, the state and taxpayers. And if you don't want to reach into the pocket of taxpayers, then you have to reach more deeply into the pockets of municipal employees and the state."
"This is a very big number," said Mr. Horton, who did not endorse a candidate in the mayoral race but whose publications and ideas figured prominently in Mr. Giuliani's position paper on the city budget. "There's no way it's going to be relatively painless."
Mr. Giuliani has sought to deflect the concerns by suggesting that people have been too quick to reject new fiscal approaches.
In announcing his selection of Mr. Lackman on Wednesday, Mr. Giuliani dismissed some fiscal complaints as revealing "defeatist attitudes." He also reiterated his belief that "the core of our agenda" would include stimulating the city's economy by eliminating several taxes, and closing budget gaps by devising creative ways to make government more efficient.
Mr. Giuliani stepped up his oratory the following day, saying in a speech that he did not wish to fill the city with doom and gloom. "Winston Churchill didn't walk out in the middle of the Battle of Britain and say, 'You know, those bombs may really win out in the long run and we may lose to the Nazis.' "
 
Symbolic Tax Cuts
 But some fiscal experts -- including several who said they were reluctant to speak publicly because they did not want to be accused of prejudging Mr. Giuliani -- said that the problem was not his optimism or his ambition, but the limitations of his program as he had thus far presented it. And by trying to phase out some taxes, in some ways he makes his problems worse. The four taxes he wants to reduce, including the hotel tax and the commercial rent tax, bring in about $1.5 billion a year.
In recognition of that problem, Mr. Giuliani's fiscal advisers say that they will begin phasing out the taxes slowly, and that next year the cuts will be mostly symbolic. Some note, for example, a comment by Mr. Lackman, the designated budget director, that he would exhaust creative new ideas before considering layoffs or other Draconian tactics.
He offered one specific idea: collecting more of the city's unpaid parking fines. Mr. Lackman says as much as $2 billion in unpaid fines could be collected, but Dinkins administration officials say the most optimistic figure would be $500 million, and even that would be very hard to get.
Many Democratic politicians noted that Mr. Dinkins and, before him, Mayor Edward I. Koch, had also seen promise in unpaid fines and had sought to increase fine collections by contracting out the responsibility to a private company. In Mr. Koch's case, it led to a bid-rigging and bribery scandal. For Mr. Dinkins, who sought to sign up the same company, Lockheed Information Management Services, it led to charges of favoritism and the forced resignation of his budget director, Philip R. Michael.
For his part, Mr. Lackman said he would probably have city officials try to improve the fine collections rather than hire an outside company. But some fiscal experts contend that even if Mr. Lackman could succeed where his predecessors had failed, the additional revenue might be the sort of nonrecurring revenue, or "one shot," that many fiscal experts and even Mr. Giuliani himself had long criticized Mr. Dinkins for using.

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeks to Narrow a Growing Wage Gap

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Seeking to please liberals as well as blue-collar Reagan Democrats, the Clinton Administration is cobbling together a multibillion-dollar strategy that aims to narrow the growing wage gap between Americans who have gone to college and those who have not.
Administration officials admit that their efforts, hamstrung by tight budgets, will make only a modest dent in the wage gap, which has grown steadily as the American economy has shifted away from its low-skilled manufacturing base toward areas requiring higher skills. But these officials say it is important that the White House is making a broad effort to reverse a trend that has fueled anxiety among tens of millions of blue-collar Americans. 
 This strategy includes a larger job- retraining plan for laid-off workers, a new apprenticeship program to provide special skills for young people not bound for college and a loan program to enable more low-income youths to afford college.
 
Money to Come From Trims
 Administration officials plan to increase spending on education and training by about $25 billion over five years, starting with about $2.5 billion this year. They say they expect to pay for it by trimming in less vital areas.
In the Administration's view, this strategy, which focuses on lifting the skills of the non-college-educated, is desirable not only because it is good politics, but also because it will reduce income inequality and help make the nation's work force -- and its economy -- more competitive with those in Japan and Europe.
But many economists say the effort will be able to offset in only a minuscule way the effect of powerful global economic forces. New technological developments, like robots and automated teller machines, are cutting demand for assembly-line workers, bank tellers and other unskilled workers, helping hold down their wages.
At the same time, the growing demand for highly educated workers, like management consultants and software designers, is pushing up wages for college graduates.
As a result, workers with college degrees, who in 1979 earned 38 percent more an hour than high school graduates, now earn 57 percent more, according to the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington-based research group. Viewed in another way, the average hourly wage for high school graduates fell 12 percent from 1979 to 1991, after factoring in inflation, remained flat for workers with college degrees and rose by 8 percent for Americans with at least two years of graduate school.
"A very, very large gap between the well-educated and everybody else," said Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich in an interview, "makes for an unstable society."
The average American wage has stagnated in the last two decades because of the slowdown in productivity growth, with wages for those without college degrees squeezed especially hard by automation and the globalization of the world economy.
"Global integration," Mr. Reich said, means the relatively unskilled are "competing with millions of people willing to work at a fraction" of their wage.
 
A Gnawing Anxiety
 Clinton aides say American voters feel a gnawing economic anxiety not only because of a pervasive fear of layoffs but also because wages are on a downward escalator for a broad swath of workers.
Mr. Reich, the principal architect of the Clinton strategy, plans to announce in January a much larger retraining program, aimed especially at workers in declining industries and hard-pressed regions. He has also pushed for more Job Corps money to train urban high school dropouts and for a new plan to set up apprenticeships for the non-college-bound -- people who often flounder before finding their first jobs.
President Clinton's college loan program aims to enable more youths from moderate-income families to afford college, and the new national service program shares that goal. The Administration's much-advertised Goals 2000 program, which seeks to improve elementary and secondary education, also hopes to better prepare all Americans -- college-bound and non-college bound -- for the 21st-century work force.
 
Vying With Market Forces
 Alan Blinder, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said: "Realistically, the underlying forces of the market are vastly stronger than anything the Government can do. Some people say the Government shouldn't try to do anything. But Government action can make a difference, if done well."
Even some sympathetic economists wonder whether there is more oratory than substance behind this strategy, not so much because Mr. Clinton's heart is not in it as because his deficit-reduction efforts have left him limited money to fight the battle.
"I wonder whether they'll end up addressing it mainly with language rather than with resources," said Gary Burtless, a labor expert at the Brookings Institution. "It doesn't seem to me they have in mind spending a lot of money."
Lawrence Mishel, research director at the Economic Policy Institute, said: "It's clear that this Administration is much more attentive than the past few administrations to the needs of workers and providing the ladder to upward mobility. All the policies are aimed in the right direction, but the question is whether they will be large enough to make a difference."
Some economists say that to narrow the wage gap substantially would require hundreds of billions in spending on education and training.
"Given political realities and budget constraints, we're doing the best we can," Mr. Reich said.
Clinton aides defend the more aggressive Federal role, saying that public schools and the private sector have not done enough to upgrade the skills of the non-college-bound.
The strategy aims to remedy several problems that Mr. Clinton's advisers and their friends in the labor movement have long worried about. Studies have found that America's non-college-educated workers have fewer skills than their counterparts in Germany, Japan and other industrial countries, although America's college-educated compare favorably.
The wage gap strategy involves more than training and education. Mr. Reich plans to push to raise the $4.25-an-hour minimum wage after Congress considers the President's health plan. Another effort to narrow the gap is the earned-income tax credit, which provides tax cuts or refunds for about 15 million low-income American households.
Even some conservative economists express broad sympathy with the Administration's efforts.
 
A 'Good Place to Begin'
 "Dealing with the education and training system is a good place to begin to deal with this problem," said John Taylor, a Stanford economist who was an economic adviser to President George Bush. But he said too much emphasis was being put on spending more and not enough on improving education through better management and offering families more choice in selecting schools.
Several Clinton aides seek to score political points by arguing that this strategy seeks to reverse the income inequality that widened in the Reagan-Bush years. But Republican economists note that as a result of potent economic forces, this gap also grew even in left-leaning European countries like France.
Some Administration officials worry that the strategy may backfire politically if it is viewed as favoring the non-college-educated over the college-educated. To dispel this perception, one official described the plan as an effort to improve the skills of all Americans, college-educated or not.

HEADLINE: U.S. Malls Luring Foreign Shoppers

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GURNEE, Ill., Dec. 11

 BODY:
Iris Collicutt would never have thought to travel from her home in Switzerland to do her Christmas shopping at Gurnee Mills, a huge discount complex halfway between Chicago and Milwaukee, if she hadn't seen a Swiss travel company's newspaper ad. Yet here she was today, along with her sister, Brigitte Muller, and her mother, Annemarie Muller, talking about how it all made great sense.
"It's not just that it's a lot cheaper, but the salespeople are much friendlier and it's all indoors," said Mrs. Collicut, pausing outside the Camelot Music Outlet, where they had bought compact disks and tapes ranging from Beethoven to reggae. 
 The three had some specific items on their lists, like Oshkosh children's clothing and Timberland boots, but the general plan of attack was to wander in search of appealing deals. Despite a stated intention to "not overdo it," by the time they settled down for a break in the food court shortly after noon, they had accumulated clothing, shoes, Christmas ornaments and the music.
 
A Powerful Phenomenon
 The Mullers' three-day shopping spree represents a slow-developing but potentially powerful phenomenon: the globalization of shopping. Foreign tourists have long been major contributors to sales and profits in exclusive American shopping districts like Madison Avenue in New York, the Magnificent Mile in Chicago, and Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills, Calif., as well as at world-famous department stores like Bloomingdale's. But until recently, few Asian or European travelers to the United States made major malls the focus of their visit.
Many of these international shoppers, like the Mullers, are not especially wealthy. They fly from Japan straight to Minneapolis to board buses for the Mall of America, or from South America to Fort Lauderdale for the short trip west to Sawgrass Mills, or from Europe to Boston for the 90-minute bus ride to outlet shops around Fall River, Mass., and Howland Place in nearby New Bedford.
Agencies like Imholz Reisen A.G. of Zurich, which organizes shopping-oriented trips to this and other destinations, typically leave a day or two in the three- or four-night stay for sightseeing or jet lag. But their advertisements make clear that standard tourist destinations like the Sears Tower and Art Institute in Chicago are extras. And some travelers, like the Mullers, who paid about $900 for air fare, bus transportation and three nights at a Day's Inn, use much of their free time for still more shopping.
Part of the allure is the availability of items that cannot be found at home. But the main goal usually seems to be a better selection or lower prices. And some analysts see the trend as a big opportunity for discount centers like Gurnee Mills, which are almost unheard-of overseas.
"Brands at a discount is what the world is buying now," said Therese Byrne, a New York-based retailing analyst who believes tourists represent a much bigger growth opportunity for retailers than local shoppers.
That certainly squares with the experience of Andrew Arluck, general manager of the clearance outlet that Saks Fifth Avenue recently opened here. "People from around here may look at some of our designer items and think they are expensive, but foreign visitors who have shopped Saks and other top stores in the cities realize they are dirt cheap," Mr. Arluck said. The foreigners occasionally buy in astonishing quantities and return periodically, he said.
Groups like the 20 or so Swiss who came here today represent the cutting edge of the new trend. The vast majority of foreign business at most American malls is generated by Mexicans along the southern border and in the north by Canadians, who are avoiding a heavy sales tax at home. But the handful of managers at large malls that have tourism departments say there is plenty to be gained by courting all long-distance shoppers.
 
'The More You Spend'
 "Basically, the farther you come, the more you spend," said Colleen Harvey, director of tourism for the Mall of America, a complex south of Minneapolis that is the largest mall in the country. In this holiday shopping season, groups of shoppers have come from Australia, Japan, Germany, Switzerland, Belgium and Britain. The mall's own exit surveys suggest that the percentage of shoppers who are foreign tourists has doubled in the last year, to more than 5 percent, a figure Ms. Harvey believes is low.
Statistics about the impact of the "shop till you drop" trips, as they are sometimes advertised, are sketchy. The Commerce Department estimates that 45 million tourists came to the United States last year and spent $71.2 billion, including an average of $539 on gifts and souvenirs. But those figures give little clue as to spending by tourists destined for malls. A handful of malls in border regions that have tried hard to appeal to foreign visitors say there are some periods when such foreign shoppers outnumber the locals.
Gurnee Mills' larger sister development, Sawgrass, may attract the most foreigners. Nearly half of its 18 million annual visitors are foreign, making it the second-largest tourist attraction in Florida after Disney World. The Western Development Corporation, the Washington-based discount mall developer that owns Sawgrass, Gurnee, and similar complexes outside Washington and Philadelphia, estimates that 46 percent of the foreign tourist traffic is from Europe, 32 percent from Latin America, and 14 percent from Canada.
 
$500 to $1,000 Each
 Sawgrass estimates that foreign visitors -- many of them from South America -- spend an average of $500 to $1,000 each, compared with $80 to $200 for the typical local shopper, depending on the season.
The influx of foreigners is based partly on currency swings. The long decline of the dollar against the yen has encouraged more Japanese to shop in Hawaii and at mainland shopping centers. And the stabilization of the peso as the Mexican economy expands has led to a sharp rebound in Mexican spending in the United States, after a decline in the mid-80's.
Similarly, the strong dollar that encouraged Americans to flock to Harrods and other famous department stores in London during the 1985 Christmas season has been replaced by a relatively strong pound. That not only makes the United States look inexpensive to British shoppers, but has caused Harrods to abandon American marketing promotions.
Moreover, some retail analysts say Europeans are increasingly likely to consider such opportunities because more and more of them belong to families in which both husband and wife work. That encourages them to concentrate their shopping in vacation periods and look for settings where a lot can be done quickly.
 
'Don't Know What to Do'
 "A lot of retailers understand that there are opportunities but don't know what to do about it," said Mark Frantz, a spokesman for Curt Salmon & Associates, a retailing consulting firm that has worked with some clients on building tourist business.
Some malls advertise overseas. Many court foreign travel writers. But most rely on local and state tourist agencies to promote them. Gurnee, for example, depends on state and local tourist officials and on Diane Sharp, who oversees international promotions for Sawgrass, to represent all of Western Development's malls at travel shows.
Ms. Byrne said she believed shoppers like those who traveled from Europe to Gurnee Mills foretell growing pressure for more equal pricing of consumer goods around the world.
"People underestimate the longterm impact of this on pricing," she said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
The Los Angeles Times Steps Back From a 'Sky's the Limit' Approach

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The Los Angeles Times, one of the country's great newspapers, is in a period of what its managers call refocusing. Others call it retreat.
Though its news coverage remains among the best in the country, the newspaper, by many measures, is shrinking. 
 Largely because of advertising declines, the newspaper's revenue this year is expected to be about $150 million less than its 1990 peak of $1.1 billion; it will be the third consecutive year of revenue declines. Daily circulation is down by more than 120,000 from more than 1.2 million in 1990.
Through employee buyouts aimed at slashing costs, The Times has cut its staff of 8,500 by about 2,000 since 1990 -- a decline of 23 percent. Other newspapers have also been trimming their work forces because of economic pressures, but the industry average is believed to be less than 10 percent.
The newspaper's predicament shows the vulnerability of many big-city dailies. The Los Angeles Times's troubles, some analysts say, come in part from declining newspaper readership generally and increasing battles for advertisers. Those underlying problems, which are affecting newspapers everywhere, are amplified by the stubborn Southern California recession.
 
A Question of Identity
 Whether the paper is refocusing or in retreat, its pessimistic financial reports and cost-cutting measures -- including the buyouts that have brought the departure of some of its best writers -- have set off something of an identity crisis for The Times.
"You have to understand, this was a paper that was the most affluent in the country and everything was possible," said Robert Scheer, a respected national correspondent who left the newspaper staff under one of the buyout programs.
"You would have to be a fool not to wonder: What does this mean for the newspaper? What does it mean for the future of newspapers?" asked Mr. Scheer, who still writes for the newspaper as a freelance contributing editor.
The struggle of The Los Angeles Times, whose enormous growth paralleled the giddy post-World War II development of Southern California, now mirrors the troubles of this region that is struggling with the economic slump.
Even some of the newspaper's senior managers acknowledge that the last several years have been disconcerting to many who remember when Times reporters traveled first class to assignments and Times executives talked of ever-bolder plans for expansion.
"It's like I was on a bullet train and so were a lot of other people," said George J. Cotliar, the managing editor, who joined the newspaper in 1957. "We've slowed down before and we've slowed down now. But that doesn't mean we've stopped."
 
Redefining Priorities
 In a series of interviews here recently, the newspaper's top editors and its publishing executives portrayed The Los Angeles Times's troubles as offering what its editor, Shelby Coffey 3d, called a "silver lining."
Mr. Coffey said the fiscal pressures had encouraged the huge organization to redefine its priorities and to "focus on its core market," a vast area the size of Ohio around this sprawling city.
"It wouldn't be reasonable," he said, "to expect cheering that Southern California has a lingering recession. But you play the cards you are dealt. Our job is to bring the paper through this with strong coverage and make it, ideally, an even better newspaper."
Mr. Coffey and other senior Times officials noted that the newspaper had expanded efforts in some important areas during difficult times. It added correspondents in Berlin, Brussels and Tokyo and started a Seattle bureau. And, after the rioting that followed the 1992 acquittal of the local police officers charged with beating Rodney King, the newspaper revived long-dormant plans for a special Sunday section covering Los Angeles's center city and started a new Spanish-language tabloid.
The newspaper has also continued its Washington edition, with a circulation of 3,000, that is aimed at solidifying the newspaper's reputation with opinion makers on the East Coast.
Times executives also described a program of efficiencies that they said had helped improve the newspaper.
Much of the circulation decline, for example, has been caused by a conscious effort to drive away readers in areas considered too remote from the newspaper's main Southern California market. It was expensive to transport newspapers to other parts of California and other states, and advertisers considered distant readers superfluous, Times executives said.
 
Changes in the Newsroom
 The search for efficiencies has spread into the newsroom, though staff cuts there have not been as large as in other divisions of the paper. In better times, the news department was known for providing its star reporters with opportunities that were rare in journalism. Some routinely worked for months at a time on long articles.
David Laventhol, the newspaper's publisher who recently announced that he would step down on Jan. 1 because of illness, said the newspaper's need for efficiency meant it now had little room for reporters who produced two or three articles a year.
A new publisher named earlier this month, Richard T. Schlosberg 3d, is a former Air Force pilot who cultivates an image of toughness. But in a lengthy conversation before his promotion was announced, he said he believed "the era of the metropolitan newspaper is going to have a rebirth" through rigorous management. Mr. Schlosberg is expected to continue most of the policies he inherits from Mr. Laventhol.
 
 
'It Sort of Hit a Wall'
 For each "silver lining" explanation from Times management, however, there is another that suggests that the newspaper's new era of limits has come at a heavy price. "All of a sudden, it sort of hit a wall," said Noel Greenwood, a former deputy managing editor who left the newspaper last year after a 25-year career there.
The results, Mr. Greenwood and other Times veterans said, are diminished goals and an unmeasurable loss of self-confidence at the newspaper.
"It was, for many years, a newspaper that aspired to be, at the least, one of the highest-quality regional newspapers in the United States," Mr. Greenwood said, "and there has been a series of retreats from that."
Bella Stumbo, one of the best-known of the newspaper's accomplished writers to accept the buyout plan, said the buyout stripped the newspaper of its most experienced reporters. Such plans often have the effect of removing senior workers because of their higher earnings.
Ms. Stumbo said Times managers were damaging the paper. "They seem," she said, "to be methodically eviscerating the senior staff."
Mr. Coffey and other Times officials denied that the newspaper had diminished its ambitions and said it had hired new writers with broad experience at other newspapers.
Mr. Coffey quoted Otis Chandler, the last member of the newspaper's founding family to serve as its publisher, as saying the newspaper was "global and local" in its influence and its coverage. Mr. Coffey said there had been no retreat from that. Mr. Chandler was publisher from 1960 to 1980 and was chairman of the newspaper's parent company, Times Mirror, until 1986.
 
Reducing Expectations

 
 But it is clear that by a series of objective measures, The Los Angeles Times is not what it was. The paper where editors and publishers once talked of ambitions to be an all-California newspaper or, indeed, one that circulated across the Western United States, can no longer be found in Tucson, Ariz., or Salt Lake City. Much of the time, it cannot be found in the central California cities of Modesto or Fresno. Even in San Francisco, the newspaper has scaled back street sales.
The Times is also cutting the number of reporters assigned to its "zoned" coverage, tailored for particular communities in some Los Angeles suburbs. And it closed its San Diego edition last year, surrendering an ambition to dominate California from Santa Barbara to the Mexican border.
For some of the newspaper's managers, one frustration of the financial pressure is that it has focused attention on The Times's problems instead of on what they thought would be a bright new era under Mr. Coffey, who is 47.
Mr. Coffey, a polished and well-read man, was promoted to editor with some fanfare on Jan 1, 1989. After moving through senior editing positions at The Washington Post, and then briefly holding the top editing positions at U.S. News & World Report and The Dallas Times Herald, Mr. Coffey arrived on the fast track at The Los Angeles Times in 1986.
 
Success, and Criticism

 
 Mr. Coffey's tenure has been marked by some clear successes, including a Pulitzer Prize for coverage of the Los Angeles riots. The Times has also been innovative in its new design, which uses color photographs and graphics and tries to give readers logical pathways through what was long criticized as a rambling newspaper.
Mr. Coffey has also been criticized. In a highly publicized dispute that boiled over after the disturbances of 1992, some minority reporters and editors said the newspaper, which has few minority journalists in top positions, was resistant to change.
A separate dispute concerns the broad powers Mr. Coffey gave to editors in Orange County, the affluent suburban county south of Los Angeles, to tailor the edition of the newspaper that circulates there. For example, the edition often uses front-page articles on Orange County issues in place of articles chosen for page 1 in the city.
Many newspapers across the country now "zone" their newspapers by substituting items of local interest for others that may appeal to an audience elsewhere.
But Mr. Coffey gave the Orange County editors an unusual level of autonomy. And some people inside and outside of the newspaper have said that remolding a quality paper to appeal to highly local concerns diminishes its stature.
 
Defending the Record
 In a lengthy interview in The Times's executive suite recently, Mr. Coffey turned aside such criticisms.
The dissension in the newsroom after the city was torn by racial tensions, he said, simply reflected that The Los Angeles Times is part of the world. "It would not have been right," he said, "to expect that none of that would have been in the newsroom."
Mr. Coffey defended his record of minority hiring, saying he had increased minority representation in the newsroom from 10 percent to 18 percent, higher than it is at many newspapers.
As for Orange County, he said, the editors there still answer to him. But he noted that since he gave them added control over the edition, The Times has been winning readers in a long-running circulation war with The Orange County Register. While The Register still holds a strong lead in the county, The Times has been gaining.
 
Deflection as ResponseDefense

 
 But Mr. Coffey deflected a series of questions about the declines and cutbacks that have cast a shadow over his tenure. To every question about circulation shrinkage or declining dollars, he answered by discussing the accomplishments of a newspaper that is finding new efficiencies and re-evaluating its priorities.
Near the end of the interview, Mr. Coffey was reminded of his comment that "you play the cards you are dealt."
Were these, he was asked, the cards he thought he had been dealt when he took over one of the richest and most ambitious newspapers in the country?
For the first time in a long conversation, the editor of The Los Angeles Times seemed momentarily at a loss. He smiled a bit awkwardly.
"Are they ever?" he answered.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Self-Defining Governor Looks Ahead

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
TWO years ago, at a breakfast for potential contributors, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo coyly appeared to have finally opened to the door to a Presidential campaign. Matilda Cuomo believed otherwise. She left the power breakfast with the distinct impression that what her husband had said was that he intended to run for Governor again.
"Either she knows all about me, or I am an enigma," Mr. Cuomo mused later. "I hope I am an enigma." 
 He later acknowledged that he had been tempted to run for President but solemnly announced that his obligations as Governor weighed more heavily on his unfinished agenda.
If Mrs. Cuomo was right all along -- if her husband announces within a few weeks, before he diagnoses the State of the State, that he will seek a fourth term -- he will, if he wins and serves most of the four years, have been Governor of New York longer than any of his predecessors. Mercifully, New Yorkers have been spared the recurring speculation about his intentions that, inadvertently or not, he had stoked in Presidential years.
The other day, he cheerfully declined to engage the subject in great detail, and contemplated what others might be saying of him: " 'The guy said for seven months he was not going to play this game.'
"I pick the time the decision has to be made and then I use up all the time. They will have nine months to find a better candidate if I don't run."
His intentions might be gauged by his State of the State address, which he is already drafting: whether it represents a legacy of unheralded accomplishments and unfinished business that he, more than any other Democratic candidate, would be best able to defend or a vision that he rather than the voters will be in a position to see through over four more years.
Against a Republican, he could be more vulnerable than ever. Even some of the voters who give the Governor the benefit of their doubts are weary, or worse, after 12 years, as they were in 1989 of Mayor Edward I. Koch. This year the liabilities of incumbency were driven home to the Governor of New Jersey, to all three citywide incumbents in New York City and to every New York City official elected last month and subject to a just-enacted two-term limit.
Mr. Cuomo is also a contrarian, a Tinkerbell in reverse. Say that he's afraid of losing or cannot win, and he will run. Clap your hands for 12 years of inspiring oratory and for a record undermined by a recession and a Republican-led State Senate and he may vanish from Albany forever.
He suffers from another challenge of his own creation: disillusionment. He has loomed like a larger-than-life colossus, straddling the two tectonic plates of expectation and accomplishment that seem to have drifted apart -- leaving him like a less-than-lithe acrobat attempting a split but seemingly about to land on his rear.
Years ago, the Governor eloquently justified his anomalous role, as President Clinton did earlier this month to a young protester. "Part of my job is to be a lightning rod," the President said. "Part of my job is to lift the hopes and aspirations of the American people, knowing that as long as you're trying to lift hopes and aspirations, you can never fully close the gap between what you're reaching for and what you're actually doing."
Which is why Mr. Cuomo was miffed this fall when it was suggested that the title of an anthology of his speeches, "More Than Words," might encapsulate what seems, to some people, to be missing from his record.
"A lot of people have worked hard to do a lot of good things since our improbable victory in 1982," Mr. Cuomo wrote in an adaptation from his diary, "and I hate to see them slighted because I failed to meet people's expectations of me personally."
"Every time the question is asked, I recall the good political advice my son Andrew gave me in 1983: 'Youll want to do everything, but the people won't be able to remember everything, so pick one thing and say it over and over -- "I'm the Education Governor," or the "Environment Governor." Keep it simple and repetitive, as we do in a political campaign, to help the people remember.' "
That might be good politics, but not good government, Mr. Cuomo wrote, deciding instead to pursue all of his goals simultaneously without worrying which might constitute his most marketable legacy.
"Frankly, I believe the result is that we have earned the right to be associated with an extraordinary range of significant -- and in some cases unique -- accomplishments, notwithstanding they are too many to put on a bumper sticker, or to describe in a 28-second commercial or even an 800-word written analysis."
Mr. Cuomo produced a five-page, single-space typed litany of them (public works, economic development, state tax cuts that in some cases prompted compensatory local tax increases, doubling prison capacity, changing the face of the State Court of Appeals).
After all is said, if not done, he conceded Andrew was right, but added: "Looking ahead, though, I plan to continue to try to do everything we can -- all at once -- to create opportunities and to meet the needs of New Yorkers. The truth is, I think the only label that would really please me would be 'The Governing Governor.' "
Blessed with the Republican-run Senate that has been a convenient foil as well as an obstacle, he also is running against a state government that he would revamp through a constitutional convention -- providing him on the eve of an economic recovery with still another vital rationale to run without having to go through hoops to rationalize the race.

HEADLINE: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.
According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.04 percent, and the rate on the six-month issue was 3.23 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television;
From radio to pay-per-view, Howard Stern climbs his mountain. Is late-night TV at the summit?

BYLINE: By Bill Carter

 BODY:
HOWARD STERN has spent most of his career confronting value judgments made about him. Now he's eager to supply a stack of green-backed evidence to anyone interested in judging his current value.
"I find myself in a position to say to the powers that be that not only is my radio show a force to be reckoned with," Mr. Stern said, "but it also has serious economic clout." 
 The 39-year-old radio comedian, who has built his reputation on the use of language and subject matter that offends many and amuses many others, has seen his stock as an entertainer soar in recent months.
Mr. Stern's morning radio show, the base of his operation, is top-rated in many of the 16 cities where it is broadcast, including New York, Los Angeles and Philadelphia. His first book, "Private Parts," reached No. 1 on the New York Times best-seller list (despite being banned from some stores) and has one million copies in print. Widespread reports have three movie studios making offers for him to star in films. And several television companies, most prominently Fox Broadcasting, are offering deals for him to jump into the swirling caldron of late-night talk shows.
Mr. Stern's bankability may be proved again on Dec. 31, when he will try to buck the trend of poor results for entertainment programming on pay-per-view television. Mr. Stern will offer an adult-oriented special lasting one hour and 50 minutes starting at 11 P.M. Eastern and Pacific time, built around his own uncensored brand of beauty pageant. The guests on the show include what amounts to an all-star team from the tabloid league: John Wayne Bobbitt, Heidi Fleiss and Joey Buttafuoco.
Mr. Stern said the pay-per-view format made sense to him now for several reasons, mainly having to do with content and money. The content can be, as he put it, "as wild and outrageous" as on the radio show, and he will be able to avoid the scrutiny of his nemesis, the Federal Communications Commission, which has no jurisdiction over pay-per-view.
Citing certain comments on the radio show as indecent, the F.C.C. has fined the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation, Mr. Stern's employer, in recent months. More disturbing, in Mr. Stern's view, has been the chill these fines have imposed on Infinity's ability to buy radio stations.
"What's good about pay-per-view," Mr. Stern said, "is that nobody gets it who didn't pay to get it."
And then there is the money. Pay-per-view has been promising a fortune to entertainers and sports promoters for more than a decade, but that promise has seldom been kept.
Pay-per-view now reaches 20 million of the country's 55 million homes with cable television, but the industry has been weak in marketing. Results for most events have been modest.
In the entertainment area, "a half of 1 percent buy rate is now considered good," said Dantia Gould, the editor of Pay-Per-View Update, a newsletter that follows the industry. The buy rate is the percentage of homes with pay-per-view that buy a program; a 1 percent buy rate translates to about 200,000 homes. The farewell concert by the Judds, for example, did 1 percent, she said, "and that was called a success."
Mr. Stern said he expected to do much better, and executives in the pay-per-view industry tended to agree. Ms. Gould said: "I think he can do sensationally. It's the right combination. He's hot, and he has the radio show where he can really promote it."
She said the price, $39.95, might be a little steep. But she said Mr. Stern's mostly young, male audience is the perfect profile for pay-per-view. She said Mr. Stern might get 3, 4 or even 5 percent of the available audience, at least in the areas where his radio show is hot.
At a national buy rate of 3 percent, or 600,000 homes, the event would take in about $24 million, of which half would go to the cable operators for distributing the event, the rest to Mr. Stern and his partners, Main Event Television.
Mr. Stern said he wanted success of that magnitude to help "prove my commercial viability." That proof is especially important now, Mr. Stern said, because a bonanza on pay-per-view "will set up the next group of things that we do."
Mr. Stern said he was torn between accepting an offer to do a film or going directly into late-night television. A movie might not be ready to go into theaters for almost two years, he noted, while a television deal could be struck fairly quickly. Fox has had a big vacancy in the late-night area since the rapid demise of "The Chevy Chase Show," and Mr. Stern said he had also talked with representatives of one of the planned fifth networks as well as syndicators.
Either way, he said, "the idea of going on television and beating Letterman and Leno would be tremendous to me." The plan is ambitious: he said his show's format would immediately grab a segment of the younger audience, eventually driving both Arsenio Hall and Jay Leno off the air and "leaving a three-way competition between me, David Letterman and 'Nightline.' "
"I wouldn't get into it if I didn't think I could win," he added.
This rosy outlook, however, has one complication: the workload. Mr. Stern said he is committed by contract to stay with his radio show for two more years. That would mean four or five hours of radio each morning followed by the preparation and taping of a talk show in the evening.
Mr. Stern said the odds of his taking on the late-night challenge were "right at 50-50." He said he would decide on the television offers "within the next two or three weeks."
He said that his book had brought him a legitimacy with the mainstream media and that he did not think he was risking any of his prospects by going into areas on the pay-per-view special "that might be perceived as blue or raunchy."
"I always have that in the back of my mind, but forget it," he said. "I have never gotten anywhere worrying about the powerful elite who run the media, the people who might be looking at me for late-night television or movies or things like that. I go by what I think is funny. When it comes to pay-per-view I know who I have to satisfy.
"There will be network types who'll say, 'All he's good for is doing this raunchy pay-per-view.' Fine. So be it."

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Shattering the Legends Of West's Pistol Packers

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Anyone who believes that Jesse James resembled Tyrone Power or that Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid lived up to their reincarnations by Paul Newman and Robert Redford will be stunned to learn tonight that it wasn't like that at all.
"Outlaws, Rebels and Rogues," the first program of the three that make up "The Untold West," performs what may be the least necessary debunking in American history as it reports that Jesse, who started his career as a Confederate bushwhacker, wrote his own press releases and that a week after he was shot, Ma James was giving tours of their house; that despite 48 movies celebrating Billy the Kid, little is known about his doings (except that he was born in New York City), which does not stop people from paying to see the hole in a wall that is said to have been inflicted by the bullet with which, the ballad tells us, Billy was "shot down by Pat Garrett who once was his friend"; that Butch and Sundance only achieved in the 1969 movie that bore their name the fame that had eluded them in life, and that Belle Starr looked a lot more like Walter Brennan than like Gene Tierney. 
 Even if such revelations do not knock off your 10-gallon hat, they are presented engagingly, with plenty of clips from old movies, some harmless re-enactments and amiable asides by Old West historians, who agree that the famous bad men and woman of pulp and celluloid were all "outlaws of the imagination."
The series continues tomorrow night with "The Black West," an account of the role that blacks -- including Mary Fields, who is said to have ridden for the Pony Express when she was 70 -- played in Western lore. Wednesday's offering, "Hot on the Trail," features Calamity Jane, the Harvey Girls and a Mrs. Noonan, a cavalry vamp who turned out to be a man. It's only a matter of time till somebody debunks them all.
 
'The Cronkite Report'
'The Uninvited: Immigrants at the Gate'
Discovery Channel, 8 P.M.
This sober and sobering survey may not tell you much you have not already read or heard about the plight of refugees and the problems of immigration, but it packs a lot of pain into an hour.
Walter Cronkite, in a somewhat pontifical mood, begins with an overview of a population explosion, particularly in Africa, Asia and Latin America, that portends dire water shortages, environmental devastation and increasing misery. Add the upheaval that has followed the collapse of the Soviet Union and other ethnic and religious conflicts around the world and the result is millions of mostly impoverished people on the move.
Mr. Cronkite reports, too, on the backlash against immigrants in a Europe floundering in recession and on outbursts of racism in Germany and even in Britain. He notes that antiforeign sentiment has been growing in the United States, too, despite this country's history as a recycling station for the wretched refuse from other shores. Nighttime pictures of Mexicans entering the United States show how porous national borders can be.
Experts, notably Doris Meissner, the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization Services, make sensible observations about the conflict between America's traditions and present-day realities, without pretending to have any solutions.
 
The Untold West
Outlaws, Rebels and Rogues
TBS, tonight at 8:05 P.M.
 
Written by Tom McMahon; directed and produced by Cathe Neukum for TBS Superstation; Michael Deane, executive producer; Pat Mitchell, executive producer for TBS; Vivian Schiller, supervising producer for TBS; Lou Diamond Phillips, narrator.

HEADLINE: Welfare Reform in the Making

 BODY:
One of every four children in America is poor; nearly one of every three is born to an unwed mother and 70 percent are raised on welfare.
The statistics are grim, which is why President Clinton put a vow to "end welfare as we know it" near the center of his domestic agenda. The central idea is to make welfare a temporary stop on the way to a job. And according to internal documents obtained by Jason DeParle of The Times, a working group appointed by the President will soon propose legislation to carry out the pledge. 
 Though the working group remains divided on important issues, it is united on the basic thrust. Welfare offices will be turned into agencies that find jobs, not just cut checks. They will provide training, education, child care and health insurance. But, in order to compel recipients to find work quickly, cash assistance will be cut off or down after two years unless there are extenuating circumstances.
Time-limited welfare is the key to Mr. Clinton's reform. But to make the threat humane -- and make the plan politically viable -- government must find work for enrollees who do everything right but still can't find a job. The draft document would require enrollees to accept a subsidized private-sector job or government employment or work off their welfare grants by doing community service. But all-important questions -- such as whether community service would also be time-limited, or what the likely cost would be -- were left unanswered.
Nor does the draft document explain how millions of new workers would be absorbed into the work force. In the past, Congress tried subsidizing employers to hire the unemployed, but the policy backfired because employers wouldn't hire applicants stigmatized by government subsidies. Congress could create public-sector jobs. But if the jobs are meaningful and the workers are paid prevailing wages, as organized labor wants, that is hugely expensive. If jobs are make-work, taxpayers may become outraged at what would appear to be a boondoggle. And any program to put welfare recipients into jobs threatens to displace equally-deserving low-paid workers.
The draft document makes a troubling promise that welfare reform will be self-funded. That could mean no more than that welfare reform will conform to existing budget laws. But if the promise means reform will have to be paid out of cuts in other parts of the welfare program, then the initiative could do more harm than good.
Skimpy funding buried Congress's previous reform, a 1988 law sponsored by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York. The law provided all the right ingredients: training, education, job-search assistance, child care and health insurance. But Congress appropriated only about $1 billion a year in matching funds, far below the $6 billion needed.
Studies by the Manpower Research Development Corporation show that in states like Florida and California, where aggressive programs of education, training and job-search were begun, welfare rolls declined and earnings rose. The impacts were small but positive. That suggests -- and the working group agrees -- that the first task is to wring everything possible from the 1988 reform by putting up much more money. Only then will it be time to fixate on the new get-tough policies. And even then, the children of those whose benefits are cut would have to be protected by providing health insurance, food stamps and some child support.
The big hurdle will be money. Mr. Clinton must convince the public that the goal isn't to save a little money in the short run. The larger goal is to save lives -- the lives of the teen-age dropouts and their children -- in the long run. Growing up in poverty for prolonged periods is a ticket to trouble. It is not just a personal tragedy for the families but an albatross for the economy.

HEADLINE: How to Get Real on Global Warming

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Philip M. Boffey correctly notes that hard questions face the Clinton Administration as it continues to search for global warming policies that will deliver real results ("China and Global Warming," Editorial Notebook, Dec. 8). Mr. Boffey raises a very controversial topic: whether American companies should be allowed to meet emissions reduction goals through investments abroad. 
 In its recently released Climate Change Action Plan, the Administration stressed that overseas ventures -- also known as "joint implementation" projects -- would be encouraged. However, the missing ingredient is an Administration commitment that reductions achieved as a result of such projects will be counted toward the domestic reduction goal.
Recently, U.S. electric utility companies have become involved in joint implementation projects that preserve valuable forest areas abroad, deliver ancillary economic benefits to local populations, and offset greenhouse gas emissions considerably. All this is accomplished at low cost, especially when compared with similar projects in the United States.
If the Clinton Administration continues to pay only lip service to such joint implementation projects without providing a clear signal that reductions achieved abroad will be counted toward the U.S. goal, companies will begin to shy away from such opportunities and costs will be driven up in the process. The only way to put a dent in emissions rates in countries like China is to provide the proper incentives now.
 
JOHN MEYERS
Bethesda, Md., Dec. 8, 1993
 
The writer is an energy-environmental policy analyst.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A building revival rekindles interest in construction stocks.

BYLINE: By Andrea Adelson

 BODY:
AS an economic recovery appears to take hold in the United States, some analysts suggest that engineering and construction stocks are likely to appreciate in the next year as the swinging of I-beams and the pounding of jackhammers begins in earnest.
But the market has failed to see that a boom within this sector is well under way, analysts say, creating opportunities for investors. 
 Companies like the privately held Bechtel Group, the publicly traded Halliburton Company and the Fluor Corporation have seen their order backlogs climb to near record levels after business bottomed out during the collapse of the oil patch in the early 1980's. Fluor may be especially attractive, analysts say.
Even in the face of such fundamental trends, economic malaise continues to depress stock prices among the construction giants. As recently as Nov. 5, shares of Fluor fell to $38.625, near its 52-week low of $38 in intraday trading on April 26. On Friday, the shares closed at $41.375. This, despite the fact that Fluor has seen its order backlog rise to $14.9 billion, and last week delivered its sixth consecutive year of earnings growth.
In a report last month, Jeanne G. Terrile, an analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company, said the stocks had been stuck in low trading ranges since 1991, in part, because since the rebuilding of Kuwait after the Persian Gulf war, "there has been no new theme with legs" for investors in the construction business.
Yet two old themes still support the long-term investment potential of engineering and construction stocks, she said. As economies recover, investment will increase in power plants, factories, consumer-goods and oil refineries in developing countries.
That, in turn, will stimulate capital investment by producers in developed nations and regions, like Japan, the United States and Western Europe to compete with new economic rivals.
Fluor, which is based in Irvine, Calif., is well positioned in both sectors because "it sells sophisticated, project-management expertise," said Mark Altman, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. "That's something that will be very valuable as we see large projects come along."
Fluor is still best known for building Saudi Petrochemical's $4 billion industrial city and gas-gathering project in Jubail during the late 1970's.
Since 1986, however, the executives who succeeded J. Robert Fluor, the late grandson of the founder of the company, have become disciples of diversification, even bidding for jobs of less than $1 billion.
Daimler-Benz used Fluor to pinpoint the location for its Mercedes auto plant in the United States. The Department of Energy awarded Fluor and its partner, Jacobs Engineering, a $2.2 billion project cleaning up nuclear-bomb refuse at Fernald, Ohio. Chicago officials chose Fluor for a $200 million modernization of the city's "911" emergency telephone system to handle five million calls a year.
"In being all things to all people, it's a certainty your profit margins will be lower," said John Simon, an analyst for Seidler Amdec Securities. But Fluor's new "shotgun" approach reduces the company's exposure to oil shocks, he said.
Because of the company's global experience and its adroitness in political hot spots, analysts said they believed that foreign business would be the company's main source of future earnings. Fluor's non-United States backlog has risen to 40 percent, from 20 percent in 1988.
While cooperating with a foreign rival to win an international job has become standard procedure among American companies, Fluor takes the strategy a step farther. The company created a joint venture with Mexico's largest construction company, ICA Industrial, even with no large deal in sight.
