HEADLINE: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: Man in the News -- Vladimir Volfovich Zhirinovsky;
Muscovite With Bravado

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 13

 BODY:
If his party had not won almost a quarter of the vote in parliamentary elections on Sunday, Vladimir Volfovich Zhirinovsky could well be dismissed as a crude parody of a primitive right-winger, fired by self-pity and primitive nationalism, quick to blame foreigners, intellectuals or unappreciative betters for all his failures, certain of his cause.
His posters show the 47-year-old lawyer wearing a badly knotted tie and a puffy scowl over slogans like, "I'll raise Russia from her knees," or "I'll not allow anyone to offend Russians." 
 His speeches are the stuff of barroom bravado: when he gets Alaska back from the United States, he'll make sure the Americans compensate Russia for the natural resources they used up. Give the Kurile Islands back to Japan? They'll forget about their claim to the land when he sends Russian warships cruising off Hokkaido.
By the time the Central Asians finish cutting each other's throats, they'll beg to become part of Russia. But if he does deem to accept them, it'll be as a volost or uezd -- the smallest administrative units of the old Russian Empire.
 
The Last Great Crusade
 He dreams of Russian soldiers massing for the last great crusade -- "The Last Play for the South" as he calls his autobiography published this year -- a vast drive to Russia's predestined borders on the Indian Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea.
To counter whispers that Mr. Zhirinovsky is homosexual, a party broadsheet in his office carries a series of five snapshots of him ogling a buxom woman's decolletage over dinner under the headline, "They say Vladimir Zhirinovsky is indifferent to women. Is that so?" Mr. Zhirinovksy is married and has a son.
His autobiography reads like a parody of Dostoyevsky's "Insulted and Injured": he remembers every childhood slight, the names of boys who beat him. He describes an unrelentingly miserable childhood in a communal apartment; he seems to revel in describing humiliations.
"I was denied the most elementary family coziness, human warmth," he wrote. "Life itself forced me to suffer from the very day, the moment, the instant of my birth. Society could give me nothing.
"Two months before her death, my mother would tell me, 'Volodya, there's nothing to remember, not one happy day.' "
Born in Kazakhstan on April 26, 1946, and educated in Moscow, Mr. Zhirinovsky spends ardent pages in his book seeking to prove that he is a Russian. "Vladimir" is a Russian name, he reminds the reader, his town and building were peopled by Russians, all his relatives -- except for the husbands of two distant aunts -- are Russians. The only problem is the name of the father who died shortly after he was born, Volf. The name, Mr. Zhirinovsky acknowledges, is "not so familiar to a Russian ear."
It is from such defensive nationalism and remembered slights that Mr. Zhirinovsky shaped the world view that met with so powerful a response from a confused, humiliated and impoverished nation.
It was a woefully familiar pattern in the 20th century, and shouts of "fascist!" quickly sounded from the ranks of democrats.
"Fascism and Communism are not synonymous," warned Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, whose powerfully promoted Russia's Choice Party failed to garner as many votes as Mr. Zhirinovsky's Liberal Democratic Party.
"Fascism is what comes after disappointment in Communism. This historic risk cannot be underrated."
It is too early to judge whether Mr. Zhirinovsky qualifies as a fascist, but his party is neither liberal nor democratic. It was formed in 1990, but before long it became purely a platform for Mr. Zhirinovsky and his menu of quick solutions, nationalist bluster and alluring promises.
One paper called it "autocratic populism." He was the little man bashing the big guys. He played to deep-seated resentments of the Communists who had enslaved Russians, of the "democrats" who had impoverished them, of the Americans who were exploiting them.
He promised protection for the poor, security for the rich, honor and dignity for the military, bread for the hungry, a peaceful life for the old and holidays in Cuba for all.
He vowed to make Russia great, feared and respected again. His symbol was a falcon over a Russia that extended from Alaska to Finland. He would reconstitute a Russia stretched to its imperial borders. He would stop closing down military industries and would resume exporting arms to old clients like Iraq.
In fact, while President Boris N. Yeltsin was acquiescing in the American-led sanctions against Iraq, Mr. Zhirinovsky traveled there and met with President Saddam Hussein.
"I am a moderate in all things," he declared in his book. "Only on the question of statehood am I firm."
It was the stuff Russians increasingly wanted to hear as their world fell apart. The first sign of Mr. Zhirinovsky's appeal came in Russia's presidential race in 1991, when he came in third.
The confusion and dislocation of Mr. Gaidar's economic reforms turned out to be a gold mine. Mr. Zhirinovsky lay low when Mr. Yeltsin disbanded the old Congress of People's Deputies, but when the campaign for a new Parliament began, he emerged with an ample war chest and probably the best understanding of the potency of television.
His rapid-fire delivery and unambiguous pledges drew more attention than the academic and stilted speeches of his opponents, and his ratings soon began to rise.
Mr. Zhirinovsky's sound bites were crisp, his delivery was entertaining: He wouldn't need war to bring former republics back under Russia, he declared. "If we cease assistance, those countries would not last for a month. Why should we create sufferings for ourselves? Let's create sufferings for others."
He wrote: "The flow of refugees is easy to stop. It's enough to threaten those regions from where Russians are driven out that we shall treat their ethnic kin living in Russia in the same way."
 
Backed the Constitution
 He was all for Mr. Yeltsin's draft constitution and the extensive powers it gave the President. "If I could, I would have increased his powers even more," Mr. Zhirinovsky said.
At his party headquarters, on the fourth floor of a dilapidated Moscow tenement, there were all kinds: bearded nationalists, clean-cut youths, dark-suited apparatchiks. Aleksandr Zivkov, a party official, said financial backers of the party were "new businessmen of a patriotic orientation."
No demographic study has yet been published that maps out his followers. But interviews and samplings showed strong support among soldiers and sailors, among disaffected youths, pensioners, workers in military industry -- among those, who, like the young Zhirinovsky, felt rejected, abused, humiliated and impotent as their country tumbled from great power to economic cripple.
"How do I see Russia?" Mr. Zhirinovsky wrote in his book. "I do not see Russia weeping. I see Russia proud, Russia in which the proud traditions of her army will be again realized, where again talented Russian engineers and businessmen will create the latest technology."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, whose ultranationalist party led the Russian voting, preparing for a news conference as an aide adjusted his tie. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: With Time Waning, Europeans Reject U.S. Movie Compromise

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The European Community today rejected an offer by the United States aimed at securing better treatment for American movies in Europe, virtually insuring that the final content of a world trade accord, likely in some form by the deadline Wednesday, will remain in doubt until the last minute.
After a report here today from the community's chief negotiator, Sir Leon Brittan, foreign ministers of the 12 members sent Sir Leon back to Geneva for renewed talks with Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. The European foreign ministers plan to meet again in Brussels on Wednesday, to make a final decision on the seven-year negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. 
 "The conditions for a definitive agreement have not yet been secured," Foreign Minister Alain Juppe of France said. "Important difficulties, particularly on the cinema issue, but also on shipping, textiles, financial services and aircraft subsidies, remain."
A GATT accord, bolstering international trade by extending its rules and lowering tariffs an average 30 percent on manufactured goods, is widely regarded by economists, diplomats and government leaders as crucial in a world tempted to create regional trading blocs, disoriented by old antagonisms and new alignments with the cold war's end, and afflicted by recession in many industrial nations.
One possibility being discussed here in Brussels and in Geneva would be to leave out of the agreement the contentious issue of a French reduction or elimination of taxes and quotas on American-made movies, television programs and music recordings. But it was by no means clear that the United States would accept such an outcome.
American officials have made clear that the movie issue is a potential deal breaker because it affects an important export industry with strong prospects for growth. But Sir Leon said, "I do not believe the Americans would prevent a Uruguay Round agreement on the audio-visual issue." The trade talks began in the Uruguayan resort of Punta del Este in 1986.
[In Tokyo early Tuesday, Japan took another step toward world trade cohesiveness. The Socialist Party, the largest member of the shaky governing coalition, dropped its resistance to opening the rice market to imports. Page A6.]
The difficulties, while real and substantial, appeared relatively manageable when weighed against what has already been accomplished, and the continuing political will in Washington, London, Paris, Bonn and Tokyo to keep pushing for an agreement -- even one that is less than complete -- by Wednesday's deadline.
"I believe we will have an agreement within the set time frame," Sir Leon said.
Peter Sutherland, chief of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in Geneva, where the negotiators are pressing for a conclusion, announced, "We have made startling progress."
And the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said: "In the end, the overall picture of what has been achieved should prevail. It would be bizarre if the Uruguay Round failed now because of film tickets and cassettes."
After Wednesday, President Clinton loses the special negotiating authority that allows him to submit an agreement to Congress for approval without amendment. He could seek renewal of that authority, but such a tactic would create the need for two GATT votes, a politically ticklish situation after the bruising battle for approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
 
In Europeans' Interest, Too
 Sir Leon, in his report to the European ministers, acknowledged this political imperative. Pointing to the tremendous potential benefits for the European economy from tariff reductions and trade freedoms that have already been agreed to, he said, "The interest of the European Community is now to accept the agreements of the Uruguay Round."
But, in his most significant reservation, Sir Leon said that the movies, recorded music and other forms of entertainment should be excluded from an accord "if the community's position is not acceptable in all its aspects to its trading partners."
This underlined that the main obstacle to an agreement still lies in the dispute over how much protection the United States is prepared to allow Europe in the highly sensitive and fast-growing movie and entertainment industries.
The issue is politically explosive on both sides of the Atlantic because films and programs are the United States' second-biggest export industry, after aircraft and aerospace, and President Clinton has an important political base in California, home to a movie industry whose exports to Europe alone were worth $3.6 billion last year. In France, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur and others have turned what is termed the defense of the nation's culture into something approaching a crusade.
Moreover, in the politics of the European Community, Sir Leon is known to have ambitions to succeed Jacques Delors as president of the European Commission, the community's year-round administrative arm, when Mr. Delors steps down at the end of this year. Thus, it is vital for Sir Leon, an Englishman, to be seen as defending French interests to the last in this contretemps.
 
Notion of One European Culture
 "What we are prepared to do on the audio-visual question is balanced and reasonable," Sir Leon said before departing for Geneva. "The United States already has 80 percent of the European movie market, and that market is growing. This is not an American industry fighting for survival. The European Community wants to have the capacity to support its own culture, and that seems to me to be reasonable."
Community officials said Mr. Kantor had made a number of compromise proposals on the issue, which centers on the United States' objections to European quotas that limit American movies on television as well as to French taxes collected on box-office receipts, of which nearly 60 percent are for American films, and cassette sales. The money raised -- about $350 million last year -- is used to subsidize the French film industry.
 
Splitting the Difference
 The American compromise offer included a request that the quotas -- limiting American programs to less than half of television broadcasts in Europe -- not apply during prime time. Mr. Kantor also suggested that when cable services increased the number of channels available in Europe, only half of them be subject to the quotas, the official said.
Another American proposal was that when new technology gives viewers access to "video on demand" -- the ability to call up a vast range of videos to the television screen rather than going to a store to rent them -- the European quota system should not apply.
These approaches were all rejected by the community ministers, and a German spokesman, Werner Wendt, said the most likely area for compromise appeared to be on France's 11 percent box-office tax. The United States has asked that some of that go to American film makers. "We feel confident there will be a compromise on this royalties question, perhaps on the basis that the money the Americans received would be reinvested in Europe," Mr. Wendt said.

HEADLINE: Study Finds Rising Concentration Of Black and Hispanic Students

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Despite three decades of costly and difficult efforts to integrate public schools, the number of black and Hispanic students in schools with predominantly minority enrollments is rising, a Harvard University study has found.
The study, released yesterday by the Harvard Project on School Desegregation, attributed the rise to higher birth rates and immigration rather than white flight to the suburbs. It also said poverty and housing patterns had concentrated black and Hispanic students in large cities. 
 The report defined predominantly minority schools as those with more than 50 percent of their enrollment made up of either black or Hispanic students, or both, but it did not specify the composition of those schools, which increasingly have mixed enrollments of black and Hispanic students, who can be of any race.
 
Highest Levels Since '68
 The report said that 66 percent of black students, or 4.6 million of the 6.9 million black students in the nation's public schools, attended the predominantly minority schools in the 1991-92 school year, the highest level since the 76 percent reported by the Federal Government in 1968.
It also found that 74.3 percent of Hispanic students, or 3.7 million of the total 5 million students, attended such schools, also the highest percentage in 25 years. Asians were not included in the report.
The report, conducted for the National School Boards Association, found that schools in the Northeast were the most racially separate of any region and that while the South remained the most integrated region, some of the efforts to integrate had slowed and were even being reversed by the same economic and population factors affecting the rest of the country.
"This report reflects what may be the beginning of a historic reversal," said Gary Orfield, a Harvard professor of education who has specialized in school desegregation. "The civil rights impulse from the 1960's is dead in the water and the ship is floating backward toward the shoals of racial segregation."
While educators and civil rights groups said yesterday that integrated classrooms were the ideal, they pointed to the quality of education as far more important than a classroom's racial mix -- that separate but equal education is possible, in spite of the Brown v. Board of Education case in which the Supreme Court ruled that a separate education is inherently unequal.
"At the present time, we are more concerned with the quality of education and this has to take precedence over whether schools are integrated," said Dr. Beverly P. Cole, director of education and housing for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. "Having said that," she added, "we still support desegregation efforts and busing is a means to that end."
 
Little Surprise
 The study's findings did not surprise civil rights or desegregation experts, who said that they had seen through their casework mounting anecdotal evidence that black and Hispanic students were being clustered in some public schools. And demographic studies have predicted that within 30 years, half the nation's public schools will be predominantly black and Hispanic. But the groups emphasized that what was more crucial was well-financed schools with strong curriculums and well-trained teachers for all children.
In the 1991-92 school year, the period covered by the study, there were 42 million students enrolled in kindergarten through 12th grade. Of those, 16.4 percent, or 6.9 million students, were black, and 11.8 percent, or 5 million students, were Hispanic. White students accounted for 67.4 percent, or 28.3 million, of enrollment, while Asians represented 3.4 percent, or 1.4 million. American Indian or Alaska native accounted for 420,000, or 1 percent.
The study found that after decades of progress, schools in the South had rising concentrations of black students and those in the West had rising concentrations of Hispanic students.
The nation's largest cities have the highest concentrations of black and Hispanic students, and in large inner cities, "15 of every 16 African-American and Latino students are in schools where most of the students are nonwhite." In medium-size cities, the report said, "63 percent of African-American and 70 percent of Latinos attend such schools."
 
Poverty and Education
 Making the link between poverty and minority concentration in schools, the report said that black and Hispanic students were much more likely than white students to find themselves in schools where achievement is lower. The educational system, the report said, thus perpetuates "the educational inequality of minority students." It said that these deficiencies could not be sufficiently overcome by the Chapter 1 program, the $6.1-billion-a-year Federal program that helps students reach grade level in reading and math.
In New York, Washington and Los Angeles, the study said that civil leaders often assume racial and ethnic separation is worse in the South. But both black and Hispanic students face the most intense separation in Northeastern states, the study said.
The study also found that the clustering of black and Hispanic students in some schools is not exclusively urban. The suburbs of the nation's largest cities "two-thirds of the Latinos and three-fifths of the blacks were in predominantly minority schools."
The NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund, the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund and the American Civil Liberties Union increasingly have filed lawsuits against school districts and states, using integration as a lever to raise the issue of disparities in wealth between rich, typically white, districts and poor, usually minority school systems. There are now 28 states involved in litigation over their method of financing public schools, and several state courts already have deemed that state finance formulas have helped create separate and unequal schools.
 
Remedies Suggested
 Noting that it took years to address the issue of integration in Federal courts, the report recommended some solutions that bypass courts altogether. It recommended the resumption of a Nixon Administration program killed by the Reagan Administration, the Emergency School Aid Act of 1972, which allocated $1 billion in its peak years to help ease the tension of integration by training teachers in integrated schools. It also supported early experiments in magnet schools, which use specialized curriculums to lure a mix of students crossing racial lines and neighborhoods.
Although busing remains the most widely used remedy for integrating schools, the study recommended a broader remedy, including greater enforcement efforts by the Justice Department and the Education Department's Office of Civil Rights.
It also calls for "restoration of Federal aid for successful integration strategies and for basic research on the consequences of segregation by race, ethnicity and poverty."
The report also recommended efforts to find ways to eliminate housing patterns that had led to segregated schools. The Palm Beach County Public Schools in Florida, for instance, reward developers by building schools near their housing developments if the developer successfully sells his homes to a diverse group of buyers.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

International
The European Community rejected a U.S. offer aimed at securing better treatment for American movies in Europe, virtually insuring that the final content of a world trade accord will remain in doubt until shortly before the deadline. [Page A1.] Germany is playing a subtle yet powerful role as an intermediary in crucial disputes involving France and the United States. [D7.]
Japan's Socialist Party dropped its resistance to opening the country's rice market to imports, pushing global trade talks closer to a successful conclusion and preserving the fragile coalition Government of Prime Minister Hosokawa. [A6.]
Britain's coal-mining industry has shrunk by half in only the last year, along with a falling demand for coal. These most recent mine closings and layoffs have had a profound effect on thousands of people, for whom the mines and mining have been a way of life for generations. [A4.]
 
 Companies
Shawmut National will pay at least $960,000 to black and Hispanic customers who were denied loans, and it promised to end discriminatory lending practices in a settlement of a Justice Department case. The settlement could clear the way for Shawmut to continue its buying binge in New England. [D1.]
Loral will buy I.B.M.'s Federal Systems military software unit for $1.58 billion, effectively taking I.B.M. out of the weapons business. Loral is growing by specializing in modernizing older equipment while many military contractors are shrinking. [D1.]
The board of Paramount Communications decided not to set up an independent panel to evaluate rival bids from QVC Network and Viacom, an executive close to the Paramount board said. [D1.]
Banks are looking for mutual fund companies to buy in the wake of Mellon's purchase of Dreyfus, but few are for sale and prices are high for those that are available. [D1.]
Southwest Airlines will buy Morris Air, a carrier roughly an eighth its size, in a $129 million stock swap. Analysts see a good fit because Morris Air, based in Salt Lake City, uses Southwest's strategy of no-frills service and low fares. [D2.]
V. F. pushed further into the licensed sports apparel business by agreeing to buy Nutmeg for $325.5 million in cash. [D5.]
General Motors will invest $25 million to assemble 10,000 Opel Astra cars at the plant of a Polish state-owned auto maker. [D5.]
Computer and telecommunications companies plan to work on standardizing how computers can talk to each other. [D5.]
National Medical will pay $89.9 million to 13 insurers to resolve the last disputes over billing at its hospitals. [D5.]
Phoenix Home Life sold $500 million of commercial mortgage loans, partly because of new capital rules going into effect. [D5.]
 
 The Economy
The Supreme Court ruled that Federal rather than state law governs an insurance company's handling of certain pension fund assets. The decision could change the way the insurance industry keeps track of billions of dollars in pension funds. [D2.]
 
 Markets
Stocks were mixed with blue-chip issues posting modest gains and the broader market slipping in subdued trading. The Dow industrials set another high, rising 23.76 points, to 3,764.43. [D8.]
Treasury prices fell and yields rose ahead of important fourth-quarter economic data and a Treasury auction. [D16.]
Oil prices fell to a five-year low and gasoline to a seven-year low on signs of weak demand. [D18.] The dollar rose. [D18.]

HEADLINE: THE RUSSIAN VOTE;
On the Russian Vote, Clinton Accentuates the Positive

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRYN MAWR, Pa. Dec. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton today welcomed the outcome of Russia's first parliamentary elections, saying that despite the strong showing by nationalist parties, the new Constitution and Parliament had swept away the last remnants of the Soviet system and had laid a foundation for democracy.
In a brief chat with reporters after an economic conference at Bryn Mawr College, Mr. Clinton sought to put the best face on the Russian vote. While noting that not all the ballots had been tallied, Mr. Clinton did say that the strong showing of the fervently nationalist Liberal Democratic Party in the early returns should serve as a reminder to the West about how difficult the transition to democracy was for Russian working people. 
 The election results should also prompt a little more sensitivity on toward the treacherous territory President Boris N. Yeltsin has to navigate, he said.
"It will be quite some time before you have a real feel for what's going to happen," Mr. Clinton said. "But I do think that this vote sends a signal about how difficult it is to convert from that old Communist system to a market economy at a time of global recession, when the ability of any other nation or group of nations to give a big infusion of capital to provide temporary security is not there."
The President, fresh from the conference about the economic troubles of the American middle class, drew a parallel to its Russian counterpart.
"Keep in mind that all of these changes, these economic and political changes, are playing out in the former Soviet Union and in Eastern Europe at a time of global recession when there is deep frustration and alienation among middle-class voters in the wealthiest countries," he said. "So this should not be too surprising.
"I think what it means is that we have to think through our approach to these nations, and to remember that there has to be a lot of sensitivity to the ability of ordinary working people to navigate their way through all these tough changes and at least be able to imagine how they are going to come out on top in the end.
"I think that there will be a little more sensitivity to that -- hopefully not just in the United States and Europe and Japan, but also in the international organizations themselves."
 
The Good News
 But throughout his comments Mr. Clinton tried to stress the positive. As a formal White House statement noted: "By approving a new Constitution and voting for a new legislature, the Russian people have eliminated the last vestiges of the old Soviet system and replaced them with new and legitimate institutions that will lay a foundation for continued development of a democratic society. The United States and the international community have a major interest in seeing this process succeed."
Senior Administration officials said that they were taken by surprise by the proportion of support for the ultranationalists, Communists and other anti-reform elements. Nevertheless, they insisted that it was still both politically and mathematically possible that the various reform parties could combine to form a working majority in the Parliament.
"I do think," Mr. Clinton said, "that it will be possible for a majority of people who favor democracy and don't favor a dramatic change in foreign policy for Russia to put together a coalition in the Parliament who can work with the President and go forward."
 
A Glimpse of Stability
 The best news of the elections, American officials said, was the passage of the Constitution, which, they hope, will bring some structure and solidity to the Russian political system and provide some stability in the relations between the legislative and executive branches, an aspect that has been absent for the last year and a half.
"President Yeltsin has stated his readiness to begin a constructive dialogue with the varied political forces that will be represented in it," the White House statement said. "We hope that this sentiment will be reciprocated by all responsible political figures in Russia."

HEADLINE: Mexico's Unions, Frail Now, Face Trade Pact Blows

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Less than a week after the United States Congress passed the North American Free Trade Agreement, with all its promises of a better future for workers on both sides of the border, three Mexicans working at a General Electric motor factory in Ciudad Juarez, across from El Paso, Tex., were abruptly dismissed.
A General Electric spokesman says the company is investigating what happened. But the men say they were dismissed for trying to organize a union not tied to the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. Bitterly, they say this is the real proof of what free trade will bring. 
 With the trade agreement set to take effect on Jan. 1, the expectations of Mexican workers have soared, and so have their fears because the unions they have relied on for job security and higher wages are weaker than they have been for half a century.
 
In a Poor Position
 Mexican and American officials say that organized labor in Mexico is poorly positioned to help ease the predicted short-term dislocation as many Mexican businesses wither under increased competition or get tougher on workers to increase productivity. Mainstream unions are too tied to the Government, while the small independent unions are too easily crushed.
"What you'll see is a very far-reaching set of changes in Mexico that the unions either are going to have to accept or be run over, given the Mexican Government's policies," said Harley Shaiken, a labor economist at the University of California at Berkeley.
The added pressure of the trade agreement could increase divisions between organized labor and the Institutional Revolutionary Party, hastening what appears to be a fundamental shift in Mexican politics. At the least, the pact appears likely to increase tensions in a labor movement ready for some type of change. Fidel Velazquez, the head of the official Confederation of Mexican Workers, is 93 years old and has been in charge since the 1930's.
Many workers feel left out of the country's economic revitalization and unprotected by their unions. And unlike unions in the United States, the mainstream unions supported the free trade accord.
 
Workers Express Bitterness
 The arrangement has led to some bitterness among workers.
"The American unions are acting as unions should -- protecting jobs in their country," said Ernesto Lucero, a 39-year-old unemployed sugar worker who camped for two weeks in Mexico City's central plaza last month along with about 200 other members of the sugar workers' union to demand help. "But here, Government and unions support each other in a nice little arrangement that has nothing to do with the working man."
Most Mexican unions have strong ties to the Institutional Revolutionary Party and members of the Confederation of Mexican Workers hold more than a dozen legislative seats and the governorships of three states.
For decades, the labor confederation has faithfully delivered five million votes to the Institutional Revolutionary Party, and the confederation has pledged to do so again for Luis Donaldo Colosio Murrieta, the party's candidate in the 1994 presidential race. But more and more the Government is using its close relationship with the unions to weaken their power.
In many cases the unions have been forced by the Government to negotiate on contracts plant by plant, rather than nationwide, and they are now being asked to bear with low wages while the economy grows, although the average wage in Mexico still has not recovered the buying power it had in the early 1980's.
Tensions between the Government and organized labor increased just a few weeks after Carlos Salinas de Gortari became President in 1988, when he took on the leader of the powerful petroleum workers union, Joaquin Hernandez Galicia. Mr. Hernandez was arrested and charged with financial impropriety, illegal possession of arms and involvement in the death of a Mexican federal agent. In July, he was sentenced to 35 years in prison.
 
Tough Line for Unions
 Mr. Salinas then hobbled the Mexican public schoolteachers' union by making education a responsibility of the states instead of the federal Government. This limited the union's power by forcing it to negotiate 31 separate contracts instead of one.
With its ambitious program to sell state-owned businesses, the Salinas Administration lopped off 400,000 jobs, many of them union jobs, and said it was for the good of the nation. In 1992, the Government backed Volkswagen de Mexico when it dismissed all 14,000 plant workers and rehired only those who renounced dissident union leaders.
"The future is black for all those unions not willing to subject themselves to the authorities or to the executive power in the nation," said Antonio Velazquez Loza, general coordinator of the Authentic Labor Front, one of Mexico's few independent labor organizations. It represents about 70,000 people in 18 states and led the modest opposition to the free-trade agreement in Mexico. It was the Labor Front that tried to organize workers at the G.E. plant in Ciudad Juarez last month.
In testimony before the United States Congress this year, Pharis J. Harvey, executive director of the International Labor Rights Education and Research Fund, described organized labor in Mexico as "sterile unions without power to represent workers." One major result of the Government-union collusion, he said, was a deterioration of health and safety standards that left Mexico with the third highest rate of industrial accidents in the world.
 
Future of Trade Unionism
 Mr. Salinas has made clear that he considers the future of trade unionism in Mexico to be embodied by Francisco Hernandez Juarez, leader of the 48,000-member telephone workers' union. Last year it was the 44-year-old Mr. Hernandez who stood beside Mr. Salinas during the May Day parade.
Mr. Hernandez said in an interview that he fully supported Mr. Salinas's efforts to get the trade agreement approved because Mexico must be prepared to compete in a global economy.
"We were in favor of the treaty," Mr. Hernandez said, "not because of complicity with the Government but because we thought integration with the United States was the only option.
The coming year is an election year in Mexico, a frenzy of politics and power that takes place every six years as the President -- constitutionally prohibited from running for re-election -- picks his successor and then steps aside. As he has for every election year since the 1930's, Mr. Velazquez of the Confederation of Mexican Workers, who is known as Don Fidel, played a role in influencing the selection of the party's candidate, announced last month.
Many critics say this could be the last Mexican transition of this type because of many factors, including the growing cry for democracy and the unraveling of the labor confederation's power. Changes demanded by the free trade agreement simply intensify the revolution begun by the opening of Mexico's economy and the need for Mexican business to become more competitive.
That process quickened in October when Mr. Salinas announced that the Government, which had limited wage increases for all workers, would encourage open-ended raises based on productivity gains. On Friday, the Govermnent announced that minimum wages would increase by 7 percent in 1994, taking productivity into account for the first time.
 
New Competitive Pressures
 This effectively reduces the power of Don Fidel's confederation. Instead of bargaining with the Government on what the maximum wage increase will be for all workers, the organization will be limited to advising union locals as they negotiate contracts individually with plant operators.
The basis of the Mexican unions' support for the free trade agreement has been the belief that it would create jobs in Mexico. The unspoken thesis was that many of those jobs would come at the expense of workers in the United States as companies were drawn by Mexico's low wages.
That history could feed the tension existing between the unions of both sides of the border long after the agreement goes into effect on Jan. 1. Still, Don Fidel said in a recent interview that he would be happy to talk with the United States unions.
"The discrepancies that we've had," he said, "will not prejudice the friendship that we've maintained for more than half a century."

HEADLINE: Factory Profits Slow

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The profit margins of manufacturers in the United States fell in the third quarter as auto makers lost money, the Commerce Department said today. Seasonally adjusted after-tax profits averaged 3.4 cents a dollar of sales in the third quarter, down from 3.8 cents in the third quarter of 1992.

HEADLINE: After 2 Weeks of Mayhem, The Nation Is Asking Why

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON

 BODY:
After a murderous two weeks that Americans could only wish was a bad made-for-TV movie, a sense of outrage and urgency has spread from small towns to big cities to state capitals and the White House, as the country searches itself for the causes of crime and ways to make people safer.
The fateful first weeks of December have been a period of random, brutal violence in which any one of a number of murders would have been chilling enough by itself. 
 A Brooklyn man opened fire in a crowded commuter train on Long Island, killing six people and wounding 17. An out-of-work computer engineer opened fire in an unemployment office in Oxnard, Calif., killing four before the police killed him. The police found the body of a 12-year-old girl, Polly Klaas, who had been abducted from her bedroom in Petaluma, Calif. The body of another kidnapped child, 9-year-old Cassidy Senter, was found in St. Louis.
 
Countless Murders
 There was a Navy murder-suicide that left three people dead in San Diego, a teen-age sniper who fired at people in the Chicago Loop during lunch hour, and countless killings of people whose names will never make the national news but whose deaths chip away at a weakening sense of safety and order.
"The human race -- what is it coming to?" said Jesus Araiza, a 20-year-old worker at a Chicago securities concern who has started taking martial arts classes. "It's getting to the place where people are not killing even for money, but just killing to be killing."
What is especially troubling, criminologists say, is that in many of these crimes gunfire seems to have become a form of communication and venting.
From interviews with more than 70 people around the country, a portrait has emerged of a country where many citizens lead a frightened, paranoid existence, where every stranger is suspect, where people think twice before venturing out at night and avoid some neighborhoods altogether.
Bess Stone, a 60-year-old Boston office worker, walks to and from the Park Street train station to get to work downtown. "Every day I go a different way to confuse people" in case someone is trying to follow her, she said.
 
Caution and Vigilance
 To be sure, many people do not let fear keep them from eating out, seeing a movie downtown or riding public transportation. But they know, as one minister in Manhattan said, not to "walk in Times Square in the middle of the night after the theater crowd goes home."
Even the bravest souls say they have become more vigilant. They operate in a battle-ready mode that seems normal to big-city people, until they travel to Tokyo or Stockholm or Toronto or think back 20 years, to life before hand-held sirens.
Many of those interviewed talked wistfully of times when people could leave their doors unlocked and children could play outside on summer evenings without a care, and the only gunfire people heard was in a Western.
"I never used to worry about gangs or violence," said Jeff Carr, a 26-year-old mechanical engineer in Little Rock, Ark. "Now I'm aware of it all the time. When I get out of my car at work or home, I do a full 360-degree turn to see if there's any danger."
His boss recently offered to let him use his gun after burglars broke into his house for the third time. Mr. Carr decided against it. But he and his wife now sleep with their bedroom door locked and keep a bat by the bed.
 
A Pervasive Fear
 Whenever Susan Shepherd, a 37-year-old flight attendant from Salt Lake City, checks into a hotel, she props the door open with her luggage while she looks under the bed, in the closets and in the bathroom to make sure she's alone. She resents the precautions she feels she must take. "I remember growing up playing in the neighborhood at night and sleeping out in the backyard," she said. "I don't think you can do that anymore."
Pearl Jackson, a 40-year-old domestic worker in Chicago, gets home from work at 4 P.M. and does not leave her house until the next day. She believes the streets are too dangerous. "You live in fear constantly, every day," Mrs. Jackson said. "You are not safe nowhere. People are getting crazier and crazier. It's out of control. The whole world is going mad."
The public alarm is actually at odds with statistics that show that the rate of violent crime has fallen slightly in the last two years. Still, the numbers are far higher than in the 1960's and 70's, and it is the spectacular, arbitrary killings that frighten most.
 
Violence as Problem-Solving
 "Violence has become the preferred method of problem-solving," said Robert Trojanowicz, director of the National Center for Community Policing and professor of criminal justice and urban affairs at Michigan State University. "We all now realize that there is a problem, and we are all vulnerable."
In the search for a cause, citizens and experts blame guns, crack, gangs, poor public schools, unemployment, television cartoons where the characters always get up after they have fallen off a cliff, politicians, movies with names like "Die Hard" and "The Terminator," rap videos, parents too busy working to tend to their children, fathers who desert their families, and a general moral decay.
By any measure, guns are a major factor. There are nearly as many guns in the country as people. In 1992, when the population was 255 million, there were 211 million guns in the United States, under mattresses, in gun shops and police departments, in the hands of teen-agers and grandmothers. That is 10 million more than at the start of 1990 and more than twice as many as in 1970, when there were 104 million guns, according to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. In 1950, the United States had 54 million guns.
 
Brady Bill Not Enough
 After last week, some people said the Brady bill, which took years of cajoling and lobbying to get through Congress, is not enough. Colin Ferguson, the suspect in the Long Island Rail Road shootings, was apparently willing to wait 15 days -- three times as long as the Brady bill will require -- to get his 9-millimeter Ruger in California.
In fact, gun dealers have reported a run on semiautomatic weapons -- and bullets by the case -- by people trying to beat both the Brady bill's effective date of Feb. 28 and the further curbs on assault weapons that Congress is expected to enact.
What frightens many people is that in a culture where "Mortal Kombat" is a children's video game and some states seem to have more gun shops than gas stations unstable people can easily be pushed over the edge.
"As the climate of lawlessness rises," said Richard Herrnstein, a professor of psychology at Harvard University and co-author of the book "Crime and Human Nature" (Simon & Schuster, 1985), "people who in another setting might be the crazy guy down the street who mutters angrily to himself now not only mutters to himself but goes out and gets a gun and kills people."
 
Sentiment for Banning Guns
 Many people interviewed said they were in favor of an outright ban on guns. They said the right to bear arms did not mean the right to bear Uzis. "The framers of the Constitution would be appalled if they thought we were having a discussion over the right to own an AK-47," Professor Trojanowicz said. "Our technology has outdistanced our logic."
Still, there seems to be a hardening among some people who feel there are too many guns out there to turn back. They say they will do what it takes to protect their families. In a kill-or-be-killed world, even quiet, law-abiding citizens can turn bellicose.
Marty Price, a 49-year-old Oakland school teacher, has gone to the funerals of five of his son's friends, boys he had reckoned would some day be his pallbearers. When he rides the bus he always sits by the window so he can kick it out if he has to escape. He has bars on his windows at home and owns a shotgun for protection.
"If someone tried to come in here, I wouldn't hesitate," Mr. Price said. "I know that drugs take the reason out of people. They don't want to hurt you, but they don't know better. I would rather face a jury than some of these people."
 
Calls for Change
 Some criminologists are calling for changes in the criminal justice system to insure that people arrested with illegal guns serve time in jail, to make prison more like boot camp and to give recent ex-convicts options like jobs or job-training rather than just returning them to crime.
Increasingly, people are linking crime to larger social problems and looking at solutions outside the criminal justice system. "Spend more money on education," said Robert Carney, a 31-year-old corporate lawyer in Boston. "Spend more money on creating opportunities for people." Especially, he said, poor people in brutal environments, "where living breeds a desire for escape in drugs, in violence."
In interviews, many people said the country could find the money if it wanted to. "When we had the floods, we found the money," Professor Trojanowicz said. "If there's a problem overseas, we come up with the billions. Let's pretend we've got an imaginary flood and put two dollars toward prevention for every dollar of reaction."
He suggested one way to raise money would be to have income tax forms include a checkoff box, similar to the one for public financing of Presidential campaigns, to finance programs for children.
 
Taking Action Now
 Some people and local governments are already seeking their own solutions. Several music radio stations have banned or edited violent or racially derogatory lyrics.
Dallas announced a tough new anti-gang policy last week after a spate of gang murders. The police will saturate gang territory, ticket people under the age of 16 if they are on the streets after midnight and put them in jail for 30 days if they are caught with a weapon.
Some Seattle women fed up with crime started a new group called Mothers Against Violence Everywhere, aimed at educating the public and stemming crime against children. The group had its first meeting last week.
One organizer, Pamela Eakes, said, "We want to say enough is enough."

HEADLINE: Clinton Says He's Wary Of Cutting Entitlements

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Dec. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton came to this predominantly Republican suburb today to warn that if there were more cuts in Federal benefit programs the middle class would be squeezed. He said the best way to cut the deficit and to slow the rise in benefits spending would be to pass his plan to control health care costs.
Mr. Clinton spoke at a daylong conference on cutting the Federal deficit by curbing automatic benefit programs like Medicare and Social Security. His attendance was part of an unusual political payback he negotiated with a freshman Democrat in Congress, Representative Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky, to win her vote for the Clinton budget last August. 
 In return for casting the decisive vote, Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky did not ask for a bridge but rather Mr. Clinton's participation in the conference about cutting entitlement programs, a move that she and many people in her conservative district favor.
Mr. Clinton agreed to attend only after Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky retreated from some of her plans to turn the conference into something of a pork-barrel of its own, by offering corporations a seat on Mr. Clinton's discussion panel in return for contributions to support today's session.
 
Lecture on Need for Programs
 If Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky was hoping that the President would endorse her drive for further cuts in mandatory benefit programs like Social Security, Medicare or Medicaid, she had to have been disappointed by Mr. Clinton's remarks.
Throughout his opening remarks and subsequent comments during a panel discussion, the President stressed that such benefits serve large numbers of people, particularly the middle class. His bifocals perched on the end of his nose like those of a college don, Mr. Clinton quietly lectured the audience in this affluent Philadelphia suburb, saying that while they might think of entitlements as something for the poor, that was simply not the reality.
"Most people are surprised to know that the welfare budget is about 2 percent of the entitlements, or about 1 percent of the overall Federal budget," he told the audience of students, local residents and invited corporate guests gathered in the Bryn Mawr College auditorium.
The biggest entitlement programs are Social Security, Medicare, and Federal and military retirement payments, which make up two-thirds of the entitlement budget.
"I think it's important to point out that behind every one of these entitlements, there is a person," Mr. Clinton said. "It's not just organized interest groups; there are people who believe they are literally entitled to receive something back that they paid into.
"It is the middle-class entitlements that have united us and brought us together, that also have the strongest constituencies. These programs are very important in human terms. Thirty-four million people go to see a doctor, or get medical care, because of the Medicare program. Social Security has changed what it means to be old."
 
'Not a Welfare Program'
 Americans, the President continued, "should not view this whole program as welfare."
"It is not a welfare program," he said. "We should be very sensitive about the fact that this is something that has worked. Because of these programs, we are a healthier people. We treat our elderly with greater dignity. This is a huge deal."
Mr. Clinton insisted that those who want to slash these programs were only going to make things worse for the middle class, not only by depriving them of benefits, but also because state governments and local hospitals would simply shift the costs of caring for the poor and elderly onto the people who could pay.
He said the best way to reduce entitlement costs would be to control health care expenses, which are driving up the costs of Medicare and Medicaid. The best way to do that without burdening the middle class, Mr. Clinton said, would be to shift some of the costs now borne by Government to employers, as his health care plan would do, by requiring employers to buy insurance for their workers.
Thus the President, in effect, turned the entitlement-bashing conference into a vehicle for promoting his health care plan.
 
'Hidden Tax Increase'
 "We could bring this deficit down," Mr. Clinton said. "We could just cut Medicare and Medicaid, even though it's an entitlement. We can just take her down. But if we do that, what will happen? Those costs will be shifted by the health care providers to the people who already are providing insurance. That will be a hidden tax increase on businesses and on employees.
"So I say to you, we can talk about these entitlements and we should. As we talk about them, let's not make our middle-class squeeze worse than it already is."
When it comes to addressing the entitlements problem, Mr. Clinton concluded, "I would argue that the real culprit is health care costs, and we can only address it if we have comprehensive health care reform."
That was not the theme of Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky's opening remarks at the conference, when she stressed the importance of more budget cutting. She said she hoped that today's gathering would be remembered as "one brief moment when public service came before the political agenda, and when we faced up to the sad legacy of debt we have left behind for our children."
Several times in his remarks Mr. Clinton referred to Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky, doing his best to give her a boost in her 13th Congressional District.
"Without her vote we would not be here talking about economic progress," he said. "We'd still be in Washington throwing mud balls at each other."

The President's visit was part of an unusual political payback he negotiated with the freshman Democrat, who cast the deciding vote for the Clinton budget in August. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
3 Schools of Thought On Clinton's '3d Way'

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
As a candidate, President Clinton prospered by promising a "third way" for the Democratic Party, an exquisitely calibrated course between left and right.
Welfare would be "a second chance, not a way of life." Government would "expand opportunity, not bureaucracy." A new health care system would "cover everybody, and control costs." 
 An artful blend of traditional values and liberal goals, Mr. Clinton's "third way" helped him straddle deep divisions in his party and reach out to the voters of the middle class as a "new Democrat." But now, on the central issues of health care and welfare, Mr. Clinton is trying to transform that careful rhetoric into actual policies. And while translating campaign promises into programs is always hard, "the third way" is proving particularly treacherous.
The tensions are most apparent on health, where Mr. Clinton has found himself at odds with the very group that incubated his candidacy and the idea of the "new Democrat" -- the Democratic Leadership Council.
Mr. Clinton has proposed a plan that promises a comprehensive benefits package to all Americans (an important nod to the left). But the Administration has also, from the very beginning, ruled out the idea of a Canadian-style system of government-financed health insurance; instead, it embraced the philosophy of managed competition, a blend of market and regulatory forces (an important nod to the right).
Has he found the magical third way? Not for many liberals, who assert that the Administration places far too much confidence in the largely untested theory of managed competition. Not for the conservatives, who worry that the Clinton version of managed competition would result in an excess of bureaucracy and government controls. And not even for the leadership council, whose president, Al From, warned in a recent essay: "The Administration plan has many of the earmarks of a new entitlement program."
In the philosophy of the leadership council this is a bad thing; Government is supposed to be in the business of creating new opportunities, not new entitlements that, it is argued, will inevitably be paid for by a beleaguered middle class. So the council has rallied around a plan proposed by Representative Jim Cooper, a Democrat from Tennessee, that promises to cover the bulk -- but not all -- of the uninsured, and to do so without requiring employers to contribute to the cost of insurance, as the Clinton plan would require. Mr. Cooper calls his plan "Clinton lite."
Meanwhile, those in the White House, including Hillary Rodham Clinton, have made it clear that universal coverage is the sine qua non of any health plan. ("There are 20 other dividing lines they could have chosen," complains Mr. Cooper.)
Politically, universal coverage is the bottom line for the party's powerful liberal wing on Capitol Hill, particularly in the House, where 93 members have signed on to a single-payer bill. It will be hard to finesse these divisions; either health care is a right or it is not. And if it is a right, the government must find some way to pay for it.
The process of overhauling welfare is much less further along, but it too may carry some inherent tensions. During the campaign, Mr. Clinton promised a two-year cutoff for welfare recipients (popular with more conservative Democrats), but pledged that training, child care and other supports would ease the transition to work (popular with liberals). Right now, Administration officials say they can finance these goals by redirecting existing budgets, but many are skeptical.
Jeff Faux, president of the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research group in Washington, asserts that there is a basic contradiction in much of the leadership council's philosophy: "The D.L.C.ers in some way remind me of the classic definition of a liberal Republican -- which is somebody who thinks you can have social justice without paying for it."
The council argues that it is simply trying to protect Mr. Clinton from all the pressures on the left -- to keep him true to the principles that won him the White House.
As for Mr. Clinton, he must occasionally long for the days when the "third way" was so vague -- and, as a result, so appealing.

HEADLINE: Germans Whisper Softly in Trade Rivals' EarsDow at Record as a Few Stocks Jump

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Everybody always knew that in the end it would come to this: the United States and Europe -- France, really -- haggling down to the wire over a global trade agreement, with millions of jobs and billions of dollars worth of potential business hanging in the balance.
Everyone knew that failure to reach an accord would be a disaster -- for the recession-ridden European Community, for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, for trans-Atlantic economic and strategic relations. 
 And everyone knew that if he had to, the leader of Europe's largest trading nation and the United States' strongest European ally, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, would put pressure on his French friend, President Francois Mitterrand, and get him to see the light.
In fact, the German influence has been subtle yet powerful, according to diplomats and other officials close to the talks. "The Germans have been indispensable to the process," one said tonight, with 29 hours left to go in the seven-year-long negotiations. "My guess is that when it's over, we'll find out that they've been as intensively in touch with the French as they were with the Americans."
 
Won't Take Sides Between Allies
 The Germans made it clear to the United States that in talks officially being conducted by European Community negotiators they could not be asked to choose between their relationship with the French and their relationship with the Americans, officials here insist. Nor did the Clinton Administration ask the Germans to pass tough messages to Paris.
But messages were passed nonetheless, officials say. For weeks, the Germans told the Americans that the French needed sweeteners to make a deal. And Mr. Kohl went to Paris last month to tell the French Parliament that an accord was vital, a plea that the American negotiator, Mickey Kantor, hailed as a poignant appeal.
"Kohl and Mitterrand have never exchanged a harsh word in all the years of the trade negotiations," a knowledgeable German official said during the meeting of European Community leaders that ended in Brussels on Saturday, just after the French and German chiefs had breakfast together. "They understand each other too well for that."
Mr. Kohl said Saturday that Germany, as one of the world's biggest exporters, had a vital interest in a successful conclusion to the trade talks, but he added, "All sides are playing high-stakes poker."
French officials point out that Mr. Mitterrand, too, has repeatedly spoken out in support of a world trade agreement, though he wants -- and got his European partners to support -- a new world trade organization to make it harder for countries like the United States to impose tariffs and quotas when they believe that other nations have broken the rules.
"Harmony prevails in the relationship between the United States and France -- except on the occasions when it does not," the French President said inimitably over the weekend. Chancellor Kohl's view, according to American and German officials who know him well, is that it is best not to get into the middle of a French-American dogfight over trade, agriculture or anything else.
 
Farmers Without Borders
 Besides, all Europeans have a certain sympathy for the French defense of European farmers' interests, and of the highly subsidized European aviation industry, against their stronger American competitors.
"The European aircraft industry must not be sacrificed as a pawn," Wolfgang Piller, president of the Federation of German Aviation, Space and Defense Industries, said today, "while the Americans are allowed to continue to provide unlimited support for their aerospace industry through indirect subisidies." The Europeans view military contracts from the Pentagon to American manufacturers as a form of subsidy.
Mr. Kohl and Mr. Mitterrand went their separate ways to let the negotiators in Geneva make the final push for a trade pact. On Sunday, as pressure mounted, President Clinton spoke by phone with both the Chancellor and Prime Minister Edouard Balladur of France.
There's a bit of high-stakes poker to the German tactic of affecting nonchalance. Where would the Germans be if the push for an accord failed?
The answer is that they believe it won't fail, because Mr. Kohl has made clear that Germany places so much importance on a successful conclusion to the trade talks that France could hardly affront the Germans by permitting them to fail.
Besides, Mr. Kohl knows that if he pushes the French or any other European country too hard to accept an accord that hurts it financially, that country will come back to the Germans, as the European Community's paymasters, for financial help.
Germany was not in a situation where it could be blackmailed, Mr. Kohl said last weekend, but it had received help from its neighbors in the past and would never have achieved reunification three years ago without their support.
Germany owes its post-World War II rehabilitation in large part to the extraordinary reconciliation with France, and to its own commitment to democracy. The one still nourishes the other, certainly as far as Mr. Kohl, a native of the Rhineland, is concerned.
 
Good for One and All
 Because of reunification, Mr. Kohl believes, Germany would be the biggest winner in Europe once the world economy recovers, and it must be prepared to take the interests of others into account, particularly those of France.
"Kohl knows that Mitterrand has problems with French farmers, and he respects his need for a solution that is acceptable to them," a German official said.
Mr. Kohl and other European leaders also went along with Mr. Mitterrand Saturday in agreeing to allow France and some others to continue levying ticket taxes on foreign films and television program rights, and use the money to prop up their own entertainment industries.
So in the end, Mr. Kohl is basically counting on Mr. Mitterrand to do the right thing and not scuttle a trade agreement because he knows how badly Mr. Kohl wants one, and knows how far the German leader has gone out of his way not to embarrass the French while they press hard for advantage with the Americans.
There is a mix of admiration and exasperation in Bonn for how well the French have played their hand, first in agriculture and, in the last few days, in entertainment. "When the Americans settled agriculture early," an envoy said, "they left the door wide open for the French to raise hell with audio-visual."
After some nervousness earlier this fall about whether the United States was really prepared to turn its back on Europe if worse came to worst and build its economic future with Asia instead, the Germans have concluded that this would be unlikely.
"You're ideally situated, if there's a trade agreement, to have the best out of both worlds," a German told an American friend recently. European and American interests are too finely woven to come apart because of a friendly, high-stakes poker game. Mr. Kohl seems to be counting on everyone coming out of the game a winner.

HEADLINE: France Is Seeking Support in U.N. For Tightening Sanctions on Haiti

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 13

 BODY:
France sought the backing of the United States, Canada and Venezuela today for tighter United Nations economic sanctions against Haiti in the hope of forcing the country's military Government to allow the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to return to office.
But French officials said it was still unclear whether France would win support for its initiative, which was presented to a meeting of senior officials from the four countries. The United States reportedly fears that tougher sanctions would bring greater suffering to ordinary Haitians. 
 The meeting of the so-called "Friends of the Secretary General" group on Haiti at the United Nations was called by Foreign Minister Alain Juppe of France, who warned in a letter last month that "the credibility of the organization and that of our countries is at stake."
The closed-door meeting, which was also being attended by Lawrence Pezzullo, the United States special adviser on Haiti, was addressed today by Haiti's Prime Minister, Robert Malval, who plans to present his resignation to Father Aristide in Washington on Wednesday. Mr. Malval has called for a conference of national reconciliation to resolve the Haitian crisis.
French officials said the purpose of the meeting here, which ends Tuesday, was to break the deadlock that has arisen since Haiti's military strongman, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, blocked Mr. Aristide's planned return to the country on Oct. 30.
"We're back where we started," a French Foreign Ministry official said. "Malval is resigning on Dec. 15. The United Nations human rights group has left. The U.N. mission to train the Haitian police has been interrupted. The Canadians have left, the French never arrived, and the Americans could not land. Something has to be done."
The official said that new sanctions would not affect relief aid, but that they could involve restrictions on air contacts as well as a tightening of the current naval blockade.
Tougher sanctions would require the approval of the United Nations Security Council, which imposed a limited embargo on Haiti on Oct. 18. France wants the support of the United States and Venezuela, which are also members of the Council, and of Canada.

HEADLINE: U.N. Agrees to Create Human Rights Commissioner

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The most contentious issue facing the 48th United Nations General Assembly this year was resolved over the weekend when the nations of the world accepted a plan, under discussion for more than 40 years, to appoint a High Commissioner charged with insuring respect for human rights around the globe.
The agreement to create a United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights with the power to intervene wherever basic freedoms are being suppressed was reached in a working group of rich and poor countries and is expected to be endorsed unanimously by the 184 members of the General Assembly next week. 
 The proposed new High Commissioner would not have the power to force governments accused of abuses to change their ways. But he could try to shame them into doing so by publicizing violations and reporting them to the General Assembly or the 53-nation Human Rights Commission in Geneva.
The draft resolution setting up the new post, first proposed by Uruguay in 1952, tries to balance the West's general support and the hesitations of China and many third world countries that have been accused of rights abuses in the past. It is a compromise that excludes the most serious limitations opponents tried to impose on the new High Commissioner.
The agreed text charges the High Commissioner with "promoting and protecting the effective enjoyment by all of all civil, cultural, economic, political and social rights." It says the post's duties include "preventing the continuation of human rights violations throughout the world." And it authorizes the official chosen to "dialogue with all governments in the implementation of his/her mandate with a view to securing respect for human rights."
The Clinton Administration, which has spearheaded the drive to create a Human Rights Commissioner, originally wanted the mandate to include a specific right to carry out fact-finding investigations into alleged abuses.
But today Madeleine K. Albright, America's United Nations representative, described herself as "delighted" with the result and called the creation of the post "an affirmation by the United Nations of an enduring United States foreign policy goal."
Some private human rights groups also supported the agreement. Felice D. Gaer, director of the Jacob Blaustein Institute for the Advancement of Human Rights in New York, called it a "remarkable victory" that ends the United Nations' "age of impotence in addressing human rights violations."
But she also called on the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, to "drop his well-known opposition to the post and make a distinguished appointment." She said she wondered whether the new Commissioner would be given the staff and funds necessary to do an effective job. The Secretary General has criticized the proposal for a High Commissioner as creating additional bureaucracy.
What is most significant about the draft resolution, in the view of many Western diplomats and private groups, is that it does not contain the major restrictions that China and other Asian opponents of the post like Indonesia and Malaysia tried to impose on it.
In particular, it does not condemn the widespread Western practice of linking development aid to the recipient's human rights performance.
It also does not contain third world proposals imposing confidentiality on the High Commissioner's dealings or requiring the Commissioner to secure a mandate from the Human Rights Commission before acting.
But the compromise resolution says that in addition to protecting human rights, the new Commissioner should promote "a balanced and sustainable development for all people." It also calls on the Secretary General to select a person for the post who has "knowledge and understanding of diverse cultures."
At a conference on human rights in Vienna last summer, which called for the creation of a Human Rights High Commissioner, opponents from the developing world argued that poor countries have a right to aid regardless of their domestic political system and that basic human rights are a Western concept alien to many other cultures.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Manages to Move Up After Early Round of Selling

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the German mark and other European currencies yesterday in thin trading after it rebounded from a round of early selling.
"We tried to test the downside of 1.69 marks in Europe, but there was buying interest at the lower levels," said Eric Butte, corporate dealer at Generale Bank of Belgium. "The market decided there is more potential in a move to the upside." 
 In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.7070 marks, from 1.6960 marks on Friday.
The mark firmed in early European trading yesterday. Over the weekend, a German newspaper quoted unidentified Bundesbank officials as saying German interest rates would not be cut again this year.
Dealers are now awaiting a meeting of the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, on Thursday. It is the last scheduled meeting in 1993. While few expect a rate cut, some said the bank might adjust its money supply targets. Other dealers predicted no change.
The dollar then rose against the mark amid reports of weak retail sales in western Germany. The continuing weakness in the German economy has put pressure on the Bundesbank to ease its monetary policy and allow interest rates to come down.
Dealers said the dollar was likely to trade in a narrow range for the rest of the year.
Dealers continued to watch world trade talks as international negotiators worked to conclude the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade before tomorrow's deadline.
"The market has shut down early for Christmas," said Eli Rausch, assistant vice president of Banque Francaise. "Barring any unforeseen developments with GATT, the market should remain in a trance until the end of the year."
The dollar did slip against the Japanese yen, falling to 109.00 yen in late New York trading, from 109.20 yen on Friday.
The British pound closed in New York at $1.4900, down from $1.4950 late Friday. Other late dollar rates, compared with Friday's quotes, included: 1.4648 Swiss francs, up from 1.4547; 5.8400 French francs, up from 5.8090; 1,690 Italian lire, up from 1,670, and 1.3275 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3287.
