HEADLINE: Banks Seek Mutual Funds, But Not Many Are for Sale

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
In the wake of the Mellon Bank Corporation's agreement to acquire the Dreyfus Corporation last week, banks across the country are taking a hard look at what mutual fund companies they might buy. But few mutual funds are up for sale.
"In the mutual fund business, there are a large number of buyers, but a small number of sellers," Avi Nachmany, an analyst with Strategic Insights, a consulting firm, said. "A lot of investment bankers are floating a lot of names. But the problem is to find the sellers." 
 The main barrier is that the asking prices are simply too high. "The prices that mutual funds are talking about is way beyond what banks can pay," said one lawyer specializing in mutual funds.
The deal for Dreyfus was unusual in that its stock was trading at a relatively low price, equal to 17 times its earnings. Most other mutual funds, either privately held or publicly traded, have higher profit margins than Dreyfus and, as a result, higher stock valuations. Funds are more typically valued at a price equal to 20 times earnings or more, making acquisitions more costly.
Yet the desire by banks continues. Searching for new forms of income, banks have been pulling away from traditional lending and seeking the steady fee-based revenues that mutual funds offer. Besides, as interest rates have fallen, banks need new products to retain core retail customers who have switched from savings accounts to mutual funds.
Many banks that have tried to build this business from within have found it difficult. Currently, more than 110 banks offer their own mutual funds, and banks take in about 15 percent of all new mutual fund dollars. But gaining the name recognition, the sufficient size and the marketing expertise that characterize the mutual fund industry has proved elusive for many banks, which have found their efforts moving with frustrating slowness, analysts say.
"There's a hunger for banks to expand into mutual funds, but they've found it harder than they had hoped," said Kurt Cerulli, a Boston consultant. "A big percentage of their funds has been money converted from existing trust departments. It's been more difficult to raise new money from retail customers."
 
Suitors Outnumber Prospects

 
 Most experts say banks will find the pickings slim. Other than the Dreyfus-Mellon deal, there has been only one notable mutual fund acquisition by a bank this year: the $130 million acquisition of the Evergreen fund family by First Union National Bank in Charlotte, N.C.
To begin with, any deal would have to be friendly, whether the mutual fund is privately held, as is common, or publicly traded. In effect, mutual funds are structured with a built-in poison pill against hostile advances: the investors in any mutual fund are represented by a board that decides whom to contract to manage their money. For instance, shareholders of a Dreyfus fund, if they want, can take their money away from Dreyfus in protest of the Mellon merger and have it managed by someone else.
"Any deal has to be friendly," Mr. Nachmany of Strategic Insights said. "Legally, you have the question of the management contract when there is a change of ownership. And, in a mutual fund, you are also buying the talent of the people who run portfolios. They could also leave. You are not buying machines."
And there's price. Most banks, not wanting to reduce capital reserves, are interested in buying mutual funds through a stock swap, like the Mellon-Dreyfus deal, rather than by paying cash. But mutual fund stocks are trading at all-time highs; banks would have to give up too much stock to buy a fund and would suffer heavy dilution in future earnings as a result.
In addition, there is a question of who is willing, and available, to be bought. The largest mutual funds are either owned by brokerage firms, like Merrill Lynch or Dean Witter, or are privately held like the Vanguard Group and Fidelity Investments. And fund families with strong name appeal like T. Rowe Price, Scudder, Stevens & Clark or Eaton Vance have so far given no indication that they want to be acquired.
 
Clash of Cultures

 
 But more importantly, many operators of mutual funds worry about cultural differences with banks. Banks tend to be more bureaucratic and have greater limits on pay, making it difficult for them to provide the freedom and high compensation that is key to attracting and retaining top money managers who run the funds.
"We love the business," said the chairman of a large mutual fund company, who declined to be named and stressed his company would not sell. "It's challenging from an investment standpoint, it's profitable and the money managers don't like oversight. They want to run their own portfolios."
Mario J. Gabelli, who heads Gabelli Funds Inc., said he was interested in buying other funds, not selling. "I don't need the distribution a bank can offer," he said. "All I need to do is buy more newspaper ads."
But when the current bull market in stocks and bonds turns bearish, mutual funds might be more willing to sell. "In time, funds may reach the conclusion that they need the bricks and mortar and big customer lists that banks offer," said Rodgin Cohen, a banking specialist at the Sullivan & Cromwell law firm. Added a mutual fund executive who asked not to be named: "Give our industry a few more years and a bear market and you may see some sellers."
Andrew Ziegler, president of Strong Funds Inc. of Milwaukee, said: "Over time, you will see a new type of full service financial firm and I don't know if it will be a combination of existing institutions, like banks and mutual funds, or a general evolution. The Mellon-Dreyfus deal is moving in that direction -- firms that offer both commercial banking and asset management."

HEADLINE: High Court Orders Shift In Insurers' Accounting

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
In a decision expected to change the way the insurance industry keeps track of the billions of dollars in pension funds that it manages, the Supreme Court ruled today that Federal law rather than state law governs an insurance company's handling of pension assets beyond those needed to pay the guaranteed minimum benefit on group annuity contracts.
The 6-to-3 decision, the first majority opinion written by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, applied the standards of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to the insurance industry's management of excess earnings on investments from contributions to group annuities, a popular type of retirement plan. 
 The result of the decision, which upheld a 1992 ruling by the Federal appeals court in New York, is to bring disputes over the management of the plans into Federal court. The ruling requires insurance companies to meet the strict fiduciary standards of the Federal pension law for funds over which they have discretion.
 
State-Federal Conflict

 
 The Federal law, commonly known as Erisa, sets standards that are in some respects inconsistent with those imposed by the states, which have historically regulated the insurance industry. New York State, the headquarters of 87 life insurance companies, joined the insurance industry in arguing that applying the Erisa standards would undermine state regulation and impose "extraordinary burdens" on insurers and state insurance departments.
The Supreme Court rejected this argument today, with Justice Ginsburg noting that Congress had considered but ultimately rejected a broad exemption for the insurance industry when it was writing the 1974 pension law. "Erisa leaves room for complementary or dual Federal and state regulation, and calls for Federal supremacy when the two regimes cannot be harmonized or accommodated," Justice Ginsburg said.
As a practical matter, the decision's effect on the insurance industry will be to require separate accounting for earnings from pension contributions that insurance companies now typically commingle in what are known as general accounts. Of some $750 billion in such general accounts, $332 billion is attributable to group annuity contracts.
The general accounts are used to pay pension benefits as well as for general corporate expenses of the insurance company. Today's ruling makes the insurers responsible as fiduciaries for managing a category of these assets for the particular benefit of pension plans, requiring the industry to devise a new form of separate accounting.
 
Bank Versus Insurer

 
 The decision came in a 10-year-old lawsuit brought by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago against the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, which has held an annuity contract since 1941 for the Sperry Rand Corporation's retirement plan. Sperry is now the Unisys Corporation. Harris Trust, a subsidiary of the Bank of Montreal, is trustee of the Unisys retirement plan.
The suit charged Hancock with breach of contract and violations of Erisa, growing out of changes that Hancock made in the plan. A Federal district court in New York dismissed the Erisa portion of the lawsuit, ruling that the Federal law did not apply. Last year, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed that decision and reinstated the suit, which will now go to trial.
In the Supreme Court, the Clinton Administration sided with Hancock's appeal, saying that applying Erisa standards would be "disruptive" to the insurance industry. The Administration's brief had a somewhat equivocal tone, noting that application of Erisa "would provide significant added legal protections against losses by pension plans, because Erisa imposes restrictions not currently provided by contract and insurance law." But, the brief said, "there has been no systematic showing of a pressing need" for the added protection.
 
Interpreting a Phrase

 
 The decision, John Hancock v. Harris Bank, No. 92-1074, does not apply to all the annuity assets in the general accounts, but only to money that has accumulated in excess of the insurance company's obligation to the annuity plans. Erisa excludes coverage of "guaranteed benefit policies," so the Court's job was to determine what that phrase meant in the context of the 1974 law.
The Court concluded that what it called "free funds," assets not committed to pay the contract's guaranteed benefits, were not exempt and were covered by Erisa. As a practical matter, however, the industry is likely to have to change its bookkeeping entirely if it is to keep track of a portion of the general accounts.
Justice Ginsburg's opinion was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justices Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens, Antonin Scalia and David H. Souter. Justice Clarence Thomas filed a dissenting opinion that was joined by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor and Anthony M. Kennedy.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
2 Groups Plan Projects On Computer Standards

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Two groups of computer and telecommunications companies announced separately yesterday that they planned to begin work on standardizing how computers will talk to each other on the future information superhighway.
Currently, when fax machines and personal computers communicate over telephone lines, they use a relatively simple language of screeches and whistles. 
 But in the future, the task will be more difficult. The immense rivers of information that form voice, video and data will require more elaborate languages spoken by different kinds of computers that may transmit over cable television lines, fiber optic lines or even low-capacity copper telephone lines.
 
Cooperative Effort

 
 Bellcore, the research arm of the seven regional Bell telephone companies, said its member companies would work with companies including Capital Cities/ABC and J. C. Penney to develop computer languages and determine how the information is displayed on the computer screen.
Lanny Smoot, a Bellcore official in charge of the project, which is known as Collaboratory, said the 16-member group would emphasize practical applications. The information superhighway will have to be versatile enough, Mr. Smoot said, for a researcher to find a single paragraph among one million books, but also allow a grandparent to send a home movie across the country.
Bellcore will also seek to develop the technology that will make services economical for companies. For example, home shopping would not be possible unless a secure method of electronic payment is developed.
Bellcore plans to work with Digital Equipment, Hewlett-Packard, Northern Telecom, Microware Systems, Wiltel, Los Alamos National Laboratory and the media lab at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
 
Nuts-and-Bolts Work

 
 Another group called the Cross-Industry Working Team, which has members that are also in the Bellcore group, said it would emphasize nuts-and-bolts standards and software. The group said it planned to define "architecture and key technical requirements" for the superhighway.
Bellcore is also a member of this cross-industry group and Mr. Smoot said the two groups were complementary. "They're determining technical requirements, but we're going to make the technology real," he said.
John R. Garrett, a senior official of the 28-member cross-industry group, said, "There is going to be a Tower of Babel of computer languages and we want to avoid having to use five different telephones or five different computers to perform five different applications." Mr. Garrett is with the Corporation for National Research Initiatives, a research firm in Reston, Va., that is coordinating the group.

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
Hope for Volvo in Rubble of Deal

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
Volvo may have built its reputation on solid reliability and a concern for safety, but its shareholders are enduring an uncharacteristically hair-raising ride.
The messy collapse earlier this month of the Swedish company's plan to merge car- and truck-building operations with those of Renault, which is owned by the French Government, has left Volvo without a chairman or a functioning board, and without a strategy or enough long-term financing for the next few crucial years. 
 Amid the wreckage of the Renault deal, however, are signs that Volvo may be able to engineer a wholesale corporate restructuring. Such a move, which could be built around the divestiture of nonautomotive holdings worth billions of dollars, could insure Volvo's survival as the company re-examines its complex relationship with the French car maker.
 
 
 
More Than a Car Company
 "One thing that not everyone has picked up on in the public debate," said Colin Gibson, an analyst at Carnegie International, a securities firm in London, "is that the big, boring cars from Sweden are only half the company."
Volvo is by no means assured of success. In an increasingly competitive automobile industry, it is among the last independently owned companies of its size. Volvo sold slightly more than 300,000 passenger cars worldwide last year, equivalent to about 6 percent of the General Motors Corporation's annual sales of more than five million units.
Volvo has suffered through three years of heavy losses in its car business, primarily caused by a sharp downturn in sales in its three main markets: Sweden, Britain and the United States. The production costs of the company remain high, by world standards.
 
 
 
Need to Buy Time
 With European, Japanese and American rivals beefing up their attention to quality and passenger safety, Volvo has lost much of the marketing advantage that made it a prestigious fixture in the driveways of affluent suburbs.
 Moreover, although its truck business remains a healthy profit generator, Volvo faces difficulty raising the hundreds of millions of dollars it needs to develop its next generation of cars.
But if, as expected by many analysts, the company shifts away from its diversification strategy of the last decade and begins selling some of its noncore holdings, like its stake in a pharmaceutical company, it could at least buy time to put its automotive operations on sounder footing.
Volvo could also then have an opportunity to unwind gradually its existing relationship with Renault, under which the companies have a web of cross-shareholdings, and perhaps even find another partner.
Indeed, it was partly pressure from Volvo's shareholders that led the company to abandon the deal with Renault and take a fresh look at its strategy.
"If you look at Volvo's balance sheet, and look at the auto operations and try to take sensible views of the values in that business, I think the conclusion most analysts would come to is that Volvo is undervalued," said Mr. Gibson, the analyst. "Unless you adopt a long-term worst-case scenario, it's quite easy to justify a significantly higher share price."
Volvo's shares are trading at roughly the level where they stood before the announcement of the Renault merger sent them tumbling earlier this year. In the United States, Volvo's American depository receipts closed yesterday at $57.875, up 37.5 cents, in Nasdaq trading.
 In the next year or two, Volvo's shares are likely to be supported by an earnings rebound that began earlier this year. Part of the gain has come from favorable exchange-rate swings after the Swedish currency was devalued last year.
 The company is also reaping the benefits of a cost-cutting program that has seen it close one of its three Swedish factories and set in motion the process of closing another. And with the economies of the United States and Britain bouncing back, vehicle sales in those markets have risen this year, helped by the introduction of the full line of its new 850 series passenger car.
For the first nine months of the year, Volvo posted an operating profit of 445 million Swedish kronor, or $53.5 million, compared with a loss in the period last year of 1.5 billion kronor, or $180.3 million. A portion of the improvement came from a one-time accounting change.
Volvo said it planned to hold a board meeting next month to elect a new chairman to succeed Pehr Gyllenhammar, who resigned after the company backed out of the Renault deal. Whoever gets the post -- it will probably be an outsider -- will almost certainly take a back seat in strategy setting and day-to-day management to Soren Gyll, the chief executive. Mr. Gyll led the management revolt against the merger and, by extension, Mr. Gyllenhammar.
 Mr. Gyll has had little experience in the automotive business, having come to Volvo last year from Procordia, the Swedish conglomerate of which Volvo and the Swedish Government were the primary shareholders. But Mr. Gyll has left little doubt that he plans to refocus the company on the auto business.
His first step, some analysts said, will be to sell the pieces of Procordia that are being divided by Volvo and the Swedish Government under an agreement reached last spring. Under that agreement, Procordia was split into two parts: its pharmaceuticals business, renamed Pharmacia, and its consumer products business, now known as BCP. When the transaction is completed, probably early next year, Volvo will own a 25 percent stake in Pharmacia and all of BCP, which includes tobacco, beer and food operations.
Volvo values its stake in Pharmacia at 9.4 billion Swedish kronor, or $1.13 billion. Analysts said it could be sold fairly quickly, perhaps later next year when the Swedish Government privatizes its stake.
Analysts also said Mr. Gyll would probably look at selling the other parts of the nonautomotive businesses as well, including BCP and the company's marine and airplane engine units. In all, Volvo's nonautomotive holdings have a market value of nearly $4 billion.
Any sales, analysts said, could help to reduce the debt taken on to buy Volvo's stake in Renault's car and truck operations, and also to finance the development of new products.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Off in Light Trading

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell and yields rose yesterday as traders and investors awaited important fourth-quarter economic data this week and a Treasury auction next week.
For now, the bond market seems to be stuck in a trading range that analysts say should hold until the end of the year unless there is some surprise in the new economic data. 
 The fear that this quarter's strong growth will continue into next year should keep yields from falling sharply, while the moderate level of inflation through November and the recent decline in oil prices should keep yields from jumping too high.
 
Price Off for Long Bond
 In light trading yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond fell 11/32 , and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.23 percent, from 6.20 percent Friday. Since a selloff began in mid-October, the yield on the 30-year bond has been as high as 6.38 percent and as low as 5.82 percent, but the yield has not been below 6 percent since Oct. 29. Its low for the year was 5.78 percent, set on Oct. 15.
The price of the two-year note, which has fallen because some analysts expect the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates early next year, was unchanged yesterday, with the yield remaining at 4.22 percent, its high since the mid-October selloff. The yield has not been below 4 percent since Oct. 28.
At the weekly auction of Treasury bills, the discount rate on the three-month bill averaged 3.06 percent, down from 3.11 percent a week ago, while the average discount rate on the six-month bill was 3.26 percent, down from 3.27 percent a week ago.
One factor that prompted selling yesterday was a rise in the price of gold, which some analysts see as a sign of inflationary concerns. Others contend that in light trading it does not take much to move the market and that the rise in the price of gold was just an excuse to sell bonds, not a reason. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the price of gold for February delivery rose $3.70, to $388.60 an ounce.
 
Influences on the Market
 Some traders may also be beginning to focus on the Treasury's auction of two-year and five-year notes next week, which can often prompt some selling.
The data coming out this week include a report on November retail sales, due today, and figures on industrial production for last month, which will be released tomorrow. On Thursday, the trade deficit data for October and the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank's manufacturing index for December will be released.
Analysts expect the data to show that the economy is growing at an annual pace of around 4 percent in the fourth quarter.
It had seemed last week that traders and investors had accepted that fact, and that data consistent with that outlook would no longer prompt a lot of selling. What would encourage selling would be indications of rising inflation or signs that the economy was not going to slow in the first quarter of next year, which is what many economists are forecasting.
But in the light trading that is possible at the end of the year, the market could wind up being highly volatile and moving more than expected or reacting in a contrarian way to news or new economic data.
 
Other Markets
 Long-term yields fell sharply in Britain yesterday after the Government reported positive news on inflation, leading to increased hopes that short-term interest rates would be cut again soon.
In November, producer prices in Britain were unchanged while the prices manufacturers paid for raw materials and fuel fell three-tenths of a percent, the Government reported. In the last 12 months, prices of raw materials have declined 1.8 percent.
The prices of government bonds rose as much as a half a point. The yield on the benchmark 9 percent 15-year note due in 2008 fell to 6.56 percent, from 6.60 percent Friday, according to Bloomberg Business News.
The base lending rate in Britain is now 5.5 percent. But the good news on inflation and the need for the Government of Prime Minister John Major to assure that the economic recovery continues is making some analysts speculate that another cut might be possible before the end of the year. The Government will report the main measure of consumer inflation tomorrow.

HEADLINE: So Long, Flint, Hello, Toronto: A Director Goes Hollywood (North)

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 13

 BODY:
During the War of 1812, Americans burned York, the forebear of Toronto, provoking the retaliatory burning of Washington by the British fleet. In the 1840's, some Americans tried to start wars of national liberation to make Canada part of the United States. During the Civil War, the Confederates used Canada as a sanctuary for raids in Vermont. Since then, the border has been pretty quiet.
But now, in this year of the North American Free Trade Agreement, comes Michael Moore, who is shooting his first commercial feature film here, a satire called "Canadian Bacon" that portrays Canada as America's post-cold war enemy. 
 Mr. Moore is a genial troublemaker best known for his 1989 documentary "Roger and Me," about the troubles in his hometown, Flint, Mich., after General Motors closed its plant there and put 30,000 people out of work. In the film, Mr. Moore doggedly pursues G.M.'s chairman, Roger Smith, who just as doggedly avoids him.
Making "Canadian Bacon" is much easier, Mr. Moore said. "I have great actors," he said. "I know exactly what we're going to do each day. I have a little bit of money to put the camera on a tripod. In 'Roger and Me,' I had to sell everything I owned."
 
'Too Left for Mother Jones'
 Mr. Moore, 39, the son of an auto worker, went to Canada in his youth for his "foreign travels." He started writing "Canadian Bacon" during the George Bush Administration's 1990 campaign to whip up sentiment for the Persian Gulf war.
"So here was Iraq, an ally of sorts," the film maker said. "We'd given Saddam Hussein $4 billion in aid to fight Iran, and the very next thing he's the enemy. I started thinking, What would be the most absurd example of how the Government and the media could convince people to fear and hate? And I thought, well, it's right here, the longest unprotected border in the world, the second largest country in land mass, after Russia."
Mr. Moore, who published an alternative newspaper in Michigan in the 1970's, and in 1986 found himself dismissed from Mother Jones magazine, is a round-faced, roly-poly man, who could convincingly dress in a Santa suit. "I was too left for Mother Jones," he said. "Can you imagine being too left for Mother Jones?" His body ripples.
 
An Enemy Restored
 In the movie, to be released next summer by MGM/UA and now being shot on location in Toronto and along the border, Canadian Bacon becomes the military code name for the campaign to whip up anti-Canadian hysteria and give back to the United States the enemy it lost when Russia became an ally.
A national security adviser in the mold of Dr. Strangelove, played by the stand-up comedian Kevin Pollak, convinces a well-meaning President that this is the way to get defense industries humming and lift his popularity in an election year, when he's being murdered in the polls.
"When we started working on this I thought, well, this is fun because it's so preposterous," said Alan Alda, who plays the harried chief executive. "But the more I do it, the more I think it's not so preposterous. The President never intends to get into any kind of war situation. He gets carried away by events."
Mr. Alda said he had no particular President in mind. "It's a bipartisan takeoff," he said, "a bipartisan knock."
 
A City Plays Itself
 The movie is one of scores shot every year in Toronto, which, thanks to the favorable exchange rate, cooperative unions and visual similarities to so many American cities, has been nicknamed "Hollywood North."
But this is one of the few films where Toronto is actually Toronto, not New York, Cleveland or Chicago. Most films shoot around the landmark CN Tower, the tallest free-standing structure in the world. In this one, the 1,800-foot tower, helicopters swarming around it, is not only visible but crucial to the climax.
Grist for this satire is most Americans' lack of knowledge about Canada. While Japan is generally considered the biggest foreign owner of American assets, Canada is actually No. 1, followed by Britain, the Netherlands and then Japan. Polls show that few Americans can name the Canadian Prime Minister (Jean Chretien), while virtually every Canadian can name the American President.
"What do we really know about what they're doing up there," asked Mr. Moore, "with all that fresh water and all that ice and all those Zamboni machines?" His grin was like a wide-angle lens.
Among "un-American activities" the Canadians find themselves accused of in the movie is eliminating the Miss Canada contest.
 
Canadians Abroad
 The plot also benefits from what Mr. Moore calls the "fifth column," the large number of Canadians in the American news and entertainment industry. They include the singer Joni Mitchell; the broadcasters Peter Jennings, Morley Safer and Robert MacNeil, and the actors Donald Sutherland, the late Raymond Burr and William Shatner.
"You round up the Arabs as car bombers of the World Trade Center, but how do you round up Canadians?" Mr. Moore asked. "They look like us. They talk like us. They walk among us undetected."
Mr. Jennings, the ABC anchor and, as that network's publicity describes him, the most-watched man in America, is sinisterly identified by an American in the script as the man who "knows who's won our elections before we do, and he doesn't even vote."
In all the nationality-scrambling, the Canadian-born John Candy stars as an American, the overzealous, superpatriotic sheriff of Niagara Falls, N.Y., whose mobilization in something called the General Schwarzkopf Shopping Mall helps the President improve his ratings. His deputy, a gun nut played by Rhea Perlman, best known as Carla the barmaid in "Cheers," plays the climactic scene in the CN Tower.
Canadians and Americans are depicted in stereotypes. Canadians are portrayed as polite and peace-loving, always willing to bow to the United States. Jokes target bilingualism. Americans are shown as aggressive, bombastic, a shade Teutonic. The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, played by Rip Torn, is a loud-mouthed general named Panzer.
When the plot of the movie was described to them, several Canadians expressed amusement. "I don't know anyone who would take offense," said Robert Bothwell, a professor of Canadian history at the University of Toronto.
Although Canada and the United States stopped fighting so many years ago, tensions between them have been an occasional theme of potboilers and the movies. In a 1967 movie, "The President's Analyst," James Coburn, playing a psychiatrist selected to be the President's secret analyst, falls prey to the Canadian secret service as it tries to subvert the United States. But the ultimate villain is the phone company.

HEADLINE: Breast Cancer Screening Under 50: Experts Disagree if Benefit Exists

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
DR. ELLEN B. MENDELSON, a 52-year-old radiologist, had her first mammogram when she was 35. She had another one when she was 38. Since age 40, she has had routine screening mammograms every year, and she passionately urges women in their 40's to do the same.
Dr. Mendelson, who directs the Breast Diagnostic Imaging Center of the Western Pennsylvania Hospital in Pittsburgh, said she knows four radiologists who had breast cancer that was found after routine mammograms when they were in their late 30's or 40's. Mammography saved them, she said. "It seems really immoral to me to remove this potentially lifesaving benefit from women who are right at the height of their careers and family lives," she said. 
 Dr. Barbara Rimer, the 45-year-old director of cancer prevention and research at the Duke University School of Medicine, used to agree with Dr. Mendelson. She had a screening mammogram two years ago and has written papers on the need for women in their 40's to have such mammograms. But now, after immersing herself in the world's data on mammography, she has decided to wait until she is 50 to have her next mammogram.
"There was something transforming about reading all those articles together," Dr. Rimer said. "The science almost called out to you with the incredible weight of the evidence." And, she concluded, the science convinced her that routine mammograms before age 50 do not save lives.
The question of when to start having regular mammograms has never been more perplexing or more disturbing. After years of recommending that women start having them every year or two at age 40, the National Cancer Institute in Bethesda, Md., has now changed its stance, saying instead that their benefits for women under age 50 are not documented and that women should look at the facts and make up their own minds. But, as the opposite views of Dr. Mendelson and Dr. Rimer illustrate, this emotion-laden issue can elicit very different responses even among experts.
Dr. Edward Sondik, the deputy director of the Division of Cancer Prevention and Control at the National Cancer Institute, said he has seen "women who understand the facts and who could not be more convinced and passionate that screening in the 40's is the right thing to do." But he has also seen "others who feel exactly the opposite, and they also understand the facts."
"My view is that if a woman is informed at age 40 and then makes a decision about mammograms, whatever she decides is fine," he said. But he added, "If she makes a decision on a rote basis, without understanding that there may be harms that go along with benefits that have not been proven, then she's making a mistake."
Dr. Ann Flood, director of policy studies at the Center for Evaluative Clinical Sciences at Dartmouth Medical School in Hanover, N.H., agreed. She said that the most important thing is that women in their 40's be informed of the drawbacks of mammography as well as the possible benefits. Too often, she said, the messages they hear stress only the benefits, with the rationale that "if it saves one person in the world, that justifies whatever harm there is."
But more goes into a decision than just a cold look at data, experts say. Dr. Flood said that often the most compelling factor is whether a woman feels she may regret her choice. That means, she said, that even though a woman in her 40's might think that not having a mammogram is the more rational decision, she also might feel she could not live with herself if she made that choice and then developed cancer before she was 50. The question, Dr. Flood said, is "Would you feel guilty and would you say, 'My life could have been saved?' A lot of people feel compelled by the anticipation of regret."
The basic facts are not in dispute. Eight studies over the last 30 years have consistently found that routine mammograms for women over the age of 50 reduce the death rate from breast cancer by 25 to 30 percent. But none of these studies has found a similar effect in younger women. And even when all the world's studies are lumped together and the 173,000 women in their 40's who participated are considered as one group, no benefit has emerged.
This may reflect the fact that most women survive breast cancer, making it difficult to show that mammography saves lives at any age. The cancer institute says that more than 79 percent of women with breast cancer are still alive five years later. Since younger women are less likely to get breast cancer than older ones, the breast cancer death rate becomes so small that it is difficult to show that screening them with mammography saves their lives.
Another difficulty is that mammography is a less efficient tool to examine younger women. Researchers find that mammograms miss as many as 40 percent of cancers in women in their 40's but just 14 percent of cancers in older women. Or it may be that there is a benefit but the studies so far have failed to document it because they have had methodological flaws.
But while they have failed to show that mammography saves lives of women in their 40's, researchers have found some drawbacks associated with it. Dr. Sondik said that in about half of all women between 40 and 50 who have annual mammograms a suspicious lesion that turns out not to be cancer will be detected. About 5 percent will be found to have an invasive cancer, he said.
 
Potential Risks
Some Fear Much Needless Surgery
 Dr. Rimer said that months after a breast cancer false alarm, women show signs much like those of post-traumatic stress syndrome. "It is not a benign experience," she said.
Another drawback, said Dr. H. Gilbert Welsh, a senior research associate at the Department of Veterans Affairs in White River Junction, Vt., is that in 40 percent of the breasts removed on autopsy from women in their 40's who died from causes other than cancer, microscopic lesions in the milk ducts are found; it is unknown which of these common lesions develop into cancer. The lesions sometimes show up on mammograms and few if any doctors or women would ignore them. The standard treatment, however paradoxical it may seem, is a mastectomy.
The dispute over mammography in younger women, however, is not over the facts; it is over how to interpret them. The studies do not prove that mammograms fail to help younger women. Instead, they show that if there is a benefit, the maximum it could be is about a 20 percent reduction in the death rate from breast cancer. However, the same studies, taking into account margins of error, also show that the numbers could be read to show that screening actually increases the death rate, again by about 20 percent. The most likely effect, however, is that mammograms neither helped nor harmed women in their 40's.
In 1990, the death rate from breast cancer for women in their 40's was about 30 per 100,000, meaning that if there were a 20 percent reduction it would save 6 lives per 100,000. If there were a greater effect, the studies would have shown it, said Dr. Peter Greenwald, director of the Division of Cancer Prevention and Control at the cancer institute.
One question the studies could not address is whether mammograms could prolong rather than save lives, because of an inherent methodological problem in asking that question. If a test finds a cancer very early, the woman may not live longer but she will know she has cancer longer. Statisticians say it is impossible to distinguish this "lead-time" effect from an actual effect on survival after diagnosis and say whether mammograms for women in their 40's prolong life even if they do not save lives.
Most nations have decided that the evidence is not sufficient to recommend routine mammograms for women in their 40's. Only Iceland, Australia, one Canadian province, British Columbia, and certain counties in Sweden screen women before they are 50. But experts in the United States are torn between urging women to have routine mammograms in their 40's and suggesting they wait.
 
Past Studies
Some Experts See Flaws in Design
 Dr. Mendelson and others, like Dr. Gerald Dodd, a radiologist at the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, are convinced that despite the statistical data, routine mammograms can save the lives of women in their 40's. If the studies did not show this, they say, it is because they are flawed.
For example, said Dr. Dodd, a past president of the American Cancer Society, researchers may simply have to wait longer to see a benefit of mammography in younger women. Most studies of younger women so far followed them for no more than 12 years, but it may take 18 years or longer to see a reduction in the death rate from breast cancer, Dr. Dodd said.
Another drawback to the studies, critics say, is that they used outdated technology. "There is a significant difference in the quality of mammograms and in the quality of interpretation now as compared to even 10 years ago, and most of these studies took place 7 to 10 years ago," Dr. Dodd said. With today's technology, mammograms are more likely to find tumors and save lives, he added.
Yet another potential problem is that many studies provided mammograms every other year to the women in their 40's who were being studied. But the American Cancer Society's guidelines call for mammograms as often as every year, or every two years at the most, for women between the ages of 40 to 49. Some cancer experts believe that breast cancer grows more quickly in younger women, Dr. Dodd said, so to get the maximum benefit from mammography and more reliable data on the benefits of routine screening, the tests should be done every year.
Moreover, Dr. Dodd and others said, there is "compelling" presumptive evidence that mammograms are lifesaving in younger women.
Dr. Clark Heath, the vice president for epidemiology and statistics at the American Cancer Society, said that the best such evidence comes from studies in Sweden and in Edinburgh that show a tendency for mammography to benefit women in their 40's. This tendency, called a trend, is not large enough for statisticians to say it is a real effect. It could just as easily turn out to be a random fluctuation in the data, and could disappear as the study continues.
Dr. Heath said the encouraging trends nonetheless could be hints that mammography is helping younger women after all. "It's not strong enough in many people's minds to warrant saying screening is indicated, but in the A.C.S.'s mind it's strong enough," he said.
 
Scientific Decision
Cost Not a Factor, Cancer Group Says
 Dr. Mendelson, Dr. Dodd and others contend that the reasons for having routine mammograms are so persuasive that the National Cancer Institute must have been motivated by concerns about the high cost of health care when it decided to drop its recommendation that women in their 40's have routine mammograms. A third of American women in their 40's have mammograms, at an annual cost of a billion dollars a year. Biopsies, said Dr. Dodd, cost from $1,500 to $3,500 when done in a hospital and from $500 to $1,200 when done in a doctor's office.
Dr. Rimer and officials at the cancer institute say that they looked only at science, not economics. The institute began examining data on the effectiveness of mammograms even before Bill Clinton was elected President and made cutting health-care costs a priority. In fact, said Dr. Rimer, when she and others were asked to help evaluate the data, "we were forbidden to discuss costs."
Some experts point out that radiologists themselves might be said to be motivated by economics when they argue for testing. Dr. Robert McLelland, a radiologist at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine in Chapel Hill, who thinks the cancer institute's position is "a very honest one," said that radiologists sound "biased and self-serving," when they urge women to have screening mammograms.
Cancer experts say they are not persuaded by the arguments of those who believe the studies were flawed.
For example, Dr. Sondik questioned the contention that the studies did not wait long enough to see a benefit. He said that waiting more than a decade will only make it more difficult to analyze the data because most of the women who entered the study in their 40's will live into their 50's, when all should be getting annual mammograms and when the tests will cut their mortality rate from breast cancer. That fact complicates efforts to see if testing the women when they were in their 40's made a difference in their life spans, Dr. Sondik said.
Dr. Greenwald of the cancer institute said that the 10 to 12 years that women in their 40's have been followed is "quite a long period of observation."
Dr. Sondik dismissed the argument that the studies in younger women failed because not all provided annual mammograms. Mammograms every other year seem to be about as good as annual mammograms at reducing the breast cancer death rate in older women, he said. In addition, he added, the survival rate for women in their 40's is virtually the same as that for older women. "Nothing convinces me that the disease is more aggressive," in younger women, he said.
Is it possible that the problem was the outdated mammography equipment used in the studies? Dr. Rimer said it is true that mammography has improved, but it is not necessarily true that today's mammograms would be beneficial when yesterday's were not. Over the last 30 years, while mammograms got better, their benefits for older women held steady. At least for women over 50, "improvements in mammography technology have not translated into clearly saving lives," Dr. Rimer said.
In addition, Dr. Greenwald said, the trends toward benefits in the Swedish and Edinburgh studies do not mean that mammography helps younger women. Picking out a couple of studies with trends in a positive direction and citing them as evidence "is not using a valid interpretation of statistics," Dr. Greenwald said.
Dr. Rimer said that scientists can quibble about each and every study, and when they do not like a study's data they can ask that it be redone. But she said: "The fact of the matter is that these are the best studies we have. We have been doing these studies for 30 years and we can't go out and replicate them. We need an answer today."
 
Opponents Agree
There May Be No Right Answer
 But what about the women who say they had a mammogram when they were in their 40's and it saved their lives?
Dr. Suzanne Fletcher, co-editor of The Annals of Internal Medicine and chairwoman of the cancer institute's panel of experts who looked at the mammography data, said she is always delighted to hear that a woman with breast cancer has had a good outcome. "First of all, I say, 'How wonderful,' " she said.
But then, Dr. Fletcher added, 79 percent of women survive breast cancer for at least five years regardless of whether they had screening mammograms. "As a scientist, I'm saying there are lots of reasons" why a woman could survive breast cancer, Dr. Fletcher said. "A mammogram is one possible reason, and better treatment is another. What you have to do as a scientist is say, 'I don't know how much one versus the other could have contributed. Let's conduct an experiment to find out.' That's what these large studies are. They're experiments."
She added that she was as surprised as anyone to discover that benefits could only be shown for women over 50.
Dr. Rimer and others say that there is no right or wrong answer on mammograms for individual women in their 40's. Instead, she said, women should look at the evidence and decide for themselves.
"It would be nice if this were an easy decision," Dr. Sondik said, "but it's not."

HEADLINE: Rifkin's Mother Testifies About Day of Son's Arrest

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 13

 BODY:
Joel Rifkin's mother took the witness stand at a pretrial hearing today, charging that the police misled her after her son's arrest on murder charges by implying that he did not need a lawyer.
But the mother, Jeanne Rifkin, 70, also said that after the arrest, Mr. Rifkin, an unemployed landscaper who has confessed to killing 17 women, told her of the killings. 
 "I did question my son," she said, "and he assured me there were no more than 17."
In nearly five hours of testimony in Nassau County Court, she insisted that Mr. Rifkin, 34, had never before spoken of the murders and that she never went into his second-floor bedroom, which was cluttered with jewelry and clothing from his victims, most of them prostitutes.
Mrs. Rifkin was called to the stand by her son's lawyer, Michael L. Soshnick. He said that investigators went to the Rifkin home within hours of Mr. Rifkin's arrest and told his mother only that he had been involved in a traffic accident. Mr. Soshnick argued that the police dissuaded her from calling a lawyer.
 
Contention of 'Stonewalling'
 He said that while police investigators were "stonewalling" Mrs. Rifkin and "denying her son his Sixth Amendment right" to counsel, the police were getting a confession. Mr. Soshnick said that because the confession and much of the evidence in the case were obtained illegally, they should not be admissible in court.
Mrs. Rifkin told the court that when the police arrived at her home on the morning of June 28, they told her that her son had been "involved in a traffic violation, but that he was O.K."
She said the police refused to give her any additional information, including the fact that he had been arrested, until that afternoon, when they said her son was being held at the state police barracks in Farmingdale for questioning.
"They then told me a crime had been committed, but would not say what kind of crime," she said. "I said if a crime was committed, shouldn't I call a lawyer? But they advised against it, said that it was not necessary and that I should wait."
 
Lawyers' Numbers Available
 During cross-examination by the prosecutor, Fred Klein, Mrs. Rifkin said that she had invited the police into her home, that they had identified themselves and that she had the telephone numbers of at least four lawyers in her address file.
Mr. Klein tried to show that Mrs. Rifkin was not influenced by the police investigators and that she was free to act on her own at any time. "The police told her that her son was under arrest for a crime," Mr. Klein said. "What more did she need to know?"
Mrs. Rifkin finally called a lawyer late that afternoon.
Mr. Klein said that Mr. Rifkin had been advised of his rights shortly after his arrest on June 28.
Outside the court, Mr. Klein said, "Mrs. Rifkin is completely lying to protect her son, who she knows killed all those girls."
"She knew about what Joel was doing," he said. "How could she not if he was cutting up bodies right in the house?"
 
'Smell Anything Funny?'
 He said she invited the police into her home and waited so many hours before calling a lawyer "because she wanted to find out what the police knew about her son."
During his cross-examination, Mr. Klein asked Mrs. Rifkin to recall a day last June when her son picked her up in her car after work. He had borrowed the car and placed the body of his latest victim in the trunk, Mr. Klein said.
'Did you smell anything funny?" Mr. Klein asked.
"No," she said, her eyes averting her son, who was slumped in a chair at the defense table, staring out a courtroom window.
"You did learn that there was a body in the car?" Mr. Klein asked.
"Unfortunately, yes," Mrs. Rifkin said, shifting uneasily in the witness chair and wincing from the discomfort of a cast on her left wrist, which she broke in a recent fall.
The body Mr. Rifkin was carrying in his mother's car was that of Tiffany Bresciani, 22, of Manhattan, whom the police said Mr. Rifkin confessed to killing when he was arrested in the early morning hours of June 28 for a traffic violation.

In nearly five hours of testimony, the 70-year-old woman said her son "assured me there were no more than 17." (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEEDIEST CASES;
From Running Family Business to Living in a Shelter

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
For Donald Armstrong, who worked steadily for 20 years and now faces every morning without a regular job, the lowest point was not when he was evicted from his apartment in Astoria, Queens.
It was not when he resigned himself to seeking charity, nor even when he had to move his battered suitcases into a men's shelter on lower Broadway. 
 The lowest point came before all that, when, at the age of 52, was forced to turn to his 78-year-old father for help with his rent.
"I didn't know where I was going to go," Mr. Armstrong said. "I was frustrated, nervous, scared, fed-up."
 
Expected More From America
 Mr. Armstrong, who looks younger than his years, was reared to expect that America would offer more for him than it gave his parents.
But now, after a year and a half without work, he has found himself among thousands of people in the New York metropolitan region who have been transformed from hard workers to public assistance recipients as the recession drags on.
Mr. Armstrong, who once owned an eight-room house with an above-ground pool, spent 10 years as a municipal worker in West Hartford, Conn., before opening an office-cleaning business with his father. During its best year, the company employed 21 people and work was plentiful. But the competition was always stiff.
"We took contracts at a certain price and then bigger cleaning companies would come in and undercut us," he said. "When you lose three big contracts, you can't afford to pay your employees any more." After five years, the business folded.
Part-time jobs kept Mr. Armstrong afloat for a while, and then came a position as a maintenance worker at a Y.W.C.A. in Manhattan. When that job ended with a layoff notice, others did not follow and the truly hard times began.
When he had lost most of his hope, Mr. Armstrong turned to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, a beneficiary of the UJA-Federation of New York, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The fund has begun its 82d annual appeal for contributions to support agencies that lend a hand to people like Mr. Armstrong and others who face the holidays with no job, a disability or no home.
Because The Times pays all expenses for the campaign, the contributions go directly to the charities to help out those with both short-term and long-term misfortune. The appeal continues through Feb. 28.
The Jewish Board, which helps people of all faiths, first helped Mr. Armstrong try to keep his apartment by providing emergency rent money. When jobs didn't appear and Mr. Armstrong was evicted, the board helped him get a bed at a 10-man shelter where he has lived since Memorial Day. The board also provides him with a mailing address and takes messages from potential employers for him. Currently, while looking for a steady job, he is working two days a week as a preparatory cook in a restaurant.
Mr. Armstrong desperately wants to get himself out of the shelter, where the rules require that he leave by 8 A.M. every morning and return no later than 6:30 P.M.
"I'm too old, and I have worked too hard all my life to be living this way," he said. "Things have got to turn around."

HEADLINE: Russia's Chastening Vote

 BODY:
Russia's parliamentary elections on Sunday, which produced a large vote for ultra-nationalists and hard-line Communists, represent a rebuff both to economic reform and warm relations with America. But they need not be a calamity.
The passage of a new Constitution gives President Boris Yeltsin new powers, and his allies will occupy ministerial posts. Still, Mr. Yeltsin and his fellow reformers will face a Parliament at least as unruly as the one he forcibly dissolved this fall. The current political mood is likely to limit the pace of reform. And the resurgence of anti-Western nationalists and the Communists is chastening. 
But Mr. Yeltsin and his allies can still outflank the extremists, and while Washington must honor the outcome, it must also do what it can to encourage markets and democracy over the long haul.
Pro-Yeltsin reformers ran second to the Liberal Democratic Party of Vladimir Zhirinovsky, who is neither a liberal nor a democrat but a demagogue who preaches contempt for ethnic minorities and urges the restoration of Russia's empire. The Communist Party, which opposes privatization, also displayed strength.
But the party slates will fill only half the seats in the Duma, the lower house of Parliament. About a third of these are extremists, by latest count. The big winners may thus prove to be regional politicians elected individually in local districts. Though their leanings will become clear only when the legislature meets in January, many of them are likely to support reform if, in exchange, they can win local concessions from Mr. Yeltsin.
Adroit maneuvering could thus produce a working coalition of reformers and regional leaders. That coalition would be strong enough to press on with privatization, but not strong enough to risk Polish-style shock therapy. The hope is that the coalition could gradually wean large enterprises and the central bank from their easy-money policies and keep inflation from wrecking reform.
Mr. Yeltsin's Constitution received solid support, though low voter turnout makes the result less than a ringing endorsement. That is likely to invigorate parliamentary challenges to presidential powers. A truly independent judiciary, not yet in place, could play a critical role in bringing the rule of law to Russia.
The President's attempt to remain above the fray certainly shortened his coattails. That will require him to engage in more sustained politicking to muster support in Parliament.
Given the desperate condition in which many Russians find themselves, given also their inexperience with democracy, it is not altogether surprising that extremists of both left and right did well. Yet it is important not to exaggerate the strength of the opposition. A new Constitution is in place. Mr. Yeltsin is in place. And he has a chance to form a parliamentary majority. These are three solid reasons that Washington should do what it can to keep Russia on the road to reform.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Deliver Your President

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Picking them up in North Korea, Russian cargo planes delivered truck chassis to Syria. They are special chassis, used as mobile launchers for Scud missiles targeted at Israel.
For months, the U.S. and Israel have kept the transfer secret from their publics. It was too embarrassing, after all the warm talk from Washington and Jerusalem about how the Russians and Syrians would now help bring peace to the Mideast. On Sunday, the story was broken in The New York Times by Michael R. Gordon. 
 The chassis are helpful to Syria but will not change the military picture in the Middle East. Next month, however, another special delivery can change the political picture to Syria's enormous advantage -- the delivery from Washington of the President of the United States.
To coax Syria back to the negotiating table with Israel, the U.S. has agreed that President Clinton will meet in Europe with Hafez al-Assad. Mr. Assad is the longtime President of Syria. He is also a longtime person-butcher -- the perpetrator of massacres that have killed thousands of his own people.
Under his rule, the arrest, torture and execution of dissidents has been made government policy, Lebanon was gobbled up and colonized, and 10 Mideast terrorist organizations are trained for and carry out attacks against foreign targets -- including American.
For these actions and more, Syria is on the U.S. terrorist list. When President Bush visited with this man in 1992, Bill Clinton richly denounced appeasement of Syria. So did Israelis.
Now Yitzhak Rabin, Israel's current Prime Minister, believes a Clinton-Assad meeting could persuade Syria to make a deal with Israel if the current Israeli mess with Yasir Arafat is patched up.
The Clinton Administration cannot be more cautious about Mideast peace arrangements than Israel, when Mr. Rabin is willing to take the risks. So it may be expected to do everything it can to bring about the agreements -- everything decent and within U.S. interests.
But by this time, the U.S. should have learned that it is neither decent nor within its interests to build up Mideast dictatorships in arms or political stature. In Iran and Iraq the U.S. found it was building up enemies, for terrorism or war.
There is no evidence that Mr. Assad pays off appeasement. He collects political, military or economic advantages in advance, banks them, and does exactly what he then decides best solidifies his hold on power. The deserts are littered with the bones of Western, Arab and Israeli diplomats who thought they were smarter than this fellow. He is not only smarter but can murder anybody at home who raises a voice against whatever he decides to do.
But what harm does it do if a President lends the dignity of his office to a big-time killer? What difference if Washington allows Kuwait to transfer American planes to Syria despite the ban on such transfers to terrorist nations?
Why, none at all, if you do not think America has an interest in promoting democracy and fighting state terrorism. None, if you do not think Clintonian democratic idealism is corrupted to the point of mockery by sidling up to one of the more vicious tyrants. None, if you feel, as do Mr. Rabin and some other American allies, that involving human rights in international deals is sentimental slop. And none if you feel that Syrian complicity in the downing of Pan Am 103 must be covered up.
Despite Western attempts to whitewash Syria, C.I.A. specialists who were on the case from the beginning believe Palestinian terrorists operating out of Syria planned painstakingly to bomb an American plane and when their group was infiltrated handed the job over to their Libyan friends.
As a candidate, Mr. Clinton promised the relatives of the Pan Am dead that he would not accept a cover-up but would answer all their questions about Syrian and Iranian involvement. He has not. It is a bit late now for credibility, isn't it? You don't first chat with a mass murderer for your own purposes and then announce he was innocent all along.
It is not too late to call off the visit with this evil man. Mr. Clinton does not belong with him. If peace is possible between Syria and Israel, it will not be brought a day sooner by allowing the demeaning of the American Presidency.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: In 1990, U.S. Was Still Training Salvador Civilians Tied to Killings

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
As recently as three years ago, American military officers in El Salvador trained a group of wealthy Salvadorans associated with right-wing death squads, State Department documents show.
The training occurred as the threat of Communism was receding and the Bush Administration was pursuing peace settlements in Central America. 
 The documents are the first to describe Americans training civilians tied to political killings in El Salvador, and the first to link American support to Salvadoran death-squad activities in the 1990's.
 
Called 'Gun-Toting Extremists'
 "My worst fears are realized," the United States Ambassador, William G. Walker, said in a cable to the State Department in October 1990. The Ambassador said he had learned that American officers were giving weekly military training to 50 to 60 wealthy Salvadorans who called themselves Los Patrioticos, the Patriotic Ones.
American officers called the unit "the BMW Brigade." Mr. Walker called its members "adventure-seeking, gun-toting, 'Soldier of Fortune' magazine-subscribing, rich young extremists." Citing United States intelligence reports, he said the unit "was being used as a cover for death-squad activities."
Mr. Walker's cable did not say what rationale had been given for assigning military trainers to a civilian group. Nor did it specify the group's activities. But it said the group was affiliated with Roberto d'Aubuisson, a right-wing politician identified this year by a United Nations-sponsored investigation of rights abuses in El Salvador as the mastermind of the nation's death squads. Mr. d'Aubuisson died of cancer in 1992.
Another memo, written by a Defense Department official, argued that the Patriotic Ones "are not the types to compose death squads (fund them, yes, but get blood on their own hands -- certainly not)."
The documents are among some 12,000 Government papers on policy in Central America that were declassified and made available to the public this year. They were found by researchers from the National Security Archive, a private foundation that works for the declassification of documents, and the Center for International Policy, a Washington research group led by Robert E. White.
 
Ties to Death Squads
 Mr. White was Ambassador to El Salvador in 1980 and 1981 and later criticized the Reagan Administration's support for the Salvadoran Government in the face of many reports of rights abuses by the Government in its war against leftist guerrillas.
Those documents and a United Nations investigation showed that the Salvadoran Army and security forces were associated with death-squad activities, including the killing of hundreds of civilians during the 1980-92 war. American military personnel worked closely with the Salvadoran armed forces, providing training, equipment and advice. But none of the $6 billion in military and economic aid received by the Salvadoran Government during the war was earmarked for military training for civilians.
The worst of the death-squad abuses occurred in the early 1980's, and were thought to have been long past in 1989, when the Berlin wall fell, the threat of Communism receded and the Bush Administration embraced regional peace negotiations in Central America.
 
Killing of Jesuits Cited
 But in November 1989, members of the Salvadoran armed forces killed six Jesuit priests in the capital, raising questions of whether a decade of training had increased the Salvadoran soldiers' professionalism, decreased their involvement in rights abuses or helped bring stability to El Salvador.
It was in this context that the question of continuing to train the Patriotic Ones, who had organized only that year, was addressed. Mr. White, the former Ambassador, said, "The idea that subsequent to the Jesuit murders this kind of program continued is repugnant."
Members of Congress and Clinton Administration officials at the Pentagon and the State Department said the fact that the training of the Patriotic Ones continued after the killings of the Jesuits suggested that United States military officers had been working at cross-purposes with United States diplomats.
Representative Joe Moakley, a Massachusetts Democrat long critical of United States policy in El Salvador, said "it shows that there were two centers of power" at the Embassy.
 
Nominated as Panama Envoy
 Ambassador Walker is now assigned to the State Department pending hearings on his nomination to be Ambassador to Panama, State Department officials said. He did not return several telephone messages left at his office.
His cable said the Patriotic Ones, armed with American semi-automatic rifles, received American military training under the supervision of Col. Francisco Elena Fuentes of the Salvadoran Army, who was commander of the First Brigade, the unit in charge of the capital region. The Ambassador identified Colonel Elena Fuentes and his brigade as "among the worst in terms of human rights."
American officers argued that they should not stop training the Patriotic Ones, saying that that would insult Colonel Elena Fuentes and that "we are already 'a little pregnant' with the training that has taken place," Mr. Walker reported.
Nonetheless, the Ambassador halted the training of the Patriotic Ones. That order set off a chain of memorandums that reached Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney in November 1990.
 
Envoy Disputed by General
 In one memorandum, Brig. Gen. M. J. Byron, then the acting Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Inter-American Affairs, questioned the Ambassador's expressions of shock and outrage, saying American officers had described the unit in messages that Mr. Walker and his aides either "never read or prefer not to remember." General Byron also played down the unit's capacity for violence.
"They are, I believe, pretty much as the Ambassador describes them except that they are not the types to compose death squads (fund them, yes, but get blood on their own hands -- certainly not)," the general wrote to Assistant Secretary of Defense Henry S. Rowen.
Mr. Rowen, in turn, wrote to Mr. Cheney on Nov. 5, 1990, saying he agreed that the training of "the suspect unit" should be stopped. "There is no doubt that this is fertile territory for potential human rights abuses," Mr. Rowen wrote.
"This was really late in the game," Mr. Rowen said in an interview today. "There was no room for argument."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 15, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about American military training of civilians in El Salvador in 1990 referred incorrectly to William G. Walker, then the United States Ambassador there. He remains with the State Department, but has not been nominated to be Ambassador to Panama.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Fills 2 Top Posts As Transition Presses On

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani turned yesterday to a Democratic insider from the Koch administration to be the city's Corporation Counsel, and he named his campaign manager, Peter J. Powers, as Deputy Mayor for Operations, who will be designated to run City Hall when the Mayor is out of town.
At a news conference at his Madison Avenue transition office, Mr. Giuliani called the appointments of Paul A. Crotty, a former finance and housing commissioner, and of his lifelong friend, Mr. Powers, a demonstration of "what we're trying to accomplish." 
 He said he was seeking "change in government, to bring in new people with fresh ideas and to also have appointments of people who have significant experience in city government."
With his move into City Hall now less than three weeks away, Mr. Giuliani said he would soon name two additional deputy mayors -- one for social services and health, the other for economic development. Earlier this month he appointed Ninfa Segarra, a Board of Education member, as Deputy Mayor for Education and Community Affairs.
 
Fewer Deputy Mayors
 As part of his campaign pledge to streamline government, Mr. Giuliani had promised to "substantially" reduce the number of deputies serving the mayor. His reconfiguration of the mayor's office, he said yesterday, would result in a total of four deputy mayors, two fewer than have served under Mayor David N. Dinkins.
During the campaign, Mr. Giuliani had often criticized Norman Steisel, Mr. Dinkins's First Deputy Mayor, and referred to the "Dinkins-Steisel" administration to suggest that Mr. Dinkins was not actually the one running City Hall. Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that he had decided to eliminate the post of first deputy mayor, at least at the beginning of his administration, after listening to the advice of "many, many people," including former Mayors Edward I. Koch and John V. Lindsay.
"It seems to me that this was the most sensible way to start an administration -- to have a mayor in essence not have the kind of relationship where one person has the vast majority of the government reporting to him and then the mayor somewhat more removed," he said.
 
First Among Equals
 Still, he made clear that even without the title of first deputy, Mr. Powers would be Mr. Giuliani's first among equals, calling him the "person that I would designate to act for me if I'm indisposed or out of the city." Although Mr. Giuliani had contemplated naming Mr. Powers as chief of staff, the idea ran afoul of the City Charter, which specifies that only a deputy mayor can be a temporary stand-in for the chief executive.
Mr. Powers and Mr. Crotty, both lawyers who live on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, have both had long relationships with Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Powers has been one of Mr. Giuliani's closest friends since they met as students at Bishop McLaughlin High School in Brooklyn. And Mr. Crotty has known Mr. Giuliani since they worked together as clerks in the office of Federal District Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon in 1968 and 1969.
But in other ways Mr. Crotty and Mr. Powers are a study in contrasts. Mr. Crotty, 52, is already an experienced New York City official from a Democratic dynasty in Buffalo. His wife, Jane, recently narrowly lost a bid for the City Council against Andrew S. Eristoff, a Republican, who had campaigned at Mr. Giuliani's side. In 1989 Mr. Crotty managed Mayor Koch's unsuccessful bid for a fourth term.
Mr. Powers, 49, a Republican lawyer who was the quiet behind-the-scenes manager of Mr. Giuliani's two campaigns for mayor and is also his transition chairman, will be assuming his first public job since he was an intern in the Parks Department more than 30 years ago. "I've known Peter for most of the life that I can remember," Mr. Giuliani said.
As the $112,000-a-year Deputy Mayor for Operations, Mr. Powers will oversee a vast segment of the municipal bureaucracy, including the Departments of Sanitation, Transportation, Personnel, Buildings and General Services and the Office of Labor Relations.
 
To Examine Regulations
 Mr. Crotty, who comes to City Hall with experience running both the Finance Department and the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said that as Corporation Counsel -- the city's lawyer -- he would re-examine a series of laws and regulations to determine if they impede efficient delivery of services and procurement.
Asked whether he would seek to appeal court rulings that have left the city little flexibility on how quickly it must shelter homeless families, Mr. Crotty was noncommittal. "I don't think anybody believes that the consent decrees have led to an entirely rational housing policy," he said.
The Corporation Counsel earns $110,000 a year.
Mr. Giuliani yesterday also named Cristyne Lategano, 28, as his press secretary and Robert E. Huber, 45, the manager of executive communications at Bristol-Myers Squibb, to an $85,000-a-year post as speechwriter.
Ms. Lategano, who was the campaign press secretary, said that her salary had not been decided and that she would "welcome a cut" in the $103,000 salary that accompanies the position of press secretary. She said Leland T. Jones, Mr. Dinkins's press secretary, had been paid a salary of $99,638.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 15, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about two appointments announced by Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani misidentified the Manhattan neighborhood where Paul A. Crotty, who was named Corporation Counsel, lives. It is Stuyvesant Town, not the Upper East Side. In some copies the picture caption with the article misidentified the official who would be designated to run City Hall in Mr. Giuliani's absence. He is Peter J. Powers, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, not Mr. Crotty.
