HEADLINE: At Purdue, a Wealth of Data on Consumer Debt

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind.

 BODY:
America speaks to Dr. Robert W. Johnson through credit cards, mortgages and installment loans -- the many voices of consumer debt.
Since 1974, Dr. Johnson and his colleagues at the Credit Research Center of Purdue University have been watching how Americans spend money they do not have, becoming the nation's leading repository of credit expertise. 
 During those years, they have seen the explosion of automobile leasing and the transformation of the traditionally dubious second mortgage into a respectable financial tool of the middle class. Those changes have muddied the basic, Government-collected credit statistics. But Dr. Johnson, by most accounts the dean of a still largely neglected field, has developed a wealth of data of his own.
For instance, what the numbers now say to him is that the nation's surge in installment credit reflects robust spending by venturesome consumers, not what some pollsters contend is desperate borrowing by pinched, pessimistic ones.
 
Consumers More Confident
 "Consumers seem to be more confident," Dr. Johnson said. Just look, he added, at sales -- what people do as opposed to what they say they plan to do -- for confirmation.
[Retail sales rose for the eighth straight month in November, the Commerce Department said Tuesday, climbing four-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $178.93 billion, following a revised 1.8 percent gain in October.
[Besides their work on bankruptcy abuse, which Margie Muller, State Bank Commissioner of Maryland, says is having a "continuing effect" on regulators and others, the Purdue researchers have contributed importantly to the understanding of loan discrimination against minorities. Citing this week's costly settlement of a case against the Shawmut National Corporation, Ms. Muller said the center's study raised the issue of whether the ability of borrowers to repay was being properly measured.]
With the center's $300,000-a-year budget supplied by banks, retailers, credit-card issuers and credit-reporting agencies, the industry largely determines what projects it undertakes. Even so, it is clear that the center, believed to be the only academic group devoted to consumer and mortgage credit, has a mind of its own, and some of its insights and conclusions in recent years have shaken up the field.
 
New Director Named
 "We like to study things that are exciting to us, as well as useful to the industry," said Dr. Johnson, 71, who turned over directorship in 1990 to Michael E. Staten, who is 39.
Two years ago, the researchers startled sponsors by finding banks and other lenders much too eager to extend credit to people who were in bankruptcy, thereby stifling an industry effort to get Congress to make it harder for people to take refuge in the bankruptcy law. Legislators said, in effect, that laxness by lenders themselves -- lending to impaired or unscreened borrowers -- was inviting delinquencies.
In the face of the widely held belief that bankruptcy cripples one's financial life for 10 years -- the length of time it can remain on credit reports -- the center found that one-third of those who had filed for bankruptcy got at least one line of new credit within three years and that half of them got credit within five years. Many, moreover, keep certain lines paid up and undeclared through the process.
"The myth that consumers didn't get new credit was pretty well destroyed," the mild-mannered Dr. Johnson said with evident satisfaction.
 
Issuers' Thinking Changed
 One early impact was the way it "totally revolutionized" thinking among issuers of credit cards, said James F. Smith, professor of finance at the University of North Carolina.
The center brought a fragmented industry -- banks, oil companies, finance companies and others -- together for first time. Before that, Professor Smith said, each issuer looked at the business from its own distinct niche.
Other questions under current or recent study are whether it pays for lenders to waive finance charges and late fees to induce overextended consumers to complete repayment plans and whether privacy-related restrictions on credit information, as proposed by Europrean governments, would be unduly costly. The answer in both cases, the center found, is yes.
In its latest study, the center's preliminary findings suggest that there is some validity to complaints about the highly profitable business of credit life insurance. Critics have long contended that this coverage, bought mainly by blue-collar workers to pay off loans for such purchases as cars and furniture, is too expensive and is often sold with strong-arm tactics.
"That's a sensitive issue, and we want to be darn sure of the results" before publishing them, Dr. Staten said, referring specifically to findings that up to 10 percent of those responding to the survey "strongly agreed" that they felt pressured. One-third of them, moreover, consider the product -- it typically carries a 1 percent premium -- overpriced.
 
Consumer Group Is Critical
 But even a study like that one criticizing the industry is unlikely to persuade, say, Stephen Brobeck that the center does much more than churn out results favorably preordained by those who pick up the tab and whose business is lending money -- often at high rates -- to tens of millions of American households.
"The Purdue Center is funded by the very industry" it is studying, complained Mr. Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America, a leading critic of credit insurance. "This kind of research is highly suspect."
To counter the charge that sponsorship taints its results, the center has included a few outsiders as advisers and project participants. One of these, Ralph Rohner, dean of the law school at Catholic University in Washington, said he was "generally impressed" with the quality of the center's work, grading it an A-. His reservation is that the industry majority determines the agenda, the subjects to be studied.
After more than a decade of 12-digit deficits by the Federal Government, which has not been in the black since 1969, one might wonder whether the coincident rise of the credit-card debt and other sources of ready borrowing have eroded the nation's financial and economic health.
 
Carries a Dozen Cards
 Dr. Johnson, who carries about a dozen cards of his own but uses them sparingly and pays monthly bills in full, rejects the idea that abundant credit has been detrimental to American prosperity.
For one thing, modern mechanisms have replaced credit formerly extended by merchants, allowing them to concentrate on primary aspects of their business and making collection more likely by putting it in the hands of third parties, he said.
Moreover, Dr. Johnson said, payment on consumer debt has remained an "extremely stable" proportion of income over the decades, and corporate America, after a binge in the 1980's, is now responding to low interest rates by repaying debt in great chunks.
If there's a credit problem, he concluded, it is that "the market doesn't restrain the Government."

HEADLINE: U.S. Concerns Split Over Japan Law

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Several American computer companies are arguing in favor of a change in Japan's copyright law that the United States Government and many other American companies vigorously oppose.
The break in the unified front of the American computer industry at a hearing here Monday could make it easier for Japan's Government to justify the revision of the law. 
 Many leading American computer and software companies -- including Apple, I.B.M. and Microsoft -- say the change would let Japanese companies "reverse-engineer" and copy computer programs. They argue that such a change would help the Japanese catch up to American software companies. Washington has adopted this position and has said it views the possible change with "gravest concern."
 
Argument for Convenience
 But another group of companies, led by Sun Microsystems, testified Monday that a revision of law would spur innovation and competition and make it easier for different programs and computers to work together.
The hearing "illustrated in high relief how deeply divided the U.S. computer industry is on this issue," said Peter M. C. Choy, deputy general counsel of Sun and chairman of the American Committee for Interoperable Systems, the group of more than 30 companies that presented the testimony. Opponents, however, say Sun and its allies represent only a small minority of the American industry.
At issue is a process known as decompilation, which is one way of reverse-engineering a computer program to find out how it works.
When software is written in a programming language like Fortran, it undergoes a process known as compilation that converts it into the ones and zeroes used by the computer. Decompilation turns the ones and zeros back into programming language.
Japan's Agency for Cultural Affairs set up an advisory committee in the summer to consider possible changes to the copyright law, including allowing decompilation in some cases. After complaints from the United States that the committee was conducting its deliberations in secrecy, the advisory committee called Monday's hearing for testimony by the United States Government and American companies.
 
Gathering Evidence
 American officials said they were told that the committee was still gathering evidence and had not yet formed a proposal. But American opponents of decompilation, citing a position paper by a Japanese business lobbying group, say they fear that Japan is considering unrestricted decompilation.
The opponents say decompilation would allow companies to copy a program in a way that would make it difficult to detect. "It would be a terrific one-shot vitamin pill for the Japanese software industry," Marshall C. Phelps Jr., a vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation, said after the hearing.
But Sun and its allies say decompilation should be permitted, to let one company make programs that work with the hardware or software of another company.
The European Community allows decompilation if it is needed to make one program work with another. In the United States, two Federal appellate court decisions have let video-game software companies use decompilation to evade lockout devices preventing them from making games for Sega and Nintendo machines.
To be sure, many companies opposing decompilation control key pieces of software or hardware that have become almost standardized. Many companies in the other camp make products compatible with those of the leaders. For instance, executives of the Storage Technology Corporation testified Monday that decompilation would help it make data storage devices that would work with the computer systems made by Hitachi and other vendors.
A senior American official said Friday that the Government based its position on the "totality" of American interests. "There is no question that the economic interests of the United States are at severe risk were this proposal to become law," the official said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Amid Concern About the Russian Elections

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most foreign currencies in light trading yesterday amid growing concerns about turmoil in Russia following a hard-line nationalist's success in parliamentary elections.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.7150 German marks, from 1.7080 on Monday. It also rose to 109.40 Japanese yen from 109. 
 Gold prices were mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery was unchanged at $388.60 an ounce. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $386.75 an ounce, up 25 cents.
Currency traders said the dollar had been bolstered by fears about the strong electoral showing of an extreme Russian nationalist party led by Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky. In the past, he has threatened to drop "100 bombs" on any country making territorial claims on Russia and insisted on the return of Alaska, Finland, Poland and other areas that once belonged to czarist empires.
"We might get some civil unrest" in Russia, said Alex Braginsky, a vice president at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. in New York. "Any time that happens, the mighty greenback goes up."
He and other traders said concerns about Russia weighed particularly on the German mark. Most of Russia's debt is to German institutions. The German economy could be upset if Russia failed to repay its loans.
The remarks "gave Europe a bit of a chill," said Margaret Kudarauskas, a foreign exchange specialist at Technical Data, an analytical service.
Traders said the dollar also gained on a news service report quoting an American official as saying the United States would tolerate a stronger dollar if it meant economic growth in Europe and a commitment by Japan to reduce its trade surplus. The official was not identified.
The news reports overshadowed a Commerce Department release showing a modest increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in retail sales in November, traders said.
The British pound slipped yesterday to $1.4885 from $1.4895 on Monday.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Ad agency stocks may fit on a contrarian's shopping list.

BYLINE: By Joshua Mills

 BODY:
THE stores are bustling with shoppers, and newspapers and magazines are thick enough with ads that they can double as barbells. Economic reports of good news have advanced to at least a steady trickle.
All this might seem to portend a bright year ahead for advertising agencies, but it ain't necessarily so. 
 "I have no buy recommendations with any of the traditional agencies," said Alison Folino, who follows advertising for Smith Barney Shearson. "They've done a great job of managing costs, but I'm just not enthusiastic about the environment."
Most investors who want a piece of the advertising action focus on the five big publicly owned companies: WPP Group and the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, both of Britain; Interpublic Group of Companies and Omnicom Group, both based in New York, and Foote, Cone & Belding Communications of Chicago.
WPP owns J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather; Saatchi & Saatchi owns Backer Spielvogel Bates and CME KHBB Advertising; Interpublic owns McCann Erickson Worldwide, Lintas Worldwide and the Lowe Group, and Omnicom owns BBDO Worldwide, DDB Needham Worldwide and TBWA International. Foote, Cone owns only itself and stakes in two foreign agencies.
Shun the British is the consensus on Wall Street, because WPP and Saatchi remain encumbered by huge debt. James D. Dougherty, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds, noted that at WPP, net interest payments are 32 percent of operating profit before interest, while Saatchi & Saatchi is in even worse shape, at 44.5 percent. "It's just brutal for the people running the agencies," he said. "How can you compete with other agencies when it comes to hiring people or having enough space?"

 At Interpublic, Omnicom and Foote, Cone, interest payments are, respectively, 10.6 percent, 14.6 percent and 8.7 percent of operating profit before interest, Mr. Dougherty said. That's one reason he is recommending all three stocks. Interpublic shares closed yesterday at $31.625 and Omnicom at $43.25, each 10 percent under its 52-week high. Foote, Cone ended at $41.50, its high for the year.
"Revenue generation is pretty good, the new business activity is pretty good," he said. "Producing good financial results is a top priority."
The growing economy is another plus, he said, predicting that sometime in 1994 the economic strength "will filter through to the agencies, though Europe is still a big problem."
Alan J. Gottesman, who tracks the industry for Paine Webber, was more skeptical. "The advertising business has its own rhythm, not tied to macro-economic performance, not tied to the real world," he said. Foote, Cone & Belding is the only advertising company he is recommending to clients.
For agencies in general, he said, "business is less than terrific. Even if they were debt-free, their prospects would not be very good."
Two forecasts of advertising spending issued last week seem to bear him out. Robert J. Coen, senior vice president at McCann-Erickson U.S.A., predicted that ad spending would grow only 6.3 percent next year instead of the 7 percent he foresaw in June. Zenith Media Worldwide predicted American advertising spending for 1994 would increase only 3.8 percent.
So why is Mr. Gottesman excited about Foote, Cone? He offered a Zen-like abstraction and contrarian reasoning: "It's more a tonal thing than a specific thing. They've had a spotty record, and they trade very lightly, so it's not an institutional favorite." He also said he liked Foote, Cone's ability to win over customers, most recently the NCR Corporation, and earlier its parent, A.T.& T.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD TRADE AGREEMENT: THE FRENCH STRATEGY
Months of Risk, Moments of Isolation, Now Boasts of Triumph

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Having risked disaster in the GATT negotiations, France said today that it had won an important victory by forcing the United States to be flexible about agricultural exports and to exclude movies and television from a proposed world trade-liberalization package.
Opposition parties and farmers were less enthusiastic over what the conservative Government of Prime Minister Edouard Balladur had achieved, but for the Government, the gamble of testing its will against Washington and risking a crisis in relations with its European partners seems to have paid off. 
 "This is a great and beautiful victory for Europe and for French culture," Communications Minister Alain Carignon said after negotiators for the United States and the European Community decided to exclude culture from the proposed accord of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. "We got what we wanted from the beginning."
In the dispute over movies and other audio-visual trade, even Jack Lang, who served as Culture Minister in the former Socialist Cabinet, sounded pleased. "It's not a victory of one country over another," he said. "It's a victory for art and artists over the commercialization of culture."
After the United States agreed last week to renegotiate a farm trade deal worked out with the 12-member European Community in November 1992, France said it had achieved a slower reduction in subsidies for farm exports. That was its main purpose in pushing the United States and the community to restructure those provisions of the accord, softening the impact on France's million farmers.
 
The Truculent French Farmer
 Mr. Balladur may have more difficulty persuading the powerful domestic farmers' lobby to accept the agreement. Today, farmers in a number of cities demonstrated against the renegotiated deal. About 30 of them occupied the area around the Arc de Triomphe here this afternoon.
"Europe laid down and France capitulated," a rightist legislator, Philippe de Villiers, told another meeting of farmers near Les Invalides. "The Government of Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Balladur has purely and simply betrayed the interests of France."
France was almost alone in opposing the original farm deal, but in the end, its repeated threat to veto the entire GATT package won it concessions. On the question of opening European markets to more American films, TV programs and music recordings, -- which France said threatened its entertainment industries -- the European Community stood behind Paris and against Washington.
Tonight, France also claimed success in its campaign to have a new trade organization replace the Geneva-based General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The proposal had the backing of most of the 117 GATT members, but the United States has said it will add needless bureaucracy.
Success was hardly assured for the French. At several points over the last year, they became dangerously isolated within the European Community, with even its strong German ally growing impatient with its stubbornness. Some French politicians were alarmed that France would be blamed for yet another failure to conclude the global trade talks, which had dragged on for seven years.
 
Help From the Left
 But crucially, the Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, continued to back his conservative Prime Minister as he steadily raised the stakes, forcing other Europeans to choose between standing up to the United States and provoking a potentially disastrous split within the community.
It was here that Mr. Balladur proved to be a cool poker player. With community nations badly bruised by economic recession, by a failure to end the Bosnian war, by currency crises and by new doubts about its plan for a single currency, he sensed that the region was in no mood for a bitter fight over GATT. Almost by default, then, it backed France.
Mr. Balladur, who inherited the trade conflict when he took office in March, is expected to present the broad lines of the GATT package to the French National Assembly on Wednesday. He will also seek a vote of confidence which, with conservatives and sympathetic centrists holding 80 percent of the seats, he is certain to win.
Former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, whose party, the Union for French Democracy, forms part of the governing coalition, also seemed reluctant to give too much credit to Mr. Balladur. "France has obtained some positive results," he said, "but it hasn't achieved all the aims it had set itself."
Mr. Giscard d'Estaing's reticence had as much to do with domestic politics as with trade. The former President harbors ambitions to again be the standard-bearer of the French right in the 1995 presidential election, but at present, polls show Mr. Balladur to be the strong front-runner.
 
Chirac Also Overshadowed
 A political victory for Mr. Balladur on GATT also poses problems for Jacques Chirac, the leader of the neo-Gaullist Rally for the Republic. Mr. Chirac also has presidential hopes, but since March he has been increasingly overshadowed by the soft-spoken man he nominated to become Prime Minister.
The opposition Socialist Party has predictably criticized the proposed GATT accord, arguing that it would have been firmer had it still been in power. At the same time, Socialist leaders hope to harvest new support among disgruntled farmers.
In the negotiations with the United States over movies and other forms of entertainment, France called for a "cultural exception," arguing that elimination both of subsidies to the French movie industry and quotas on American films shown on European television would enable Hollywood to crush the arts of European nations.
The French Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, warned that the issue was not closed, with Washington likely to seek alternate ways of liberalizing audio-visual trade. "We won satisfaction today," he said, "but we will have to be vigilant tomorrow. The United States will return to the charge."
Jean-Jacques Beineix, a film director who joined the battle for "cultural exception," used a similar metaphor. "The enemy troops are sticking to their positions," he said. "They have not been able to launch their final assault, but they will."
But France's new Culture Minister, Jacques Toubon, who had warned that the nation's culture was at risk in the dispute, said the agreement would at least give the European Community time to develop "a competitive European audio-visual industry representative of our cultural identity."

HEADLINE: Buyers Turn Wary, and the Dow Falls 21.80

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks declined in moderately active trading yesterday as buyers turned cautious following a drop in bond prices that pushed interest rates higher.
Blue-chip stocks gave back much of their gains of the previous day. Usually positive news like lower oil prices, the successful negotiations in Europe on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and a modest gain in November retail sales was discounted. 
 Analysts said surprising election gains made by Russian hard-line nationalists created a drag on the market. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.80 points, to 3,742.63, one day after reaching a new all-time closing high. The Nasdaq composite fell 8.25 points, to 751.47.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 275.1 million, up from the 256.6 million shares on Monday. Losing issues led gainers by 1,376 to 696.
 
A Rebound Possible

 
 Harry W. Laubscher, senior vice president and market analyst for Tucker Anthony, pointed to the combination of lower bonds and Nasdaq stocks as a source of weakness in the market.
"The Dow dropped into a minor support zone near 3,740 and approached a short-term oversold condition," he said.
Mr. Laubscher added: "It should be kept in mind that in triple witching weeks like this week, when futures and options expire, prices of stocks tend to rise into the expiration day more often than not. That means we could see a bounce back by the market." That could come by the end of Friday, he said, when the contracts expire.
Traders said yesterday's selloff in blue chips was likely a result of investors selling to lock in any gains from Monday's rally.
David Shulman, equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, attributed the Nasdaq weakness to continuing erosion in technology and health care stocks, the result of worries over industry pricing and product cycles. "While some investors may have gotten out in November," he said, "others are trying to get out now."
 
Medco Research Jumps

 
 Elsewhere, Medco Research rose 2 1/2, to 15 3/4, after the company received preliminary approval by the Food and Drug Administration for Andenoscan, a heart drug alternative to the exercise stress test. Kemper Securities upgraded the stock to strong buy from long-term buy.
Vical rose 1 1/2, to 12 1/2, as the company and Baxter Healthcare announced an agreement to jointly develop Vical's proprietary gene-based pharmaceutical technology for treatment of hemophilia. Baxter was up 3/8, to 23 1/4.
Anheuser-Busch fell 1 1/8, to 49 1/4. Traders said the stock was down on reports that the company was planning to cut the price of its Budweiser beer brand in its biggest market, California.
Morgan Stanley initiated coverage of Zilog with a buy rating that set $37 a share as a price target. The computer maker's stock rose by 1, to 28 5/8.
Anthem Electron fell 1 7/8, to 26 1/2. The company said it expects fourth-quarter earnings to be below the third quarter's 46 cents a share because of a decline in semiconductor sales and lower gross profit margins at its Eagle Technology unit.
Shares of Federal Express rose after the package delivery company reported quarterly results that were higher than expected. The stock gained 1 1/2 to close at 71 1/2 in active trading.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rule on Contributions Is Delayed

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The board that governs municipal bond dealers said yesterday that it had set April 1 as the effective date for its proposed restrictions on political contributions by underwriting firms.
The Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board also made some changes in the proposed rule, which was first revised last month. The additional changes increase the amount of disclosure required of firms and the number of employees covered by the restrictions on political contributions. Officials would not provide details, except to say that the "basic outlines of the rule" had been retained. 
 The proposed rule prohibits a firm from doing business with state or local issuers of bonds for two years if it or any employee covered by the rule has made a political contribution to an official involved in the selection of municipal bond underwriters.
David C. Clapp, the chairman of the M.S.R.B. and head of the municipal finance department at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said he would decline comment until the final language of the proposed rule had been written and reviewed. The board met Monday evening in New York City.
 
Time for Compliance
 The effective date was delayed from Jan. 1. In a statement, the board said the delay would give dealers time to set up compliance procedures.
The rule will go to the Securities and Exchange Commission for final approval, which is expected early next year. But it is facing growing opposition from state and local officials who choose bond underwriters and who often receive political contributions.
The strongest opposition has come from the Florida Association of Counties. It opposes the M.S.R.B. rule and the separate voluntary ban on political contributions that has now been endorsed by more than 40 major municipal underwriters. The group is distributing a letter calling for a boycott of the 17 Wall Street firms that initially endorsed a voluntary ban.
National associations, like the National League of Cities, have also opposed the rule, saying it abridges the right to make political contributions and may entail enormous burdens of record-keeping. The league also said it "takes exception to the presumption that if an elected official accepts a legitimate campaign contribution from a municipal securities professional, then that elected official will be unable to carry out his or her fiduciary responsibilities to taxpayers."
 
Delay Is Sought
 In a statement adopted on Friday, the National Association of Counties asked the rule-making board and the Securities and Exchange Commission to delay approval of a final rule until they had completed a "cost-benefit impact analysis" and consulted with state and local issuers of municipal bonds.
The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Arthur Levitt Jr., has not taken kindly to the opposition, especially from the group in Florida. In a statement last week, Mr. Levitt said that "such attempts are self-interested and a misunderstanding of both the potential problems we face and the proposed solutions we contemplate."
"Boycotting the progress we've made," he said, "is counterproductive to our common goal of increasing the integrity and public confidence so vital to the market."
Many of the objections, including the concern over the right to make contributions, have been raised since August, when the rule-making board proposed the idea of a ban. Because of that concern, the board revised its proposed rule last month from a ban on political contributions to a ban on doing business with municipal bond issuers if contributions have been made.
 
Treasury Market
 Prices of longer-term Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday but the bond market continued to trade within a wide trading range as the end of the year approached.
With little interest in trading among investors and with professional traders unwilling to risk losses, the market is easy to drive down. The price of the 30-year bond was down 28/32 in trading around 5 P.M. as the yield, which moves in the oppositie direction, rose to 6.29 percent from 6.23 percent on Monday. Shorter-term interest rates were little changed.
In the weeks ahead, traders are likely to be talking about President Clinton's comment yesterday that there was no need to raise interest rates at this time because inflation was in check. Many market analysts are predicting that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term rates early next year if the economy keeps growing at a 3 percent pace.

HEADLINE: Sales Brisk At Stores Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Spending heavily for big-ticket goods, shoppers kicked off the holiday gift-giving season by sending retail sales in November up briskly, a preliminary tabulation by the Commerce Department showed today.
Consumers shoved $178.93 billion across counters last month, four-tenths of 1 percent more than in October, despite severe wintry weather that curtailed activity in much of the country toward the end of the month. 
 Although the rise was less than some expected, the Clinton Administration and most private analysts expressed satisfaction with it, noting that this was the eighth straight rise in retail spending, a category accounting for one-third of the nation's economic activity.
They also noted that the department revised upward its sales tally for the two preceding months, with October now showing a robust 1.8 percent surge.
"They're really strong," said Susan M. Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers, of today's results. "Consumers are spending with considerable abandon."
 
Furniture Sales Surge
 Perhaps the most impressive reading was a 3.7 percent jump in spending at stores selling furniture and other home equipment, the biggest monthly advance in 10 years, according to C. J. Lawrence, a New York investment house.
This, along with a 1.1 percent rise for building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes, appeared to result from a pickup in the housing market this autumn.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown pointed to this as evidence that cuts in interest rates, which he said were made possible by the Administration's economic program, "are fueling the recovery."
The November gain was achieved even without a contribution from the automotive sector, which edged down one-tenth of 1 percent last month after soaring 5 percent in October.
Leaving out motor vehicles, retail sales rose five-tenths of 1 percent in November, compared with a nine-tenths of 1 percent October gain.
 
Retailers Optimistic
 Tracy Mullin, president of the National Retail Federation, called last month's sales gain a "moderate" prelude to what is likely to be a holiday season surpassed in recent years only by last year's spending spree.
"Consumers are doing window-shopping in November, trying to size things up," Ms. Mullin said. "We expect them to do the buying in December."
She also predicted that sales would continue strong after the holidays. Between Christmas and Easter, members expect a 5.5 percent increase, up from 4.2 percent last year, she said.
In all, durable goods, those intended to last three years or more, were by far the stronger of the two over-arching sales groups last month, rising nine-tenths of 1 percent.
Commentators were not particularly disappointed by flat sales of cars and trucks, since October was one of the best months in several years. The strength in durable goods lifted sales for the period September through November 12.3 percent ahead of the comparable 1992 period and 3.4 percent higher than in the June through August period.
 
Nondurables Sag
 Nondurables, however, did markedly less well, rising just one-tenth of 1 percent. Consumers seemed to feel a need to balance big purchases with a bit of frugality elsewhere.
Stores selling general merchandise, including department stores, posted a 1 percent decline, and sales fell six-tenths of 1 percent at restaurants and bars.
Spending climbed 1.4 percent at apparel and accessory stores and five-tenths of 1 percent, at drug and proprietary stores, but gains at food stores and gasoline service stations were just one-tenth of 1 percent.
Sales at gasoline stations had jumped 1.5 percent in October as higher Federal fuel taxes took effect. November was marked by tumbling oil prices that continued into December.
Over the last three months, sales of nondurables have been just 3.6 percent higher than in the period September through November 1992, and just 1.5 percent higher than in the June through August period.
The department's figures are adjusted for seasonal, holiday and trading-day differences but not for inflation, discounts or other price changes. Before adjustment, retail sales rose 2.6 percent in November after rising 3 percent in October, today's report showed.

HEADLINE: Victims of Drunken Driving Seek to Heighten Awareness

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
"What you see is the headlights, and you know it's predestined," said Marge Lee, of Franklin Square, L. I. At that moment -- 10:10 P.M. on a crystal-clear summer night in July 1990 -- she told her stepson, as he drove their Suzuki Samurai down Route 7 in New Jersey toward the Holland Tunnel, that it looked like the oncoming Mustang was straying across the double yellow line.
She had always worried about her stepson, Kenney, because he rode a motorcycle. "Typical neurotic mother, right?" she said yesterday at a news conference given by "survivors" of drunken drivers. But he died in a car. 
 It came as if it were in slow motion, she said, although the head-on impact was estimated later at 80 to 100 miles an hour. The dashboard disintegrated and her stepson was impaled on the steering wheel. There was a long silence, Ms. Lee recalled. Then Michael, 5, and Elizabeth, 3, started crying from the back seat. But she could do nothing, could barely call out to reassure them, because her left lung had collapsed.
He was 25, she said. So was the driver of the other car, who died leaving a wife and a 2-year-old child, she said. Ms. Lee, a member of the board of Long Island Mothers Against Drunk Driving, says she lives in fear that it could happen again.
 
Survivors' Stories
 Drunken driving kills all year, at a rate of about 18,000 people a year. At this time of year there are holiday parties with alcohol, raising the risk slightly, and giving public safety officials a reason to raise public awareness, which was the object of a news conference yesterday called a "Celebration of Life," at which survivors, with scars visible and invisible, told their stories.
If the recent past is any guide, over Christmas weekend about 20 people will die and about 2,700 will be injured in 11 New York counties and 7 in New Jersey, officials say, roughly a third of them in accidents involving alcohol. Separate statistics for southwestern Connecticut were not readily available from that state's Department of Transportation, but 130 people died in that state last year from drunken-driving accidents.
(Sobriety advocates, though, avoid the word "accident" in describing these deaths, since the drinking, they point out, was deliberate.)
Thomas M. Louizou, regional administrator for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said that there are 385,000 serious injuries each year caused by drunken or drugged driving, and $48 billion in economic losses.
The years have brought some progress. In 1992, there were 17,699 alcohol-related fatalities, representing 45 percent of all fatalities, down from 25,165 such fatalities 10 years earlier, when they comprised 57.3 percent of the total. The drop in fatalities is attributed to increased publicity, to raising the drinking age and to stricter enforcement of drunken-driving laws.
 
Hit on a Parking Lot
 But the toll is still high, cruel, and stunningly random.
For example, there was Melinda Banks, who was reaching for a glass bowl on top of her refrigerator on March 2, 1991, when the bowl broke and cut her forearm. She woke her husband Christopher, a 26-year-old motorman for the Transit Authority, and he drove her to Caledonia Hospital in Flatbush. While she was in a curtained enclosure for stitches, she heard someone in the emergency room declare a "code blue," for extreme emergency, and another patient was brought in.
When Ms. Banks had been bandaged and went into the waiting area, she was directed to a police officer, who handed her her husband's wallet. He had gone to the parking lot to check on the car, where he had been hit, and was the patient in the next cubicle; he died there.
"The drunk who hit him got out of the car and staggered," said Ms. Lee yesterday. "He didn't know what he had hit."
The driver who killed him, a 50-year-old man, had "two priors" for drunken driving, she said. He received five years' probation, and served weekends at Rikers Island for four months, she said.
The consensus among the victims is that the courts are not nearly strict enough. "It's the only crime that John Q. Public can relate to," Ms. Lee said. Jurors will sympathize with a drunken driver, she said, perhaps thinking to themselves, "oh, what about that time I went to a wedding and drank too much." In contrast, she said, if they are hearing a burglary case, they do not think to themselves, "what about that 7-Eleven I knocked over last week."
Another victim at the news conference yesterday illustrated the tenacity of the problem. Timothy Flynn has been using a wheelchair since he broke his neck in the spring of 1981, when he was home in Carmel, N.Y., on vacation from Kenyon College, in Gambier, Ohio, where he was a freshman. The drunken driver at fault was Mr. Flynn himself; he had consumed about half a bottle of Canadian Club, he said, and had gone with a friend to a local bar where he had a beer. On the way home he lost control of the family's Ford station wagon.
Eager to talk about the problem, Mr. Flynn extended a hand to shake but he does not have enough control over it to open it.
It was not his last drunken-driving accident, though; on his 30th birthday, a year and a half ago, he became intoxicated and crashed his Plymouth Reliant with special hand controls into the car in front of him. Finally he gave up drinking.
Mr. Flynn now works for the Manocherian Foundation, a traffic safety group established by Fraydun Manocherian, which helped sponsor the event yesterday, lobbying for stricter laws. Tough penalties would help, he said, but so would better enforcement of existing laws. "You can have the death penalty for drunk driving, and it's not going to do a thing, unless it's enforced," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The increased number of parties and drinking over the holidays inspired yesterday's "Celebration of Life," a meeting at which survivors of drunken-driving accidents told their stories in hopes of preventing others. (Ed Quinn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: State Sales Of Old Guns Are Faulted

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 14

 BODY:
New York State agencies sold or traded more than 6,800 guns to licensed gun dealers over the last five years, at least one of which might have been used in the commission of a crime.
The gun sales were legal and were carried out in an attempt to reduce the cost of buying replacement weapons for state law-enforcement officials. But the transactions, which are detailed in a report released today by Republican Assembly members, are likely to fuel an emerging national debate over what law-enforcement agencies should do with their old guns as they upgrade to rapid-fire semiautomatic weapons. 
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has repeatedly called for tougher gun-control laws, including a ban on assault weapons. Some weapons that have been sold or traded by state agencies in recent years -- mostly semiautomatic rifles -- would be outlawed under Mr. Cuomo's proposal.
But aides to the Governor yesterday defended the gun trades as good fiscal policy during a time of tight budgets. During the five years studied in the report, the state saved $1.57 million through the trades.
 
Similar Trades Common
 Federal officials and gun control advocates said it was common for law-enforcement agencies around the country to trade old weapons for discounts on new ones. Though statistics are not available, state and local police departments in Michigan, California and Ohio have routinely engaged in such trades.
"It's a thoroughly counter-productive practice," said Jeff Muchnick, legislative director for the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence, a gun-control lobbying group in Washington. "It's an instance of how re-inventing government has gone awry."
Among the agencies now grappling with the problem is the New York City Police Department, the nation's largest, which is switching from .38-caliber service revolvers to 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistols, which can be fired more rapidly and hold more bullets.
In a recent television appearance, Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani said he would try to prevent police officers from selling their old guns on the open market as they upgrade to semiautomatics.
 
Officers Buy Own Guns
 But a spokesman for Mr. Giuliani said today that because New York City police officers purchased their own guns, unlike many state law-enforcement officers, it would be difficult to regulate how they dispose of their old weapons.
For New York State agencies, trading old weapons for new increased in the late 1980's as law-enforcement officials worried that they were being outgunned by criminals.
Among the state agencies that took part were the Division of Parks and Recreation, the Division of State Police, the Department of Taxation and Finance and the Division of Parole -- all of which employ law enforcement agents authorized to carry weapons.
The largest of the transactions occurred in 1990, when the State Police sold 4,553 guns to a federally licensed gun dealer in Billerica, Mass., called Interstate Arms Corporation, according to the report.
 
Savings on Glocks
 In exchange, the state police received 4,310 Glock 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistols. The deal saved the state $1.2 million, the report said.
The vast majority of the guns sold by the state were .38- and .357- caliber handguns. But state agencies also sold 702 semiautomatic pistols, 39 12-gauge shotguns and at least six semiautomatic rifles.
In a sampling of about 100 guns sold by the state, the Assembly Republicans found that at least one, a 9-millimeter handgun, has been traced by the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, indicating that it was used in a crime. The trace was requested by police in Detroit. Because the report did not contain the gun's serial number, it could not be determined why the trace was sought.
At the request of the Assembly Republicans, the A.T.F. is now checking all 6,807 guns sold by the state since 1989 to see if others have been used in crimes.
 
The State as Gun Dealer
 "This just isn't consistent policy," said Assemblyman John J. Faso, a Republican from Kinderhook, who helped write the report. "We shouldn't put the state in the position of being a gun dealer."
Richard H. Girgenti, the state's Director of Criminal Justice Services and Mr. Cuomo's top adviser on crime issues, said today that he would recommend that state agencies destroy their aging weapons in the future.
Mr. Cuomo's office did not return calls for reaction to Mr. Girgenti's recommendation. But his aides called the Assembly report a politically motivated effort to help Mr. Faso, who is running for state Comptroller next year.
The gun sales were not irresponsible, said Claudia V. Hutton, a spokeswoman for the state Budget Division.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD TRADE AGREEMENT;
A Realignment Made Reluctantly

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 14

 BODY:
For all its arcane murkiness, the trade agreement struck today has traced important contours of the post-cold war era. The negotiations that began seven years ago in moderate obscurity have ended as a pivotal political event, engaging heads of state in discussions about rice and placing the likes of Steven Spielberg and Mario Vargas Llosa in heated debate about cultural values.
Most fundamentally, this unlikely transformation reflects the collapse of the Iron Curtain. In a world no longer defined by military and ideological conflict, what counts for politicans are economic success and the creation of jobs. That is why President Clinton and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany have been as involved in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks as their predecessors were in negotiations to station new missiles in Western Europe. 
 For artists, the barricades are at a different place in a different ideological war, dividing those for and against a completely free market for their creations. That is why Hollywood and the Rive Gauche now talk GATT.
 
Beneath the Visions
 But if the GATT discussions were supposed to be about the end of conflict and the laying out of a commercial framework for a new world -- offering a vision of a planet without barriers enriched by freer trade and open to the invitations of an unfettered market -- they came instead to reveal something more akin to unease than to enthusiastic expectation.
Although failure was averted by an outline agreement today that will cut tariffs by about one-third and extend trade rules to a host of new areas including agriculture, what emerged from the 117-nation talks was a world suspicious of American economic and cultural domination and reluctant to accept an invitation to the global mall.
While, in the end, nobody was prepared to countenance a collapse of the talks -- tantamount to inviting political and economic dislocation within the Western alliance and the emergence of regional economic blocs in the Americas, Asia and Europe -- there was little evidence that nations felt sufficiently reassured by the demise of Communism to embrace a global economic opening that would transcend narrow self-interest and national traditions.
"The hope was that the GATT talks could be the centerpiece of a new era in which global institutions and opening would replace the old postwar alliances and provide a new sense of cohesion for the international system," said Robert D. Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. "But there was resistance to that. If the global economy is a glue, it's a weak one."
 
Not Entirely Successful
 Thus, although agreement was reached to establish a new Multilateral Trade Organization to symbolize the world's common interest in orderly commerce, the effort to extend GATT rules to the more than $1 trillion in annual worldwide trade in services had limited success.
Shipping was set aside, and the opening of markets to financial services like banking and securities trading was effectively postponed to a later date. Most significant, the world's, and particularly America's, booming trade in movies, music and other entertainment became a subject not for agreement but for unresolved and vitriolic conflict between the United States and Europe.
"Services, intellectual property and investment should have been the core of this round, because they are the core issues in the real world," said Alan Stoga, the managing director of Kissinger Associates. "In the end, these issues were put on the agenda, but not much more than that."
Even the appearance on the agenda of the movie question -- part of the debate on trade in intellectual property -- was enough to provoke an extraordinary European outcry, rooted in but not confined to France. The target was Hollywood, portrayed as a marauder as mindless as the dinosaurs of "Jurassic Park," intent on devouring the vestiges of European culture.
It was "Dallas" versus Depardieu, culture as commerce versus culture as art -- and the result was an impasse hailed by Jack Lang, the former Culture Minister of France, as "a victory for art and artists over the commercialization of culture."
 
Presidential Reaction
 In Washington, President Clinton told reporters that he was disappointed that the audio-visual portions of the agreement remained unresolved, but that no one "thought it was worth bringing the whole thing down over."
But, at a deeper level, it was Europe against the most visible symbol of the spread of American culture and economic influence in a world that is no longer bipolar. And for several French intellectuals and writers, the conflict assumed global dimensions.
Did the world, by endorsing the free-trade principles of GATT, really want to demolish national identities in favor of a blanket American-dominated culture and so encourage the emergence, in angry reaction, of the likes of the Russian nationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky?
"Should we really convert the planet into a supermarket in order to leave people with a choice between Coca-Cola and the local ayatollah?" the French philosopher and writer Regis Debray asked.
 
Baseball Caps and Dinosaurs
 That may sound like an extreme point of view -- and there has been much relentless caricaturing of the United States in Europe in recent weeks. But it has become clear that GATT does raise the delicate political question of how far national traditions and policies are prepared to cede to the economic globalization symbolized by universal baseball caps and universal screen dinosaurs.
For example, in opening its market to imported rice for the first time, Japan was taking more than a small trade step. Rice cultivation is central to Japan's religion, culture and folklore and the bar on imports symbolized its sacredness. Each spring, the Emperor plants the first seedling on the grounds of the Imperial Palace. But in the end, the Japanese Government decided that access to markets outweighed these considerations.
Europe, however, balked, preserving its quotas and subsidies that penalize American films and limit the prospects in Europe of fast-expanding American services like pay-per-view and cable television channels.
As a result, the GATT accord emerged as a two-headed beast. On the one hand, said John Lipsky, chief economist for Salomon Brothers, "This is far better than no agreement, an encouragement to economic growth and a vital statement that the world still believes in trade liberalization."
On the other hand, the limits of that liberalization have been shown. By standing up for what they see as their threatened culture, European governments effectively said no to globalization. They also insured that the GATT accord will fall significantly short of its target, and suggested to many economists that regional agreements like the North American Free Trade Agreement may prove to be more of a model for the future than a much-vaunted, but somewhat hollow, multilateralism.

HEADLINE: U.S. Surpasses Japan on Chips

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 14

 BODY:
United States semiconductor makers surpassed their Japanese rivals in total sales in 1993 for the first time since 1985, according to Dataquest Inc., a leading market research firm.
American chip makers, led by the Intel Corporation, controlled 41.9 percent of the worldwide semiconductor market this year, up from 41.5 percent in 1992, according to preliminary figures released today by Dataquest. 
 Japanese companies, led by NEC, accounted for 41.4 percent of worldwide sales, down from 42.3 percent last year, Dataquest said.
Intel had 9.6 percent of worldwide sales, up from 9.4 percent last year, when it regained its position as the largest semiconductor producer in the world. NEC had 7.4 percent, Motorola 7.2 percent, Toshiba 6.9 percent and Hitachi 6.1 percent.
Texas Instruments sold 4.8 percent of the chips on the world market, followed by Samsung with 3.7 percent, Fujitsu 3.5 percent and Mitsubishi 3.4 percent.
Gene Norrett, vice president of Dataquest's semiconductor group, attributed the change to "a declining Japanese economy coupled with increased foreign competition in the Japanese semiconductor market" as well as booming Intel sales and penetration of the personal computer market.
Dataquest said that chip sales by the International Business Machines Corporation, estimated at $2.5 billion, were not factored into the survey so that valid year-to-year comparisons could be made. I.B.M. , which formerly produced only for itself, has aggressively entered the open chip market.

HEADLINE: Japan's Trade Surplus Dips; Long-Term Decline Is Seen

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus, which has been a political sore point worldwide, has peaked and is starting to decline, according to a growing number of economists.
The strongest evidence came today when the Government reported that the excess of exports over imports fell 2.2 percent in November from a year earlier to $7.4 billion, the first such decline in 35 months.
"This really confirms that the direction of the Japanese surplus basically has turned," Mineko Sasaki-Smith, senior economist in the Tokyo office of Morgan Stanley & Company, said. "The decline will continue." 
 Economists said that the sharp rise of the Japanese yen against the dollar, from about 123 to the dollar a year ago to about 108 now, was finally having an effect on the trade surplus. The yen's rise makes Japan's exports less competitive while making foreign products cheaper and more attractive to the Japanese.
But the surplus with the United States continues to grow, climbing 13 percent in November to $4.3 billion from $3.8 billion a year earlier. That is because the United States economy is recovering, pulling in more Japanese products, while Japan's economy remains mired in recession.
If Japan's economy starts to recover next year, analysts say, the nation will buy more imports, speeding the decline of the overall surplus and perhaps beginning to reduce its surplus with the United States.
However, some analysts have noted, Japan's surplus has grown in the long run despite a steady rise in the yen's value in the last two decades. The Plaza Accord in 1985, in which the United States and its allies agreed to reduce the strength of the dollar, led to a sharp jump in the yen's value, and the surplus declined for a couple of years. But it then rose to record levels as Japanese companies adjusted cost structures.
Japan's overall trade surplus, the largest of any nation in history, is expected to exceed $115 billion this year, compared with $106.6 billion in 1992, as measured by the Japanese Government on the so-called customs clearance basis.
Using the balance-of-payments method, which is preferred for international comparisons, the trade surplus is expected to top $140 billion this year compared with $132 billion in 1992. Geoffrey Barker, economist with Baring Securities in Tokyo, said he expects the figure to drop to $125 billion or less in 1994.
A decline in the surplus could lead to a weakening of the yen, since the yen's value has been propped up by the belief of currency traders that the United States favors a strong yen to bring down Japan's trade surplus.
A declining surplus could also take some pressure off Japan from its angry trading partners.
In discussing a new trade framework accord in July, the United States sought Japan's commitment to reduce its current account surplus, a broader measure of trade in goods and services, to less than 2 percent of economic output in three or four years from more than 3 percent now. Japan said it could not control its trade surplus by itself and thus could not set a target.
But now, Japan might achieve the goal anyway. Jesper Koll, an economist with S. G. Warburg Securities in Tokyo, estimated that Japan's current account surplus is likely to fall to 1.8 percent of gross national product by early 1995.
For much of this year, Japan's trade surplus has been declining in volume terms and when measured in yen. But when measured in dollars it has continued to rise because the dollar is worth less now than it was a year ago. Economists call this temporary rise in the dollar-denominated surplus the J-curve effect.
Now, however, exports are becoming weak enough and imports strong enough to show a decline in the surplus even when measured in dollars.

HEADLINE: Fewer Are Insured For Medical Care

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
The number of people without health insurance reached 38.9 million last year, up 2.3 million from 1991, new Government data show. The increase was greater than in the two previous years combined.
The Employee Benefit Research Institute, which tabulated the data, said today that "a major reason for the 1992 increase in the number of uninsured is a decline in coverage among people working for small firms." 
 But it also reported that 19 percent of the uninsured -- 7.2 million people -- are in families headed by those who work for businesses with 1,000 or more employees.
 
Fuel for Debate
 The data show why there is a political clamor to overhaul the nation's health care system. They also suggest that the clamor will not abate until the number of uninsured people begins to decline. But the data do not necessarily support any specific proposal for extending health insurance.
President Clinton wants to require employers to provide coverage for their workers. His proposal has provoked vigorous protests from owners of small businesses. The rise in the number of uninsured does not necessarily increase the cost of Mr. Clinton's plan for the Government. But it probably does increase the number of employers who would, for the first time, have to contribute to the cost of coverage for employees.
From 1989 to 1992, the number of uninsured people increased by 4.2 million, the report says. More than half of the increase, or 2.3 million, occurred last year.
 
Higher Cost a Factor
 William S. Custer, research director of the institute, a nonpartisan research organization whose members include businesses and labor unions, said the rise in the number of uninsured probably reflected increases in unemployment in 1992 and increases in the cost of health insurance, which rises along with the cost of health care.
The civilian unemployment rate averaged 7.4 percent in 1992. That was higher than for any year since 1984. As for the rising cost of insurance, some small companies are reacting by dropping coverage, and some consumers say they cannot afford coverage on their own.
Hawaii and Connecticut had the highest rates of coverage, with less than 10 percent of residents under age 65 uninsured in each state. Residents of Southern states were more likely to be uninsured. In each of four states -- Louisiana, Texas, Oklahoma and Nevada -- and in the District of Columbia, more than one-fourth of the residents were uninsured. In New York, 16 percent of those under 65 had no health insurance. The comparable figure was 15 percent in New Jersey.
The number of people without health insurance has been a source of fierce debate in the last year. Conservative members of Congress say the most commonly used estimate, 37 million, overstates the problem because it includes people changing jobs, people uninsured for just a few months and healthy young people who choose to go without insurance.
The data in the new report are drawn from interviews conducted in March by the Census Bureau with 57,000 households chosen to be representative of the entire population. If people answered accurately, the results mean that 38.9 million people did not have health insurance at any time in 1992. But in this year's survey, as in past years, researchers say that many people seem to have misunderstood the questions and to have described the insurance coverage they had at a particular point, rather than for the full 12-month period.
Mr. Custer, the research director of the institute, said the most cautious reading of the data suggests that, on any given day last year, 39 million people were uninsured.
In other words, he said: "A snapshot would show 39 million people without insurance at a given point in time. But some of those people will gain coverage, while others with insurance will lose coverage. Over the course of a year, as many as 53 million Americans may be without insurance for a month or more. But as few as 22 million people may be uninsured for the entire year."
"Our numbers show that the uninsured are not a homogeneous group," Mr. Custer said in an interview. "Some are between jobs. Some have fairly high incomes. But the chronically uninsured are low-income people who work or live in families with workers. They tend to be low-skilled workers employed by small firms."
The report shows that 177.5 million Americans had private health insurance last year, while 63.2 million had public health insurance through programs like Medicare and Medicaid. There is some overlap between the two groups because, for example, many elderly Medicare beneficiaries buy private coverage to fill gaps in the Federal program.
 
Three-Year Pattern
 In its report, made public today, the institute made these points:
*Over the last three years, there has been a gradual decline in the number of people with private health insurance and in the number getting coverage through employers.
*The probability of having health insurance rises with a person's earnings. Among those earning less than $10,000 a year, 50 percent lack coverage.
*Nationally, 17.4 percent of Americans under 65 were uninsured last year. In 1989, the comparable figure was 16.1 percent.
*The probability of having health insurance rises with the size of the company for which a person works. Among people in families headed by workers in small businesses with fewer than 10 employees, 39 percent get health insurance through employers. But in families headed by workers at large companies with 1,000 or more employees, 81 percent have such coverage.
In a separate action, three groups of doctors said today that employers should be required to provide health insurance for their employees. The groups, the American Academy of Family Physicians, the American Academy of Pediatrics and the American College of Physicians, distinguished their position from that of the American Medical Association, which last week urged Congress to consider alternatives to such an employer mandate.
"The most certain way to achieve universal coverage is through an employer mandate," said Dr. J. Robert Graham, executive vice president of the American Academy of Family Physicians.
The three groups supporting employer mandates say they have a total of 200,000 doctors as members. The A.M.A. says it has 290,000 members.
Charles Leonard, a spokesman for the Health Care Reform Project, a coalition of 32 organizations seeking health insurance for all Americans, said: "The A.M.A. is not the sole voice of the nation's doctors. One-third of the physicians in America are represented by these other groups, which support an employer mandate."

HEADLINE: Real Estate Investment Trusts Face a Sour Market

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
The fortunes of two much-anticipated initial public offerings yielded more signs yesterday that the market for real estate investment trusts appears to be souring because of fears of rising interest rates and a glut of issues.
A $600 million offering from the DeBartolo Realty Corporation was postponed after the company announced that it would not lower the stock price to the level that investors seemed to be demanding. And an $840 million offering from the Simon Property Group Inc., the largest REIT in the nation's history, went through only after the company dropped its stock price.
 
A Blow to the Market
 Investor reaction to the two offerings was another blow to the REIT market, which has stumbled recently after soaring the last two years because of an influx of money from investors fleeing low rates of returns on bonds and bank accounts. Several other REIT offerings were also been postponed in recent weeks. 
 REIT's are a kind of mutual fund that buys real estate or mortgages, converts them into securities and passes on dividends to investors. They are generally considered a relatively risky equity, and some investors suffered enormous losses in the mid-1970's and late 1980's.
DeBartolo, based in Boardman, Ohio, and headed by the real estate entrepreneur Edward J. DeBartolo, had sought to raise capital to pay off huge debts incurred in part from buying shopping centers and other properties during the real estate boom of the 1980's.
The company had planned to sell 31.6 million shares at $18 to $19.25 each. The REIT would have controlled a 51 percent stake in DeBartolo Properties Partnership L.P., which owns 51 retail malls and seven strip shopping centers in 14 states.
"We gave notification on Sept. 14, and since that time, the REIT market as a whole has declined 15 to 20 percent," Marie Izzo Cartwright, a spokeswoman for DeBartolo, said. "Our decision today was based on the fact that we were not willing to continue with the offering at a discounted price."
Shares in Simon, based in Indianapolis, closed at $22.50 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday on volume of nearly 7.2 million shares, making it the most active issue on the Big Board.
But Simon had to cut its initial stock price to entice investors. In its preliminary prospectus filed on Nov. 8, the company announced that it would sell 36 million shares in the range of $23.75 to $26.25. On Monday night, it decided to sell 37.75 million shares at $22.25.
The Simon REIT is the largest offering since a $750 million deal by Rockefeller Center Properties in 1985. The Simon REIT controls a 52 percent stake in Simon Property Group L.P., which owns 54 malls, 53 shopping centers and three mixed-use properties in 28 states.
DeBartolo and Simon, which is headed by another major real estate executive, Melvin Simon, are the latest in a string of big real estate companies that have tried to dive into the REIT market in the last year.
Many of these companies turned to the investments because they had trouble obtaining money from banks and other traditional sources, which sharply reduced their real estate lending after suffering losses during the real estate slump in the late 1980's.
So far this year, 40 REIT's have raised a record $8 billion in initial public offerings, topping the previous record of $3 billion in 1987. Another $5.5 billion are on file at the Securities and Exchange Commission waiting to be sold.
But with a growing number of real estate companies considering REIT's, the market has become bloated, according to some analysts. And anxiety about rising interest rates has further driven away investors.
Among the REIT's that have been postponed or canceled in recent months are Glimcher Realty Trust, Macerich Company, Prime Retail and Mid-America Apartment Communities.
 
 
Offering Termed a Victory
 Martin J. Cicco, a managing director at Merrill Lynch, the lead Simon underwriter, contended that even though Simon had to drop its initial price, it was still a victory to issue so much stock in such a climate. And he pointed out that the stock price did not fall yesterday.
"The market is not being friendly now to these issuers, which is why DeBartolo was pulled," said Mike Kirby, a principal at Green Street Advisors, a research firm in Newport Beach, Calif.
DeBartolo executives "looked at Simon, and they said, 'Even though we are hard-pressed here, even though we have bankers holding a gun to our heads, it is just foolish for us to sell these assets at this price,' " Mr. Kirby said. He added, "So they are going to explore the private market."

HEADLINE: U.S. Aide to Seek New Policy on Fleeing Haitians

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 14

 BODY:
With human rights abuses increasing and the number of people leaving Haiti on the rise, the United States should review its policy of forcibly returning all Haitian boat people, the Administration's top human rights official said today.
At the end of a 24-hour trip to Haiti, the Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, John Shattuck, said he would return to Washington and advise that the policy be re-evaluated. 
 "I'm going back with a view that a policy review is necessary," Mr. Shattuck told reporters at a news conference shortly before leaving Haiti.
Mr. Shattuck did not say what the alternatives might be but said a fact-finding mission would precede any changes.
The announcement came on the same day that the United States returned 110 boat people, the third boatload to be sent back to Port-au-Prince in a week. The recent increase in the number of boats picked up heading for Florida has prompted fears that a mass exodus may be imminent, similar to the one that came after the overthrow of the country's President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
The forced repatriation order of May 1992 stemmed the tide of flimsy, overloaded boats but American officials fear increased repression, especially in the provinces, may force more and more Haitians to take to the seas. Almost 40,000 Haitians have attempted the trip since the September 1991 coup.
Haitians' discontent with the current political climate has also been illustrated by the huge jump in the numbers seeking asylum at refugee-processing offices.
Mr. Shattuck said the deteriorating situation may cause the United States to seek a broader means for assuring that those with legitimate claims for asylum receive consideration.
A relatively low percentage are accepted under the present program and officials say many of those applying do so for economic, not political reasons. Applications have more than tripled in recent weeks, with many applicants blaming a stepped-up campaign of violence by the army.
Reports of repression surged at the end of October as the military and its civilian allies used all means to block the scheduled return of Father Aristide. Under an accord negotiated at the United Nations, Father Aristide had been scheduled to reassume the presidency on Oct. 30, but the plan was aborted after the army leader, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, failed to honor his promise to resign.
Father Aristide, a leftist priest elected with more than two-thirds of the vote, is living in exile in Washington.
Necker Dessables, head of the Roman Catholic church's human rights organization, Justice and Peace, said that if the military does not yield "people will continue to try to leave to save their lives," adding "most people are leaving because of the repression."

Haiti's Rulers Get New Warning
 PARIS, Dec. 14 (Special to The New York Times) -- The United States, France, Canada and Venezuela warned Haiti's military rulers today that they would face tougher United Nations sanctions unless they restored democracy and permitted the return of the country's ousted President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
The four governments, which comprise the so-called "Friends of the Secretary General" group on Haiti at the United Nations, said the new measures could include imposition of a universal and mandatory trade embargo as well as a ban on noncommercial flights in and out of the country.
After a two-day meeting here, they also announced the dispatch of a high-level mission, including military officers, to Haiti "to transmit this message of resolute determination to the Haitian military authorities." But the four did not say when the additional sanctions could go into effect.
Western diplomats said the idea of banning noncommercial flights in and out of Haiti was to make it more difficult for international drug traffickers to use the country as a refueling stop for small aircraft heading from South America to the United States.
