HEADLINE: Picking a Class of '98: The Early Returns Are In

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
After an 11-day struggle that started on Dec. 3, the admissions team at Brown University began assembling the class of 1998, selecting the first members from among the 1,975 high school seniors who applied last month for early-decision admission.
Today, Brown, like many universities across the country, is mailing out its acceptances, deferrals and rejections to these applicants. Of them, 535, or 25 percent, have been accepted, 15 percent rejected and 60 percent held over for consideration in the spring, when they will have to compete with 20,000 other applicants for the remaining 2,000 acceptance spots. About half will go elsewhere, leaving an entering class of about 1,350. 
 The admissions committee opened the process to a reporter on the condition that the applicants' names not be used, though their qualifications could be described. Among them were these four:
*A young woman from Westchester County who had Scholastic Assessment Tests scores of over 1,400 but who had so-so recommendations from her teachers and wrote a personal essay considered prosaic.
*A four-time class president from North Carolina whose test scores were low for Brown.
*The son of two Brown alumni from a wealthy suburb of Albany. He had respectable, but not outstanding, test scores.
*A young woman from Queens with brilliant test scores. Final action on her application was delayed by the dean of admission because of her personal essay.
Like many universities, Brown offers the early-decision option to high school seniors who apply by early November and who say they are sure of their first choice of college. For these students, the institutions agree to act on their applications by Dec. 15, leaving students a couple of weeks to meet the Jan. 1 deadline for regular admission elsewhere. Brown, like Harvard, Yale and Princeton, does not make early acceptance binding.
For the universities, the early-decision option creates an opportunity to cement their relationship with superior students in a highly competitive market. For the students, the option may provide a better chance to receive financial aid when the coffers are relatively full. Brown's total cost, on a par with the other Ivy League universities, is $24,618 a year. More than half pay the full amount; the average scholarship is $11,500.
In recent years, Brown, like many other elite colleges, has dropped its long-standing policy of considering applicants for admission without regard to their ability to pay. Previously, if an applicant had been accepted the means would always be found to meet the student's financial need.
Because of difficult economic times and, in the case of Brown, the fact that its endowment of $643 million remains the lowest of any Ivy League institution, the need-blind admission policy could not be sustained.
 
Scramble for Money
 Dean Eric Widmer, the college's admissions officer, said last week that the scramble for money mainly takes place in the spring, after the annual financial aid budget of $24 million had been dipped into repeatedly. Students who apply for early-decision admission do not face such a scramble. "It's only in the last few cases," Dean Widmer said, "that an applicant's need for scholarship assistance may work to his or her disadvantage."
In fairness, experts in higher education point out that many other institutions are less forthright about this matter than Brown. In addition, some colleges practice what is called admit-deny, in which the applicant is admitted but the request for financial aid is denied.
The work of Brown's admissions staff got under way on Dec. 3, when Dean Widmer, 53, who has been dean of admission and financial aid since 1988, summoned 10 admissions officers to the ornate committee room of the 19th-century mansion where the admissions office is housed.
In front of each officer was a three-inch stack of computer print-outs that listed each of the 1,975 candidates for early-decision admission to the Providence, R.I., campus and a quantity of coded information about them. M40 signified Asian-American, for example; M11 meant African descent, and L indicated a "legacy," meaning that a parent, aunt, uncle or cousin attended Brown. These notations are all pluses in an application. Thirty percent of Brown's students are from minorities, and the school is committed to sustaining that percentage.
Only rarely had applicants been interviewed. Decisions were based on S.A.T. scores, grade point average, class rank, recommendations from teachers, a hand-written essay on "who you are and how you think" and anything else that would disclose, in Dean Widmer's words, "the sentient human being behind the application."
Each admission officer made a recommendation about candidates from the geographical areas for which the officer was responsible, spelling out the pros and cons of each applicant, and, except in the most obvious cases, the officer, or presenter, was questioned sharply. Sometimes spirited debate followed with remarks such as these:
"Her teachers say she's an intellectual powerhouse."
"He retains information, but has no creativity."
"Academically, he can't cut it."
Dean Widmer gave his associates their head, only occasionally steering the discussion with low-key remarks like "I'm waiting to be inspired," or "I'm beginning to hear, 'Hold Over.' "
 
'She Can Even Juggle'
 The discussion of the application by the young woman from Westchester consumed half an hour. Her S.A.T. scores and grade point average are "out of sight," the presenter began. The presenter added: "She's a very successful student. She can even juggle, but when I look at her recommendations I say, 'Yuk!' "
Another officer concurred, "She has no real sense of engagement."
The discussion reversed course when one officer observed that the woman's application would have been stronger had she asked different teachers to write her recommendations. "Her guidance counselor," he said, "quotes a teacher who says her love of language is lyrical, and he himself says she's the brightest student he's ever worked with."
Someone else said, "Here's a case where we have to dig deeper into the application to find out what's really there."
Finally, Dean Widmer said: "She seems to have the intelligence to succeed. The chair proposes A," meaning accept.
She was in.
When the class president's turn came, the presenter explained his low verbal test scores. "His parents run a restaurant, and they speak Korean at home," she said. "But he's been elected class president every year. I like him."
The discussion seesawed until Dean Widmer supported the presenter. "It's tough for us to get kids out of North Carolina," he said. "Duke is there. Sure, we're doing something for the candidate, but also for ourselves and our future in that part of the country."
Another "A."
 
Fighting Back Tears
 "I can't make much of an argument for this kid," began the officer who presented the alumni's son. "Grades and tests are nice and solid, and both parents went here, but there's nothing special."
"Looks mediocre," said another.
"He's not in any way a unique personality," somebody else said.
"This is hard," said the presenter. "But let's hold over. He'll be around in the spring if we want him then."
When the young woman from Queens was presented, it was immediately clear that she would be accepted. Her tests scores, grade point average and recommendations were dazzling. What delayed action was Dean Widmer's desire to have all of his colleagues read her essay.
When they did, at least one admissions officer was fighting back tears.
The woman, who is black, began her essay in a bold hand by saying that returning to her impoverished community as a doctor was her "most precious dream." Then last summer, she continued, she became frightened when she learned that her 45-year-old mother, who is burdened with the care of an autistic child, had become pregnant.
Two days before her 17th birthday, the woman wrote, she had overcome her fear and held her mother's hand as she helped her mother deliver the child.
As a result, she wrote, she came to understand that as a doctor she could be not only a life saver but "a life giver."
Slowly -- sometimes agonizingly -- the class of 1998 is taking shape.

SECTION: Section B; Page 8; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Head of Failing S.& L. Helped Clinton Pay a $50,000 Personal Debt in 1985

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH with STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
The owner of a failing Arkansas savings and loan association raised money for Gov. Bill Clinton in 1985 to help relieve the Clinton family of a $50,000 personal debt that the Clintons would otherwise have had trouble repaying, newly discovered documents show.
The disclosure that the money covered a heavy private debt, rather than a less personally onerous campaign obligation, shows that the savings and loan executive, James McDougal, performed a more valuable favor for Mr. Clinton than has been previously known. 
 Federal investigators and Congressional officials are looking into the costly collapse of Mr. McDougal's savings and loan, and one aspect of the inquiries is whether his friendship with the Governor influenced the state regulatory treatment he received.
The Government took over the institution, Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan, in 1989 at a cost to taxpayers of more than $60 million. That was five years after Federal regulators first found numerous violations at Madison and three years after they acted to remove Mr. McDougal.
Three months before Mr. McDougal helped Mr. Clinton cover his debt, the Governor had appointed as the new state regulator in charge of savings and loans a Little Rock lawyer who had previously represented Mr. McDougal's troubled institution.
Over the next 18 months, up to the point where Federal officials removed Mr. McDougal, the new regulator took no significant action against Madison, even as she was moving vigorously against another failing institution with similar problems.
Bruce Lindsey, a senior Presidential adviser chosen by the White House to respond to questions about Mr. McDougal, said today that the relationship between the Clintons and the savings and loan owner had been entirely proper.
But Mr. Lindsey said he was unable to answer specific questions about the $50,000 debt or its repayment. As for the appointment of the regulator, Beverly Bassett Schaffer, he said, "The President felt she was a respected securities attorney and turned out to be a respected securities commissioner."
 
$50,000 Loan From Aide's Bank
 A Federal investigation uncovered evidence some time ago that Mr. McDougal had diverted money from his institution to help repay debts left over from Mr. Clinton's 1984 re-election campaign.
But the newly discovered documents, and interviews with onetime political aides to Mr. Clinton, show for the first time that the campaign's only debt was to Mr. Clinton, who had contributed $50,000 to help finance his own candidacy. Mr. Clinton borrowed the money from the tiny Bank of Cherry Valley, which was owned and run by a senior aide to the Governor.
By borrowing the money and giving it to his campaign, Mr. Clinton was incurring a liability that his financial records suggest he barely could have met without help.
Just a few weeks after Mr. McDougal raised the money for him, Madison Guaranty won approval from Mrs. Schaffer, Mr. Clinton's new financial regulator, for a novel plan to sell stock. And Federal investigators have learned that Mrs. Schaffer previously served for a short time as one of Madison's lawyers.
In her legal work, the investigators say, she gained inside knowledge of some of Madison's wrongdoing. Yet when she became a regulator, she never told her subordinates that she had worked for Madison, present and former state officials say. And she continued to make decisions about the institution despite state ethics guidelines that, according to leading ethics experts in Arkansas and nationally, suggest she should have stepped aside.
Mrs. Schaffer, now a lawyer in Arkansas, denied in an interview that Madison had received preferential treatment and said her predecessor in the post had allowed Madison to pursue risky investments. She said Mr. Clinton had not intervened on behalf of Madison, adding of her own role: "I didn't try to protect anyone. And I didn't try to hurt anyone."
In an interview last year, Mr. McDougal said the appointment of Mrs. Schaffer and his role in retiring the campaign debt were part of a relationship in which he and Mr. Clinton had done favors for each other. Mrs. Schaffer was his preferred candidate for the post of regulator, he said.
By 1985, however, he had come to resent Mr. Clinton's requests for help on such matters as the campaign debt, Mr. McDougal said.
"I was beginning to feel I was getting used," he said. "I would have gotten Bassett anyways," he said of Mrs. Schaffer.
 
Rapid Growth, 'Willful' Violations
 Mr. McDougal's relationship with Mr. Clinton dates from the 1960's, when they met while working as aides to Senator J. W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas.
Mr. McDougal later served for a year as Governor Clinton's economic development aide, then left government and in 1982 bought a savings and loan in Augusta, Ark., a sleepy rural town. The institution, Madison Guaranty, quickly got caught up in the go-go ethos of the early 1980's. Its growth was exponential, from assets of $3 million to more than $120 million by 1985.
Federal auditors took a dim view of Mr. McDougal's activities. A 1984 review found "unsafe and unsound lending practices" and concluded that "the viability of the institution is jeopardized."
Mr. McDougal promised to make amends, and state and Federal regulators eventually allowed him to go forward, provided he made adjustments to his books and obtained required state approval for several large real estate projects.
One of those was a project to sell land on a foggy Canadian island off the coast of Maine. In violation of Federal land law, Madison had sold scores of lots without making disclosure of risks to purchasers and had failed to register any such disclosure statement with the Department of Housing and Urban Development, according to state and Federal records and former Madison officials.
Madison's lawyers learned of these omissions in 1984. Mrs. Schaffer, then at the Little Rock firm of Mitchell, Williams, Selig, Jackson & Tucker, wrote a memo describing the failure to comply with land law as "willful," Federal officials say.
Madison registered with HUD in February 1985 and began providing buyers the federally required disclosure on the project's considerable risks. One year later, roughly half the buyers of Canadian lots had canceled their purchases, increasing Madison's losses and pushing it to the brink of insolvency, according to a 1986 Federal examination of the institution.
As Mr. McDougal faced questions from Federal regulators, Mr. Clinton was gearing up for his 1984 re-election campaign for governor. By the fall of 1984, he had raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for the drive, and polls showed him comfortably ahead.
Still, in the final week Mr. Clinton put himself at significant personal financial risk to inject an additional $50,000 into the coffers. He and his wife, Hillary, applied for a loan from the Bank of Cherry Valley, a tiny institution in northeast Arkansas then run by W. Maurice Smith, who was also a senior aide to the Governor.
Mr. Smith said in an interview that the loan had been unsecured, meaning that the Clintons had not been required to pledge any collateral and would repay the loan on the basis of their joint income. According to the Clintons' tax returns, their combined income in 1984 and 1985 was about $100,000 a year.
Further, they had only modest personal assets. They did not own a home, and they had substantial debts. Records released by the Clinton Presidential campaign in 1992 show that in 1984, the couple owed more than $75,000 in bank loans stemming from their investment in Whitewater Development, an unsuccessful real estate company that they owned jointly with Mr. McDougal and his wife.
Asked whether he was aware of the Clintons' debts when he approved the loan, Mr. Smith said that "if it was in their financial statement" that they filed with the bank as a requirement for the loan, then "I knew about it."
 
A Spring Evening Worth $35,000
 In January 1985, Mr. Clinton named Mrs. Schaffer as head of the State Securities Department, the Arkansas agency that shared with Federal regulators the responsibility for overseeing state-chartered savings and loan associations.
Separately, his political aides began raising tens of thousands of dollars for his 1986 re-election bid. At the same time, according to Mr. McDougal and Betsey Wright, who had managed the 1984 campaign, Mr. Clinton asked Mr. McDougal to take care of the debt still left over from 1984.
"He asked me to knock out the deficit," Mr. McDougal recalled.
In the spring of 1985, Mr. McDougal held an early-evening fund-raising event at Madison's office in Little Rock, near the governor's mansion. There, he says, he delivered about $35,000 in checks to Ms. Wright.
The records reflecting the contributions from the fund-raiser are missing from campaign documents on file with the Pulaski County clerk in Little Rock. But among the documents that are on file there are those listing Mr. Clinton's $50,000 contribution to his own campaign.
Investigators reviewing Madison's records in the wake of its collapse found evidence that led them to suspect that some of the campaign donations assembled by Mr. McDougal had been improperly diverted from the savings and loan, Federal officials have said.
The investigators traced checks totaling $12,000 from Madison to the Clinton campaign's account at the Bank of Cherry Valley. Those checks were issued on April 4.
The day before, senior Madison officials met in Dallas with Federal regulators who wanted to know how the savings and loan intended to meet minimum requirements for capital. Madison said it planned to raise the money by selling stock, according to a Federal memo describing the meeting. The institution planned to issue preferred stock, the sale of which had rarely, if ever, been attempted by an Arkansas savings and loan.
The search for new capital took Madison to the offices of Mrs. Schaffer, who had the ultimate authority to approve any such stock sale. One of the lawyers employed by Madison to argue its case before the state regulators was Mrs. Clinton.
Within weeks, Mrs. Schaffer wrote a letter to Mrs. Clinton giving preliminary approval to Madison's stock plan.
The sale never went forward. But this fall the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency that disposes of failed savings and loans, asked the Justice Department to examine a number of Madison's transactions, and Federal officials say the state's approval of the stock plan was among the matters raised by investigators.
The R.T.C. noted that Mrs. Schaffer's approval of the stock sale had come in the face of her own, prior knowledge that Madison had failed to comply with Federal land-sale laws.
Mrs. Schaffer says that even in not stepping aside in matters involving Madison, she acted properly. Citing lawyer-client confidentiality, she declines to discuss what she learned when she represented Madison. Whatever she learned, she now says, did not seem important later, when she became a state regulator.
 
2 Institutions, 2 Approaches
 Mr. McDougal, who was acquitted of Federal bank fraud charges in 1990, maintains he did nothing wrong. He blames overzealous regulators for his problems.
But a blistering Federal report in 1986, three years before Madison was seized, found that records were missing or inaccurate, that the institution was probably insolvent and that millions of dollars had been improperly diverted to Mr. McDougal, his friends and his family.
State records show that from 1984 to 1986, as Madison hurtled toward collapse, Arkansas regulators imposed no special requirements on it. The state's only action against Madison was to concur when Federal regulators removed Mr. McDougal in the summer of 1986.
But Arkansas regulators were not hesitant to move against another failing institution.
Mrs. Schaffer said she had urged Federal regulators to shut down Guaranty Savings and Loan, a $450 million institution based in northern Arkansas that was closed in December 1985. She said the problems at Guaranty had been growth that was too rapid, bad loans outside of Arkansas and reliance on large deposits brokered by other financial institutions -- virtually the same problems that regulators found at Madison.
Mrs. Schaffer said she had moved against Madison as soon as legally possible, relying on her own staff and acting in conjunction with Federal regulators. Even looking back now, she said, "I don't see what I could have done differently."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

STRUGGLING TO RETAIN BIOTECH COMPANIES
Innovir Laboratories, a company seeking cures for hepatitis, leukemia and other maladies, plans to leave New York City. The move reflects the problem city and state planners, who have identified biotechnology as one of New York's most promising industries, have had attracting and keeping biotechnology companies. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 

LEADER IN KILLINGS IN THE WORKPLACE
Nearly half the deaths on the job in the New York metropolitan region last year were caused by homicides, a far higher percentage than in any other big urban area, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics found. B3.
 
LETTER LINKED TO FIGURE IN BLAST TRIAL
The text of a letter warning that the World Trade Center would continue to be a target if "our demands are not met" was presented as evidence by prosecutors in the trade center bombing trial and linked to one of the defendants, Nidal A. Ayyad. B3.
Mayor Dinkins postponed signing a lease for expansion of the National Tennis Center. B3.

Her New York is again in chaos, with new staff members and complaints over money. D24.
 
REGION
 
'DAD'S GONE,' SON IS TOLD
Carolyn McCarthy could not be sure how much her son remembered of what happened on the night of the shooting on the Long Island Rail Road. So when 26-year-old Kevin McCarthy began asking about his father from his bed at the hospital in Manhasset, his mother was at something of a loss. B6.
 
STATE'S ROLE AS GUN DEALER IS CRITICIZED
New York State agencies sold or traded more than 6,800 guns to licensed gun dealers over the last five years, at least one of which might have been used in the commission of a crime. The transactions, which are detailed in a report released by Republican Assembly members, are likely to fuel an emerging national debate. B6.
 
COMPANY ACCUSED OF FUSE SALES TO IRAQ
Rexon Technology Corporation of Wayne, N.J., and its top officers were charged with violating Federal arms-export laws by participating in an illegal plan to provide Iraq with 300,000 fuse systems for artillery shells. B6.
 
ENCOUNTERS WITH DRUNKEN DRIVERS
Drunken driving kills at a rate of about 18,000 people a year. At this time of year, holiday parties with alcohol increase the risk. So, to raise public awareness, public safety officials held a "Celebration of Life" at which survivors, with scars visible and invisible, told their stories. B6.
 
CLAIM OF RIGHTS VIOLATION IS REJECTED
A Federal judge ruled that a Rockland County village had not violated the housing rights of Orthodox and Hasidic Jews by attempting to place zoning restrictions on the establishment of small synagogues in private homes. B5.

HEADLINE: THE RUSSIAN VOTE;
RESULTS IN RUSSIA SHAKE WASHINGTON

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Despite their confident public comments, President Clinton and senior officials in his Administration were "startled and shaken," one of them conceded today, by the results of Sunday's parliamentary voting in Russia.
Several said that while it was not clear precisely how American policy would change toward Russia, the other former states of the Soviet Union and the former Soviet satellites, it was clear that the policy would have to be rethought. At a minimum, several officials said, Mr. Clinton will have to find some way to ease the exclusive identification of American policy in the region with the success of the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin. 
 "We don't want to look in any way as if we're dumping Yeltsin and moving toward the fascists," a State Department expert said, referring to the ultranationalists who ran surprisingly strongly on Sunday, "but we need to find some way to take account of them and to strengthen contacts with them."
 
Reform Program's Future
 In Moscow, a senior official accompanying Vice President Al Gore on his current trip in the area said that strong nationalist and Communist blocs in the new Russian Parliament could slow Mr. Yeltsin's reform program and force a change in American aid plans.
"If this result holds, it's very bad," the official commented.
Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said he viewed the ultranationalists with alarm but was not sure how strong they would be once a decisive result had emerged from the complex Russian electoral system.
He said Congress would continue to support substantial American aid for Russia as long as the general trend seemed to move in the direction of reform, even if there were setbacks. But on the other hand, he warned, "if Russia moves decisively or even modestly" in the nationalists' direction, "Congress will either be less supportive or just won't approve any aid."
Today's on-the-record comments by the Administration had a bit more bite than Monday's, although President Clinton continued to speak of "a protest vote" that was not very surprising, given the Russian people's "high level of anger because they've been through a lot of tough times."
 
Nationalist Assailed
 Michael McCurry, the State Department spokesman, delivered a scathing indictment of Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, the nationalist leader propelled by the elections into the center of Russian politics. Mr. Zhirinovsky's statements, the spokesman said, "embody views that are obviously completely an anathema to principles of democracy, to our own views on issues like human rights and the democratic process, economic reform and relations among sovereign states."
Among the many things that will be complicated by the nationalists' success will be the President's planned trip next month to a North Atlantic Treaty Organization summit conference in Brussels, to Prague, to Moscow and to Minsk, the capital of Belarus.
"I have talked to nobody about anything," he said today when asked to discuss the trip. "I have not had time to think about it."
James H. Billington, the Librarian of Congress, who is one of the nation's leading students of Russia, said of Mr. Clinton's visit to Moscow:
"This is not going to be the victory celebration he had hoped for. We now have a very tough row to hoe there. Yeltsin and the reformers have behaved with staggering political ineptness, but they remain the real democrats in Russia, the people who have committed themselves to what we believe in. The danger now is that we might act in such a way as to insure what is now only a possibility, albeit a larger one than before -- the downfall of reform."
 
East Europeans Are Uneasy
 The President's stop in Brussels could be equally fraught. On the agenda for the meeting there is the question of enlarging NATO by admitting or promising eventually to admit Poland, the Czech and Slovak Republics and Hungary. The United States and western Europe have resisted the idea, arguing that such an action might make the Russians feel dangerously isolated.
But the eastern European nations, who have been pressing the West to reconsider, are sure to press harder now, given the renewed specter of Russian nationalism to the east.
Andrzej Olechowski, the Polish Foreign Minister, who is on a visit to Washington, said in an interview today that he thought Mr. Yeltsin would find it necessary to "find some accommodation with the nationalists and speak more about Russia's role in the world -- about Russia's sphere of influence."
"We were concerned until now," he said. "Now we are worried."
Some analysts of the region think that the United States now runs the danger of letting Moscow's fears deform its policies in the rest of the area.
"At a certain point, enough's enough," said Robert Zoellick, a key figure in the State Department in the Bush Administration. "We need a more unified approach, because we shouldn't allow Russia to dominate the attitude of the United States to central and eastern Europe. Sooner or later, if we do, we will be accused of another Yalta sellout and all of that."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD TRADE AGREEMENT: The Overview;
U.S. AND EUROPE CLEAR THE WAY FOR A WORLD ACCORD ON TRADE, SETTING ASIDE MAJOR DISPUTES

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 14

 BODY:
The United States and Europe agreed to put aside major trade disputes today, clearing the way for a world trade accord covering more industries in more countries than any other trade agreement in history.
Though the negotiations involved 117 countries, the major sticking points lay between the United States and the European Community, principally over agricultural issues and greater access for American films and television programs in Europe. Seven years of talks had resolved some of them, notably some of the farm-subsidy disputes. 
 But in the end, the two sides were compelled to agree to disagree over some of the thorniest issues: movies, television and music; civil aircraft, and shipping and financial services like banking and stock brokerage.
 
Less Than Hoped For
 Therefore, while the overall pact includes some industries that have never before been covered in a world trade agreement, the accord is smaller in scope than intended and may bear the seeds of future trade wars.
The agreement would reduce tariffs by a third, on average, over six years, and bring industries like accounting and farming into the purview of global trade agreements for the first time. Worldwide, tariffs on manufactured goods average only about 5 percent, but they add up to billions of dollars a year.
As the first world trade accord since 1979, it is expected to provide a quick boost to investment and business activity through much of the world by opening markets for goods and services and encouraging countries to specialize in producing whatever they can make most efficiently and exporting those products.
 
Clinton Is Guardedly Optimistic
 President Clinton hailed the pact today.
"The stakes are immense," the President said. "This would be the single largest trade agreement ever. It writes new rules of the road for world trade well into the next century."
Although Mr. Clinton cautioned that "thorny issues remain," he said the United States was "on the verge of a historic victory."
At the end, the thorniest issues involved cultural trade and access between the United States and Europe, and today, the American film industry expressed heavy reservations that its needs had been deferred.
But the President's deputy national security adviser, Samuel I. Berger, said the agreement signaled Mr. Clinton's success in elevating "national economics to the top echelon of American foreign policy, to put international economics on the front burner of American foreign policy."
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the Council of Economic Advisers, said the United States would probably gain $100 billion to $200 billion a year in new output as a result of the agreement.
Carla A. Hills, who as President George Bush's trade representative had sought a much broader package, said tonight that the Clinton Administration might have done the right thing by accepting what could be agreed upon and postponing the rest.
"I believe that you have to compare what was achieved with the status quo," she said.
As with the North American Free Trade Agreement, the GATT accord must be approved by Congress, but American officials won many changes during the final days of the talks to address concerns on Capitol Hill. Mr. Clinton is expected to notify the House and the Senate on Wednesday that the United States will sign the accord on April 15.
Senator Max S. Baucus, Democrat of Montana, who heads the Senate Finance subcommittee on trade, said today that while the pact would face some criticism in Congress, "I believe the agreement will ultimately be approved."
 
U.S. Industry Not Delighted
 But the American movie and television industries responded angrily to the Europeans' refusal to budge on their limits and fees on American-made programming.
"I am disturbed by the refusal of the European Community to negotiate seriously," said Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America. He called the European stance "blatant protectionism."
Still, he praised the American decision to pull the issue out of the pact entirely, which preserves the Administration's right to take retaliatory measures, like raising tariffs on European wine or other goods.
A few details of the agreement remain to be worked out over the coming months, but Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, told reporters here today that he did not consider any of them significant. Among these are specific tariff cuts, rules for the occasional copying of patents and copyrights without permission from the owner, and the extent to which developing countries must open fabric and clothing markets in exchange for similar openings by richer nations.
The pact would modify the existing General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which has regulated most of the world's trade since 1948. This round of negotiations, begun in 1986 in Uruguay, is scheduled to end officially Wednesday about 5 P.M., but trade officials here said that Peter Sutherland, the Director General of GATT, might be forced to delay the final gavel for hours because of dissatisfaction among developing countries that they were not offered more concessions by the industrial nations.
 
Disparity With Poorer Nations
 One example of this disparity is that the United States and the European Community agreed to reduce their tariffs with each other by half, but agreed to cut their average tariffs on goods from the rest of the world by less than one-third.
It is conceivable that objections from developing countries might delay the conclusion of the talks, but that is considered unlikely and is not expected to affect the overall agreement.
The agreement is tentatively scheduled to take effect on July 1, 1995, allowing the 117 GATT nations a year and a half to approve it.
There is no minimum number of those 117 nations required for approval, and the pact goes into effect among all who sign it. The way out for those who wish a way out is by withdrawing their signatures, presumably because of legislative rejection in some cases.
 
Worldwide Approval Process
 In the meantime, subsidiary trade talks will continue for as long as a year as lawyers work out the precise legal language of the last-minute deals. Each country will also be formally committing itself to making specific changes in each of tens of thousands of categories of internationally traded goods.
Although the French had expressed concern that a further influx of American movies and television shows would overwhelm European national cultures, Mr. Valenti called this issue irrelevant. "The negotiation has nothing to do with culture unless European soap operas and game shows are the equivalent of Moliere," he said. "This is all about the hard business of money."
Privately, some international financial experts in Hollywood said Mr. Valenti had overstated the case. They said the agreement would not prove especially damaging because American films and television shows are so popular in Europe, and the use of tariffs and other taxes and levies to protect and promote local markets is common procedure.
But Glenn J. Gumpel, executive director of the Directors Guild of America, which represents more than 10,000 directors, said in a telephone interview from Geneva: "The results were exceedingly frustrating, disappointing. The Europeans led by the French had no bona fide intention of actually negotiating an agreement to cover the audio-visual issue within the GATT, other than in the most minimal terms. I don't think they ever came to the bargaining table."
Mr. Gumpel said there was no displeasure at all with President Clinton or Mr. Kantor, his trade representative. "Obviously, this was not a negotiation over one single issue or one single industry," he said. "No one on our side believed we should ask the President or Mickey Kantor to walk away from the GATT negotiations at this point after America has achieved what it reported in other areas and other industries."
Under legislation passed last summer, if President Clinton notifies Congress by Wednesday that he intends to sign the agreement, the House and Senate must vote yes or no, with no amendments allowed.
The April 15 signing ceremony is planned to be held in Marrakesh, Morocco.
Each country signing the agreement must lower its average tariff, which is a tax on imports, by a third for manufactured goods. Also, farm trade is included in a world trade agreement for the first time. The increases in government assistance to farmers that have drained national treasuries will be reversed. Subsidies for food exports will drop fastest, over a six-year period, beginning when the pact takes effect in 1995. Subsidies for domestic programs, like crop price supports, will also be reduced.
Tonnage limits on food imports, such as the very low United States quota for imported peanuts, which works out to half a dozen peanuts for each American each year, will be replaced with less restrictive tariffs on peanuts that would open the door a bit to imports.
Copyrights, patents and trademarks will all receive new international protection, as will cross-border investments. Preferential government purchasing practices, including some Federal, state and local "Buy America" rules, will be banned. A new international agency, the Multilateral Trade Organization, will replace the GATT Secretariat in reviewing violations of free trade rules and will have greater powers than the Secretariat to authorize international trade penalties, like higher tariffs, on countries that break the rules.
 
Extension to Services
 The pact will also take steps toward extending GATT rules to cover services, but these steps will be much more modest than anything envisioned when the current round of trade talks began in 1986.
The Uruguay Round's Final Act, as the pact is officially called, sets forth many principles calling for countries to write laws, regulations and licensing procedures that treat service companies of other nations the same as domestic ones. But countries have made only very modest commitments to change their rules to reflect these principles.
Mr. Kantor and Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's top trade official, agreed this morning that they would make no commitments whatsoever concerning movies, television programs and music recordings. The stickiest issues in the final days of talks had been the community's refusal to share the proceeds of levies on blank videocassettes and tapes, and its refusal to clarify limits on the broadcast of foreign films and television programs.
Sir Leon said at a news conference in Geneva that the community had been willing to discuss sharing the taxes that are collected in Europe on the sale of blank tapes, which are used by consumers to copy domestic and foreign entertainment without payment of royalties. But Mr. Kantor described Sir Leon's offer as inadequate because it set no time limit for these talks.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I believe the agreement will ultimately be approved," said Senator Max S. Baucus of Montana, who heads the Senate Finance subcommittee on trade. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times) (pg D18)
 
Chart: "The Shape of the Accord"
 
The Overview
Negotiators from the United States and 115 other nations agreed yesterday to reduce tariffs and rewrite the free trade rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the organization that has governed most international trade for 45 years.
The negotiations, the eighth round of talks to broaden the original postwar agreement, began seven years ago in Punta del Este, Uruguay, and became known as the Uruguay Round. One of its main goals was to expand GATT rules to cover trade in agriculture issues, and after years of dispute, the negotiators succeeded in reaching an agreement to phase down government subsidies and other market distortions and barriers in farm trade. The other goal was to expand rules to cover insurance, banking and other financial services, but here negotiators accomplished relatively little.
In order to conclude the talks, negotiators for the United States and the European Community, after battling intensively on cultural issues for a week or more, agreed yesterday to disagree on greater access to Europe for American movies, television and music, and on cutting European subsidies for commercial aircraft.
President Clinton is expected to notify the House and the Senate today that the United States will sign the world trade pact on April 15. By meeting the deadline, set by Congress last summer, the President retains "fast track authority -- the House and the Senate must decide on the GATT agreement by simple yes-or-no votes, without amendments.
The pact is tentatively scheduled to take effect on July 1, 1995.
 
What Is At Stake Stays The Same
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based consortium of 24 of the more prosperous nations, estimates that a successful completion of the trade talks would mean about $270 billion more in annual trade by the year 2002. The extra economic output would come from the more efficient use of labor, capital and other resources.
 Some American economists, industry groups and labor unions say that the proposed accord will channel most of the benefits to other countries, at least in the short run, and some economists question whether the overall gains have been overstated.
 But most economists believe that over the course of years, free trade allows each country to specialize in products that it can make most efficiently, trading them for products made more effeciently elsewhere.
 
The Basics
 
Tariffs
The 117 nations have agreed to reduce their tariffs by an average of one-third. The United States and the European Community will reach this average by cutting their tariffs on each other's goods in half, while cutting tariffs on goods from the rest of the world by much less. In addition, agricultural tariffs will be reduced by 36 percent in industrial nations and 24 percent in developing nations. Agricultural tariffs vary widely because they are often charged by the penny per kilogram or liter, rather than as a percentage of the product's value.
 
Quotas
These are limits on the quantity of imports, like American limits on the number of tons of imported peanuts. Previous talks have eliminated most manufacturing quotas except for textiles and finished apparel. The Urugay Round would eliminate this exception and also require countries to replace their extensive quotas or bans on farm imports with tariffs that provide comparable protection. Quotas are pervasive in international farm trade, and the United States imposes them on dairy products, peanuts and sugar. Some of the new tariffs could start as high as several hundred percent, and would gradually be reduced.
 
Intellectual Property
The agreement, as it now stands, requires that all countries, including developing ones, protect patents, copyrights, trade secrets and trademarks. For years, pirated computer programs, record albums, videocassettes and prescription drugs have been available in developing countries.
 
A New Trade Organization
The current text would create an institution in Geneva to enforce GATT's free trade rules. The new institution would be much more powerful than the GATT Secretariat is now, having the power to assess trade penalties against countries by a vote of two-thirds or three-quarters of the nations. The Secretariat can act only when the members unanimously vote to do so - something that is rare.
 
Investment
The proposed text would ban the widespread practice of requiring high local content in some products like cars and of requiring factories to export as much as they import. The aim of that practice is to preserve local jobs and discourage imports. The proposed agreement would limit the ability of countries to favor domestically owned factories at the expense of foreign-owned ones.
 
Anti-dumping
American law bans foreign companies from selling goods here for less than they are sold in any other country, or for less than they cost to produce, a practice known as dumping. At the request of American companies, which must prove to the Government that dumping exists and has caused them financial harm, the Commerce Department and International Trade Commission periodically impose steep anti-dumping tariffs on imports. Until Sunday, the new pact would have barred many cases and reduced the tariffs in other cases. Changes made on Sunday at the United States' urging mean that cases will still be filled but the tariffs may be slightly smaller than before.
 
Health and Safety
The agreement bars countries from administering health and safety standards in ways that restrict trade and have no scientific basis. For example, a country that raised cattle without hormones could not use health grounds to ban imports of beef with hormones unless it could prove that the hormones were unsafe for human consumption.
 
Safeguards
Countries may temporarily raise tariffs or other import barriers an import surge causes rapid, severe damage to domestic producers. If a country keeps these temporary barriers in place for more than three years than countries losing sales have the right to impose retaliatory trade barriers.
 
MAJOR INDUSTRIES AFFECTED BY THE TALKS
 
Agriculture: The big dispute holding up the talks for the last three years has been a quarrel between the United States and the European Community over farm subsidies. Last year, the Untied States and the Europeans agreed to reduce the tonnage of subsidezed grain exports by 21 percent, and to limit other farm subsidies. But France, Europe's biggest agricultural exporter, wanted the subsidy deal renegotiated. Last week, in negotiations in Brussels, the United States tentatively agreed to allow the Europeans to subsidize more grain exports over the next six years than previously planned. In exchange, the Europeans tentatively agreed to convert some of their quotas on farm imports into low tariffs, as Washington demands.
 
Automobiles: Over the years, the United States and the European Community have each force Japan to accept limits on its auto exports. The current agreement text would virtually ban these restrictions. Each country would only be allowed one such export limit on any foreign industry, and Detroit car makers worry that they might not get the exemption.
 
Textiles and Apparel: The current text would phase out more prosperous nations' quotas on clothing imports over a 10-year period. The quotas would then be replaced by less restrictive tariffs. But only poor countries that reduced their own quotas on Western fabric and clothing imports would be allowed to take advantage of the phase-out.
 
MAJOR INDUSTRIES NOT AFFECTED BY THE TALKS
 
Aircraft: The United States and the European Community agreed today to continue talking for a year about how to limit government subsidies to civil aircraft makers. Meanwhile, a 1992 deal stays in effect that requires the European aviation consortium Airbus Industrie to reapy many European subsidies and limits indirect American subsidies in military contracts.
 
Audio-Visual. The United States and the European Community agreed today that while the final text of the trade accord contains broad principles espousing free trade in movies, TV programs and music recordings, neither side will put these principles into effect. Because the United States still objects to the Europeans' restrictions on the broadcast of American movies and television programs, further trade confrontations on this issue are likely.
 
Financial Services Companies. This covers commercial and investment banks, insurance and leasing companies, traveler's-check issuers and mortgage brokers. The pact sets forth broad principles calling for these companies to be allowed to do business around the world, but few nations are expected to put the principles into effect.
The United States currently limits the activities of many foreign financial services companies because their home countries do not give American companies access to their markets. The United States has agreed to accept license applications from any foreign financial services company for the first six months after the pact takes effect in mid-1995, but will dismiss these applications if their home countries do not open their financial markets during that time.
 
Shipping. The pact contains broad free trade principles, but the United States and the European Community have agreed to exempt all their current shipping-trade restrictions from these principles.
 
Steel. The United States and the Europeans agreed last week that they would keep talking next year about limiting European subsidies to steel makers.
 
Telecommunications. The United States and the European Community have agreed to continue talking about allowing telecommunications companies to offer long-distance telephone service and other services anywhere. Most European nations still have a giant telephone company like the old Bell System. (pg. D18)

HEADLINE: THE RUSSIAN VOTE;
Russian Nationalist Leader Offers To Cooperate in New Government

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 14

 BODY:
While Russia continued its painfully slow counting of votes from Sunday's election, its biggest vote-getter, the acerbic nationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, offered today to play a responsible part in any new government.
Appearing at a news conference in a black tuxedo, Mr. Zhirinovsky, who appears to have won nearly a quarter of the vote from a population angry with the price of change, was by turns reasonable and bombastic, promising to do nothing to destabilize the Government while he waits for a presidential election to be called.
 
Willing to Wait
 Even if President Boris N. Yeltsin completes his five-year term in June 1996, Mr. Zhirinovsky said, "then my election to that post would be a nice present for my 50th birthday." 
 His jauntiness was not shared by the reformist parties, which continued their angry hand-wringing and mutual accusations about who was to blame for the showing of Mr. Zhirinovsky and his Liberal Democratic Party, which favors a restored Russian empire, an end to Western-style economic reform and a harsh crackdown on crime.
Moskovsky Komsomolets, a liberal daily, had a banner headline that read: "Russia! Think About It! You Must Be Stupefied!" Vitaly Tretyakov, the editor of the independent Nezavisimaya Gazeta, urged the Government and Mr. Yeltsin "to try to assess the situation soberly" and "admit your mistakes."
Nor were Russia's neighbors any happier, with officials of the three formerly Soviet Baltic nations planning to meet on Wednesday to discuss Mr. Zhirinovsky's success and President Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine saying he was alarmed, especially at any prospect that Mr. Zhirinovsky's imperial reach could become state policy.
 
Parallel to Czarists Drawn
 "So many people voted for the Czarist empire," Mr. Kravchuk said today in Kiev. "We are talking here about revanchism."
[Despite confident public comments, President Clinton and senior officials in his Administration were "startled and shaken," one of them conceded, by the results of the parliamentary voting. Several said it was clear that American policy would have to be rethought. Page A18.]
Even though two days have passed since the election, it is still not possible to predict with certainty the power balance that will emerge in the new Parliament. No single party will have a majority, but if the Zhirinovsky nationalists unite with the Communists in a so-called brown-red coalition, they could command as much as 45 percent of the lower house, within striking distance of a working majority. That would be unsettling to the Western nations backing the new Russia.
It is also possible to conceive of coalitions in which the pro-Western, reform-minded parties might combine with centrists to control the new Parliament. In any event, the new legislature seems likely to be just as contentious as the old one that Mr. Yeltsin abolished, although this time it will lack the authority to block the President that the old one had.
In preliminary results from 68 of Russia's 89 regions, Mr. Zhirinovsky has won 24 percent of the party preference votes for the lower house of Parliament. These votes will be the basis for apportioning half of the lower house's 450 seats, with the rest filled by candidates elected from districts, as is the entire upper house.
 
Minimum Vote Needed for Seats
 If parties do not gain more than 5 percent of the national vote, they cannot win party-list seats and their seats are distributed among the other parties. So Mr. Zhirinovsky's 24 percent, if it holds up, would translate into about 67 seats, or 30 percent of the 225 seats at stake.
Second was the pro-Government Russia's Choice, led by First Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, with 13.66 percent of the votes and an estimated 38 party-list seats.
The revived Communist Party led by Gennadi A. Zyuganov was third with 11.65 percent, or about 31 seats, and their ideological ally, the Agrarian Party, came next with 9.59 percent, or about 29 seats.
The reformist parties appear to have done better in the district seats, which are being filled mostly by well-known local officials, who may dislike the reform but also dislike the radicals.
Still, a Yeltsin aide predicted that the reformists in the lower house would be outnumbered by the followers of Mr. Zhirinovsky, the Communists and the Agrarians, making the unpredictable centrists key players.
"Zhirinovsky is the bete noire du jour," a senior Western diplomat said. "But I wouldn't be surprised if the Communists and Agrarians together ended up with more seats than Zhirinovsky. Once the single seats are counted, the big concern will be a red-brown coalition."
 
Willing to Join a Coalition
 Mr. Zhirinovsky said today that he would work with anyone, either within the Government or outside it. "Let Yeltsin form any government he wants," Mr. Zhirinovsky said. "For the salvation of Russia, we are prepared to cooperate with Russia's Choice, with Communists, with anybody."
He did say that he would prefer a government without three top Yeltsin deputies: Mr. Gaidar, Privatization Minister Anatoly B. Chubais and Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev.
Mr. Gaidar again ruled out any deal with Mr. Zhirinovsky and urged a deepening of economic reform, but Mr. Zyuganov, the Communist leader, suggested that a deal with the Liberal Democrats might be possible if they dropped "everything connected to restoring the Russian empire," which he called "not serious or constructive."
"When someone calls us to form an alliance for Russia, we'll be there," Mr. Zyuganov added. But he indicated that he did not consider Russia's Choice to be for Russia.
"Gaidar is responsible for the destruction of the society," he said, "and we cannot back such a policy."
If the "red-browns" have a majority, the senior diplomat said, "the question becomes whether the democrats can really work together." But he cautioned that results from key areas of the country were still unknown.
The vote count is going so slowly that some responsible politicians are raising the prospect of fraud, especially on the question of the real turnout for the constitutional referendum. Yeltsin officials have repeatedly announced that the new Constitution received a majority of votes from the necessary 50 percent of the electorate.
 
Vote on Constitution Questioned
 But the figure for Russia's eligible voters keeps shrinking as the figures are released by the Central Electoral Commission and its Yeltsin-appointed head, Nikolai Ryabov. The figure has gone from 107 million to 106.3 million on Sunday to 105.284 million in today's Izvestia. Turnout is said to have been 52.3 percent of that last figure, and of the 55.987 million who are said to have voted, 29.337 million are said to have voted yes. While Yeltsin officials have said the yes vote was "around 60 percent," these figures indicate that it was only 52.4 percent.
The Communist leader, Mr. Zyuganov, said today that he thought the Constitution had not in fact received enough votes, a charge echoed in an interview today by Oleg D. Beznisko, the deputy chief of staff for Mr. Yavlinsky's bloc. "We have reasons to think less than 50 percent voted," he said.
But several diplomats said Mr. Yeltsin was very unlikely to acknowledge the invalidity of the constitutional referendum, if in fact it is invalid.
"A strong presidency in this Constitution is what saves Russia from Zhirinovsky," one Western diplomat said bluntly. "Yeltsin needs this Constitution, and in a way, so does everybody."
Asked if Western countries would now stop complaining about Mr. Yeltsin's apparently broken promise to hold a presidential vote in June instead of serving out his full term, the diplomat said, "We're not complaining."
In his news conference, Mr. Zhirinovsky ranged from Chinese astrology to the idea of inviting South African farmers, "who might be facing ethnic problems," to come live in Russia. He denied being anti-Semitic and said he envied the Jews, "the richest nation in the world." Pressed to address widespread speculaton that his father was Jewish, Mr. Zhirinovsky finally said that both his parents were "Russian."
He said voters had asked him to do something to reduce the number of "non-Russian announcers on the television" and replace them with "good, kind Slavic faces who can speak a good Russian without any accent."
Asked if he meant Jews, he yelled, "If people of a certain kind speak to the nation every day and every hour, this creates anti-Semitism!"
 
Explanation for Success
 Mr. Zhirinovsky explained his success by "our sincerity, openness and faithfulness." For many years, he said, "Russians have felt the way we do but had no chance to express those feelings. But thanks to the elections, we were able to speak openly and they could support us."
Ivan Rodin, writing in Nezavisimaya Gazeta, summarized a popular judgment: "A few years of tumultuous reforms -- political and economic -- have not changed Russians' liking for convinced leaders who promise quick change without great difficulty. Once Boris Yeltsin capitalized on this; now it's Vladimir Zhirinovsky's turn."
Some well-known names won seats in Parliament in votes tallied thus far. They include an ultranationalist television reporter from St. Petersburg, Aleksandr Nevzorov, who was removed from the air after calling for rebellion against Mr. Yeltsin; Yuri Vlasov, a former Olympic weightlifting champion and a nationalist, and the world chess champion, Garry Kasparov, a Russia's Choice supporter.

HEADLINE: In America;
Nurses On the Advance

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
Nurses have been moving steadily, relentlessly toward more autonomy and responsibility, advancing ever more boldly in the last few years into territory previously controlled by physicians. Now the doctors, feeling threatened, are counterattacking.
The issue is whether registered nurses with advanced training should be allowed to deliver primary health care on their own. Primary care refers to the first contact a patient has with the health care system. It's the basic, initial care that you receive when visiting a clinic or a doctor's office -- the care you get before being referred, if necessary, to a specialist. 
 Registered nurses have been delivering this kind of care for decades, but almost always under the supervision of doctors.
In recent years, however, nurses with advanced training -- such as nurse practitioners and nurse midwives -- have been moving toward greater independence. This has occurred as the country has experienced a growing shortage of primary-care physicians.
In many states, including New York, nurse practitioners are allowed to write prescriptions and to be reimbursed by third-party insurers. A growing number of health maintenance organizations are using nurses as primary care providers, and some nurse practitioners are going into practice on their own.
As long as the nurses were working for the doctors, there wasn't much of a problem. The nurses lightened the workload. They helped bolster profits. For routine visits, the doctor told the patient, in effect: "See the nurse, and have your insurance company send me a check."
Now the Clinton Administration, with its health reform package emphasizing primary care, has added its considerable weight to the move toward greater responsibility for advanced-practice nurses.
Hillary Rodham Clinton could not have been clearer last month when she told a group of Georgia physicians, "We are increasing the scope of practice opportunities for advanced-practice nurses because we don't have adequate numbers of primary-care practitioners in either the private or the public sector."
Last week the doctors struck back. The American Medical Association issued a report that could easily have been titled, "Enough Is Enough." It criticized virtually every argument on behalf of greater autonomy for nurses. "Quality medical care," the report said, "requires that a physician be responsible for the overall care of each and every patient."
The A.M.A. even rejected the idea that nursing care is less expensive than physician care. The report said, "There is no convincing evidence that nurses are the most cost effective health care providers."
That is particularly interesting when you consider that the average income for doctors last year was $170,600, while for nurse practitioners it was $43,600.
But the cornerstone of the doctors' argument is that nurses acting independently would be a threat to the health of their patients.
There does not seem to be any evidence at all for that argument.
Mary Mundinger, dean of Columbia University's School of Nursing, noted that nurse practitioners have been delivering primary care since 1965 and that hundreds of studies have examined the quality of their work, including their diagnostic ability and management effectiveness.
"There is not a single study that shows any lapses," said Ms. Mundinger, "and most of the studies have been done by physicians."
When asked if any studies had shown any problems with the quality of care delivered by advanced-practice nurses, Dr. Lonnie Bristow, the A.M.A.'s chairman, said: "No, certainly not. In fact, we believe the quality of care is quite good." But he stressed that the nurses studied had all worked with -- or for -- doctors.
Every team, he said, "needs a quarterback."
With health care costs creating economic havoc, it is not likely that doctors or anyone else will be able to slow the movement toward greater independence for advanced-practice nurses.
If nurses with special training are delivering high-quality health care at a reasonable cost, then we need a reason other than doctors' anxiety to stop them.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Don't Blame Slovakia for Gypsy Problem

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A report on Gypsies in Slovakia surprised me by its subjective approach and lack of objective information (some editions, Nov. 28). 
 You point to the $71 monthly welfare payment a Gypsy widow receives. It is necessary to compare the value of the dollar in Slovakia against its value in the United States. For example, the average income of one working person in Slovakia is $150 a month. Thus, $71 is quite adequate to sustain a moderate life style in Slovakia, compared with the United States.
You give the number of Gypsies in Slovakia incorrectly. According to the 1991 census, there are 80,000 Gypsies in Slovakia. Because of the number of Gypsies who did not respond to the census, experts estimate their population to be approximately 5 percent of Slovak inhabitants, totaling 250,000 Gypsies in the country and not, as you estimate, 400,000.
I find it inexplicable that you did not make any effort to give more information on Gypsies in Slovakia, except for personal impressions and descriptions of what was seen and heard in one village.
You did not mention, for example, that the Slovak Government supports Gypsy society with approximately 70 million Slovak crowns a year (average monthly income is about 4,500 crowns). The money is used for improving living standards in Gypsy villages, education and children's summer camps, including 3.6 million crowns for Gypsy periodicals, and 10.7 million crowns for Gypsy cultural activities.
The negative approach of some Slovak citizens toward Gypsies is not based on racial intolerance, but on a significant difference in life styles and standards. You failed to note, for example, that approximately 40 percent of all crimes are attributed to the Gypsy population, and that Gypsy teen-age criminality accounts for 40 percent to 50 percent of all youth cases in Slovakia each year. Similarly, the Gypsy population is plagued by a high percentage of alcoholism.
The Gypsy problem is not unique to Slovakia. It is common to most states of Europe. Slovak efforts to solve the problem through special programs and policies are being coordinated with the European Community.
The situation in Slovakia is not simple. Yet the Slovak economy, now rid of the old Communist regime, is based on a free market system, which is increasingly stabilizing.
The free market in Slovakia has created a market for labor. Only the most qualified and hard-working citizens can be employed, as in all democratic free market economies. The Slovak Government aims to create the same opportunities for all citizens.
 
MONIKA NEMCOKOVA
Press Secretary, Slovak Embassy
Washington, Dec. 10, 1993

HEADLINE: THE WORLD TRADE AGREEMENT: U.S. AND EUROPE CLEAR THE WAY FOR A WORLD ACCORD ON TRADE, SETTING ASIDE MAJOR DISPUTES;
How Free Trade Prompts Growth: A Primer

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Free trade means growth. Free trade means growth. Free trade means growth. Just say it 50 more times and all doubts will melt away.
Those who dutifully followed the debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement and are now struggling to figure out what the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has to do with the price of peas in Peoria may be excused for a dash of skepticism about a link that is more often asserted than explained. It is, in fact, one of the most widely held yet most difficult to prove ideas in economics. 
 In the end, the nearly universal conviction that open trade drives global prosperity rests more on observation than on well-developed theory: "We all noticed that the countries doing well were exporting like crazy," said Stanley Fischer, the World Bank's former chief economist.
College instructors love to illustrate the British economist David Ricardo's insight about the gains from free trade with a story about Woodrow Wilson. President Wilson, they say, could type faster than his secretary. But it made sense to leave the White House correspondence to others so he could concentrate on making the world safe for democracy and other higher-productivity endeavors.
 
A Victorian Example
 By this same rule of "comparative advantage," it made economic sense for Victorian England to break the political influence of its cosseted farmers by opening its borders to wheat from central Europe and North America. That allowed entrepreneurs to focus more capital and labor on manufacturing, where it could (and did) make Britain the richest country on earth.
These gains from economic specialization are still nothing to sneeze at. The World Bank estimates that in 1985 free trade in dairy foods would have lowered average prices by two-thirds and doubled global output. All told, free trade in grain, meat, milk and sugar would have added $40 billion to world income -- mostly by shifting production away from Western Europe and toward lower cost producers.
And the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development calculates that the combination of reduced tariffs and more generous import quotas penciled into the new GATT accord would increase world income by $270 billion annually by the turn of the century.
Big as these numbers are, though, they are modest compared with the total world output, which will probably exceed $30 trillion a decade hence. And even if one imagined free trade nirvana in which shirts sewn in Jakarta could be sold as freely in Seattle as shirts made on Seventh Avenue, the direct impact of the resulting global specialization of production would not be overwhelming.
Gary Hufbauer and Tim Elliott of the Institute for International Economics in Washington estimate that free trade would add about 1 percent to the average American's income.
Why, then, is Sebastian Edwards, a development specialist at the University of California at Los Angeles, convinced that "free trade is the cornerstone to modern economic systems?" Because it does not take an econometrician to tell which way the winds of prosperity have been blowing.
In the 1890's, Argentina had roughly the same income per person as the United States and seemed as well endowed with resources, both human and physical. A century of protectionism, though, left Argentina with hundreds of inefficient industries serving only local markets and a living standard roughly a third as high as that of the colossus to the north.
 
Asian Comparisons
 Or compare the economies of Asia that stumbled into the 1960's in more or less wretched condition. Those that focused on the expansion of trade (Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Malaysia) have done very well. Those that tried to develop by pushing for self-sufficiency (India, Vietnam, Myanmar, North Korea) have done very badly. And those that came late to the open trade game but are now big players (Indonesia, China) seem to be on their way to a chicken in every wok.
In the end such comparisons may be the only hard evidence that economists have. But it has not stopped them from speculation about the inner workings of the machinery translating trade into growth.
The puckish explanation, suggests Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is that the relationship is, in fact, specious, that cause has been confused with effect.
Countries ready to grow may be more inclined to gravitate toward open trade. More specifically, the cultural values that seem to underpin growth -- thrift, rule of law, respect for property rights, fiscal discipline -- may also create political systems that are better at defending the interests of efficient, export-minded producers against those of groups demanding a free economic ride.
Certainly the view of the overwhelming majority of economists, though, is that trade kindles growth. "Trade is a vehicle for technology transfer," Mr. Fischer points out, flashing what many see as the free traders' trump card. The successful Asian economies that protect local producers of consumer goods, he notes, have been careful to permit easy access to modern foreign equipment and materials.
What's more, openness to imports generally pays greater dividends than access to faster computers and tougher plastics. It also offers the chance to "learn by looking," suggests Mr. Edwards -- "to be exposed to foreign ideas on a massive basis."
Trade is also a source of competition for would-be local monopolists, keeping prices down and disciplining the locals to reduce waste. And it can have a critical impact on competition out in less obvious ways. "Without the Japanese to lead the way on quality control and fit and finish," argues Robert Crandall of the Brookings Institution, it is hard to imagine Detroit would have pulled up its socks.
 
The 'British Disease'
 Mancur Olson, the director of the Center on Institutional Reform and the Informal Sector at the University of Maryland, offers another connection between trade and competition-spurred growth. In every economy special interests are organizing to slow change, he suggests, creating sinecures for themselves and generally preventing boat-rocking innovation. This, he believes, goes a long way toward explaining the failure of many poor countries to grow and the tendency of industrialized countries to catch what has come to be known as "the British disease."
But economic systems can be made more resistant to the infection by increasing the number of actors -- companies, unions, property owners -- who must be organized and kept in line in order to stifle competition. "The smaller the economy," Mr. Mancur reasons, "the greater the likelihood of successful collusion."
Thus, he explains, expanding the economic borders of economies helps, as in the case of the European Community or the North American Free Trade Agreement, "But global free trade helps even more."
 A news analysis article in Business Day yesterday about the agreement referred incorrectly in some copies to the number of participating nations. There are 117, not 116.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 16, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page chart yesterday about the highlights of the world trade agreement referred incorrectly in some editions to the timetable for its approval by Congress. The agreement requires the President's signature by April 15; he may submit it to Congress at any time after signing it. The pact is scheduled to go into effect July 1, 1995. If Congress has not approved it by then, the United States will be vulnerable to trade sanctions.
A related front-page article yesterday about how free trade promotes growth misstated the first name of an economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. She is Kim Elliott, not Tim.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Highlights"
 
The United States and 116 other nations agreed to substantially reduce tariffs and rewrite the free trade rules that have governed most international commerce for 45 years.
 
Changes: The United States and the European Community will cut their tariffs on each other's good in half. Tariffs on good from the rest of the world will be cut less. Agricultural tariffs will be reduced by 36 percent in industrial nations and 24 percent in developing nations.
 
Effects: The agreement is expected to boost business and investment activity by opening markets and encouraging countries to specialize in producing whatever goods they can make most efficiently.
 
Unresolved Issues: Negotiators could not reach agreement on free trade involving movies, television programs and music; civil aircraft; shipping and financial services like banking and stock brokerage. Rather than jeopardize reaching an agreement, the issues were put aside for the time being. They have the potential to fuel future trade disagreements.
 
Approval: Under a Federal law, Congress must approve or disapprove the agreement by an April 15 deadlin. The other countries have until mid-1995 to ratify it.
